title: Andy Harris pushes GOP bill to expel, block Palestinians from U.S. amid Israel-Hamas War
content:
Andy Harris pushes GOP bill to expel, block Palestinians from U.S. amid Israel-Hamas War

 November 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 928
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A group of conservative Republicans - including U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, R-Maryland - have introduced a bill to expel Palestinians from the U.S. if they entered the country on or after Oct. 1.The Safeguarding Americans from Extremism (SAFE) Act also puts a hard stop on all visas, refugee and asylum requests from individuals holding Palestinian Authority passports.The bill is in response to Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks in the Israel and the resulting Holy Land war in Gaza and cites worries about Islamic terrorists and extremists entering the U.S. It is sponsored by by U.S. Rep. Ryan Zinke, R-Montana, Cosponsors include Harris and U.S. Reps. Andy Biggs, R-Arizona and Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Georgia."This legislation keeps America safe. I don't trust the Biden Administration any more than I do the Palestinian Authority to screen who is allowed to come into the United States," Zinke said in a statement. "This is the most anti-Hamas immigration legislation I have seen and it's well deserved. Given the circumstances, the threats to our immigration system and the history of terrorists abusing refugee, asylum and visa processes all over the world, the requirements in this bill are necessary to keep Americans safe. This bill does exactly that."Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks inside Israel killed 1,400 people (including civilians and close to 450 children). Israel Defense Forces have responded with a siege of Hamas-controlled Gaza, a sustained bombing campaign and ground invasion.Palestinian authorities under Hamas' control in Gaza say the death toll there exceeds 10,000 people including more than 4,100 children. U.S. and Israeli officials have cast some doubts on the Palestinian figures pointing to Hamas' control of health agencies and information flows.According to Harris and Zinke, the bill would "render Palestinian Authority passport holders (covered inadmissible to the U.S". revoke visas to Palestinians issued on or after Oct. 1 and prevents the U.S. Department of Homeland Security from granting current or future visa, asylum and refugees requests from Palestinians.Last month, U.S. Sen. Steve Daines, R-Montana, introduced a bill to block the Biden administration from allowing Palestinian refugees into the U.S.Conservative Republicans have also resisted some proposed U.S. humanitarian aid outlays for Gaza, especially fuel, contending it will end up being stolen and used by Hamas in its war against Israel.Zinke, Daines and other conservatives have also voiced concerns about Hamas, Hezbollah and other Islamic terrorists entering the U.S. via the Mexico border for potential terrorist attacks. Zinke cites a U.S Customs & Border Protection alert from the agency's San Diego alerting personnel to potential crossing by "foreign fighters' related to the Hamas war with Israel.Democrats as well as Palestinian and Muslim advocates oppose Zinke's legislation."Today, extreme MAGA Republican Ryan Zinke introduced a bill to Palestinians from entering the U.S. and possibly even expel those already here. This is the textbook definition of racism," said U.S. Rep. Barbara Lee, D-California. Lee is a progressive, anti-war Democrat who has called for a ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war.Zinke served as U.S. Secretary of the Interior in the Trump administration. Former President Donald Trump also pushed for a U.S travel ban from certain Muslim and other countries with ties to terrorism during his term in office.Both Palestinian territories - the West Bank and Gaza - are overwhelmingly Muslim and are home to anti-Israeli, anti-American Islamic militant and terrorist groups (including Hamas and Islamic Jihad).But there are also between 1,000 and 1,300 Christians in Gaza and 50,000 Christians in the West Bank and Jerusalem, according to the U.S. State Department and other estimates.The Biden administration has supported Israel after the Hamas terrorist attacks dispatching two aircraft carrier groups, fighter jet squadrons and troops to the Holy Land war zone. The Democratic administration has also pressed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for pauses to conflict to allow for humanitarian supplies and releases fo some of the more than 220 hostages held by Hamas in Gaza after the attacks inside Israel.The Biden administration has launched new federal efforts to combat Islamophobia even as antisemitic threats and vandalism rise. The move comes as substantial numbers ofyoung voters and progressives oppose and criticize Biden's support for Israel and fault Netanyahu's war against Hamas."Israel's indiscriminate bombing is hitting hospitals, refugee camps, and killing thousands of innocent people. It must stop now," said U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vermont.Netanyahu and Republicans have opposed prolonged pauses and ceasefires in the war arguing they will help Hamas. The IDF has also pushed back on increasing criticism internationally and U.S. progressives over the civilian casualties in Gaza saying Hamas purposefully locates its rocket and missile launch locations and terrorists operations near schools, playgrounds, mosques, hospitals and churches.Israel has agreed to four-hour daily pauses to allow for civilian movements away from battle zones. Netanyahu said the pauses are not ceasefire.U.S. Sen Lindsey Graham, R-South Carolina, said told CNN Nov. as much as 80% of the population in Gaza supports Hamas and its bid to destroy Israel and much of the Palestinian population there is radicalized.Harris - who represents Maryland's Eastern Shore - said in a statement the focus should be on defeating Hamas "We have to support Israel 100%. Hamas started this war. Hamas is a group of radical Islamic terrorists. They must be defeated otherwise they are a threat to the entire world," Harris said.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaks during a press conference with Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and Cabinet Minister Benny Gantz in the Kirya military base in Tel Aviv, Israel, Saturday, Oct. 28, 2023.

A man waves a Palestinian flag as protestors cross the Brooklyn Bridge during a demonstration demanding a cease-fire on Saturday, Oct. 28, 2023, in New York.

title: White House Christmas ornament honors Gerald Ford
author: Destiny Herbers; Capital News Service
content:
White House Christmas ornament honors Gerald Ford

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Destiny Herbers; Capital News Service | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 635
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The White House Historical Association unveiled earlier this month its Official 2023 White House Christmas Ornament honoring the 38th president of the United States, Gerald R. Ford.Each year for President's Day, the association releases a custom ornament honoring a former president. A team of up to 20 people work on planning and designing the American-made ornaments throughout the year."The ornaments serve as a wonderful teaching tool designed to tell the story of the White House during a specific presidency or anniversary," said Stewart McLaurin, president of the White House Historical Association. "Through these collectibles, we've been able to further our mission to protect, preserve, and provide public access to the rich history of America's Executive Mansion." The 2023 ornament, a three-dimensional wreath, features symbols on the front inspired by the First Lady Betty Ford's White House decorations that could be recreated on Christmas trees at home, Matthew Costello, senior historian at the White House Historical Association, said."One thing that Betty Ford did, and it was reflective of the times, was this old-fashioned, handcrafted Christmas," Costello said."This was a feature amongst their Christmas decorations every year that they were at the White House." The front of the wreath is adorned with tiny decorations including dolls, doves, stars, candles, and gingerbread men, as well as red ribbons with "Christmas 2023" and "The White House." On the back of the ornament are a series of emblems relating to the life and presidency of Ford and a gold plaque featuring the North Portico of the White House.A member of the U.S.House of Representatives since 1949, Ford was nominated as vice president by Richard Nixon in 1973 after the resignation of the previous vice president, Spiro Agnew. Ford assumed the presidency just 10 months later when Nixon resigned over the Watergate scandal.Ford was the only president to have never been elected to the office of vice president or president.Ford is also the only president to become an Eagle Scout, the highest achievable rank in the Boy Scouts of America, an accomplishment that is referenced in the "Troop 15" emblem on the White House ornament."Gerald Ford was either one of our most, or our most, athletic presidents," Costello said. "He played collegiate football at University of Michigan and was offered contracts to play professionally but he decided not to and went to law school instead, which was probably a good decision." A football with Ford's jersey number 48 is featured at the top of the ornament's wreath alongside a line portrait of Liberty, the Ford family's famous golden retriever, who had a litter of puppies in the White House.The ornament also features a bicentennial pin, commemorating the Ford family's celebration of the 200-year anniversary of America's founding, and an emblem for the U.S.S. Gerald R Ford, a firstin-class aircraft carrier commissioned to honor the president's service in the Navy."All of these different element emblems tell us a part of the story of who Gerald Ford was and you know, what he did earlier in his life, and what took place when he was president of the United States," Costello said.Proceeds from the ornaments fund the White House Historical Association's educational work, Costello said, including a teacher institute and resources, public programming, a web series called "White House History Live," and research initiatives.The association is a private, nonprofit organization founded in 1961 by First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy.The popular Christmas ornaments date to 1981. That first ornament depicted a flying angel. The next year, the ornament honored George Washington; subsequent ornaments have honored each president in order. 
 
 Caption: Gerald R. Ford, the 38th president of the United States, is this year's White House Christmas Ornament inspiration
 
PHOTOS COURTESY OF THE WHITE HOUSE HISTORICAL ASSOCIATION
 
The reverse side of the 2023 White House Christmas ornament, with symbols honoring Gerald R. Ford, is shown.
 
Courtesy of the White House Historical Association 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a recent White House Historical Association release—a nationally relevant story about a presidential commemorative ornament—making it primarily a piece of national news rather than a local, educational, or cultural feature.

title: Election takeaway: abortion remains a potent issue for voters
author: Bridget Byrne; Capital News Service
content:
Election takeaway: abortion remains a potent issue for voters

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bridget Byrne; Capital News Service | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 858
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Tuesday's elections brought multiple victories for reproductive rights advocates, a strong sign that abortion access will be a durable issue and a motivating factor for many voters in 2024."In case it wasn't already blindingly obvious before, the abortion issue in a post-Dobbs political environment continues to be a significant advantage for Democrats," Kyle Kondik and J. Miles Coleman wrote Wednesday in Sabato's Crystal Ball, a nonpartisan website at the University of Virginia's Center for Politics.Ohio passed a ballot measure enshrining reproductive rights in the state constitution, and Democrats in Virginia retained control in the state Senate and flipped party control of the House of Delegates.In Kentucky, Democratic Gov. Andy Beshear won re-election after making support of abortion rights a key message of his campaign.And in Pennsylvania, Dan McCaffery, a Democrat who campaigned on abortion rights won a seat on the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.At the center of all these races was the Supreme Court's decision last year in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, in which a majority of justices ruled that the Constitution does not guarantee a right to an abortion. The ruling effectively overturned the landmark 1973 decision in Roe v.Wade in which the right to an abortion was protected."Abortion access is still a salient message a year and a half after the Dobbs decision, and demonstrating that while voters may be dissatisfied with the direction of the country and its Democratic leader, they're still hesitant to put Republicans in charge instead," said Jacob Rubashkin, an analyst with Inside Elections.Polling shows Americans largely support access to abortion.A Gallup poll in July found only 13% of Americans thought abortion should be illegal in all circumstances; 69% said abortion should be legal in the first trimester, although support dropped to 37% for the second trimester and 22% for the third."Abortion access isn't just a winning issue with voters; it's a fundamental right that impacts every aspect of their lives," Mini Timmaraju, president and CEO of Reproductive Freedom For All, said in a statement."Ohioans have now constitutionally guaranteed this right, and the nation is watching." Ohioans voted in favor of Issue 1, a ballot measure that would change the Ohio Constitution to include protection for abortion access.The amendment states that "every individual has a right to make and carry out one's own reproductive decisions." It also states that "the State shall not, directly or indirectly, burden, penalize, prohibit, interfere with, or discriminate" against those seeking abortions or those performing them. Abortions may be prohibited once a fetal is viable, generally considered between 22 and 24 weeks of pregnancy.Ohio Sen. J.D. Vance, a Republican, said on X that his party needed to evaluate how its candidates will argue against reproductive rights in 2024."We need to understand why we lost this battle so we can win the war," Vance said in an X post. "We have to recognize how much voters mistrust us on this issue.We've fallen behind on the moral argument. I'm talking about sustained, years-long efforts to show the heart of the pro life movement." In an appearance Wednesday on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Ohio's other senator, Democrat Sherrod Brown, praised the grassroots efforts to pass Issue 1 in his state."People understand that a national abortion ban takes their rights away, maybe forever, and that's why people worked so hard last night," Brown said.Brown has held his seat since 2007 and is up for reelection next year. He said the vote on Tuesday proves that abortion will be a critical issue in the race."The three Republicans running in the primary next year to be the nominee against me, all three of them have called for a national abortion ban. So they are so out of step with Ohio voters," Brown said.Virginia Gov. Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, said before balloting Tuesday that if the GOP won the majority in both houses of the state legislature, the state would "lead" by enacting a 15-week ban, with exceptions. The current law bans abortion after 26 weeks."I think this is what Virginians expect. I think they know that in a state that is so purple, that we do debate.We do argue," Youngkin told reporters Wednesday. "But they expect us to find common ground on these most important topics and to press forward." In Wednesday's Republican presidential debate, the candidates - all opposed to abortion - disagreed on the path forward for the GOP in handling the issue.Businessman Vivek Ramaswamy, who is from Ohio, said he was upset about the votes on Tuesday and said the Republican Party was a "party of losers." Florida Gov. Ron Desantis said Tuesday's results caught the party "flatfooted." Former New Jersey Gov.Chris Christie said abortion rights should be decided state by state and argued that the bigger issue is that "we're not pro-life for the whole life," advocating for funding drug addiction rehabilitation.South Carolina Sen. Tim Scott was not ready to concede any ground, criticizing states that have passed legislation affirming abortion rights and calling for a nation-wide 15-week limit to stop "reckless behavior" in states that have affirmed abortion rights, such as Kansas, California, New York, and now Ohio.Former United Nations Ambassador Nikki Haley said she would support any abortion ban that can get the votes to pass. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses how abortion, a health‑related issue, is shaping voter behavior and election outcomes across multiple states, making it a broad political story of national relevance.

title: 'No more deliberation, there's no more questioning' - Maryland leaders defend FBI relocation
author: Tommy Tucker; Capital News Service
content:
'No more deliberation, there's no more questioning' - Maryland leaders defend FBI relocation

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tommy Tucker; Capital News Service | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 689
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENBELT - Maryland leadership, in a news conference Friday, Strenuously rejected claims that the decision process for the FBI headquarters was tainted and called the matter a done deal.The U.S. General Services Administration announced Wednesday that the FBI would relocate to a new facility to be built in Greenbelt by the Metro station. In response, Virginia officials, along with FBI director Christopher Wray, called for a reversal of the decision, with Wray claiming in a letter to the agency last month that the GSA failed to address conflicts of interest in the selection process.Gov. Wes Moore, along with U.S. Rep. Steny Hoyer, U.S. Sens. Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen, all Democrats, as well as other Maryland leaders, celebrated the decision Friday, while criticizing the statements made by Wray.Cardin threw back some of the claims, calling out Wray for his actions."We saw the hand ofthe director ofthe FBI trying to change what should be a fair, competitive, open process to steer it to Virginia," said Cardin. "The GSA has released all of the information on how they made the decision. Transparency, it's there. Take a look at it-it's not a close call."Finding the FBI a new headquarters has been an ongoing issue for more than decade. Hoyer described how former FBI Director Robert Mueller came to him in 2009, describing the need for a new building and how the current headquarters is crumbling.Van Hollen defended Nina Albert, the commissioner of GSA's Public Buildings Service, who has been named in published reports as the official who Wray claimed had a conflict of interest. Albert previously worked for the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority, which owns the land where the new FBI headquarters will be located."It is absolutely wrong ofdirector Chris Wray to impugn and question the character, the integrity and the independence of the site selection administrator," said Van Hollen. "She's an expert in the field ofreal estate and transit, she's a public servant and she had a distinguished career as an Army veteran. "Virginia leadership, including U.S. Sen. Tim Kaine, a Democrat, and Gov. Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, responded to the relocation decision, echoing some ofthe issues brought up by Wray."We are deeply disturbed to learn that a political appointee at the General Services Administration overruled the unanimous recommendation of a three-person panel comprised of career experts from the GSA and the Federal Bureau of Investigation concluding that Springfield, Virginia, is the site best suited for the new FBI headquarters. We have repeatedly condemned political interference in the independent, agency-run, site selection process for a new FBI headquarters. Any fair weighing ofthe criteria points to a selection of Virginia. It is clear that this process has been irrevocably undermined and tainted, and this decision must now be reversed."GSA Administrator Robin Carnahan responded to Wray, calling the claims ofinterfer-ence "unfounded" in a statement released Thursday."At every step, the GSA team has worked to incorporate the FBI's feedback and appropriately address their concerns, including conducting a legal review ofeach concern raised."The new facility will sit on an undeveloped 61-acre plot, directly across from the Greenbelt Metro Station. It is expected to be significantly cheaper than the Springfield site, the officials have said. Proximity to NASA, the University of Maryland, College Park and the NSA factored into the final decision.At Friday's news conference, Maryland leadership expressed repeatedly that they are confident that the decision is final.To illustrate why he is confident the process will proceed, Hoyer brought up Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz's attempt to restrict funding for the FBI's new headquarters which "lost overwhelmingly" in a vote on Wednesday. Van Hollen echoed this sentiment "I am confident that we will work with our colleagues to get it done because, as you heard in the House the other day, an effort to, I think, essentially claw back a lot of the monies that have already been there, lost," said Van Hollen. 
 
 Caption: CAPITAL NEWS SERVICE/TOMMY TUCKER
 
U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen defends the federal government's choice of Greenbelt, Maryland, for a new FBI headquarters. He's joined by Maryland leaders (from left) Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller, Gov. Wes Moore, U.S. Rep. Steny Hoyer, U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin and Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a federal decision about the FBI headquarters location, involving national agencies and interstate political debate, which fits the scope of national news more than local or safety-specific topics.

title: Christmas decorations taken down in Bethlehem 'in honor of martyrs' killed in Gaza war - Holy Land Christians are calling for somber Nativity and holiday celebrations amid death and devastation of Israel-Hamas war
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Christmas decorations taken down in Bethlehem 'in honor of martyrs' killed in Gaza war - Holy Land Christians are calling for somber Nativity and holiday celebrations amid death and devastation of Israel-Hamas war

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 1241
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Palestinian officials in Bethlehem - the birthplace of Jesus Christ - are taking down Christmas decorations and "removing all festive appearances in honor of the martyrs and in solidarity with our people in Gaza" and nixing traditional holiday celebrations in favor of protests against Israel's war against Hamas and all its impacts on civilians.The city of Bethlehem said in statements that Christmas celebrations will be replaced with events geared "to deliver protest messages repelling aggression against our Palestinian people in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank where the world's eyes are focused on the cradle of Christ at this time." Bethlehem is home to the Church of Nativity and is believed by Christians to be where the Virgin Mary gave birth to Jesus. There are often scores of tourists, Christian pilgrimages and Christmas events.But the war has greatly diminished tourism, restricted travel and closed businesses. There has also been skirmishes and violence in the West Bank as the war rages in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks inside Israel killed more than 1.400 people.Christmas, as it is traditionally celebrated in the West Bank, is essentially being canceled in Bethlehem in response to the war."Bethlehem Municipality crews announced the dismantling of Christmas decorations installed several years ago in the city's neighborhoods and removing all festive appearances in honor of the martyrs and in solidarity with our people in Gaza," the West Bank local government said More than 11,000 Gazans have been killed in succeeding Holy Land war with dire conditions reported by relief agencies.Hamas is also holding 240 Israelis including some children hostage inside Gaza after the Oct 7 attacks. That includes several Americans with dual Israeli citizenship.There are an estimated 50,000 Christians in the West Bank and Jerusalem and 1,000 to 1,300 in Gaza.Both Palestinian areas are overwhelmingly Muslim.There are another 185,000 Christians living in the Jewish state of Israel The Church of the Nativity is operated by a consortium of Holy Land churches.The church said the war, its impacts and restrictions, including restrictons on businesses, travel and workers, are taking a toll."The lack of pilgrims, closed economic activities, difficulty traveling to work, make daily life and the possibility of having a dignified life difficult," the Catholic order of the Franciscans said in plea for help.A SOMBER CHRISTMAS The move comes after Christian churches in the Holy Land called for a somber and subdued Christmas season this year in the birthplace of Jesus Christ with the war between Israel and Hamas bring death and destruction to Gaza and the region.The Patriarch and Heads of the Churches of Jerusalem - who lead and represents Christian denominations in Israel, the Palestinian territories and other Holy Land countries - issued a joint statement calling for understated and retrospective Christmas observances this year because of the war.Christian communities in the Holy Land often celebrate Christmas with "public festivities and the large-scale displays of brightly lit and expensive decorations as a mean of expressing our joy at the approach and arrival of the Feast of the Nativity," the patriarchs write in a statement."But these are not normal times, Since the start of the war, there have been an atmosphere of sadness and pain," the heads of the Roman Catholic, Episcopal-Anglican, Greek-Eastern Orthodox, Coptic, Syrian Catholic, Armenian Catholic and other Holy Land churches said.They are calling for toneddown yuletide season with a focus on praying for those suffering because of the war - which started after Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks in inside Israel."Thousands of innocent civilians, including woman and children, have died or suffered serious injuries.Many more grieve over the loss of their homes, their loved ones or the uncertain fate of those dear to them.Throughout the region, even more have lost their work and are suffering serious economic challenges.Yet, despite our repeated calls for humane ceasefires and de-escalation of violence, the war continues," the Jerusalem patriarchs write in a joint statement.STANDING WITH ISRAELBefore the Oct. 7 bloodshed in Israel and ensuing bloodshed in Gaza, there were sectarian tensions in Jerusalem and other parts of the Holy Land.In early October (before the Hamas attacks), Pope Francis and Orthodox Christian leaders condemned Orthodox Jewish men spitting at Christian pilgrims in Jerusalem. There has also been harassment and vandalism of Christians in Jerusalem and West Bank.Christian pilgrimages to the Holy Land date back to Byzantine and Crusader times and have continued into contemporary times. They have a $3 billion regional economic and tourism impact, according to a 2021 study by the University of Birmingham.Islamic militants - including Hamas - have also used ultra-Orthodox Jewish incursions near and at the al-Aqsa Mosque as of one of the drivers of the Oct. 7 attacks. The mosque, where Muslims believe the Prophet Muhammad ascended into heaven, is on the site of the Temple Mount, a Jewish holy site.More than 1,400 Orthodox Jews visited the Temple Mount site Oct. 3 during the Sukkot holiday upsetting Muslims and drawing a promised response from Hamas. Four days later the Islamic terror groups launched its surprise attack.Israel enjoys strong war support from some Evangelical leaders. That includes John Hagee, a prominent Evangelical pastor and chairman of Christians United for Israel who helped organize the March for Israel in Washington.Hagee said many of the Christians at the pro-Israel were not alive during the Holocaust. "But we are here now and we stand shoulder to shoulder with the Jewish people. We stand until those 240 hostages are returned to their homes," said Hagee who backs Israel's war efforts.'STOP THE KILLING'Pope Francis, the World Council of Churches and Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby have been part of the calls for a ceasefire, de-escalation of violence and release of hostages.Michael Curry, presiding bishop for the Episcopal Church in the U.S. wants President Joe Biden to press the Israel to relent in their invasion and attacks in Gaza."U.S. leadership must tell Israel to stop bombing civilian areas and allow access for full humanitarian aid to flow freely into Gaza. Every human child of God-Palestinian and Israeli-deserves safety and security. We need to stop the killing. Today," Curry said in statement Nov. 7. "Vengeance will not bring back the dead. Retaliation will not repair the harms and the hurt. We are called to love, even and especially when it seems impossible." Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has agreed to humanitarian pauses in the fighting but not a general ceasefire as Israel Defense Forces look to root out Hamas installations and fighters via ground and air attacks.Netanyahu also said Israel security forces will remain in Gaza after the war."In order to ensure that there is no such threat, the IDF will continue to have security control over the Gaza Strip for as long as necessary to prevent terrorism from it," Netanyahu said.The Holy Land church leaders said in their joint statement Nov. 10 they want the bloodshed and war to end and Christians celebrating Christians to focus on the spiritual side of Christmas and "to stand strong with those facing such afflictions this year by foregoing unnecessarily festive activities." 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Palestinian scouts march in the Christian Orthodox Christmas Eve celebrations at the Church of the Nativity in the West Bank city of Bethlehem, the traditional birthplace of Jesus, Friday, Jan. 6, 2023.
 
ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
A woman lights candles inside the Church of the Nativity, traditionally believed to be the birthplace of Jesus Christ, in the West Bank town of Bethlehem, Saturday, Dec. 24, 2022. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a politically significant event (removal of Christmas decorations) tied to the Israel-Hamas war, involving municipal decisions and broader national/international implications, making it best classified as National News.

title: Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1895
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Holy Land war between Israel and Hamas is birthing increased police and government surveillance of social media, prompting calls for more Americans to report "hate crimes" and proposals to require all social media accounts to have public name verifications amid concerns about increases in antisemitism and terrorism threats.There are also pushes to deport some anti-war, pro-Palestinian foreign college students deemed supportive of U.S. designated terror groups and expel and ban Palestinian refugees from entering the country.The efforts are born out of security concerns stemming from U.S. support for Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza after the Oct. 7 terror attacks. But they are also sparking concerns about stunting or intimating dissent, privacy and other free speech protections.There is also a new social media battle over Twitter/X owner Elon Musk's support for a social media post that talked about anti-white sentiments among "Jewish communities." A number of major media and technology advertisers, who also compete with social media platforms and some of Musk's technology ventures, have paused advertising on X. That includes Disney (which owns ABC and ESPN), Apple, Paramount Global (which owns CBS and Comedy, IBM, Comcast/NBC Universal (which owns NBC and MSNBC) and Warner Bros/Discovery (which owns CNN).Musk said he agreed with a post from a Twitter who said "Jewish communities have been pushing the exact kind of dialectical hatred against whites that they claim to want people to stop using against them." "You said the actual truth," Musk said in a reply Nov. 15, latter adding that his concurrence was geared toward progressive activist groups and the Anti-Defamation League.The Biden administration condemned Musk's statement Friday. "We condemn this abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate in the strongest terms," the U.S. administration said in statement drawing parallels to the beliefs of the Robert Bowers, who faces the death penalty after the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh left 11 congregants dead.The ADL on Nov. 16 also criticized Musk. "it is indisputably dangerous to use one's influence to validate and promote antisemitic theories, said ADL CEO Jonathan Greenblalt, who on Friday then praised Musk for his condemnation of pro-Palestinian and pro-Hamas phrases 'from the river to the sea' and 'decolonization.' Musk said Saturday some of the critics are dangerously using the episode to squelch free speech and that. he plans on suing progressive activists he claims inaccurately showed neo-Nazi and antisemitic posts next to Twitter/X advertisers' promotions."I am sticking to my principles. As for any fake advocacy groups who seek to suppress free speech, they should remember that karma is real," Musk said on his social media platform.EXPELLING FOREIGN COLLEGE STUDENTSThere is a GOP push to expel foreign college students deemed to be supporting Hamas, Hezbollah and other groups on the U.S. government's list of terrorist groups.A group of 21 GOP attorneys general - including Ashley Moody of Florida and Austin Knudsen of Montana - want the federal government to "vigorously renew vetting of foreign students' and deport those deemed to have endorsed or provided "material support to foreign terrorist organizations." "It is possible that renewed vetting of foreign students already admitted to the United States may reveal activity that renders them ineligible to hold a student visa and liable to deportation," Knudsen, Moody and their cohorts wrote in a letter Nov. 8 to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and the U.S.Department of Education.Free speech and civil liberties advocates say the reactions to anti-Israel war protests (some of which have seen antisemitic rhetoric) can bleed into censorship as well as quieting and punishing voices of dissent."Free speech means protecting speech you don't like. Sometimes it even means protecting speech you find abhorrent and hateful," said U.S. Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Kentucky, after voting against censure measure aimed at U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Michigan, over her anti-Israel rhetoric and use of a pro-Hamas slogan.BANNING PALESTINIAN REFUGEESA group of congressional Republicans - including U.S. Reps. Andy Thomas, who represents the Eastern Shore, along with U.S. Reps. Ryan Zinke of Montana and Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia and U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, are also leading efforts to keep Palestinian refugees from the war out of the U.S. Zinke, Harris and Greene also wants to kick out Palestinians who entered the country on or after Oct. 1 in the aftermath of the Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks inside Israel that sparked the war in Gaza.They say said he does not trust the Biden administration or Palestinian authorities to adequately screen potential refugees.Critics say the proposal is xenophobic.Similar sentiments related to refugees and college students have been echoed by 2024 GOP presidential candidates such as former president Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who has suspended pro-Palestinian students' groups in his home state deemed extremist and favored restrictions on public library and school curricula content deemed inappropriate or offensive.While conservatives press universities, who have sometimes aggressively banned right-wing voices from their campuses, to condemn and crackdown on pro-Palestinian student protesters, the American Civil Liberties Union wants them to uphold free speech principles."It is precisely in times of heightened crisis and fear that university leaders must remain steadfast in their commitment to free speech, open debate, and peaceful dissent on campus.These principles are the bedrock of academic freedom at all universities," the ACLU said in a statement."The First Amendment protects all people who live in this country, whether they're here as citizens, foreign nationals, or visitors," the civil liberties group said.ENCOURAGING MORE HATE CRIME REPORTINGDaines and a bipartisan senators including U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, have also recently written to FBI Director Christopher Wray and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security asking for more investigative and enforcement resources to be dedicated to addressing antisemitism.The Anti-Defamation League reports a 300% increase in anti-Jewish threats, vandalism and violence since the start of the war, which has seen more than 1,400 Israelis and more than 11,000 Gazans killed.In a separate letter, U.S. Sen Jon Tester, D-Montana, also said FBI and DHS efforts should also be focused on white supremacists echoing past and current Biden administration efforts to go after alt-right groups.The Biden White House, which has put a focus on going after right-wing groups since taking office in 2021, has also launched a new task force to go after "Islamophobia" during the war.On Tuesday, the FBI said it added Oregon to a nationwide effort aimed at encouraging getting more Americans to report "hate incidents' ' with billboards posted in Eugene, Medford and Corvallis as well as digital signs at Portland International Airport.Similar hate crime billboards have been put up across the country, including last month in North Carolina, along with ads on public transit systems, social media platforms and local media outlets.Last month, the U.S. Department of Justice and FBI released new data showing there was a 7.3% increase in reported hate crimes in 2022 (11,634 cases versus 10,840) in 2021.There were more than 6,500 racially motivated incidents - 52% of them aimed at Blacks - and more than 2,000 cases related to religion - with 55% targeting Jews, according to DOJ.SOCIAL MEDIA SURVEILLANCE, FORCED VERIFICATIONSA state law in Montana backed by Knudsen and GOP Gov.Greg Gianforte banning Chinese-owned social media app TikTok is also one of the central fronts in efforts to restrict social media platforms and content.Montana lawmakers worry about TikTok's data security and ties to the Chinese government.The ban is being mirrored in other states.The Montana prohibition is being challenged by TikTok and free speech advocates in court.But there are also other efforts to increase government regulations and scrutiny and law enforcement surveillance of social media.New York Gov. Kathy Hochul said Nov. 13 that state police have ramped up social media surveillance and will reach out more to individuals and groups posting hate speech online."We're very focused on the data we're collecting from surveillance efforts. What's being said on social media platforms.And we have launched an effort to be able to counter some of the negativity. and reach out to people when we see hate speech being spoken about on online platforms," Hochul said. "Our media analysis, our social media analysis unit, has ramped up its monitoring of sites to catch incitement to violence; direct threats to others." The New York governor said the rise in extremist and violent threats after the start of the war in the Middle East "poses a clear and present danger." But the idea of more aggressive police surveillance of social media posts raises some concerns.Gerard Kassar, chairman of the New York Conservative Party, said police social media monitoring is potentially "chilling to the core"."Law enforcement authorities can and should monitor legitimate terrorism suspects online, but spying on everyday citizens is unconstitutional and wrong," Kassar said.Republican presidential candidate and former South Carolina governor and U.S. ambassador Nikki Haley wants to require all social media accounts be verified by name thus eliminating anonymous online speech on major platforms."Every person on social media should be verified by their name," said Haley, who is increasingly being promoted as an establishment and neoconservative 2024 alternative to former president Donald Trump."First of all, it's a national security threat. When you do that, all of a sudden people have to stand by what they say. And it gets rid of the Russian bots, the Iranian bots and the Chinese bots. And then you're going to get some civility when people know their name is next to what they say, and they know their pastor and their family members are going to see it," Haley told Fox News.Haley also backs a TikTok ban pointing to the recent viral traffic of a letter criticizing Israel and the U.S. from Osama Bin Laden.Harris told Fox News Nov. 16 that Congress could soon take some actions related to TikTok and the issue will come down to speech versus national security, citing the platform's Chinese ownership.The verification push sparked a backlash from free speech advocates, particularly on the right who have already been upset over social media bans and content restrictions over coronavirus vaccines and challenges to the 2020 election results.They say it will eliminate anonymous dissent and speech."Nikki Haley is 'openly' pushing for the government to use private tech companies to censor speech. This is a flagrant violation of the Constitution and straight out of the Democrats' playbook.Any politician who thinks it's OK for the government to use the private sector as its censorship bureau shouldn't be allowed anywhere near the White House," said Vivek Ramaswamy, who has frequently sparred with Haley over TikTok and other issues. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Twitter/X, Tesla and SpaceX's CEO Elon Musk gestures during an in-conversation event with Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in London, Thursday, Nov. 2, 2023.
 
ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Republican presidential candidates former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and businessman Vivek Ramaswamy pose for a photo before the start of a presidential primary debate Nov. 8 in Miami. Haley has called for all social media accounts to be verified by name and DeSantis wants pro-Palestinian foreign college students who support Hamas deported.
 
ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
A protester chants slogans during a demonstration to support the Palestinian people in Gaza, Saturday, Nov. 4, 2023. Protests opposing the war and criticizing Israel and the U.S. have occurred across the U.S., Europe and Middle East.
 
ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
A young Israeli supporter holds up a sign during a pro-Israel rally in Los Angeles, Tuesday, Oct. 10, 2023.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses nationwide political and security issues—police surveillance, hate‑crime reporting, and debates over free speech—related to the Israel‑Hamas conflict, fitting the broad scope of national news more than any specific subcategory.

content:
CHRISTMAS AT THE WHITE HOUSE

 November 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)
