title: Senate panel OKs Maryland's O'Malley as next Social Security commissioner
author: Ryan Mercado
content:
Senate panel OKs Maryland's O'Malley as next Social Security commissioner

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ryan Mercado | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 398
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - The Senate Finance Committee voted 17-10 Tuesday to advance to the full Senate the nomination of former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley to be the next commissioner of the Social Security Administration.All 14 Democrats and three Republicans - Sens.Chuck Grassley of Iowa, Bill Cassidy of Louisiana and Thom Tillis North Carolina - supported advancing O'Malley's nomination.Ten other Republicans voted against O'Malley."Gov. O'Malley will demand that there be better customer service at the Social Security Administration," Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Maryland, told his colleagues before the finance panel's vote. "We need someone responsible to report to us as to why it takes so long for our constituents to get the services they need from the Social Security Administration.Gov. O'Malley will take that responsibility as the accountable person."O'Malley was nominated by President Joe Biden in July to head Social Security after removing Andrew Saul, a holdover from the Trump administration. Saul's term as commissioner proved controversial for his connection to a conservative think tank, the Manhattan Institute, that calls for cuts to Social Security. Biden's action drew the ire of Republicans."When the Biden administration removed the last Senate-confirmed commissioner prior to the completion of his six-year term, I expressed strong concerns that this decision politicized the SSA to the detriment of Social Security beneficiaries," said Idaho Sen.Mike Crapo, the finance committee's top Republican."I will not be supporting his (O'Malley's) nomination today."Crapo noted that Saul did not have sufficient time to implement any reforms before he was removed and that the Biden administration now had set a precedent to shorten the Social Security commissioner's term, and that future administrations could do the same.The committee's chairman, Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Oregon, rejected Crapo's concerns, saying "the Supreme Court ruled that single agency heads serve at the pleasure of the president There is the authority of the president to replace an individual."O'Malley's nomination now awaits a confirmation vote by the full Senate. If confirmed, O'Malley would head the federal agency for a term ending in January 2025.The Social Security Administration had a budget of $1,3 trillion in fiscal 2022 and had about 60,000 employees. The agency handled benefits for some 70 million people in 2021. 
 
 Caption: Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., talks during a Senate Finance Committee business meeting to consider the nomination of Martin O'Malley, of Maryland, to be Commissioner of Social Security on Capitol Hill, Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a federal Senate committee's action regarding a high‑profile national appointment (Social Security commissioner), which is classic national political news rather than a local, sector‑specific, or cultural story.

title: Inspector general launches probe into selected FBI headquarters site
content:
Inspector general launches probe into selected FBI headquarters site

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - A federal watchdog will investigate how the Biden administration chose a site for a new FBI headquarters following a contentious competition marked by allegations of conflict of interest.The Inspector General for the General Services Administration is probing the decision to locate the facility in Greenbelt, Maryland, over a site in Virginia., according to a letter released Thursday by Virginia lawmakers.The new building would replace the FBI's crumbling headquarters in nearby Washington, D.C.Virginia's senators and representatives said in a joint statement that there was "overwhelming evidence" suggesting the process was influenced by politics and called on the GSA to pause anything related to the relocation until the review is complete.The acting inspector general said that his office would immediately begin evaluating the GSA's process and procedures for selecting the site and share a copy of any report that results, according to a letter sent to Democratic Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia."We applaud the inspector general for moving quickly and encourage him to move forward to complete a careful and thorough review," Virginia's delegation said in a joint statement.The agency said it welcomes the review and pointed out that it had already released decision-making materials and a legal review of concerns raised by the director of the FBI."We carefully followed the requirements and process, and stand behind GSA's final site selection decision," an agency spokesperson said in a statement.The review comes after FBI Director Christopher Wray told staff in an internal message earlier this month that he was concerned about a "potential conflict of interest" in a GSA executive choosing a site owned by a previous employer.Wray said his objections were about the process rather than the site itself.GSA, which manages the government's real estate portfolio, denied any conflict.The agency said the site about 13 miles northeast of Washington was the cheapest one with the best access to public transit.Maryland and Virginia have long been vying to land the FBI's heasquarters.Maryland's leaders applauded the Greenbelt choice, saying was "never about politics" and the new facility would meet a "dire, longstanding need." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a federal watchdog investigation into the selection of a site for a new FBI headquarters, a matter of national significance and federal government activity, fitting best under National News.

title: 'Progressive feminists of the world: where are you?' - Mayim Bialik, others criticize progressives, UN, women's groups for muted responses to Hamas' Oct. 7 rapes, violence against women
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers
content:
'Progressive feminists of the world: where are you?' - Mayim Bialik, others criticize progressives, UN, women's groups for muted responses to Hamas' Oct. 7 rapes, violence against women

 December 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 990
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Progressives, women's groups and the United Nations are facing criticism for their silence or reticence to denounce or condemn Hamas for rapes, torture and other violence toward women and girls during and after the Oct. 7 terror attacks inside Israel.Actress Mayim Bialik, former Facebook/Meta COO Sheryl Sandberg and Israeli First Lady Michal Herzog have been pushing for women's and feminist groups to step forward to condemn Hamas' violence which sparked the Holy Land war.More than 1,200 people were killed and more than 240 hostages were taken into Gaza Oct. 7. There were also rapes, sexual assaults and the killing of women (including some who were pregnant) as well as children (and unborn children), according to Israeli authorities.'ABHORRENT & CONSPICUOUS ABSENCE'"Progressive feminists of the world: where are you?," Bialik wrote in a post on social media platform X."There has been an abhorrent and conspicuous absence of women's organizations around the world unequivocally condemning the systematic rape and torture of women on October 7 by Hamas. Brutal gang rapes, sexual torture, and murder of foetuses happened-period.Where are the "BELIEVE THEM" voices? These crimes against women were in many cases documented by the terrorists themselves and broadcast for the world to see. Those of us who have fought for women's rights and have sought to shout from the rooftops when women's bodies are being used in war for the sadistic pleasure of perpetrators are astounded at how the world has been silent surrounding this" Bialik wrote. "The UN (U.N. Women - the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women) took 50 days to express "alarm." The actress is a co-host of the "Jeopardy" game show and is best known for her roles on American television shows "Big Bang Theory" and "Blossom".Herzog also wrote in a Newsweek piece that she was disappointed by international women's groups relative silence towards Hamas' violence towards women and girls, including rapes and sexual assaults. She referenced the killing of a pregnant Israeli woman and removal of her unborn baby shown in a jarring Hamas video.'TOO LITTLE TOO LATE'UN Women - an arm of the United Nations focused on women's and gender matters - issued a statement Friday, Dec. 1. condemning the Oct. 7 attacks. This came after officials from the group were unwilling to condemn the attacks."We deeply regret that military operations have resumed in Gaza, and we reiterate that all women, Israeli women, Palestinian women, as all others, are entitled to a life lived in safety and free from violence.We unequivocally condemn the brutal attacks by Hamas on Israel on 7 October. We are alarmed by the numerous accounts of gender-based atrocities and sexual violence during those attacks. This is why we have called for all accounts of gender-based violence to be duly investigated and prosecuted, with the rights of the victim at the core," the statement reads.The UN Women's group's statement was met by criticism from Israeli officials and backers."This statement is shameful and morally distorted just like the organization who issued it. UN Women - do you really think you can get off the hook so easily after having kept silent for more than 50 days?! You have betrayed the Israeli girls and women victims of terrible sex crimes perpetrated by Hamas," said Emmanuel Nahshon, deputy director general for diplomacy for the Israeli Foreign Ministry.Patricia Heaton, an actress who backs Israel in the war, also faulted the UN statement as tardy."Too little too late," Heaton said.'THIS IS A WAR ON CHILDREN'The United Nations, other international groups and U.S. progressives have been critical of Israel's air strikes and ground invasion of Gaza after the Hamas attacks. Palestinian authorities have said more than 14,800 Gazans have died in war.A number of activists and progressives - including on college campuses and within political groups - have strongly criticized Israel and its Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the war. They point the number of women and children being killed in the Gaza war."We cannot see more children with the wounds of war, with the burns, with the shrapnel littering their body, with the broken bones. Inaction by those with influence is allowing the killing of children.This is a war on children," said UNICEF spokesman James Elder.A top official with the Roman Catholic Church's Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem said late last month that 21 Christians have been killed in the Gaza war so far.That includes an 80-yearold woman who was shot in the leg and bled to death in the street. The church group said the Christian woman's body laid in the street for three days.'I BELIEVE WOMEN - DO YOU?'But some UN and politically progressive groups have been reticent or in some case muted when it comes to criticizing Palestinian side and Hamas, Herzog and Bialik and other supporters of Israel note."When people march and assert RESISTANCE BY ALL MEANS NECESSARY, this is what they are supporting: gang rape, mutilation of women's bodies, and torturing foetuses.I can't believe I have to say this again: Rape is never an act of resistance. Cutting off body parts is not an act of resistance. This is what happened on October 7. I believe women and I believe the footage Hamas has broadcast showing sexual crimes against women. Do you?," Bialik posted on X.U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-New York, also voiced frustration that civil rights and other Democratic groups for not condemning the Oct. 7 attacks.U.S. President Joe Biden has seen his approval ratings sink with progressives and younger voters over his support Israel in the Holy Land war.The Biden administration brokered a temporary ceasefire and hostage-prisoner exchange between Hamas and Israel and has pushed Netanyahu to extend that ceasefire and take less strident tactics against Hamas in Gaza.That ceasefire ended Friday, Dec. 1. 
 
 Caption: JORDAN STRA USS/AP PHOTO
 
Mayim Bialik arrives at the 27th annual Critics Choice Awards on Sunday, March 13, 2022, at the Fairmont Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a politically charged, internationally relevant controversy involving women's groups, the UN, and the response to gender‑based violence in the Israel‑Gaza conflict, fitting the scope of a national news story rather than the more specific categories like sports, health, or arts.

title: 'Destruction of the Nazis of Hamas' - Netanyahu pressed from Israeli right to keep up war as U.S., Biden push for truce, less aggressive tactics in Gaza
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers
content:
'Destruction of the Nazis of Hamas' - Netanyahu pressed from Israeli right to keep up war as U.S., Biden push for truce, less aggressive tactics in Gaza

 December 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 928
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu faces pressure from the U.S. and the Biden administration to forge a new truce with Hamas and to take less aggressive tactics in the southern part of Gaza but is also being pushed from the Israeli right to not relent in the Holy Land War to dismantle the Islamist group.The Israel-Hamas war restarted Friday after the end of a 7-day truce that saw some of the hostages held by Hamas and prisoners held U.S. President Joe Biden - who faces sagging approval ratings from Democrats sympathetic to the Palestinian cause in the war (and in some instances Hamas) and international pressure to curtail Israel's attacks inside Gaza - had wanted a continued ceasefire.The U.S. administration has also been pressing Israel Défense Forces to be more sensitive to civilian casualties in the southern part of Gaza with the war restarting after Hamas gunman killed three people and injured six others at bus stop in Jerusalem.'DESTRUCTION OF THE NAZIS OF HAMAS' But Netanyahu has also faced internal pushes from Israeli right-wing ministers who are part of his government to restart and keep up the war to destroy Hamas after the Oct. 7 terror attacks killed more than 1,200 people inside Israeli and more than 240 were taken hostage.Itamar Ben Gvir, minister of national security, said his far-right political party would potentially quit Netanyahu's government if the war did not restart."Stopping the war = dissolution of the government," said Ben Gvir in a social media statement Wednesday.He also called for the war to restart saying Hamas violated the ceasefire when two gunmen opened fire Thursday at bus stop in Jerusalem killing three and six more.The gunmen were killed by Israeli security forces. Hamas claimed responsibility for the Jerusalem attack."With one hand, Hamas signs a ceasefire, and with the other, it sends terrorists to murder Jews in Jerusalem.This is not a ceasefire, but the continuation of the concept of inclusion and surrender.We must cease the deals with the devil, and immediately return to fighting with tremendous intensity in order to achieve the supreme goal of the war: the complete destruction of Hamas, with all its metastases and affiliates," Ben Gvir said in statement Thursday.Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich, also called for Netanyahu to resist pressure from the U.S and its Middle Eastern mediators in Egypt, and Qatar to extend the war's stoppages."Not on the agenda, not even as a suggestion. There is no discussion about it at all. This is a plan to eliminate the State of Israel. We continue until the absolute victory with God's help and the destruction of the Nazis of Hamas," Smotrich said on X.He also said the Jerusalem terrorism shows a wider Holy Land conflict."We are at war on all fronts. The terrible attack in Jerusalem reminds us that our enemies are not only the Nazis in Gaza. We will pursue and destroy them with God's help everywhere," Smotrich said.'NOTHING WILL STOP US' Netanyahu promised that Israel's war will not relent in a speech Wednesday and then again Thursday after gunman killed three people and injured others at bus stop in Jerusalem. Israeli security forces killed the gunman and Netanyahu blames Hamas."I have just concluded a meeting with U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken, shortly after Hamas murderers murdered people here in Jerusalem. I told him that it is the same Hamas," Netanyahu said in a video posted social media platform X on Thursday "It is the same Hamas that perpetrated the terrible massacre on October 7th and the same Hamas that is trying to murder us everywhere. I told him: We have sworn, I have sworn, to eliminate Hamas.Nothing will stop us." On Friday, Blinken and White House officials blamed Hamas for the end of the ceasefire and restart of the war.The Israeli prime minister's vows to continue to war welcomed by Ben Gvir."Just to be clear: we must return and fight with all our strength until the absolute decision," he said The IDF and Hamas restarted the war Friday.The ceasefire has seen more than 100 hostages (all women and children) released by Hamas-including two with dual American-Israeli citizenship was well as some from Thailand and the Philippines, according to tallies from the White Huse, BBC and other groups. In exchange, the Israelis have released 240 Palestinian prisoners (all women and teens) from jails, according to various media tallies.There are still an estimated seven Americans (with dual Israeli citizenship) among those still held captive by Hamas inside Gaza. The U.S. brokered ceasefire deal calls for three Palestinian prisoners to be released for every one hostage.Palestinian authorities in Hamas-controlled Gaza say more than 14,800 people have died since the war started after the war after the Oct. 7 attacks. The United Nations and other relief groups have warned of already dire situations for women and children in Gaza getting even worse.Biden wants Israel to scale back its attacks on Hamas in southern Gaza if and when the war starts. Progressives in the U.S. as well as a sea of international interests are also faulting Israel Defense Forces for civilian casualties in the Holy Land war.That includes Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez who supports broader European recognition of a Palestinian state and said Israel is violating humanitarian law in the war.That prompted Netanyahu to recall Israel's ambassador in Madrid and to call in Spain's ambassador in Jerusalem. 
 
 Caption: MOHAMMED HAJJAR/AP PHOTO
 
A Palestinian man sits in an armchair outside a destroyed building in Gaza City on Wednesday, Nov. 29, 2023, the sixth day of the temporary cease-fire between Hamas and Israel. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses international conflict, government policy, and diplomatic pressure, which aligns with broad national-level news rather than any of the more specific categories.

title: 'If Christ Were To Be Born Today He Would Be Born Under The Rubble' - Bethlehem Church Features Nativity, Baby Jesus In War-Torn Gaza
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers
content:
'If Christ Were To Be Born Today He Would Be Born Under The Rubble' - Bethlehem Church Features Nativity, Baby Jesus In War-Torn Gaza

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 822
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Christian church in Bethlehem - the birthplace of Jesus - has unveiled a Nativity displaying the baby Jesus within a depiction of the rubble of war in Gaza.The Christmas Lutheran Church in the West Bank displayed the Nativity earlier this month in its sanctuary to highlight the war in Gaza between Israel Defense Forces and Hamas.
Reverend Munther Isaac, who leads the Evangelical Lutheran Church in the West Bank, said baby Jesus and other Nativity characters in a display of rubble inside the church aims to highlight the plight of children in Gaza and the hope Christians find in Christmas and Christ.
"If Christ were to be born today he would be born under the rubble," Munther said in a video message the Palestinian church posted on social media platforms X and Facebook. "I invite you to see the image of Jesus in every child killed and pulled from under the rubble In every child struggling in destroyed hospitals." More than 17,000 Gazans and more than 1,200 Israelis have died in the war which started after Hamas' terror attacks inside Israel, according to authorities on either side of the conflict.
There are just over 1,000 Christians in Hamas-governed Gaza (which is overwhelmingly Muslim and has a population 2.3 million.) Another 50,000 Christians live in West Bank and Jerusalem and 185,000 Christians live in Israel making up smaller percentages of the total population of the Holy Land.
More than 20 Christians have died in Gaza, according to estimates from the Roman Catholic Church's Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem.
Christmas celebrations have been canceled in Bethlehem because of the war, many businesses are closed and Holy Land tourism (a $3 billion industry) has significantly slowed because of the war. Holiday decorations have been taken down.
Munther hopes the Jesus in the rubble stirs thoughts and prayers regarding Christmas and the Middle East war.
"I realize this is a difficult idea," he said. "But believe me, this is precisely the meaning of Christmas this year as death, destruction and rubble in our land. This is how we welcome 'the King of Glory'. If Jesus was to be born into our world today, I wonder would he have entered our world in any other way?
Christmas is the presence of baby Jesus with those who suffer. Christmas is God's solidarity with the oppressed. Christmas is a ray of light and home from the heart of pain and suffering. Christmas is the radiance of life from the heart of destruction and death. In Gaza, God is under the rubble. He is in the operating room," the Lutheran pastor said.
"Christmas celebrations are canceled this year but Christmas itself and is not and will not be canceled for our hope cannot be canceled.
Jesus birth is our hope. Jesus is our hope, " the Palestinian church pastor said.
"The child of Bethlehem is our hope," he said in another post Christian churches in the Holy Land - which include Lutheran, Catholic, Anglican and Orthodox denominations - have called for subdued and Christmas observances and have pressed for a ceasefire in the war.
In the U.S., Evangelical Christian churches have been some of the strongest supporters of Israel - backing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's bid to dismantle Hamas after the Islamic militant group's Oct. 7 attacks.
"In keeping with Christian Just War tradition, we also affirm the legitimacy of Israel's right to respond against those who have initiated these attacks as Romans 13 grants governments the power to bear the sword against those who commit such evil acts against innocent life," the Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission, a public policy arm of the Southern Baptist Convention said in a statement shortly after the Hamas attacks.
That statement has been signed by more then 2,000 Baptist and Evangelical pastors and other U.S.
Christians.
On Nov. 25, another set of Evangelical evangelists, pastor and political advocates wrote congressional leaders voicing support for U.S. backing of Israel's war against the Hamas.
The letter calls for the U.S. to "support Israel's efforts to degrade and destroythe Islamic terrorist organizations Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad in Gaza; help Israel defend its civilian population with more IronDome protection; press for economic and diplomatic normalization between Israel and regional Arab nations." It was led by the Faith and Freedom Coalition and was signed by the group's chairman, Ralph Reed, as well as some prominent Evangelical pastors including John Hagee (who is also chairman of Christians United for Israel), James Dobson, Jentezen Franklin and Gordon Robertson (chair of the Christian Broadcasting Network).
American Evangelicals have often sided biblical instructions to stand with Israel and point to 'End-Time' prophecies of Jesus' Second Coming.
Munther wants Evangelicals to focus more on the carnage, suffering and casualties of war and the Christian commandment to 'Love your neigbhor as yourself ' rather than 'End Times' prophecies. 
 
 Caption: TWITTER/MUNTHER ISAAC

 A Lutheran church in Bethlehem has a Christmas Nativity centered on the war and suffering in Gaza.

 TWITTER/MUNTHER ISAAC

 The war-focused Nativity is at the Christmas Lutheran Church in Bethlehem, the birthplace of Jesus 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a church's Nativity display used to highlight the Gaza war, linking local religious actions to a major international conflict, which fits the broader scope of national/international news rather than sports, health, or other specific categories.

title: Deepening Divides - Democrats Split Over 'Anti-Zionism Is Antisemitism' Measure; Poll Shows U.S. Racial, Generational Differences Over Israel-Hamas War
content:
Deepening Divides - Democrats Split Over 'Anti-Zionism Is Antisemitism' Measure; Poll Shows U.S. Racial, Generational Differences Over Israel-Hamas War

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 954
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. House of Representatives approved a measure Wednesday declaring that "anti-Zionism is antisemitism" prompting a split among Democrats.A majority of House Democrats did not vote for the measure as a public opinion poll from Gallup shows substantial divides among Americans over the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza by age, race and political persuasion.
Whites, older voters and Republicans tend to back Israel in its war against Hamas after the Oct. 7 terror attacks while younger Americans, people of color and Democrats disapprove of Israel's air strikes and ground invasion of Gaza aimed at the Islamic militant group, according to a poll released Nov. 30 by Gallup.
The congressional measure condemning antisemitism passed with support from 216 Republicans and 95 Democrats. The resolution's most controversial component was plank equating anti-Zionism with antisemitism.
Zionism is a movement and belief system that supports the Jewish state of Israel in the Middle East.
"Zionism is the movement for the self-determination and statehood for the Jewish people in their ancestral homeland, the land of Israel," according to the Anti-Defamation League.
Thirteen Democrats voted against the measure and 105 Dems voted 'present' or did not vote neither supporting nor opposing the resolution.
One Republican - U.S.
Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky - voted against the anti-Zionism/antisemitism measure. Another four GOP lawmakers did not vote.
"Anti-Zionism isn't antisemitism," Massie said in a social media statement pointing to congressional remarks by U.S. Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-New York, that some Orthodox and other Jews are not in agreement with modern Zionist constructs.
Nadler, the House's most senior Jewish members, said some Orthodox Jews believe only the Messiah can establish a new state of Israel and the measure can label progressive Jews and others critical of controversial judicial reforms in Israel as antisemitic.
Nadler and U.S. House Majority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-New York, were among those voting present on antisemitism measure.
The 13 Democratic no votes came from progressives who have been critical of Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas and U.S. support for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after the Islamic militant group's Oct. 7 attacks.
Opponents of the measure - which referenced rises antisemitic vandalism and violence - included U.S. Reps. Jamaal Bowman and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota and Pramila Jayapal of Washington "We must be steadfast and clear in condemning antisemitism. The extreme GOP resolution on the floor today had no Democratic cosponsors and inappropriately said all anti-Zionism is antisemitism. Muddying the waters about what antisemitism is, is completely wrong and unhelpful," said Jayapal who had to clarify recent comments about whether she condemned Hamas' rapes and violence against women and girls in the Oct. 7.
GOP SUPPORTS MEASURE U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican representing the Eastern Shore, voted for the antisemitism measure along with Maryland Democratic U.S. Reps.
Steny Hoyer, David Trone, Dutch Ruppersberger and Kweisi Mfume. Maryland Democratic U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin and John Sarbanes voted present.
House Republicans overwhelmingly backed the resolution which labels some pro-Palestinian slogans as antisemitic.
"More Jews were murdered on October 7th than on any other single day since the Holocaust.
Let that sink in. We have even seen members of this very body repeat blatantly antisemitic rhetoric and spread lies about Israel and her right to exist. Let me be absolutely clear: such hate has no place in the halls of Congress nor our national discourse. It is our fundamental responsibility as leaders and Members of Congress to condemn and fight these horrific acts of hate and discrimination against the Jewish community," said U.S. Rep. David Kustoff, R-Tennessee, one of the main sponsors of the resolution.
GOP backers of the measure point to a rise in antisemitic incidents and pro-Hamas and pro-Palestinian rhetoric that calls for or insinuates the destruction of Israel. They also point to the 106 no or present that did not support the measure - 105 of them from Democrat.
"The world has seen a drastic rise of antisemitism since October 7th that is deeply disheartening and extremely concerning," said U.S. Max Miller, R-Ohio. "Elected leaders must have the courage to condemn and fight all forms of domestic and global antisemitism.
While I am glad this resolution passed the House today, I am disappointed that 106 of my colleagues failed to take this opportunity to condemn antisemitism forcefully." AMERICA DIVIDED The Gallup poll released Nov. 30 shows significant splits over the Holy Land war by race, political party and gender.
The polls shows 71% of Republicans back Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza versus support from 36% of Democrats.
Fifty nine percent of men approve of Israel's war in Gaza versus 44% of women, according the Gallup Among people of color, 64% disapprove of Israel's attacks against Hamas in Gaza while 61% of whites backs Netanyahu's efforts to dismantle the militant group.
There is a similar split my age with 67% of younger Americans (ages 18 to 34) disapproving of Israel's war against Hamas and 63% of voters 55 and older backing the Israel Defense Forces' military effort.
Palestinian health authorities in Hamas-controlled Gaza say more than 17,000 people have died since Holy Land war stared in October Israeli officials say Hamas fighters killed more than 1,200 people and took more than 240 hostages in the Oct. 7 terror attacks. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS

 Noa Mittelman, 15, center, and Maya Talby, 15, right, hold up flyers of people kidnapped by Hamas during a rally and march for Israel, Sunday, Nov. 19, 2023, in the Seattle suburb of Kirkland, Wash.

 ASSOCIATED PRESS

 Muslim protesters burn U.S. and Israel national flags during a rally against the Israeli airstrikes in Gaza, outside the U.S. Embassy in Jakarta, Indonesia Wednesday, Oct. 11, 2023.

 ASSOCIATED PRESS

 A demonstrator waves a Palestinian flag as Kenyan police officers fire teargas canisters during a protest against Israel and in support of Palestinians, in Nairobi, Kenya Nov. 9, 2023. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a congressional measure and a nationwide Gallup poll about attitudes toward the Israel-Hamas war, covering political and demographic divisions across the United States, which fits the scope of national news.

title: Record U.S. defense money for AI, quantum weapons, Israel, Ukraine - $886 billion military spending bill keeps FISA surveillance, approves $600M for Kyiv, R&D, weapons for IDF
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Record U.S. defense money for AI, quantum weapons, Israel, Ukraine - $886 billion military spending bill keeps FISA surveillance, approves $600M for Kyiv, R&D, weapons for IDF

 December 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 1266
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The deep partisan divides in Washington do not extend to U.S. military spending - which is approaching $1 trillion annually.Congress approved the $886 billion National Defense Authorization Act this week with bipartisan support from both U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
The record-high, U.S. military spending bill includes weapons and outlays for Israel (including joint development or artificial intelligence and quantum technology weapons) and Ukraine and extends a controversial government surveillance program.
The measure approves $600 million in U.S. military aid to Ukraine in its war against invading Russia forces. The U.S. has already provided $44.2 billion in weapons and other aid to Ukraine since Russia 2022 invasion and President Joe Biden wants to provide $61 billion more as part of a $106 billion war package that also includes outlays for Israel, border security and Taiwan.
The bipartisan legislature also bolsters U.S. support for the Israel as it continues its war against Hamas in Gaza after the Oct. 7 attacks by the Islamic militant group. More than 18,000 Gazans and 1,200 Israels have died in the Holy Land war.
The U.S. measure has $500 million for Israel missile defense systems including the Iron Dome which is used to repeal rockets from Hamas, Islamic and Hizbollah. The package - which will soon be signed by Biden - also allocates $47.5 million for new U.S and Israeli joint military research related to artificial intelligence (AI) and quantum technologies.
It also extends the Pentagon's ability to ship "precision-guided munitions" and other weapons systems to Israel as well as a joint anti-tunneling program.
Israel Defense Forces are in the midst of a ground invasion of Gaza including efforts to root out and destroy Hamas tunneling system below the densely populated Palestinian area.
The NDAA also instructs the Pentagon and federal agencies to implement a "national strategy" to combat antisemitism.
AIPAC - a pro-Israel lobbying group - and the Anti-Defamation League - leading Jewish group - both back the defense measure.
House Majority Whip Tom Emmer, R-Minnesota, said the NDAA "includes numerous provisions to expand U.S.-Israel defense cooperation and one to ensure that no military resources go to anyone participating in anti-Israel boycotts."
Israel already receives more than $3 billion U.S. defense aid annually.
The NDAA also includes a 5.2% pay increase for U.S. military personnel, funds National Guard deployments aimed cross-border drug trafficking in particular fentanyl and approves more than $16 billion to bolster the U.S. military's posture in the Pacific Rim and help allies such as Taiwan and the Philippines which have faced saber rattling from China.
BIPARTISAN BACKING
The House approved the U.S. military spending package by a 310 to 118 vote Thursday.
Republicans voted for the measure by a 147 to 75 margin. Among Democrats, 163 House members supported the defending spending program while 45 opposed.
"I was proud to support the NDAA, which include a historic pay raise for our troops, additional tools to disrupt fentanyl trafficking and critical support for Israel," said U.S. Rep. Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a freshman Republican from Oregon.
U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-Louisiana, House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-New York, Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Kentucky, all backed the Pentagon measure.
The Senate approved the measure Wednesday by an 87-13 vote.
Schumer hailed the bill as helping the Pentagon develop and deploy more AI systems and weapons.
Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Ben Cardin, D-Maryland, said the measure reinforces U.S. backing for Israel, Ukraine and NATO and will propel next generation weapons.
"By harnessing the power of America's science and technology, the NDAA will invest in disruptive technologies like hypersonic weapons, artificial intelligence, and quantum computing while continuing to modernize our ships, aircraft, and ground combat vehicles," Cardin said in a statement.
INDUSTRY BACKING
Lobbying groups and associations representing the aerospace, technology and defense contracting sectors back the bill including increase U.S. Defense Department spending on AI and quantum computing.
"The U.S. must be the global leader in the investment, development, and deployment of artificial intelligence (AI) to ensure it is implemented responsibly across the world. This year's NDAA includes provisions that will strengthen our leadership in AI and other emerging technologies, including quantum computing," said TechNet, a group whose members include Apple, Deloitte, Amazon, Google and Meta, in a statement supporting the NDAA.
The Aerospace Industries Association, whose members include Honeywell Aerospace, Northrop Grumman, General Dynamics, RTX (Raytheon), BAE Systems and Boeing, also supports the big defense spending and more money for AI.
Biden is expected to sign the bill which was approved shortly after a visit to Washington and Capitol Hill by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, which included meetings with lawmakers and defense contractors.
Biden warned U.S. support for Ukraine could run out if the $106 billion war supplemental is not approved. White House officials said that could embolden Russian President Vladimir Putin and results on direct conflicts between Moscow and NATO involving U.S. troops.
The no votes in the Senate came from six Democrats (including Oregon Sens. Ron Wyden and Jeff Merkley), six Republicans (including U.S. Sens. J.D Vance of Ohio, Rand Paul of Kentucky and Mike Lee of Utah). U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vermont, also oppose the measure
FISA FIGHT
Some NDAA opponents were upset with a provision in the 3,000-page bill that reauthorized Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.
An effort to block that reauthorization failed in the U.S. Senate.
Critics of the FISA section (including the American Civil Liberties Union), which is focused on investigating foreign terrorists, say it allows the FBI and intelligence agencies to spy on Americans without a court-approved warrant.
U.S. Rep. Matt Rosendale, R-Montana, said he's backed past defense spending measure but voted no Thursday on the latest NDAA over the FISA surveillance issue and concerns over taxpayer money being used to pay for abortions and gender reassignment surgeries and to allow drag queen shows on military bases. The final bill did not include GOP language specifically restricting Pentagon on those social issues.
"A vote in favor of this bill is a vote to allow the U.S. government to spy on you.
A vote in favor of this bill is a vote to allow the U.S. military to pick you up and lock you up in Guantanamo Bay without representation. A vote in favor of this bill is a vote to inflict the radical left's social experiment on our military and is an insult to our men and women in uniform, which is why I voted no," Rosendale said.
Rosendale also said the FBI used FISA Section 702 to spy on "U.S. citizens more than 278,000 times without a warrant."
U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican representing the Eastern Shore, and Jamie Raskin, a Democrat from Montgomery County, voted against the defense bill. The rest of Maryland's delegation - all Democrats - voted for the spending measure.
U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, said measure will bring $886 million to Fort Meade which is home to the National Security Agency for renovations and expansion of NSA operations.
Some of the Democratic opposition came from progressives who have been critical of U.S. and Biden administration support for Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas after the Oct. 7 attacks.
Democratic no votes includes ones from U.S.
Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota and Pramila Jayapal of Washington.
While GOP leadership backed the measure along with former House Speakers Kevin McCarthy, R-California and Nancy Pelosi, D-California, some notable populist conservatives joined progressive "Squad" member in opposing the defense budget.
GOP U.S. Reps. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia, Matt Gaetz, Anna Paulina Luna and Greg Steube of Florida, and Doug LaMalfa, of California, voted against the NDAA. 
 
 Caption: President Joe Biden meets with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the Oval Office of the White House, Tuesday, Dec. 12, 2023, in Washington. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: QA honors veterans' memories with Wreaths Across America
author: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com
content:
QA honors veterans' memories with Wreaths Across America

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE's COUNTY - This past weekend saw the Wreaths Across America truck convoy headed to Arlington National Cemetery with thousands of Christmas wreaths.Stopping over night Thursday. Dec. 7, for the 14th consecutive year, they were again hosted by Kent Island American Legion Post 278, in Stevensville, under direction of Past Post Commander and the 2023 Maryland State Legionnaire of the Year Nikki Randolph.
Randolph has earned a reputation for her passionate care for all veterans, making sure veteran grave sites are bestowed with American flags and Christmas wreaths at appropriate times of the year, every year.
The yearly tradition began when she was then commander of Post 278 and contacted Morrill and Karen Worcester of Maine, who had already begun the Wreaths Across America program - hauling Christmas wreaths from their state to the nation's capitol to place those wreaths on all veteran's grave sites at Arlington National Cemetery.
Randolph and Legion 278 volunteers provided three meals, dinner, breakfast and boxed lunches to the convoy before they made the final leg of their journey to Arlington.
This year, the Wreaths Across America sent out over 3,000,000 Christmas wreaths across the nation to more than 4,200 locations to be placed on those grave sites. Most were placed on Saturday, Dec. 9.
Eleven wreaths were also presented to families connected to Post 278, whose veterans chose to be cremated rather than buried in a cemetery.
One of those was to the wife of the late George Dashiell, who served during World War II in Germany.
Mrs. Wally Dashiell, now 100-years-old has been a widow for the past 17 years. She said, "I'm truly grateful that the Legion honored George in this way." The wreath was placed next to the urn that holds his ashes, the American flag presented during his memorial service, and a picture of George.
Friday morning the convoy departed from Legion 278 along Route 8, children from both Matapeake Elementary and Middle Schools cheering and waving small American flags. An emotional scene, it was clear the children were excited to participate.
Saturday at noon, American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18 in Centreville, hosted their annual Wreaths Across America ceremony at Chesterfield Cemetery. Approximately 200 people were present, many of them children and teens with their parents. 
 
 Caption: PHOTOS BY DOUG BISHOP

 U.S. Army veteran John Nizer is pictured laying a Christmas wreath for all POWs and Missing in Action veterans at the annual Wreaths Across American ceremony at Chesterfield Cemetery in Centreville, Saturday afternoon, Dec. 9. In the background, Legion 18 member John White takes a photograph and Sea Cadet Unit members stand at attention. Over 3 million wreaths were laid at more than 4,200 locations across the nation of Saturday.

 Pictured at the Chesterfield Cemetery in Centreville, American Legion Vice Commander Ken Huddleston gives opening remarks during the annual Wreaths Across America ceremony there. To his far left, Legion Riders Chaplain Andy "Wizard" Cowley prepares to give the blessing for the event. More than 200 people turned out to help lay wreaths.

 Pre-k children from Christ Episcopal Church Day School wave small American flags at tractor trailer drivers departing from the Kent Island American Legion Post 278, in Stevensville, Friday morning, Dec. 8, as the trucks headed toward Arlington National Cemetery to deliver Christmas wreaths to be placed on military veterans grave sites. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Finding a political identity in a red state
author: TIMOTHY HOLDINESS
content:
Finding a political identity in a red state

 January 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TIMOTHY HOLDINESS | Section: Columns 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Born into a Republican family in Louisiana, a state increasingly painted in shades of red, I grew up amid conservative dialogues with honest values. My childhood was steeped in Republican ideologies, shaping my early political outlook. However, as I matured, my views began to diverge from my family's, leading me on a journey through America's polarized political landscape.My first significant political shift occurred during my college years. Drawn to Bernie Sanders' progressive policies and candid demeanor, I found myself aligning more with the Democratic Party. Sanders' message of social justice and economic equality resonated with me, contrasting sharply with the conservative values I was raised on. This shift was not just ideological but deeply personal, reflecting a desire for a more equitable society.
However, disillusionment soon set in. As the Democratic Party nominated a candidate I couldn't wholeheartedly support in the 2016 election, I switched my registration to the Green Party and voted for Jill Stein in protest. This decision, born out of frustration with the party's direction, was my way of asserting a political identity independent of the mainstream options.
Yet, this stance was short-lived. Recognizing the practical limitations of third-party voting in our binary political system, I returned to the Democratic fold. But this reunion was not a homecoming; it was a strategic choice, a compromise of sorts.
Today, I stand as an independent, disenchanted with the binary party system that seems more focused on partisan rivalry than on addressing the real issues facing our nation. As a Louisianian, this stance is particularly challenging. Louisiana's political landscape has become overwhelmingly Republican, often leaving little room for alternative viewpoints. This environment has sharpened my understanding of political diversity and the importance of open, respectful discourse.
Living in Louisiana has offered unique insights into the Republican psyche. It has helped me understand the concerns and motivations the GOP, even as I disagree with some of their policies, I can't help but agree with others. This understanding is crucial in a state like ours, where political discussions can quickly become divisive, it's important to be able to see from all points of view and vote for action over ideas.
The journey from a Republican upbringing to a Democratic supporter, then to a protest voter, and finally to an independent, mirrors a broader disillusionment with party politics in America. It reflects a yearning for a political system that transcends binary choices and embraces a more nuanced, inclusive approach to governance, as many other nations on Earth.
As a nation, we face a critical question: How do we foster a political environment where diverse viewpoints are not just tolerated but valued? My journey suggests the answer lies in embracing our political diversity, engaging in open dialogue and prioritizing issues over party allegiance.
My political evolution is not just a personal narrative; it's a reflection of a growing segment of Americans disenchanted with the two-party system. As a Louisianian, I've witnessed firsthand the limitations of this system. Perhaps it's time for our state, and our country, to embrace a new political paradigm — one that truly represents the diverse voices of its people.
Timothy Holdiness is a community Rreporter for The Daily News in Washington Parish, Louisiana. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an opinion column discussing political identity, party affiliation, and broader national political dynamics, which aligns best with the 'National News' category. It does not focus on race, local issues, or any of the other listed topics.

title: U.S. weapons deal with Ecuador in ‘war’ with gangs would swap out, send Russian arms to Ukraine
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
U.S. weapons deal with Ecuador in ‘war’ with gangs would swap out, send Russian arms to Ukraine

 January 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: World 
 
 609
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A planned deal would have the U.S. send $200 million in new weapons and military equipment to Ecuador to help the government in its fight against drug gangs in exchange for older Russian armaments that Washington could then potentially transfer to Ukraine.The U.S. is also sending top military and drug enforcement officials to Ecuador after criminal gangs took more than 100 prison guards hostage and gained temporary control of a television station.
Ecuador President Daniel Noboa has deployed military troops throughout the country and declared a state of emergency in response to the gangs and viral videos of prison guards being held hostage and the takeover of the TV station. There has also been social media footage of Ecuadorian troops and police officers cracking down on gang members.
Noboa, who was born in Miami and educated in the U.S., said the South American country is in a "state of war."
U.S. State Department spokesman Matthew Miller condemned "violence and terrorism at the hands of narco-criminal elements" in Ecuador and promised to increase intelligence sharing and other resources with the government.
"To accelerate that cooperation, senior U.S. officials will visit Ecuador in the coming weeks to explore with Ecuadorian counterparts ways we can work together more effectively to confront the threat posed by transnational criminal organizations. These officials include Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Assistant Secretary Todd Robinson, Bureau of Western Hemisphere Affairs Deputy Assistant Secretary Kevin Sullivan, Commander of U.S. Southern Command General Laura Richardson,' Miller said.
"U.S. law enforcement officials will also travel to assist Ecuador in criminal investigations. In addition, the United States will increase intelligence sharing, cooperation to combat malicious cyber activity, and assistance with the implementation of prison reforms and will employ other available tools to hold accountable those individuals and organizations engaging in criminal activity and undermining the rule of law," the statement continued.
U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Maryland (who chairs the Senate Foreign Relations Committee) echoed American backing for the Ecuadorian government in the strife which also included a prison escape of a top gang leader.
"Ecuador is a key partner of the United States. Its security and prosperity are in the mutual interest of our peoples. We are horrified by the heinous acts of violence perpetrated by armed criminal groups across the country. We reaffirm our support for President Noboa as he moves to restore order and bring justice to those undermining the country's stability," said Cardin in a joint statement with House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul, R-Texas.
Noboa talked about the U.S. military deal on the Canela radio station.
"We will receive help from the United States. The swap will involve outdated Russian and Ukrainian scrap for modern equipment and technology worth $200 million," Noboa told the station.
Last year, Richardson said the U.S. was asking Latin American countries to swap out older Russian and even Soviet-era weaponry for new American systems and munitions and ship that older equipment to Kyiv in the fight against Russia.
"We are working with the countries that have the Russian equipment to either donate it or switch it out for United States equipment," Richardson said during an appearance at the Atlantic Council in Washington, according to Voice of America and other outlets.
The U.S. has sent more than $44.9 billion weapons and other military aid to Ukraine since Russian forces invaded the Eastern European country in February 2022.
But a new $61 billion aid package for Ukraine that is part of a larger proposal that includes $14 billion for Israel's war in Gaza and $14 billion to bolster border security has been stalled in Congress as Republicans press for more stringent immigration reforms and some press against more spending on the European war. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
