title: 'This is our mandate': What's driving Evangelical Christians steadfast support for Israel and the war against Hamas in Gaza
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
'This is our mandate': What's driving Evangelical Christians steadfast support for Israel and the war against Hamas in Gaza

 January 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: World 
 
 1939
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Shawn York said he felt "a commission" to support Israel and to "do something" after Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks that sparked the war in Gaza.York is lead pastor at Highpoint Church in Gulf Breeze, Florida. The 1,100-member Evangelical church is located near Pensacola.
York partnered with local Jewish rabbis and hosted "A Night to Honor Israel" event in December to show solidarity after the Hamas attacks that killed more than 1,200 people Oct. 7 and to condemn antisemitism.
The Evangelical pastor said the event came together after meeting with a local rabbi whose synagogue had been vandalized after the Oct. 7 attacks sparked Israel Defense Force airstrikes and a later ground invasion of Gaza aimed at dismantling Hamas.
"We had a cup of coffee and hit it off," said York, adding that the pro-Israel event was aimed at bringing the local religious community together. "It was a very grassroots effort."
Across the U.S, Evangelical Christians have emerged as some of the strongest supporters of Israel and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's war against Hamas and other Islamic militants.
Some conservative Christians point to biblical instructions to support Israel and the Jewish people. Others also see events in the Holy Land as part of 'End Times' prophecies that result in establishment of a third Jewish temple in Jerusalem (where the Al-Asqa Mosque sits) and eventually the Second Coming of Jesus Christ.
Six hundred people attended the Florida event in-person and another 1,400 have watched it online. York said it is in important to get supportive messages out about Israel pointing to a rise in antisemitism and vocal criticisms of the war and supportive U.S. policies on social media as well as from progressives and pro-Palestinian activists on college campuses.
"Israel's fight is a cyber war just as much as a ground war," the Florida pastor.
'AMEN FOR THAT'
York said he and his wife had previously visited Israel and toured the Gaza border. He was at a conference hosted by Christians United for Israel in Texas in the midst of the Holy Land war.
Christians United is a pro-Israel group formed by prominent pastor and television evangelist John Hagee. The group was one of the organizers of the March for Israel rally in November on the Washington Mall and has helped local churches put on their own events.
The San Antonio-based group did not respond to requests for an interview about their efforts.
The group's 2022 nonprofit tax form said its mission is to "increase the knowledge of Christian Zionists in order to help them become more effective in defending Israel to the public and in Washington."
The "Christian Zionist' group's goal is to train Evangelicals, including pastors, to become advocates for Israel and to lobby every member of Congress by dividing them into "hundreds of 'teams'."
"CUFI Action Fund will instruct approximately 5,000 attendees at a Washington D.C. meeting on what it takes to effectively influence Congress," the tax filing reads.
The pro-Israel group also said in the filing that it would "select over 300 attendees who possessed exceptional communication skills and have wide circles of influence in their communities to be Action Fund leaders."
A number of churches have partnered with Christians United to host events supporting Israel since the war started.
That includes the Grand Island Baptist Church, which hosted a "Stand with Israel" event in December and had another update on the Middle East situation on Sunday, Jan. 14.
Grand Island Baptist Pastor Freddy Young told his congregation that CUFI has 13 million members and is an important advocate for pro-Israel policies in the U.S.
"CUFI is the largest grassroots organization supporting Israel to be found anywhere in the world. Amen for that," Young said during the Dec. 4 event.
"When people in Washington D.C. do crazy things, we blow their computers ups. We can send them several thousand messages in almost the snap of a finger."
Hagee and CUFI are organizing an annual summit for pastors and other Christians supporters of Israel in Washington in late July.
"The people of Israel are fighting to protect their loved ones and their ancient homelands. We must stand by Israel," Hagee said in a social media post voicing biblical support for Israel, its right of self-defense and its battle with Hamas. "Together, we can show the Jewish people that they are not alone."
Some other Christian cable networks and television evangelists have also been supportive of Israel after the Oct. 7 attacks.
Joni Lamb, co-founder and executive producer of the Daystar Television Network, told viewers that the Texas-based Christian cable channel had raised more than $6 million since the October attacks to support Israel including sending protective gear, mobile bomb shelters and provisions to communities impacted by the war.
The dynamic places Evangelicals not only among the strongest backers of Netanyahu but aligns one of former president Donald Trump's most solid constituencies with U.S. President Joe Biden who has vowed steadfast support for Israel and also calls himself a Zionist, advocating for Jewish homeland and nation-state in the Middle East.
Netanyahu has invoked biblical passages during the war including a reference to Amalek and Amalekites — an Old Testament foe of the Israelites. Israeli officials say they have killed approximately 8,500 Hamas and other Islamic militants fighter in Gaza in addition to the 1,000 fighters killed during the Oct. 7 attacks inside Israel that also included more than 240 hostages being taken into the Palestinian territory.
'WE CANNOT LET THIS SLIP AWAY'
Other Evangelical Christians say their cause is two-fold — to support Israel's war against Hamas and to combat a rise in antisemitism that has manifested since the bombings and ground invasion.
Antisemitic incidents are up 360% since the Hamas attacks and ensuing war compared to a year ago, according to the Anti-Defamation League.
"The American Jewish community is facing a threat level that's now unprecedented in modern history," said Jonathan Greenblatt, ADL CEO. "It's shocking that we've recorded more antisemitic acts in three months than we usually would in an entire year."
ADL reports 3,238 incidents between Oct. 7 and Jan. 7, including anti-Israel, anti-Zionist and anti-Jewish rhetoric at pro-Palestinian and anti-war rallies on U.S. college campuses, That compares to 712 antisemitic incidents a year ago.
The rise in antisemitism — along with supporting Israel after the Hamas terror attacks — are calls to action for many American Evangelicals..
"We cannot let this slip away and not be noticed by the world or understood," said Tiz Huch, who is part of a Tulsa, Oklahoma-based Christian ministry with her husband Larry Huch.
"And this is our mandate — is to tell the world. The battle (between) light and darkness is real. And we all have to step up and do our part and be a voice for goodness and for God in the world today," said Tiz Huch during a broadcast and social media post Thursday, Jan. 11.
The Oklahoma-based ministry also sees End Times prophecies in the intersections of faiths in the Middle East.
"We will stand with Israel, repair the breach between Jews and Christians and fulfill biblical prophecy. This is how we prepare the world for the coming of the Messiah," Huch Ministries says on its website in a statement on support for Israel.
'A USELESS SLAUGHTER'
But not all Christians are as steadfastly supportive of the Holy Land war and all its human costs.
There have been more than 24,000 deaths in Gaza since the war's start, according to Palestinian health authorities. Another 8,000 people are missing beneath the rubble. Most are presumed dead. More than 1.5 million people have been displaced and many of Gaza's homes and buildings have been destroyed since the war started in October.
Save the Children International says approximately 10,000 children have died in Gaza since the war started. "Gaza is becoming a graveyard for children," said United Nations Secretary General Antonio Guterres earlier this month.
Approximately two dozen Christians have died in Gaza during the war. That includes those killed at St. Porphyrius Church in October and two women killed at the Holy Family Church campus in December.
The former was built in the 5th Century and the latter is the only Catholic parish in Gaza where there are only an estimated 1,000 Christians in an overwhelming Muslim area of 2.3 million people.
The Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem — which oversees Roman Catholic parishes in the Holy Land and Cyprus — blamed Israel Defense Forces for the killing of a woman and her adult daughter and the shelling of a convent building at the church compound. The IDF says it is not to blame for the church shootings or damage to the Catholic property.
An Israeli spokesperson said in a statement that it takes military actions against Hamas in civilian areas "with the utmost seriousness — especially churches — considering that Christian communities are a minority group in the Middle East."
"The IDF only targets terrorists and terror infrastructure and does not target civilians, no matter their religion. The IDF takes vast measures to avoid harm to uninvolved civilians, while fighting against a terrorist organization which does everything to put civilians at risk — including by using civilians and holy sites as human shields for its terror activities,' the Israeli statement continued.
Pope Francis, the World Council of Churches and the heads of Anglican and Episcopal churches have called for ceasefires in the war.
"Civilian victims are not collateral damage. They are men and women with names and surnames who lose their lives. They are children who are orphaned and deprived of their future," Pope Francis said Jan. 10.
Catholic officials previously condemned the shooting deaths and injuries at the Holy Family parish. The pope also called the war and its heavy humanitarian toll in Gaza a "useless slaughter that offends the dignity of every person on earth."
'THE DOWNTRODDEN AND THE OPPRESSED'
Holy Land Christians — which include Armenian, Greek and other Orthodox denominations as well as Roman Catholics, Anglicans and Evangelical Lutherans — have criticized American Evangelicals and others supporting the war citing its humanitarian costs.
In an open letter to American and other Western Christians, a coalition of Holy Land Christians questioned support for the war and called for a focus on Jesus' message of peace and mercy.
"We reject all theologies and interpretations that legitimize the wars of the powerful. We strongly urge western Christians to come alongside us in this. We also remind ourselves and fellow Christians that God is the God of the downtrodden and the oppressed," the letter reads.
There are also an estimated 50,000 Christians living in Jerusalem and the West Bank (which has a population of 3 million) and 158,000 living in Israel (which has a population of 9.7 million)
Christmas celebrations — including Bethlehem where Jesus was born — were subdued and decorations taken down because of the war in Gaza and conflicts in the West Bank and Lebanon where the IDF is exchanging fire with Hezbollah.
In the U.S., the Episcopal Church has called for the U.S. to tell Israel to stop the attacks in Gaza.
Justin Amash, a former Michigan congressman and Palestinian-American Christian, points in a Substack article earlier this month that Gaza has been home to one of the longest standing Christian communities. Mary, Jesus and Joseph passed through the area in their biblical journeys to and from Egypt.
"A lot of people were surprised to learn there are Christians living in Gaza, but this community has existed since the earliest days of Christianity. Followers of Christ have long called Gaza home," said Amash who lost family members in the Orthodox church bombing.
"The people known today as Palestinian Christians are the descendants of Canaanites, Phoenicians, and Israelites who resided in the region that comprises present-day Israel, Gaza, and the West Bank. Palestinian Christians can trace much of their ancestry back to Jews and Samaritans who lived in the Levant thousands of years ago and became early Christians," Amash writes. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a nationwide religious‑political phenomenon—Evangelical support for Israel and the Gaza war—relevant to U.S. national politics and foreign policy, fitting the scope of National News more than any other listed category.

title: Gone down a dark road
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gone down a dark road

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 312
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gone downa dark road
And so begins the Democrats' long-awaited dream of managing the election process in America. The ballot process has begun, and it is mid-January.
Funny how elections everywhere seemed to pretty much go off without much controversy for many decades. I'm sure someone will come up with a small incident and make it sound like something major but as usual, the hysterical comments will surely arrive.
I just received in the mail, taxpayer paid, forms to apply for voter mail-in ballots for this years elections. You can opt to get mail-in ballots for future elections as well. Believe it or not you can also print these online yourself. Yes, print your own. What could possibly go wrong? Nothing, according to the Democrats and socialists who have pushed this agenda for years.
Our government, our military, our schools and our banks have been hacked by people who have bad intentions or just the plain everyday criminals. But why worry about our votes? Sure voting may be difficult for a very small group of citizens and that has been and will always be the case.
Does anybody think that computer fraud is not an even greater risk to our democracy? Who started this ridiculous "risk to our democracy" campaign anyway? How cliche. It seems like only a select few believe that this new era of voting technology will go smoothly because that is what supports that group's agenda. Watch what accusations and problems are sure to happen during this election cycle.
Our presidential elections are in the fall as usual and just about the time that our annual fall harvests conclude. Funny that it's about the same time the election ballot harvesting will begin. Maybe I'm the only one who thinks our election balloting process has gone down a dark road. I doubt that I'm alone. Which political party controls the Board of Elections anyway?
Rich Adrian
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses concerns about mail‑in ballots, election security, and the broader democratic process, which are topics typically covered under national news rather than the other listed categories.

title: Steady leadership, respect earn voters' support
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Steady leadership, respect earn voters' support

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 625
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As we proceed full speed into the 2024 presidential election, the levels of bitter, vitriolic, divisive, often misleading, bombastic and demeaning rhetoric from candidates of both parties continues to escalate.This election cycle reminds me of a bitter and contentious general election for governor in Pennsylvania.
In that election, the Republican candidate was William Scranton, a former one-term Republican member of Congress. The Democratic candidate was Richardson Dilworth, the incumbent mayor of Philadelphia.
Scranton's political resume was thin. His only experience as a candidate was his successful run for Congress. Despite that, the state GOP was bullish on him after losing to Democratic candidates in two previous gubernatorial elections. They believed Scranton's success as a volunteer civic leader on economic development issues in a depressed region of a rust belt state would resonate well with voters.
Dilworth on the other hand, had a long history of political success in Philadelphia. He was elected city treasurer, district attorney and twice as mayor. His success was due in part to Philadelphia being a deep blue city with huge numbers of Democratic votes cast in local and statewide elections.
Dilworth's electoral success in Philadelphia was also based in part on a simple, but effective campaign strategy. His campaign would purchase time on a local TV station to which he would invite his opponents to a debate. He did so fully expecting his opponents would not participate. They always obliged him. As a result, he had a full hour of viewers to himself, where he reminded them not only of his accomplishments, but also repeatedly mentioned that his opponent chose not to participate in the debate.
As the November gubernatorial election heated up, Dilworth again rented TV time and invited Scranton to join him for a debate. He smugly assumed that Scranton, like all his previous opponents, would be a no show.
Dilworth assumed wrong.
Minutes before airtime Scranton unexpectedly strolled into the TV studio. A surprised and angry Dilworth had a meltdown. It started when Dilworth shouted at Scranton, "What are you doing here?"
During the debate, Dilworth peppered Scranton with insults. With thinly disguised contempt he called Scranton a phony, a coward, a Little Lord Fauntleroy, and an Ivy League Dick Nixon. Unruffled, Scranton calmly but forcefully responded with "You, sir, are a desperate man."
All of this was captured on film and was also widely reported by the print media who were there for the debate. Even those who did not see the actual television debate read all about Dilworth's meltdown.
The debate was an unexpected and game changing negative branding movement for Dilworth's grace under pressure, civility and steady leadership credentials.
By contrast, the debate was an unexpected and game changing positive branding moment for Scranton's grace under pressure, civility and leadership credentials.
In November, Scranton beat Dilworth with 55% of the total statewide votes. This occurred despite strong support for Dilworth from President Kennedy who had carried Pennsylvania in the preceding statewide presidential election.
This is a lesson for the candidates the Republican Party and the Democratic Party eventually nominate for president in 2024.
American voters have long deserved and rarely seen a presidential election where candidates are not demonizing those who disagree with them and their supporters, by questioning their motives and their intellectual capability to make informed decisions.
Regularly showing grace under pressure, civility, steady leadership and respect for all views during a long and often grueling campaign is the best way for candidates to earn voter's support and gain their trust to govern fairly and inclusively if elected.
Now is the time for presidential candidates from both parties to commit to disagree on issues without being extremely disagreeable. Voters deserve nothing less.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who serves as a trusted adviser on strategy, advocacy and media matters. He lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses presidential and gubernatorial elections, candidate behavior, and political strategy, which are matters of national political news rather than local, sports, or other categories.

title: Moral sanity arises from both sides of war
author: ROBERT C. KOEHLER
content:
Moral sanity arises from both sides of war

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT C. KOEHLER | Section: Columns 
 
 887
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "I am begging the world: stop all the wars, stop killing people, stop killing babies. War is not the answer ... War is not how you fix things. This country, Israel, is going through horror. And I know the mothers in Gaza are going through horror ..."I can only kneel in awe.
Yes, there is sanity in the world — moral sanity — even, and especially, now, as revenge rages in Israel, fed by American armaments. There are courageous voices calling not simply for "peace," essentially understood by much of the world as nothing more than a ceasefire, but for, oh my God, compassion, healing, love.
The "enemy" is as human as we are. And waging war against the enemy guarantees nothing but ... endless war.
The words above are those of Michal Haley, whose beloved son was murdered by Hamas, crying out in a Facebook video: "In my name, I want no vengeance."
Perhaps what matters most here is that she is not alone. Many courageous people across the planet are speaking out against the current war — the current genocide — from their wounded souls, demanding that the human race transcend its commitment to violence, dominance and revenge, which do nothing but perpetuate the carnage. War equals suicide.
It's also seductive and lucrative and built into the planet's geopolitical infrastructure. It's so simple: good vs. evil. It makes a great narrative, which much of the media surrenders to. Transcending the mindset of war requires facing life at a far deeper level of complexity, beginning, perhaps, with the understanding that all of humanity and all of life are connected. Most people know this, but the dark psychology of dehumanization — "othering," creating an enemy to blame for our troubles — retains a prominent place in the collective mind.
Transcending this may be the biggest challenge we face. What's crucial to understand is that this challenge is underway. South Africa's charge before the International Court of Justice that Israel is committing genocide against Palestine is one example of this.
As Craig Mokhiber and Phyllis Bennis write: (The case) "has opened a crack in a 75-year-old wall of impunity through which a light of hope has begun to shine. If global protests can seize the moment to turn that crack into a wider portal towards justice, we may just see the beginnings of real accountability for perpetrators, redress for victims, and attention to the long-neglected root causes of violence: settler-colonialism, occupation, inequality, and apartheid."
But South Africa's challenge is only part of the global outrage against Israel's war on Palestine — and the challenge amounts to more than simply a ceasefire. It is also a cry for transcendence. For instance:
"We condemn the recent attacks on Israeli and Palestinian civilians and mourn such harrowing loss of life. In our grief, we are horrified to see the fight against antisemitism weaponized as a pretext for war crimes with stated genocidal intent."
This is from an open letter to the world, signed by several thousand Jewish writers, artists and activists, declaring that condemnation of the slaughter of Palestinians is the opposite of antisemitism. The letter continues:
"We find this rhetorical tactic antithetical to Jewish values, which teach us to repair the world, question authority, and champion the oppressed over the oppressor. It is precisely because of the painful history of antisemitism and lessons of Jewish texts that we advocate for the dignity and sovereignty of the Palestinian people. We refuse the false choice between Jewish safety and Palestinian freedom; between Jewish identity and ending the oppression of Palestinians. In fact, we believe the rights of Jews and Palestinians go hand-in-hand. The safety of each people depends on the other's."
Oh my God, this is what matters: the cessation of the stripping of religion from its deepest values and turning it into a game of dominance. My religion's better than yours. We are at a stage of our existence where we must begin disarming our hatred and fear and facing the future with — you might say — empowered compassion. We must begin living our deepest values, not simply "defending" them. This is moral sanity.
And the voices the people who are saying this with the most courageous clarity are the ones who have been wounded by, or who have lost loved ones to, the moral insanity that continues to cut swaths across our world.
Here's another such voice, one of many quoted by Orly Noy in +972 Magazine. The words are those of Maoz Inon, whose parents were killed in the Oct. 7 Hamas attack: "My parents were people of peace ... Revenge is not going to bring my parents back to life. It is not going to bring back other Israelis and Palestinians killed either. It is going to do the opposite ... We must break the cycle."
Yes, yes, yes.
Please, please, please.
It is time to break the cycle. I address the words to Joe Biden, along with everyone else. It's not sufficient to tell Israel to "be careful" when it uses our bombs, to try to avoid killing (too many) children.
It's time to break the cycle. That means living our values, not defying them. That means ceasing to wage war.
Robert Koehler is a Chicago award-winning journalist and editor. He is the author of "Courage Grows Strong at the Wound," and his newly released album of recorded poetry and art work, "Soul Fragments."

title: 2024 election ... 'the evil of two lessers'
author: DAVID REEL
content:
2024 election ... 'the evil of two lessers'

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 572
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In one response to my most recent previous commentary — "Voters Deserve Better from Presidential Candidates Going Forward," it was suggested that because I serve at a consulting firm that provides counsel and services to Republican candidates, it "seems that my mission is to create false equivalency between the two presidential candidates and obscure the facts."That response uses a rhetorical strategy (argumentum ad hominem) where one attacks the character, motive or some other attribute of the person offering an opinion, rather than attacking the substance of the opinion itself.
In that commentary I did not mention the names of any current or future 2024 presidential candidates.
In my commentary, I wrote about two candidates in a previous divisive gubernatorial election in Pennsylvania. I suggested it provides good advice for whomever the candidates will be for president in 2024.
At this point in the 2024 election cycle, I do not know who the candidates will be.
I do know this.
I am not an apologist for or zealous supporter of former President Donald Trump or any other Republican candidate.
I am not an apologist for or zealous supporter of President Joe Biden or any other Democratic candidate.
I am not an apologist for or zealous supporter of any third party or independent candidate.
My guiding principle in the political arena has always been never to support or vote for a candidate based solely on party affiliation. My support and votes are based solely on how closely a candidate's views on public policy issues align with my views on those issues.
My guiding principle when writing guest commentaries is acceptance of the thinking of Frank Luntz who said this about messages — "It's not what you say or write. You can have the best message in the world, it's what people hear or read. The person on the receiving end will always understand it through the prism of their own emotions, preconceptions, prejudices and preexisting beliefs."
Presently my views on the two most likely major party candidates for president in 2024 are perfectly captured in a recent commentary by syndicated columnist Cal Thomas titled The Evil of Two Lessers.
In it, Thomas includes the following thoughts:
"Some voters in recent elections have complained about being forced to choose between the lesser of two evils. In the 2024 election, it appears we are heading for a worse choice — the evil of two lessers."
Thomas writes, "Donald Trump continues demeaning and defaming anyone who disagrees with him. He repeats unproven claims that the 2020 election was 'stolen.' A myriad of other inaccurate statements has apparently had a negative influence on President Biden who has joined him in the mud pit. In his recent speech near Valley Forge, America will become like Germany in the '30s. The very future of democracy is at stake, he [Biden] claimed."
Thomas goes on to write, "This isn't Biden's first trip into the mud. During the 2012 presidential campaign Vice President Biden told a Black audience that Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney "would put you all back in chains."
Thomas ends his commentary about 2024 by asking the question: "Where is this corrosive language getting us? Why can't we have a true debate over the best ways to fix our problems? Claiming your opponent would rule like a Nazi, or that the other is a crook, solves nothing."
I agree.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who serves as a trusted adviser on strategy, advocacy and media matters. He lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a political opinion column discussing the upcoming 2024 presidential election and candidates, which aligns with national political news rather than any of the other specific categories.

title: Many reasons to get out and vote in elections
author: LENA GILL
content:
Many reasons to get out and vote in elections

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 562
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Most of us need a reason to get out of the armchair and vote. The best reason is that it is your chance to decide on what future world you want to inhabit. Do you want a world of personal freedoms and rights or do you want the state and ultimately the president to be able to cancel these freedoms and rights?The freedom to vote without standing in line for hours. In Maryland we have the option of requesting a mail-in ballot for all future federal and state elections. If this is your preference, check your incoming mail or go to vote.md.gov/MDvotes24 and fill out the ballot request form soon. If you are not registered to vote in Talbot County contact talbot.elections@maryland.gov to register. Other Maryland counties each have a Board of Elections registering voters. With a valid Maryland driving license or state ID your signature on one of these documents along with a Social Security number can become your official on-line voter registration. This form is found at the MVA.The freedom for women to decide over their own health care and reproductive care. Ohio's voters just amended their state constitution to add the right to reproductive freedom with protections for health and safety of patients and providers. Kansas voters preceded Ohio with a similar change in their constitution. State legislatures in Maryland and New York are planning to codify the right to abortion by putting the issue before the voters in the November 2024 election. Nine other states, including Florida, are in the process of collecting enough signatures to put this issue on the ballot in 2024.The freedom to legally marry whomever you choose or to be whatever gender you choose to be. Right now, these are legal rights, but they can be changed, just as the Supreme Court overrode their nearly 50-year old decision in Roe v. Wade that guaranteed the right to an abortion, and left abortion rights to each state to decide.The right to live in a democracy with a constitution and laws that must be followed by all including the president and the Department of Justice. Threatening federal or state officials performing their jobs prevents a democracy from functioning and should be a federal crime.The right to bear arms but only with obligatory background checks and training, resulting in a license similar to a driver's license. All states should pass a red flag law to keep arms away from mentally disturbed people. And most importantly, all states (or the federal government) must renew the assault weapons ban. Those weapons were made to use in wars, not on our streets and in our schools. Bullets from assault weapons can damage a body to the point where the body is unrecognizable. Especially a child's body. Firearms have been the leading cause of death of children and young adults in the United States since 2020. There is no reason to accept this carnage.
Which federal and state candidates are you planning to vote for who would protect these freedoms and rights? It is up to you to inform yourself about the candidates. You can find out most of what you need to know on-line.
The forms for your option to vote by mail have already been sent out. It could not be easier than that to vote.
Lena Gill lives in Easton and is a member of the Talbot County Democratic Forum 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses voting, constitutional rights, and upcoming elections, which are broad political issues of national relevance rather than a specific local, sports, or cultural subject.

title: Society is broken ... not the Constitution
author: BRIAN GRIFFITHS
content:
Society is broken ... not the Constitution

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRIAN GRIFFITHS | Section: Columns 
 
 735
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every so often, the left starts to complain about the Constitution. Kinda like this recent piece in The Atlantic by Larry Schwartztol and Justin Florence:The American experiment with constitutional democracy is in grave peril. If Donald Trump becomes president again, fighting to preserve U.S. constitutional democracy through his second term will require the courage, commitment, and creativity of a broad prodemocracy coalition.
But the problem is not merely Trump. The U.S. Constitution itself contributes to the country's crisis. As David Frum observed in a recent issue of The Atlantic, "If Trump is elected, it very likely won't be with a majority of the popular vote" but rather because our system for selecting the president "has privileged a strategically located minority, led by a lawbreaking president, over the democratic majority." America must fight the immediate threat, but it must also go beyond that and stop this problem at its core: addressing once and for all the aspects of the Constitution that enable an authoritarian leader to remain within striking distance of the presidency.
I, of course, don't disagree with the premise that Trump threatens the American Order and American governance. Trump has openly stated his disdain for our Constitutional system and his wish to rule by decree while surrounded by sycophantic narcissists who will not give a rip about being restrained by Congress, by the Courts, or by the Rule of Law.
But that's not the Constitution's fault.
The arguments by Schwartztol and Florence center around two basic premises, both of which have been left-wing complaints for years:
The original Constitution was written when democracy meant something radically different than it does today. Over time, Americans have amended the Constitution to make it more democratic, but shortcomings remain. The most significant, in our view, are the hardwired constitutional structures that are inimical to any modern understanding of democracy: the Electoral College, which could put Trump in office without majority support for a second time, and the equal allocation of two seats in the Senate to each state (an arrangement that gives a Wyoming voter 70 times more senatorial clout than a Californian). Reforming those structures would get the country much closer to the one-person, one-vote democratic ideal.
Those two "hardwired constitutional structures that are inimical to any modern understanding of democracy" are what make us so unique and are a symbol of American exceptionalism.
The thing that the left continues to try and ignore or flat out just doesn't understand is the 10th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution:
The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people.
The premise of the Republic is federalism. It is not democracy.
Ever notice that the unitary states like the U.K., France and Italy always have the most instability with their parliamentary systems?
There's a simple reason for that. In these countries, states and localities have practically no power that is not bequeathed to them by the states. Whereas in federal systems like ours, the 50 states retain the power to do things on their own.
That's the real reason the left hates the Electoral College so much and hates that each state has an equal number of senators. They hate the fact that not all decisions are made in Washington. They hate the concept of federalism itself.
They close their piece with this warning:
In the midst of an ongoing democratic crisis — where a leading presidential candidate speaks openly of acting as a "dictator" and exacting retribution against his political opponents — investing in long-term reform can seem like a fantasy. Failing to do so, however, carries its own risks. Without attending to the architecture of American democracy, the inherent weaknesses at its foundation may, in time, cause it to come tumbling down.
But Trump isn't the problem here. Neither is the Constitution. It's us, as a society. That America has become so polarized has led us to this. That Republicans became so fed up with losing that they would embrace anybody they thought they could win. That Republicans convinced themselves that their side was so feckless that they would embrace a left-wing, gun-grabbing, pro-abortion Hillary Clinton donor statist like Trump "because he fights".
Worries about Constitutional governance should not be focused on fixing a document that works. They should be focused on fixing a society that is broken.
Brian Griffiths is a lifelong Marylander and publisher of TheDuckpin.com. You can reach him at linktr.ee/briangriffiths. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trump is on a roll showing his true colors
author: SUSAN ESTRICH
content:
Trump is on a roll showing his true colors

 January 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SUSAN ESTRICH | Section: Columns 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Donald Trump is on a roll. No, I'm not talking about his victories in Iowa and New Hampshire, although of course he won them both. I say "of course" because he's a president running for his second term, and if you judge him like you would an incumbent — who you would expect to do better than 80% or more — the fact is that he underperformed, especially in New Hampshire.He may be on a roll to the nomination, but the roll I'm talking about has to do with showing his true colors, which will end in his defeat.
The man cannot control himself. Start with where he finds himself — in a courtroom, at the defense table, being chastised by a judge because he can't keep his mouth shut. It's becoming an all-too-familiar position for the former president, sure to be even more so in the months ahead. He can't stop muttering insults, notwithstanding the defense's objections that the jury could hear him. But that's not the only place he's shown his lack of control.
Last week, at 2 a.m., he took to Truth Social to rant about his quest for absolute immunity. This was after his lawyer told a court that even if he ordered a team of Navy Seals to assassinate a political opponent, he could not be arrested or prosecuted until and unless the House impeached him and the Senate convicted him. Trump was even more blunt: The rant was that, as president, he was entitled to "ABSOLUTE IMMUNITY" even if he "crossed the line." So much for the fundamental principle that, in a democracy, no one is above the law.
On Sunday night, he went off the rails in his campaign stump speech on the subject of absolute immunity, adding in references to pedophile priests and rogue cops, seeming to suggest that their existence somehow buttressed the case for him to be absolutely immune. How? Why? Slurring his words, and making no sense, he sounded like a befuddled would-be dictator with no morals at all.
And then came Tuesday night. He took obvious pleasure in humiliating his former rivals, Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott. He gave Ramaswamy exactly one minute to grovel (he actually took an additional 40 seconds) before mocking Scott for having announced his engagement to marry the day before, leading commentators to explain that his feigned surprise was in fact a reference to the rumors that Scott is gay.
That was nothing compared to the wrath he displayed for Nikki Haley, who he spent most of his speech attacking on the ground that "I find in life you can't let people get away with bulls---." Scott, who was appointed to the Senate by Haley, clapped uncomfortably while Trump attacked her for everything from her clothes to her determination to stay in the race. To say that he didn't act like a winner, but a bitter old man, is an understatement. His former press secretary, appearing on Fox News, pointed out the obvious: that with seven out of 10 Haley voters saying they would not vote for Trump, it was time for the former president and presumptive nominee to reach out to unify the party rather than excoriate his opponent.
Just before midnight on Truth Social, he reacted by calling them both names: "I don't need any advice from RINO Kayleigh McEnany on Fox. Just had a GIANT VICTORY over a badly failing candidate, 'Birdbrain,' and she's telling me what I can do better."
Then he returned to New York, bringing even more attention to the E. Jean Carroll trial, where he had already been found liable for sexual assault and defamation, and the only question was how much it would cost him. The day before, Trump had walked out of the courtroom muttering loudly, "This is not America." The jury had an answer for that: $83.3 million.
No one is above the law. Loose lips sink ships. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Birds of a Feather: What’s really driving conservatives to leave blue states and big cities for red regions?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Birds of a Feather: What’s really driving conservatives to leave blue states and big cities for red regions?

 January 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: News 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Across the U.S, there are migration trends showing conservatives leaving progressive states and big cities for more politically red destinations.Adams Publishing Group will explore this trend in a four-part series starting Monday, Feb. 5, in the national e-edition available at StarDem.com.
Some highlights from the first story:
Idaho Secretary of State Phil McGrane has quantified the trend in the Mountain West. His office's analysis of transplants' voter records show 65% of those moving to Idaho are registered as Republicans and just 12% are Democrats.
Seventy-five percent of those moving from California to Idaho are Republicans while 10% or Democrats.
Other conservative states — including Wyoming, Montana and Florida — also are seeing the similar migration movements.
Victoria Stultz, a residential real estate broker on Florida's Southwest coast, sees an influx of small business owners as well as remote workers born out of the coronavirus pandemic relocating to the Sunshine State where there is no state income tax. "They're moving their businesses down here," she said, pointing to construction, air conditioning and other firms relocating from northern states.
The dynamic has led to population gains for the likes of Texas, Florida and Idaho while California, New York and Illinois have lost residents.
Real estate agents in Montana and Wyoming also report influxes of residents from the coasts as well as Colorado — including remote workers.
Buck Wilson, president of the Wyoming Realtors industry group, said he sees some residents moving to his state because it is friendly toward gun ownership and others from neighboring Colorado to escape the proliferation of legalized marijuana, especially in Denver.
"We've definitely seen an impact," he said.
In Montana, Mike DeVries, a commercial real estate broker in Bozeman, also sees politics, quality of life and post "I would say a majority of them cite politics, over cumbersome regulation and quality of life," DeVries said. "Since COVID, we have been seeing a lot more people moving here from the East Coast and bigger metro areas, as well as the West Coast."

title: Push is on to disband, defund UN refugee agency
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
Push is on to disband, defund UN refugee agency

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: World 
 
 815
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. and a number of its allies — including Britain, Japan, the Netherlands, Canada, France and Germany as well as the European Union — have temporarily cut off funding to the United Nations refugee and relief group in Gaza and the West Bank after allegations from Israel that some of the group's employees participated in Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks and that even more of the staff are supportive of the Islamic militant group.Now, a Florida congressman wants to completely eliminate the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) and have it operations in Gaza and the West Bank shifted to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).
UNRWA provides relief supplies, medical treatment and operates schools inside Gaza and the West Bank. It has also been criticized by Israel and some conservatives in the U.S. and Europe as being pro-Palestinian and pro-Hamas in the Middle East conflict.
The UN says 12 UNRWA employees took part in the Oct. 7 massacres inside Israel that sparked the current Holy Land war.
According to UN Watch, an independent watchdog group, 75% of UNRWA's $1.16 billion annual budget comes from the U.S. and EU countries.
The U.S.— which is the Palestinian relief group's top donor — suspended $343.9 million in funding in response the allegations of UNRWA staff taking part in the Oct. 7 massacres. In all, more than $920.9 million in international funding for UNRWA has been frozen while the United Nations investigates the group's links to Hamas and the Oct. 7 terrorism.
"No more money to UNRWA. Never again," said Dutch Prime Minister Geert Wilders, who is part of a populist right-wing wave winning elections in Europe.
Other countries cutting off or suspending money for UNRWA include Italy, Romania, Australia, New Zealand and Sweden.
U.S. Rep. Brian Mast, R-Florida, wants the Biden administration to push to replace UNRWA and his legislation would potentially restrict U.S. aid to countries who oppose the change.
The push and temporary suspension of funding comes after Israel accused 12 UNRWA workers of actively participating in the Oct. 7 terror attacks inside Israel that killed more than 1,200 people and resulted in more than 240 hostages being taken back into Gaza.
"UNRWA is a front, plain and simple," said Rep. Mast. "It masquerades as a relief organization while building the infrastructure to support Hamas. It is indoctrinating Palestinian children to hate all Jews and filling the future ranks of jihadists. It is literally funneling American tax dollars to terrorism. And now we know with certainty that a significant part of the UNRWA workforce are members of Palestinian terrorist organizations, including participants in the October 7th attack. No more. The United States must lead the effort to permanently disband UNRWA and end its nurturing of terrorism."
United Nations officials and defenders of UNRWA — including some U.S. progressives opposed to American support for Israel and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's war in Gaza — want the Western funding restored
"More than 26,000 Palestinians have been killed in this war, seventy percent of whom are women and children. Today, hundreds of thousands of children face starvation and disease. Obviously, it's not acceptable for any of the 13,000 UNRWA employees in Gaza to be involved with Hamas, and allegations against the 12 people charged must be investigated. However, we cannot allow millions to suffer because of the actions of 12 people. The U.S. and other countries must restore funding to stave off this humanitarian catastrophe," said U.S Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vermont.
UN officials, some of who have also routinely been critical of Israel and have been reticent to criticize sexual violence against women and girls committed by Hamas. said of the 12 UNRWA staffers accused of taking part in the Oct. 7 attacks 9 have been fired, one is dead and "the identities of the remaining two are being clarified."
UN Secretary General António Guterres has called for UNRWA funding to be restored citing worries about humanitarian and public health conditions in the Gaza war zone.
"UNRWA is the backbone of all humanitarian response in Gaza. I appeal to all Member States to guarantee the continuity of UNRWA's life-saving work" — Guterres said in a statement in New York.
The Trump administration dramatically decreased funding to UNRWA arguing the group is too closely tied to Palestinian groups. The Biden administration restored those funding levels when it came to office.
Nikki Haley, who served as U.S. ambassador to the UN in the Trump administration and is running president, criticized Biden's previous funding restoration.
"I fought to cut funding to UNRWA. It was the right move then, and it's the right move now. Joe Biden never should have restarted the funding," Haley said.
Some pro-Palestinian countries — including Ireland and Spain — have promised to continue to support UNRWA and offered some additional financial support even with the question about the group's employees support for Hamas and potential knowledge of its tunnel system and weapons caches. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses U.S. and international political decisions about funding a UN refugee agency, which is a national-level news story rather than sports, health, or local issues.

title: Celebrating 95 years, Vietnam vet reflects on war, rescue efforts
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Celebrating 95 years, Vietnam vet reflects on war, rescue efforts

 February 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Samuel Tiller, celebrated his 95th birthday on Nov. 25. Although he's safe at home, he sometimes stares up at the ceiling, tears in his eyes, reliving those times in the rice field. That's due to the fact he was in a firefight in the Vietnam War, where he rescued soldiers under him.After a hellish conflict, he considers himself lucky.
The Army gave him the purple heart and the bronze star for his bravery — luck not mentioned.
On his certificate it read: "Sergeant Tiller distinguished himself by heroic actions during the Operation on 12-14, April 1964, in the Republic of Vietnam."
As much as the military is known for detail, that statement doesn't paint the picture of Sgt. 1st Class Tiller.
In his career he did everything from transporting officers, to drill sergeant to training the Vietnamese army. Starting in Maryland, he went from Germany, to Korea, and ultimately to Vietnam.
And he doesn't have any regrets.
From an early age living in Big Woods, near Worton, Tiller wanted to be a soldier. He got that chance, enlisting during a time when the military was segregated. While in the Army he suffered prejudice, but also received advice from grizzled World War II veterans.
They told him to advance in rank as a Black man, he had to go to the Korean War front.
Tiller remembered the heaving ocean waves as he and others climbed a rope ladder to get onboard the ship to Korea. He was fortunate being there in the waning years of the conflict.
"I didn't receive a scratch on me," Tiller said.
It was not unproductive. He went from a "nothing to an E-5."
A sergeant, finally, after serving for ten years.
Tiller's time in Korea allowed him to pay for his first car when he returned to Chestertown where Mary, his future wife lived.
Like many, the military life called him back.
By Fountain Park, a recruiter talked to Tiller and his friends. Tiller noted that of all his friends, he was the only one who reenlisted.
He was whisked off to Fort Bragg — to warfare training, along with 75 officers and NCO's preparing for deployment.
During that time, President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. Tiller recalled a sergeant, who was involved in the band, raising his hand and telling the class about it.
Soon after, Tiller was sent to another war.
Vietnam.
To his wife's great concern.
She'd write him everyday until he was home safe.
When Tiller touched ground he immediately sensed danger.
His role was to assist the company commander as they trained the Vietnamese army to fight the Vietcong. He moved with the Vietnamese in convoys, mingling with them, while they loaded up their chickens, rabbits, pots, pans and everything they owned.
Close calls while in-country remain fresh on Tiller's mind.
The first time he sat down to eat after a convoy, somebody tossed a grenade in the window. Tiller hit the ground and squeezed his eyes shut, awaiting the explosion. It didn't happen. The pin was not pulled properly.
A place they frequented often was blown up at the entrance he was about to choose. A bomb rigged beside a bicycle.
Tiller had close-calls and saw his share of tragedy.
He witnessed a translator die, reflecting on how young and intelligent the boy was.
Tiller was lonely too, in temperatures exceeding 107 degrees.
It was just him and the company commander and the translators.
One balmy Sunday that loneliness was shattered by a call.
A battalion of hardcore Vietcong attacked a village in Tam Phu. He boarded a helicopter along with other companies — 16 Huey choppers and four Piasecki H-21's, called "banana choppers."
Tiller said his helicopter was doorless and two fifty-caliber gunners thundered fire down on the Vietcong below when they approached the landing zone; an open field. Unable to hear a sound except gunfire and propellers, Tiller and the company commander evacuated, retreating for the tail of the chopper.
Vietcong were in the woodline to the left, firing on Tiller's men.
A Vietnamese captain stood up in the middle of the conflict and was shot dead.
Hugging the ground, they deployed a "fire and maneuver," action. Some soldiers engaged the enemy allowing others to retreat to the woodline.
Scrambling for it, they jumped into a ditch, pinning them down. Someone threw smoke to show their location to air support, but the dry brush caught fire. Immediately, they were caught between a spreading fire and the enemy shooting at them.
With bullets bearing down on him, Tiller pulled one of the wounded Vietnamese from the part of the ditch that was closer to the fire. They were in a hopeless situation, but thankfully the smoke did its job.
A tactical fighter squadron dropped a napalm bomb on the enemy allowing Tiller's company to retreat to the woodline.
Tiller looked up and said, "If it wasn't for that plane I wouldn't be here today."
But the Vietcong were a continual presence.
Every time a plane dropped a flare that night, mortars would fire off.
The next morning, they tried to get down a river for pickup and Vietcong pushed them back to the woodline.
During that conflict, three of Tiller's guys were wounded.
Risking his life, he told the company commander to lay down fire and cover him.
"I brought those guys back by myself, one at a time," Tiller remarked.
The assault continued throughout that day.
Monday evening, a helicopter made an attempt to rescue six wounded. The enemy lurked in the woods. The helicopter had to retreat because they opened up fire again.
For almost three days, the threat of danger and death was imminent.
When Tiller slept, it was with one eye open.
He was uncertain he'd make it out.
"I can't tell you how scared I was."
On Tuesday morning, the violence was drowned out by calm.
Within that silence, a chopper brought the Vietnamese Colonel and an American Major.
This time the enemy didn't fire back.
U.S. forces delivered water to the war-weary and parched soldiers.
Then they marched single-file beside the river towards the special forces camp to get picked up. Tiller was behind 15 men, but he alone set off a land mine. It knocked him down and broke two toes, with the shrapnel from the explosion striking the commander.
Tiller, who carried so many others, was carried himself, then placed on a small boat and then helicopter-bound for Saigon.
Four-Star Gen. Wes Mooreland had visited wounded soldiers in the hospital every Sunday. On one of those times, he asked Tiller how he was. Tiller said he's alright physically but his morale was down. He hadn't received any letters from Mary since he was there.
Orders were given.
If Tiller had any mail in Vietnam, Mooreland would make sure he got it.
That Monday after coming back from the chow hall, there were a pile of her letters on Tiller's bed.
It was the boost Tiller needed.
Tiller recovered and reported to headquarters, received a scolding typical of military life and was soon on the way to the Philippines. He received a hero's steak dinner, and then took a double-decker plane from California back to Philadelphia.
War was over.
Physically.
Tiller still sees Vietnam.
"It stays with you," he said.
Tiller retired from the Army in 1967. He became an employee in the Air Force working roads and grounds. A steady job, away from danger, where he could be alone with his thoughts.
He had a good career there. In New Jersey, where he lived, he was known for his impeccably kept yard and as, "Big Sam the Fish Fry Man," cooking fish on weekends.
On his 95th birthday, he celebrated with his family in Chestertown with a big cookout.
Tough-as-nails, a sharp wit, and a natural storyteller, Sfc. Tiller shakes his head, "War is hell. I know. I been through two of them." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a human‑interest profile of a 95‑year‑old Vietnam veteran, focusing on his wartime experiences and personal history, which aligns best with a national‑level news story rather than any of the more specific categories.

title: Four World War II chaplains honored at American Legion
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Four World War II chaplains honored at American Legion

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 349
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — There was reverence and patriotism ringing across a room full of veterans at American Legion Post 70 Sunday as the group gathered to honor four chaplains who gave the ultimate sacrifice.The program, held annually by the American Legion, marks the anniversary of the Feb. 3, 1943, sinking of the U.S.A.T. Dorchester. The ship was torpedoed by a German U-boat shortly after midnight, just 90 miles short of its destination.
Aboard were four chaplains, George L. Fox, Alexander D. Goode, Clark V. Poling and John P. Washington, who gave up their life jackets to save the lives of four servicemen.
"They didn't have life jackets when they went down with the ship," American Legion Post Cmdr. Wayne Hall said to those gathered Sunday. "The story goes that they were all holding hands and singing hymns when the ship went down."
During the service, the four chaplains were represented by local religious leaders — Rabbi Peter Hyman of Temple B'nai Israel, the Rev. Jonathon Moyers of Grace Lutheran, the Rev. Gary L. Moore of the Trappe Faith Chapel United Methodist Church and the Rev. Michael Angeloni of Sts. Peter and Paul Catholic Church.
The JROTC from Easton High School presented the colors.
After the color guard cleared, the four religious leaders took turns coming to a lectern up in front of the room. They told narratives that fleshed out the four men who gave their lives on that ship.
After they were finished, a citation from U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Maryland) was presented to Post 77 and Post 70 for honoring the four chaplains.
"It is an important way for the community and society to make sure that the veterans know that their sacrifice and their effort has been appreciated," said local veteran and community liaison for Rep. Andy Haris Mike Detmer, who served in Falluhah during the Iraq War.
"I do a lot of invocations and benedictions at services," said Paula Grimes, Department of Maryland chaplain for the American Legion. "It is from the heart. It is important to spread the word of the sacrifice about these four gentlemen. Everyone should know the story." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a ceremony honoring WWII chaplains, a historically significant national event, even though it is covered by a local paper. It does not fit sports, education, health, or other categories, making 'National News' the closest match.

title: Cardin, Van Hollen back new foreign aid bill after bipartisan immigration deal dies
author: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service
content:
Cardin, Van Hollen back new foreign aid bill after bipartisan immigration deal dies

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 818
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Maryland Democratic Sens. Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen have criticized Republican colleagues for blocking the bipartisan package that included border security and military aid to Ukraine.Now aid to Ukraine and Israel has new life as senators on Thursday voted 67-32 to advance consideration of the foreign aid package without an immigration component. Cardin and Van Hollen were among the "yes" votes.
"We simply cannot allow this impasse to undermine our commitments to support Ukraine, Israel, and our partners in the Indo-Pacific," Cardin said in a Wednesday statement.
The Senate failed on a procedural vote earlier Wednesday to take up the $118 billion supplemental spending bill after Republicans effectively killed the immigration reform measures aimed at addressing the massive influx of people along the U.S.-Mexico border.
Republicans had initially refused to consider a Ukraine aid spending bill unless it was tied to immigration reform. That included House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana), who had suggested the pairing as far back as a November Fox News interview. This insistence fell away Tuesday when Republican senators declared that the package was "dead" after a negative review by former President Donald Trump.
"We can't give up, it's too important to our national security," Cardin insisted as Republican support for the original bipartisan bill faded.
The supplemental spending measure being considered by the Senate includes $60 billion to support Ukraine, $14 billion for Israel security assistance and $9 billion for humanitarian assistance in Palestinian territory and Ukraine. The package also includes sanctions against individuals involved in dealing fentanyl.
Cardin, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, expressed frustration with Senate Republicans as GOP support for the earlier bill with immigration reforms evaporated.
"The failure to move this bipartisan funding package forward represents both a dereliction of American leadership on the world stage and a refusal to uphold our responsibilities to secure the integrity of our borders at home," Cardin said in a statement Wednesday.
Cardin added: "I fear the consequences of deserting our allies abroad and turning our backs on critical immigration reform merely for political exploitation will have real and far-reaching implications."
The European Union announced a $54 billion aid relief package for Ukraine last week, but Cardin said that Europe's action wasn't enough.
"Europe has stepped up, we have to step up," Cardin said Tuesday. "It affects not only our position for Ukraine, but our global influence and credibility."
Van Hollen said in a post on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter, that every time Republicans make new requirements to pass Ukraine funding, "autocrats of the world celebrate" — naming Russia's Vladimir Putin and China's Xi Jinping.
"They're eager to see the US back down from the fight for democracy — and most Republicans are apparently happy to oblige," Van Hollen said in the post.
The now-failed Immigration would have given $20 billion to increase the operational needs of the U.S. Border Patrol. The bill's reform policies included barring illegal border crossings — detaining and deporting those who attempt to cross instead of processing and screening migrants — if they hit an average of 5,000 average crossings a day in a given week.
The bill also would have allowed officers to decide asylum cases at the border and increase requirements for asylum. The package was endorsed by the National Border Patrol Council, the union for Border Patrol agents.
Cardin called this border reform "critical" in a Wednesday statement.
Sen. Rick Scott, R-Florida, said in a news conference with other Republican senators Tuesday that he wouldn't vote on any bill that codified what he calls Biden's "open border policy" or that would give humanitarian aid money to Gaza.
Scott added that while many in his party want Ukraine to win and Russia to lose, they have different views on if and how funding should be sent.
He also pushed for the Republican conference to get together to make a bill that would get passed, claiming that this bipartisan deal was made behind closed doors by leadership.
"Why don't we start coming together as a conference to get something done?" Scott said.
The package was negotiated by Sens. James Lankford, R-Oklahoma, Chris Murphy, D-Connecticut, and Kyrsten Sinema, I-Arizona. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Kentucky, initially endorsed the bipartisan immigration bill but reversed himself as fellow GOP senators raised objections.
Many Democrats in both houses said GOP lawmakers who rejected the immigration-foreign aid package were doing the bidding of Trump. Republicans, including Johnson, denied that.
Trump called the border legislation a "death wish" for Republicans and called for a separate border and immigration bill Monday on Truth Social.
But Cardin said Wednesday that the immigration bill collapse "makes clear that there are those in this legislative body who will prioritize fidelity to Donald Trump and his personal interests over the safety and security of our country and the global community."
The revived Senate package still faces potential procedural delays and Republican amendments. And it is unclear if the narrow Republican majority in the House will agree to the new legislation stripped of immigration reforms. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses federal legislation, foreign aid to Ukraine and Israel, and immigration/border security policy—issues that are national in scope rather than local, sector‑specific, or cultural topics.

title: 'I’m an elderly man, and I know what the hell I’m doing': Biden shoots back after special counsel cites 'poor memory'; references to conversations with dead foreign leaders
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
'I’m an elderly man, and I know what the hell I’m doing': Biden shoots back after special counsel cites 'poor memory'; references to conversations with dead foreign leaders

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 651
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Joe Biden struck back at a U.S. Justice Department's special prosecutor's report questioning his memory and mental acuity while recommending against charges for classified documents found in the 81-year-old's Delaware home and a private office in Washington after he served as vice president in the Obama administration.Special Counsel Robert Hur's report said Biden inappropriately took classified documents from during his time as vice president with some of those used to help write a memoir with a ghost writer.
Hur recommended against charges against Biden in part because he came off in interviews as a "well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory," according to the report.
That added fuel to the fire regarding Biden's age, gaffes and memory lapses as he seeks a second-term and a looming rematch with former President Donald Trump, 77. Many voters worry about Biden's age and memory, according to public opinion polls.
"I am well-meaning, and I'm an elderly man, and I know what the hell I'm doing. I've been President. I put this country back on its feet. I don't need his recommendation," Biden said during a raucous press briefing Thursday evening after the report's release
The counsel's report said Biden — who was interviewed Oct. 8 and 9 just after Hamas' bloody Oct. 7 — had trouble remembering what year his son Beau Biden died (2015), details of the U.S. war in Afghanistan and the years that started and ended his term as vice president.
According to the Associated Press, the special prosecutor's report described Biden's memory as "hazy," "fuzzy," "faulty," "poor" and having "significant limitations."
Biden angrily denounced the prosecutor's reference to Beau Biden, who served as Delaware Attorney general and died in 2015 of brain cancer at age 46. The Democratic president frequently mentions his deceased son during public remarks.
"I know there's some attention paid to some language in the report about my recollection of events. There's even a reference that I don't remember when my son died. How in the hell dare he raise that," Biden said during his remarks from the White House. "Frankly, when I was asked the question, I thought to myself it wasn't any of their damn business."
"Let me tell you something. Some of you have commented — I wear, since the day he died, every single day, the rosary he got from our Lady of —," Biden said stopping short of naming the church. "Every Memorial Day, we hold a service remembering him, attended by friends and family and the people who loved him. I don't need anyone — I don't need anyone to remind me when he passed away or if he passed away."
Reporters peppered Biden with questions about his age and memory citing the report and remarks in Las Vegas where he said he spoke to former French President Francois Mitterrand at G7 Summit in 2021. Mitterrand died in 1996.
A White House transcript of Biden's remarks said the Democratic president meant to refer to French President Emmanuel Macron. In 2022, Biden also claimed to have spoken to former West Germany Helmut Schmidt during the same conversation at the same 2021 G7 summit. Schmidt died in 2015.
The White House later corrected Biden's speech transcript to refer to current German Chancellor Olaf Scholz though it was the last G7 attended by former German Chancellor Angela Merkel.
Biden shot back at White House reporters questions about public opinion polls showing as many as two-thirds of voters have concerns about memory and age.
"My memory is fine," said Biden who later misspoke and called the president of Egypt, Abdel Fattah El-Sisi, the president of Mexico when talking about the situation in Gaza.
"I think that — as you know, initially, the President of Mexico, El-Sisi, did not want to open up the gate to allow humanitarian material to get in. I talked to him. I convinced him to open the gate," Biden said.
The White House later corrected to transcript to show Biden meant to say Egypt. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a political controversy involving the U.S. President and a federal special counsel, which is a matter of national significance rather than local, business, or other specific categories.

title: Maryland’s Hogan makes surprise entry into GOP race for US Senate
author: BRENNAN STEWART, YESENIA MONTENEGRO, TORRENCE BANKS, LISA WOELFL and ANGEL GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s Hogan makes surprise entry into GOP race for US Senate

 February 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRENNAN STEWART, YESENIA MONTENEGRO, TORRENCE BANKS, LISA WOELFL and ANGEL GINGRAS Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 788
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan will run for a seat in the U.S. Senate.Hogan, a Republican, announced his campaign on Friday via social media, releasing a video just nine hours before Maryland's candidacy deadline and surprising a lot of political observers.
"Fifty years ago, my father, Maryland congressman Larry Hogan Sr., made a very tough decision. He became the first Republican to come out for the impeachment of President Nixon," Hogan said. "He put aside party politics and his own personal considerations, and he stepped up to do the right thing for Maryland and the nation."
"Today, Washington is completely broken, because that kind of leadership, that kind of willingness to put country over party, has become far too rare," Hogan added.
Hogan joins the list of 20 candidates fighting for outgoing Sen. Ben Cardin's seat. Cardin, a Democrat, announced in May his plan to retire at the end of his current term.
Notable Senate candidates include Democrats Angela Alsobrooks, Prince George's County executive, and Rep. David Trone, as well as Republicans Robin Ficker, a former member of the Maryland House of Delegates and a perennial candidate for various offices, and John Teichert, a retired Air Force brigadier general.
"The beauty of living in this great republic that I fought to defend for over three decades is that we give Americans a choice about who represents us in elected public office," Teichert said in a statement released Friday. "Marylanders deserve to have a choice and I welcome anyone to the race who wants to offer them one."
If elected, Hogan would become Maryland's first Republican senator since Charles Mathias, who served in the Senate from 1969 to 1987.
"He's the only Republican in the state who stands a chance," Todd Eberly, associate professor of political science and public policy at St. Mary's College of Maryland, told Capital News Service.
"His chances depend on a couple of factors," said John Dedie, political science professor at the Community College of Baltimore County. "First, if the Trone, Alsobrooks primary gets contested with nastiness and they can't make peace after the primary… that could help Hogan because maybe one side stays home and doesn't vote."
According to Dedie, Hogan will have to focus on his accomplishments during his two terms as governor and his work with the Democrats. He may have to criticize Republicans, but then some of those voters may stay home, Dedie said.
Trone said in a statement that Hogan's bid is an attempt to boost the agenda of Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) and former President Donald Trump.
"Larry Hogan's candidacy is nothing but a desperate attempt to return Mitch McConnell and Donald Trump to power and give them the deciding vote to ban abortion nationwide, suppress votes across the country, and give massive tax cuts to the wealthiest Americans," Trone said in a statement.
Hogan has always said that he is pro-life, according to Dedie. On this year's ballot, Maryland voters will see a "measure of basically codified abortion rights into the state constitution," which will affect Hogan's campaign, Dedie said.
Cardin believes that the Republican nominee for Senate will be in a tough battle against Democratic candidates Alsobrooks and Trone for the seat.
"Regardless of who is the Republican nominee, I am confident that Marylanders will keep our state in the blue column this November, holding the Senate as a bulwark against a dysfunctional and chaotic House of Representatives," Cardin said in a statement.
According to Bloomberg, McConnell recruited Hogan.
"This is the best one in the sense that we are now competitive in a state nobody thought we could win. He's a proven winner," McConnell told Bloomberg.
Maryland's primary election is May 14, giving Hogan just three months to campaign.
Sabato's Crystal Ball at the University of Virginia's Center for Politics slightly changed its rating for the Maryland Senate race after Hogan's announcement from "Safe Democratic" to "Likely Democratic," a reflection of the former governor's immediate impact on the contest.
In Annapolis, one Republican lawmaker said he wouldn't count Hogan out.
"I certainly believe that Governor Hogan feels that he has a path to victory, or else he would not get into the race," said State Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Caroline, Cecil, Kent and Queen Anne's ). "He certainly has a chance. He's proven that he can win in Maryland, on a statewide basis … He has found a way to map that out and believes that he can be successful."
But another fellow Republican asserted that running on the ticket with Trump would be no easy task for Hogan.
House Minority Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, told CNS that Hogan's announcement took him by surprise.
"It's going to be an uphill climb," Buckel said. "He'll have to navigate being on the ticket with Donald Trump … and it will be a challenge for him." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a former Maryland governor entering a U.S. Senate race, a political development of national significance rather than a local, sports, or cultural story.
