title: Will world's leadership role pass to China?
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Will world's leadership role pass to China?

 May 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 714
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tom Blair, a former Eastern Shore resident who shared imaginative and amusing displays on his estate on St. Michaels Road between Easton and St. Michaels, wrote a New York Times bestselling book — "Poorer Richard's America — What would Ben Say?"His book is based on Poor Richard's Almanack, a widely read annual publication written between 1732 and 1758 by American patriot, diplomat and prolific inventor Ben Franklin.
In his book Blair artfully blends a "what if" scenario if Ben Franklin traveled through time to offer his observations on America today along with Blair's personal observations on the same.
There are chapters on such issues as federal budget deficits, democracy, political parties, leadership, the Bill of Rights, foreign affairs, America's greatest generation, Keynesian economics, health care and many others.
One very timely chapter is "The Rise and Fall of Nations."
In it, Blair recaps a hypothetical conversation between an American scholar and a professor at Cambridge University on Charles Darwin's theory on natural selection on the evolution of animal and plant species.
In Blair's recap of that conversation, the Cambridge professor maintains, as have others, that natural selection applies to civilizations, societies and nations as well as animal and plant species.
Accordingly, civilizations, societies and nations also rise and then fall as the fittest become less fit and others become more fit.
The reasoning put forth by the Cambridge professor is the fitness level of civilizations, societies and nations are impacted greatly by changes in the speed of commerce. The speed of those changes increases continuously over time. Such increases must be met with a commitment by a dominant civilization, society and nation to develop and use technology to maintain its position.
Failure to do so will inevitably lead to the rise of another dominant civilization, society and nation.
That view is affirmed with a review of the 16th and 17th centuries when Spain was the dominant global power. Spain chose not to apply their wealth to technology to expand their power further, but to enjoy a "good life." As a result, Spain entered a period of steady and permanent decline.
During Spain's decline, Britain built a navy using steam-powered ships rather than wind-powered ships as used by Spain.
As Spain became less fit, Britain became more fit and became the largest empire in history. When Britain eventually controlled roughly a quarter of the earth's land mass, it was said the sun never set on the British Empire.
After World War II, Britain was exhausted from years of enduring relentless German bombings, preparing for a German invasion that almost occurred and demands for freedom from a large number of their colonies.
As a result, Britain replicated Spain's steady and permanent decline as the world's dominant nation.
America replaced them and has held that role ever since.
Blair suggests America may be the next dominant nation to be replaced.
He further suggests the new dominant nation in the world may be China.
Blair writes that China astutely watched the decades long cold war superpower arms race between America and the former Soviet Union.
In that decades long war, America and the former Soviet Union spent enormous amounts of resources on defense spending. That led to widespread economic turmoil in the former Soviet Union that ultimately led to their complete economic restructuring and an end to a cold war without a hot war between the two superpowers.
While exact levels of defense spending by China are difficult to determine, experts estimate China's defense spending has been and is approximately one third the levels of America's defense spending.
China shrewdly decided their strategy would not be to try and position themselves as the preeminent military power in the world. Instead, their strategy has been to be the preeminent economic power in the world by developing (and in many cases stealing from America) the most innovative technologies in the world.
So far, they have been largely successful.
Blair ends his book with a warning: "America is peering in the wrong direction to see its greatest challenges; it is playing the wrong game."
Left unanswered in Blair's book is whether the American public and America's government leaders will acknowledge this grim reality.
If they do, another unanswered question is whether they will take necessary steps to avoid passing the role of world leadership to China before it is too late.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses geopolitical shifts, the potential transfer of global leadership from the United States to China, and related economic and defense considerations, which aligns best with national/international news coverage.

title: Korean War veteran, 92, mindful of those made 'supreme sacrifice'
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Korean War veteran, 92, mindful of those made 'supreme sacrifice'

 May 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Korean War veteran Zeford Gaddy is blind because of injuries he suffered to his eyes in battle some 70 years ago, but the 92-year-old Port Deposit resident downplays his blindness whenever someone broaches the subject.That's because Gaddy knows all too well that some of his fellow soldiers lost their lives in combat during his 21-month stint in Korea.
"They made the supreme sacrifice," Gaddy emphasized, before noting that he is mindful of and ever-grateful to all U.S. servicemen and servicewomen who were killed in all wars and conflicts.
Raised in Cecil County, Gaddy was drafted by the U.S. Army in the early 1950s, when he was about 21, and he was sent "straight to Korea" after finishing boot camp in Fort Indiantown Gap, Pa.
"Something had to be done and others did it before me. I was just picking up the baton," Gaddy said, explaining how he viewed his wartime military service as necessary and as a privilege. "It was an honor. I knew what my purpose was. I was there to serve and protect our country."
Gaddy spent much of his tour of duty in battle zones and, as a result, he experienced that deep bond — that brotherhood — that soldiers have with one another because they're fighting side by side. "You lived on a line and that puts you in a different frame of mind," he said.
Despite the closeness that grows among soldiers in combat, there was little time for mourning in the heat of battle when a serviceman was killed, according to Gaddy. "When one dropped out, you had to move up. Everything was too fast-paced. You had to keep the rest safe," Gaddy said.
Gaddy is blind today because metal fragments from a nearby explosion peppered his eyes in the midst of battle, sending him to a military hospital for about one week before he returned to duty.
But the damage to his eyes caused his vision to diminish gradually over the decades that followed Gaddy's honorable discharge from the Army in 1953. Gaddy's wife, Monolyne — they have been married 62 years — told the Cecil Whig that her husband has undergone 10 surgeries because he found himself plagued by cysts every time once-imbedded metal fragments surfaced on the front of his body.
On Sunday, Gaddy will be recognized for his wartime military service at Port Deposit VFW Post 8185 moments after the Memorial Day ceremony is completed, confirmed William Ward, who is the post commander. (Kevin Clark, a Gaddy family friend, was instrumental in bringing attention to Gaddy.)
"We are going to present him with a VFW coin at the end of our ceremony," Ward said.
Ward noted that Gaddy will be recognized during the portion of the program when the post honors "our living veterans," which occurs after servicemen and servicewomen who made the ultimate sacrifice have been honored. During that latter part of the ceremony, Ward will present the Order of St. Michael medallion — a high honor — to one of the veterans affiliated with the Post 8185.
As for recognizing Gaddy, Ward commented, "I will speak well of him, and I will speak well of his service." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Like a lot of Americans, Congressman Harris may be a victim of Russian propaganda. During an August, 2023 Town Hall he changed his previous support for Ukraine by parroting Kremlin talking points.
During the meeting he advocated "winding down" Ukraine spending, citing concerns of waste and fraud and suggested the war was a stalemate. DAVE ROOT
Damascus

title: Maybe there is hope for America to recover values
author: JOHN McCULLOUGH JR.
content:
Maybe there is hope for America to recover values

 June 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHN McCULLOUGH JR. | Section: Columns 
 
 764
 Words 

 Read News Document

 About a dozen years ago, I wrote a Star Democrat letter to the editor lamenting that the political Left had taken over all of the societal corridors of power and influence.I also stated that I believed this would require either a collapse of our nation, requiring conservatives to rebuild it, or that it would require a 30-year plan to raise our children to take them back. Thankfully, there was not a collapse, though movies like the recent "Civil War" remind us that this is still a possibility and in the mind of some, a very distinct possibility.
The American people, except for those on the coasts and in big cities, are still predominantly conservative, but the "flyover" areas of the country just didn't have the societal influence to prevail in the culture wars that have erupted. And though I have to admit that I was not exactly right, because conservatives are not trying to take back those lost corridors of influence, but rather I am seeing them set up a sort of "political parallel universe" to basically try to make those former corridors of influence obsolete, or at least to take away their power to control all narratives.
This is actually a better scenario for the country, because it can happen faster and without having to find ways to fire or replace those in power (who have dug in like ticks, and black ball any who might threaten them, to hold onto their positions). Instead, it simply gives Americans alternative choices on where to find more worldview-friendly places to get news and information, education, entertainment, goods and services, social media, etc.
Let me give you some examples to buttress my point.
A dozen years ago there was only one conservative news cable channel to get information, Fox News, while there were seven to eight liberal ones, which included the likes of CNN, MSNBC, the alphabet stations and several others. Now conservatives have at least four to five cable news channels to choose from and myriad places to get conservative news on the internet.
Conservative leaning colleges, like Hillsdale, Patrick Henry, Regent and Liberty University, are bursting at the seams as parents want to keep their children away from the culture rot and "group think" that is spewed by most of higher education nowadays. School board elections are being hotly contested as conservatives have realized they have to stop the liberal machine at an early age to protect their kids. Parents want their students to be taught how to think, not what to think.
And Hollywood, through both viewers voting with their feet and even through the natural weaning away from movie theaters that happened during the pandemic, is also finding itself ignored in their woke bubble of self-importance. There is now even a conservative actors' guild being formed by those who were previously being muzzled or intimidated by power wielding Hollywood execs.
In sports, those who were being idolized for sitting down during a national anthem are now being booed. In goods and services, there are now those who proudly announce their "made in America" or patriotic stance on things to promote their products, and patriotic Americans are now "canceling" liberal businesses who try to shove their political views down our throats ... see Bud Light for a glaring example.
And liberal social media, probably the most ruthless bullies out there, are now finding themselves challenged by alternative conservative options. Facebook is challenged by Truth Social and others. Twitter, bought out by Elon Musk, is a bold attempt of his to bring balance to the information universe. YouTube being challenged by Rumble. Podcast after podcast, talk radio show after talk radio show of conservative commentators are regularly growing their audiences while attempts by liberal commentators to do the same largely fall flat.
After waiting a dozen years, it is encouraging to see Americans demanding and supporting this "parallel political universe" or what some have called an "alternative economy" that allows us to choose who we want to support with our time, attention and wallets.
In that old letter to the editor mentioned at the beginning, I stated that progressivism is just a new word for socialism and communism, and thankfully, the country is starting to push back in a dramatic and tangible way against that worldview. Maybe there is hope for us yet, to recover the values that made us the greatest nation in history with our foundations of faith, family and freedom.
John McCullough Jr. is a licensed residential homebuilder. A former touring golf pro, he has been golf coach for Delmarva Christian High School in Georgetown, Delaware, for the last seven years.

title: Emotional hearsay

 In reading Ms. Robertson's Letter to the Editor in the May 26 edition, I initially viewed it as one person expressing an opinion which is fully within her rights to do so. However, as I reflected further on it, there were at least two major flaws in her comments.The first was accepting the media's out of context and its widespread distribution of reporting (deliberately or not) on former President Trump's response to a question on becoming a dictator if elected. The second was her assuming the accuracy of the media and others making that erroneous interpretation and then applying it to her assertion that anyone "wanting to be a dictator for even a day (Trump's words not mine) has no place in this country as a citizen, let alone president." One can only challenge the extent to which any research was involved in supporting her opinion as expressed in that letter
In searching Politifact, (not known for its support of former President Trump), it references that interview between Sean Hannity and the former president wherein the question of his allegedly wanting to be a dictator emerged. The former president's response as reported in Politifact was "No, No, No, other than day one we are closing the Border and we are drilling, drilling, drilling. After that I am not a dictator, OK."
That second flaw also highlights her avoiding any mention of the executive orders issued by President Biden, early in his term of office which opened the border to all and stopped the drilling. Obviously, both those actions have evidenced many negative consequences for the citizens of this country irrespective of political affiliation and presidential preference and was the basis for the former president's remarks. Therefore, I am puzzled by the illogic of some that the current president's actions had simply been accepted as a legitimate executive order despite the economic damage it has created while another candidate, if successful in the upcoming election, is being criticized as a dictator for considering that same approach in correcting it.
I pray that the results of the upcoming election in November will be based on informed reason rather than emotional hearsay.
TOM McLOUGHLIN
Easton

title: Shedding a tear on Memorial Day is appropriate
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Shedding a tear on Memorial Day is appropriate

 June 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 579
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last Monday was Memorial Day.The origins of Memorial Day go back to the end of America's Civil War, the deadliest war in American history. In that four-year conflict more than 622,000 Americans died, more than died in World War I and World War II combined.
By the late 1860s, countless towns and cities across America launched springtime tributes at the graves of fallen soldiers from both sides of the civil war.
These tributes were often community-wide events during which businesses closed, residents decorated the graves with flowers and flags and recited prayers to honor and remember the fallen.
The historical practice of placing flowers on the graves of the fallen led these events to be widely referred to as "Decoration Day."
The first national observance of what is now called Memorial Day occurred on May 30, 1868, in the Arlington National Cemetery in Washington, D.C.
The speaker was Civil War veteran James A. Garfield, then a member of Congress and a future president.
In 1938, Congress officially approved Memorial Day as a federal holiday.
From 1868 until 1970 Memorial Day was observed annually on May 30. That date was selected because it was not connected to any battle or end date of any war.
Over the years, the scope of Memorial Day was expanded to honor and remember all the members of the United States military who died in World War I, World War II. Korean War, Vietnam War, Operation Desert Storm, the war in Iraq and the war in Afghanistan.
In 1971, Congress decided Memorial Day should be observed annually on the last Monday in May partly to provide federal employees a three-day holiday weekend.
Sadly, since then Memorial Day has largely been replaced by far too many Americans from being a solemn day of remembrance, to being just the third day of a long holiday weekend.
It is characterized as the unofficial start of the summer vacation season, trips to the ocean or mountains, family picnics and retailers holding sales events.
It is time to restore Memorial Day to what it was intended to be.
It is a time to reflect upon stories like the one below by June Wandrey Mann.
June Mann served as a dirst lieutenant in the U.S. Army Nurse Corps during World War II.
Between 1942 to 1946, she served in Africa, Sicily, Italy, France and Germany.
In her post war book — "Bedpan Commando" — she wrote about her experiences. In it she wrote, "Working in the shock wards, giving transfusions, was a rewarding but sad experience. Many wounded soldiers' faces still haunt my memory."
Her recollection of one experience in August 1943 while serving in Sicily is especially heartbreaking.
"An 18-year-old boy is carried into the shock ward, and he looks up at me trustingly asking, 'How am I doing, nurse?' I just kiss his forehead and say, 'You are doing just fine, soldier.' He smiles sweetly and says, 'I was just checking.' Then he dies. We all cry in private. But not in front of the boys. Never in front of the boys."
With all due respect to Nurse Mann who was a member of the "greatest generation," I suggest that at least once on every Memorial Day weekend, it is not only OK, but very appropriate to cry … in private, in front of others, or do both.
We should do so in remembrance of all American military veterans who as Abraham Lincoln observed in his Gettysburg Address, "gave the last full measure of devotion."
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Reagan believed in the promise of America
author: LARRY HOGAN
content:
Reagan believed in the promise of America

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY HOGAN | Section: Activate 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The power of Ronald Reagan was not just his extraordinary policy achievements that helped revitalize America at home and defeat the Soviet Union abroad. It was his power to tell stories that help define who we are as Americans and commit us to a greater cause.At a tumultuous time in American history following the Kennedy assassination, Vietnam War, Watergate, widespread civil unrest and rising global tensions, "Morning Again in America" meant more than a booming economy. It symbolized a new era of confidence and optimism in our country.
There may be no greater example of this than President Reagan's historic address at Normandy on the 40th anniversary of D-Day honoring the selfless and heroic actions of the "boys of Pointe du Hoc."
The heroes President Reagan paid tribute to exemplified the values that make our nation exceptional: noble, courageous, committed to our allies and higher ideals.
These Americans believed that our country and democracy as "the most deeply honorable form of government ever devised by man" was "worth dying for." President Reagan's America "loved liberty" and "willing to fight tyranny."
While others hid for their lives, these Americans took the cliffs.
Today, in a fractured media environment and deeply polarized electorate, that idea of American heroism seems to be further and further from the popular imagination. These truly American stories are a language that are not spoken nearly enough by leaders today, including in our party.
Despite these divisions, these stories still have the power to remind us that there is far more that unites us than that which divides us.
In his Pointe Du Hoc address, President Reagan posed a question to the surviving heroes of the Normandy landings. He asked, "You were young the day you took these cliffs, ... yet you risked everything here. Why? Why did you do it?"
"We look at you, and somehow we know the answer," President Reagan said. "It was faith and belief; it was loyalty and love."
That answer President Reagan provided can guide us through the turmoil of our times. Faith in America; belief in the American people; loyalty to our nation; love of country, spoken with an optimistic spirit that resonates with Americans across generations and of any political affiliation.
That's what makes Reagan the Great Communicator and reminds us that our country's brightest days are still ahead because of the character and courage of the American people.
I still believe, as President Reagan did, with faith, loyalty and love, in the promise of America.
Former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan wrote this essay to mark the 20th anniversary of the passing of President Reagan and observe the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in Normandy. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an editorial reflecting on Ronald Reagan and the D-Day anniversary, topics of national historical and political significance, fitting best under the 'National News' category.

title: Get involved, be a patriot
author: Staff Writer
content:
Get involved, be a patriot

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

The shameful actions of the district attorney, the political activist judge, and his apparatchiks in the media, have shaken Americans' confidence in a fair and just legal system.The May 30 verdict is much bigger than President Trump; they are damaging the rule of law. This decision is a travesty that will haunt our nation long after Donald Trump is gone.
Our country continues to be divided by inflation, making people with low incomes poorer, with undocumented workers not paying taxes while they are using our social services; the education process "dumbing down" students, causing the parents to flee to private schools as a substitute.

 Words

 Does it matter whether you are a registered Democrat, Republican, or Independent? Should you actively participate in U.S national elections or any other political or civic election? You registered? Will the outcome be affected whether you participate or not? Does the nation have a future?Do you have a sense of responsibility for governance? Do you feel you may leave the future of the nation and family to others without your participation and involvement? Do you feel any ownership for basic rights and quality of life in the U.S.? Are you at home with your role and status in American life? Have you hope for a strong and equitable life for Americans? Is America's future status secure in the world?

Please take the time and pray sincerely for His counsel in 2 Chronicles 7:14 (ESV), "If My people, who are called by My name humble themselves, and pray and seek my face and turn from their wicked ways, then will I hear from heaven and will forgive their sin and heal their land."

title: Refugee crisis: Record 120 million people displaced by wars, persecutions, strife worldwide
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Refugee crisis: Record 120 million people displaced by wars, persecutions, strife worldwide

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: World 
 
 690
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A record 120 million people worldwide are currently refugees or have been forcibly displaced by wars, religious and social persecutions, civil strife, gang violence and extreme weather, according the United Nations.That's a 51% rise since before the coronavirus pandemic in 2019 when 79.5 million were forcibly displaced and up 165% from 2012 when 45.2 million forcibly displaced, according to the United Nations High Commission for Refugees.
Civil wars, persecutions and violence in Sudan, Syria, Myanmar, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Haiti and Gaza are big contributors to the record upheavals along with Russia's war in Ukraine and strife in Venezuela .
Record numbers of refugees and displacements come as U.S. President Joe Biden restricts asylums for migrants and refugees trying to enter the country via the border with Mexico.
Syria continues to be "the world's largest displacement crisis" with 13.8 million people forcibly displaced, according to UNHCR.
Another 10.8 million people in the Sudan have been uprooted by the African country's civil war — which threatens to turn into famine.
In Gaza, the UN agency said 1.7 million Palestinians have been displaced in the post-Oct. 7 war between Israel and Hamas. That's 74% of Gaza's population.
More than 1.3 million have been uprooted in Myanmar due to a civil war and persecution from the ruling military regime — many of them Rohingya refugees who have fled to Bangladesh (where 920,000 mostly Muslim Rohingyas live in a sprawling refugee camp, according to the Danish Refugee Council), Malaysia and Indonesia.
There are 10.9 million refugees and other displaced persons from Afghanistan where the Islamist Taliban took over in 2021 after President Joe Biden withdrew U.S. troops and military assets and the pro-American government and military promptly fell. Many Afghan refugees have fled to Pakistan and Iran while many Syrians are in Turkey.
"Behind these stark and rising numbers lie countless human tragedies. That suffering must galvanize the international community to act urgently to tackle the root causes of forced displacement," said Filippo Grandi, UN High Commissioner for Refugees. "It is high time for warring parties to respect the basic laws of war and international law. The fact is that without better cooperation and concerted efforts to address conflict, human rights violations and the climate crisis, displacement figures will keep rising, bringing fresh misery and costly humanitarian responses."
Refugees, migrants and other displaced persons face harrowing journeys, persecutions and often have to pay smugglers, women and girls face rapes and sexual assaults and sexual trafficking.
The UN said 68.3 million people are internally displaced within their own country — a 50% rise over the past five years.
Another 43.4 million people are refugees worldwide with Afghanistan, Syria, Venezuela and Ukraine all with more than 6 million refugees, respectively, according to UNHCR.
In addition to wars, religious and ethnic persecutions and gang violence, extreme weather — such as storms and droughts some drive by climate change — and poverty are also driving migration waves from poor countries and regions to the U.S. and Europe.
The UN refugee agency and other migrant advocates are upset the Biden administration new asylum restrictions aimed at curtailing illegal crossings into the U.S.
The UNHCR said in a statement it was "profoundly concerned" about the Biden action which quickens deportations and looks to reduce asylum claims amid migration waves and domestic political worries about immigrants entering the country illegally.
"The new measures will deny access to asylum for many individuals who are in need of international protection, and who may now find themselves without a viable option for seeking safety and even at risk of refoulement. Any person who claims to have a well-founded fear of being persecuted in their country of origin must have access to safe territory and have this claim assessed before being subject to deportation or removal," the agency said.
Biden's new asylum and immigration restrictions exempts unaccompanied minors entering the U.S.
The U.S. administration says that is being done for humanitarian reason by some migrant and anti-human trafficking groups worry more migrant and refugee families will split up to allow kids and teens to enter the U.S on their own and Mexican cartels and sex trafficking syndicates will take advantage of the exemption on both sides of the border. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a worldwide refugee and displacement crisis, linking it to wars, persecution, and policy decisions, which aligns most closely with broad national/international news coverage rather than the other specific categories.

title: Ranger captures D-Day heroism in low-key talk
author: Staff Writer
content:
Ranger captures D-Day heroism in low-key talk

 June 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 953
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Earlier this month was the 80th anniversary of D-Day, the largest liberating invasion in history and the beginning of the end of World War II in Europe. As has been customary in election years, President Biden traveled to France to offer a speech to commemorate this anniversary.Most D-Day speeches have been largely forgotten … with one notable exception.
That exception occurred on the 40th anniversary of D-Day, when then President Ronald Reagan delivered a D-Day speech affirming his status as "The Great Communicator" and a master of the spoken word.
Ever mindful of the power of optics in communications, the setting for his speech was the U.S. Ranger Monument at Pointe du Hoc France, overlooking the landing beaches of Normandy.
Joining Reagan at the event were 62 Army Ranger D-Day veterans, the Queen of Britain, the Queen of the Netherlands, the King of Norway, the King of Belgium, the Grand Duke of Luxembourg and the Prime Minister of Canada.
Following Reagan's remarks, presidential historian Douglas Brinkley told the Washington Post: "For sheer oratorical eloquence, it would become one of the most inspirational presidential speeches ever delivered."
Even longtime CBS News anchor Walter Cronkite, who previously covered World War II as a correspondent (and was never a Reagan fan), was reportedly deeply moved by the speech.
In what is now widely known as the Boys at Pointe du Hoc speech, Reagan included the following remarks:
"We're here to mark that day in history when the Allied peoples joined in battle to reclaim this continent to liberty. For four long years, much of Europe had been under a terrible shadow. Free nations had fallen, Jews cried out in the camps, millions cried out for liberation. Europe was enslaved, and the world prayed for its rescue. Here in Normandy the rescue began. Here the Allies stood and fought against tyranny in a giant undertaking unparalleled in human history.
We stand on a lonely, windswept point on the northern shore of France. The air is soft, but forty years ago at this moment, the air was dense with smoke and the cries of men, and the air was filled with the crack of rifle fire and the roar of cannon. At dawn, on the morning of the 6th of June 1944, 225 Rangers jumped off the British landing craft and ran to the bottom of these cliffs. Their mission was one of the most difficult and daring of the invasion: to climb these sheer and desolate cliffs and take out the enemy guns. The Allies had been told that some of the mightiest of these guns were here and they would be trained on the beaches to stop the Allied advance.
The Rangers looked up and saw the enemy soldiers — at the edge of the cliffs shooting down at them with machine-guns and throwing grenades. And the American Rangers began to climb. They shot rope ladders over the face of these cliffs and began to pull themselves up. When one Ranger fell, another would take his place. When one rope was cut, a Ranger would grab another and begin his climb again. They climbed, shot back and held their footing. Soon, one by one, the Rangers pulled themselves over the top, and in seizing the firm land at the top of these cliffs, they began to seize back the continent of Europe. Two hundred and twenty-five came here. After two days of fighting only ninety could still bear arms.
Behind me is a memorial that symbolizes the Ranger daggers that were thrust into the top of these cliffs. And before me are the men who put them there.
These are the boys of Pointe du Hoc. These are the men who took the cliffs. These are the champions who helped free a continent. These are the heroes who helped end a war.
As memorable as Reagan's remarks are, I remember different D-Day remarks at a different time, in a different place. They occurred when I was in college during the Vietnam War.
One of our professors told us we would have a guest speaker at our next class. That was not unusual as our professor was well connected in the community and frequently secured prominent people to meet with us. He did not elaborate further so we had no idea who the speaker would be or why they were invited.
When our guest arrived, we learned that he was not only a survivor of D-Day; he was one the surviving boys of Pointe du Hoc.
This veteran spent over an hour sharing his D-Day experiences.
Sadly, I no longer remember his name, but I remember his talk. He was low key, soft-spoken, reflective and humble.
Occasionally, he paused as though the memories were too difficult to discuss. We could tell he was still deeply pained by his D-Day experience but was also glad his story was being heard.
His presentation was not a carefully crafted or rehearsed speech. There was no media coverage of it. His remarks were not recorded or distributed. There were no political dignitaries there, just a group of college students. Many of them were disdainful of older people (anyone over the age of 30) and disillusioned with the ongoing American military involvement in Vietnam.
In his closing comments, our guest said what so many of the greatest generation so often said after serving in the second world war: "I didn't do anything special. I was not a hero."
What happened next was totally unexpected.
Every student spontaneously stood up, shook his hand and thanked him for what he and his Army Ranger colleagues did. We told him what he did was very special, and he was a hero.
That was a special moment that I will always remember and cherish.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the 80th anniversary of D-Day, a major national historical event, and includes reflections on presidential speeches and veteran experiences, fitting best under National News. It also references a historic date, making Today in History a secondary candidate.

title: Precedent has been set
author: Staff Writer
content:
Precedent has been set

 June 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Precedent hasbeen set
Our former president, Donald J. Trump, has been found "guilty" on 34 counts of what amounts to a misdemeanor under the usual circumstances. But since Trump is running for president of the United States, the circumstances are not usual, and so the law has been compromised in order to try to halt his campaign.
A precedent has been set for political enemies to dig up frivolous charges against each other in order to take the other out of the running. This could result in chaos and the complete collapse of our system of government. Are politicians going to begin assassinating each other, as they do in other countries?
I am reminded of Robert Bolt's play "A Man for All Seasons" about Sir Thomas More who refused to violate his conscience to please King Henry VIII. In a debate with his son-in-law, Thomas Roper, More claims that he would give even the devil the benefit of the law. Roper is appalled and wishes he could tear down every law which stood in the way of destroying the devil.
More responds thus: "Oh? And when the last law was down, and the devil turned round on you — where would you hide, Roper, the laws all being flat?"
Two hundred and fifty years later, one of our founders, John Adams, defended in a court of law several British soldiers who had shot his countrymen in what is known as the Boston Massacre. Adams was an expert on British common law and to him the defendants, whether he liked them or not, had the right to a fair trial; he made sure they had one.
What is British common law? It began with the seventh century laws of the Angles and the Saxons who began to have hearings in which evidence was presented. In the late ninth century, Alfred the Great codified the laws of the Angles and the Saxons, insisting that rich and poor, high and low, were equally treated. In 1215, the Magna Carta stated the presumption of innocence until proven guilty, which is one of the foundations of our judiciary.
We have taken our legal system for granted. When some people who commit crimes go free while others are hounded for much lesser offenses, then the laws become meaningless. The people who hate Trump are willing to destroy our legal system in order to ruin him.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a federal legal case involving a former U.S. president and its implications for the national legal and political system, fitting the scope of national news rather than any other listed category.

title: Trump endorses Hogan Senate bid
author: Staff Writer
content:
Trump endorses Hogan Senate bid

 June 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan, who has been one of former President Donald Trump's fiercest critics in the GOP, received Trump's endorsement in his Maryland Senate bid on Thursday in an interview on Fox News."I'd like to see him win," Trump told the network during a trip to Washington, D.C. "I think he has a good chance to win."
The Maryland race could determine control of the Senate, a point Trump noted in the interview.
"I would like to see him win, and we got to take the majority. We have to straighten out our country, so I'd like to see him win," Trump said.
Hogan, who was a popular governor, is trying to become the first Republican in more than 40 years to win a Senate seat in Maryland, where Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 2-1 ratio statewide.
Late last month, Hogan angered Trump's campaign when he said that the public should "respect the verdict and the legal process" prior to Trump's conviction by a Manhattan jury on 34 felony counts related to hush money payments.
"At this dangerously divided moment in our history, all leaders — regardless of party — must not pour fuel on the fire with more toxic partisanship," Hogan posted on X before the verdict was announced. "We must reaffirm what has made this nation great: the rule of law."
Chris LaCivita, a senior Trump campaign adviser, shot back on X: "You just ended your campaign."
Hogan, who is trying to navigate a difficult path running in a heavily Democratic state, has said he will not be attending the Republican National Convention next month in Milwaukee, July 15-18. Hogan did not attend the party's conventions in 2020 and 2016.
In the past two presidential elections, Hogan said he did not vote for Trump, the party nominee. Hogan said he wrote in the name of his father, former U.S. Rep. Larry Hogan Sr., in 2016 and the late President Ronald Reagan in 2020.
Hogan is running against Democrat Angela Alsobrooks, the chief executive of Prince George's County near the nation's capital. The Senate seat is open due to the retirement of Sen. Ben Cardin, a Democrat.
