title: Coming for the kids
author: Staff Writer
content:
Coming for the kids

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I have had several persons of a liberal persuasion question me about Project 2025, which I had not even heard of until recently.I was informed by said liberal persons, with complete certainty on their part, that Project 2025 would be imposed on the USA if Trump were elected for a second term, which would mean the end of the republic, with the imposition of a fascist dictatorship.
After some research it became clear that Trump and his campaign have no connection with Project 2025. Project 2025 is a project of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank that only a Marxist would describe as "fascist" or "bourgeois." Project 2025 has as its goals such things as securing the border, making federal bureaucrats accountable to Congress, cutting government spending and other policies which I have heard both Democrats and Republicans defend.
More of a matter of concern is the Reproductive Freedom Amendment or Ballot Question No. 1 for Maryland voters in the upcoming November general election. All you have to do is think for a minute about why we would need such an amendment. What reproductive freedoms do Marylanders lack?
Under current Maryland laws, adults are free to reproduce with other consenting adults, except blood relatives. They are even free not to reproduce by engaging in same sex relationships, dignified by the laws of Maryland as marriage. Those who engage in reproductive activity are free, according to the law, to terminate a pregnancy any time before the moment of birth.
Minors once required the permission of a parent or guardian in most circumstances but under the new laws parents may lose their rights. If parents object to gender reassignment surgery, the state is already empowered to remove the child from the home. If the Question No. 1 passes, then legal action in favor of parents will be almost impossible as will be repealing the unjust laws. It already is happening in other states. So the news is: they are coming for the kids.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses political legislation and policy issues (Project 2025, reproductive freedom amendment) that have broader national relevance, fitting the National News category better than the other topics.

title: rest of mike's story
author: Staff Writer
content:
rest of mike's story

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Rest Of Mikes Story 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FOCUS ON THE BASERyan Waite, a veteran campaign consultant and vice president of public affairs with northern California-based consulting firm Think Big, said the political parties and most campaigns are focused on ginning up and turning out their voter bases and don't tend to engage with low-propensity voters."They put resources where it is going to make the most difference. Typically, you are looking at people who have previously voted, who are kind in that soft middle," said Waite, who has mostly worked on Republican campaigns.
Waite said while social media can help engage more voters and could help engage nonvoters, especially young ones, the medium presents challenges.
"You are competing with everything else. The slice of time you get in front of them is very very small," he said of the social media content streams.
Negative campaigning, coarse social discourse and misinformation on key issues have also magnified on social media leaving voters and nonvoters distrustful of content and disparate and sometimes ideological information sources.
"It's hard for average voters to figure out what's going on," said Waite.
In an Aug. 26 letter to the House Judiciary Committee, META Platforms chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the Biden-Harris administration "repeatedly pressured" Facebook and Instagram to censor dissenting content (including humor and satire) related to COVID-19.
The White House defended those actions as helping protect public health from misinformation.
Recent surveys show low levels of trust in politics, the media and government, as well as plenty of economic stress stemming from the post-pandemic inflation wave.
A June survey by financial firm Credit Karma and research firm Qualtrics found 68% of Americans don't believe official economic data touting job gains and easing inflation after post-pandemic spikes in prices.
Another recent poll by Gallup and the Walton Foundation shows Gen Zers (ages 12 to 27) have little trust in the media, government and politics. But they showed strong turnout in 2020 and are expected to also show up in November, said Craig Snyder, campaign director for Haley Voters for Harris (a group that hopes to get GOP supporters of former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley to eschew Trump).
NEW ENERGY?Snyder said Harris' campaign should energize younger voters more than the matchup between Trump and President Joe Biden.
"They weren't excited about a race between two 80-year-old men," said Snyder, noting that Democratic enthusiasm for Harris will also generate GOP energy for Trump.
Harris was installed at the top of the Democratic ticket after Biden, 81, was pressured to quit the race by donors and party power players over concerns about his age.
Snyder said voting groups such as suburban women, Black and Hispanic men, along with voters on both sides of Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas could tip the race in battlegrounds such as Michigan, Wisconsin, North Carolina and Pennsylvania.
Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s endorsement of Trump could also shift his voters, many of whom are disaffected by COVID policies (including vaccines), in key states.
Snyder also sees another contingent of nonvoters beyond the disaffected and those with logistical barriers.
"There's a third group," he said. "They just don't connect politics to their lives."
GOTV EFFORTSPolitical organizations on both sides do have get-out-the-vote (GOTV) efforts across the country, including some aimed at first-time and nonvoters.
Conservative groups — such as Christians United for Israel — hope to turn out evangelicals for Trump and Republicans. That includes working with churches across the country on support for Israel and voter mobilization.
Democrats look to college campuses, as well as Native Americans, Blacks and Hispanics in key races.
In Montana, Nick Marroletti, coordinated campaign director for the state Democratic Party, said grassroots turn-out efforts have included knocking on 100,000 doors and making 97,000 phone calls supporting U.S. Sen. Jon Tester, who faces a tough challenge from Republican Tim Sheehy.
'LACK OF FAITH'Mara Ostfeld, a research scientist at the University of Michigan, analyzed voting sentiments in Detroit and found Latino voters, in particular, have lower turnout propensities.
Ostfeld agrees that nonvoters, especially lower-income ones, don't see the outcome of elections impacting their daily lives.
"There is a disconnect," Ostfeld said. But she also said that doesn't mean nonvoters are not engaged or connected to their communities in other ways and don't follow politics.
"It's not like they are disinterested or disengaged," Ostfeld said. "There is just a lack of faith in the political system in particular." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses nationwide political campaign strategies, voter engagement, and election dynamics, which aligns most closely with the National News category.

title: Division in unison in Trump-Harris, Senate races: ‘It’s the economy’ reverberates from voters
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Division in unison in Trump-Harris, Senate races: ‘It’s the economy’ reverberates from voters

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: National 
 
 1880
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Public opinion polls show stark voter divides — including ones centered on gender, age and educational status — in the race between former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris as well as key U.S. Senate races.But those same polls show voters across disparate demographic and political groups consistently list economic angst — including high inflation, personal financial stress and lack of affordable housing — at the top of their concerns this election cycle.
What public opinion surveys indicate could be an advantage for Trump — even after his contentious debate performance — and a challenge for Harris, who Democratic Party leaders installed at the top of the ticket after they pressured President Joe Biden to quit the race.
Polls have shown voters tend to trust Trump more with the economy than Harris.
Pollsters also see a divided American electorate.
In a nutshell, men, older voters, those without college or advanced degrees and Evangelical Christians, back Trump and Republican candidates. Women, younger voters and those with college or advanced degrees, as well as urbanites, are supporting Harris and Democrats.
OLD VS. YOUNGBob Ward, a partner in the polling firm Fabrizio Ward LLC, has seen an enthusiasm gap between older voters (who tend to favor Trump and Republicans) and younger voters (who are key to Harris' and Democrats' turnout efforts).
The Republican polling firm has teamed with Democratic firm David Binder Research to conduct polls for AARP in presidential and U.S. Senate battlegrounds including Wisconsin, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Nevada, Maryland and Montana.
"It's the economy," said Ward of the top issue across the board, potentially discouraging younger voters from turning out in November.
"Younger voters are really economically stressed. Inflation is a big deal, as are housing prices," Ward said. "We've seen it in every state we've polled."
U.S. prices are up 20% since Biden and Harris took office in 2021 and 23% since the COVID pandemic (which cut across both the Trump and Biden-Harris administrations and saw big government spending and central bank monetary infusions).
Ward said younger voters are also concerned about the shortage of affordable housing options. Home prices and rents soared during and since the pandemic.
He said younger voters are as concerned about home affordability as seniors are about Social Security. Ward said the war in Gaza between Israel and Hamas after the Oct. 7 attacks has, at least in public opinion, ranked lower than economic issues.
Appealing to voters — especially younger ones — on the economy will be key to Harris (who inherits Biden's economic standing). National and battleground polls show Harris with healthy leads among voters under the age of 45. Trump has the advantage among older voters.
But older voters are much more energized to vote, according to AARP's polling.
Ward said that polling shows inflation, personal finances, and the economy are also top of mind for voters age 50 and older, with 77% ranking it among the top two election-year concerns in red-state Montana, 85% in blue-state Maryland and 87% in battleground Wisconsin — with many seniors living on fixed incomes (i.e., Social Security as their primary income source).
HISPANIC VOTERS
Concerns about costs of living and the economy and increased GOP outreach could potentially also help Trump with Hispanic voters, even with his hardline immigration stances opposed by a majority of Latinos.
Anaís Lopez, a pollster with BSP Research, conducted a survey of 3,000 Latino voters for UnidosUS with an oversample of Florida Hispanics and found inflation, jobs and housing are their top concerns.
"Those are really tied together to concerns about the economy across the country," she said.
Lopez also said there are many young and first-time voters in the 2024 cycle, adding that 60% of Latino voters in Florida say they have not been contacted by either party. That figure is 55% nationally, according to the polling group.
"We have a lot of new young voters in this electorate," she said.
Lopez said the UnidosUS-BSP poll released this month shows Harris with a 47% to 42% lead over Trump in Florida with Hispanic voters.
That spread could be tighter than in previous elections, said Clarissa Martinez de Castro, vice president of the Latino Vote Initiative for UnidosUS, stressing the need for more outreach to Latinos.
In the 2024 Florida survey, Trump does well with Cuban voters and leads 48% to 47% with Hispanic men in Florida.
Harris leads with Hispanic women, 48% to 37%.
Harris holds larger leads among Hispanics in other states including some battlegrounds. She leads Trump by 27 points among Hispanics nationally. But that is down from Biden 2:1 vote edge in 2020.
Harris also leads with Hispanics in some key battlegrounds such as Arizona (28 points), North Carolina (29 points) and Nevada (23 points).
But how does that compare to 2020?
In 2020, Biden won Arizona's Hispanic vote by 30 points, North Carolina by 20 points and Nevada by 19 points, according to the Americas Society / Council of the Americas. Biden won Pennsylvania's Latino vote by 60 percentage points in 2020. Harris leads Trump by 35 points, according to the UnidosUS-BSP poll.
Some of the demographic voting trends are long-standing divides in American politics. But, some of the divisions are more distinct this cycle.
Trump was almost assassinated in July, has faced criminal and civil prosecutions and perpetually stirs controversy. If elected, Harris' would be the first woman U.S. president. But she was installed at the top of ticket after Biden was pressured to quit.
The 2024 campaign is also just a few years removed from all the stresses, fights and impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Polls — which could potentially shift after the Sept. 10 presidential debate — have shown a close race with questions about how much Trump "under polls" in surveys as he did in 2016 and 2020.
MEN VS. WOMEN
Voting differences between men and women continue to be a prime dividing line in American politics.
"We are seeing a pretty pronounced gender gap," Ward said.
The most recent New York Times-Siena College national poll (taken before the Sept. 10 debate) shows men favoring Trump 54% to 38% while women back Harris 51% to 41%.
That mirrors an August AARP poll in Michigan showing men backing Trump by 20 points and women favoring Harris by 13 points.
The gender gap is also showing up in key Senate races.
A recent AARP poll of Montana voters shows Republican Tim Sheehy leading Democratic U.S. Jon Tester by 19 points among men. The high-priced race could decide which party controls the U.S. Senate next year.
Sheehy leads Tester 49% to 41% among all voters, but by 30 points among men age 50 and older.
Patrick Gonzales, principal with Maryland-based Gonzales Research and Media Services, said women make up 60% of the Democratic Party, so the gender divide in the presidential race and other races reflects that.
"Older women are very heavily Democratic," Gonzales said.
A pre-debate survey in Pennsylvania, a key Electoral College battleground, by CBS and polling firm YouGov found Harris leading among women by 11 points and Trump among men by 13 points. Overall, the race is 50% to 50%, according to that Pennsylvania poll.
In the race to fill an open U.S. Senate seat in Maryland, Democratic Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks leads anti-Trump former Republican governor Larry Hogan 46% to 41% with a split along gender and racial lines, according to a new poll from Gonzales.
Alsobrooks leads among Blacks (78% to 16%) and women (51% to 39%). Hogan leads with whites 55% to 29%, but only has a 44% to 42% edge among men in heavily Democratic Maryland.
Nationally, Trump does better with White voters. Harris is preferred by voters of color.
A wild card in the race could be how well Trump does with black and Hispanic men, Gonzales said.
Trump is courting more conservative Catholic voters, including Hispanics who might be opposed to abortion rights. He also is courting Jewish voters, a traditional Democratic voting block, touting his support for Israel. Abortion and Israel are issues that also appeal to Evangelicals, a key GOP voting block.
Harris is hoping to gain support from neoconservatives and other Republicans who don't like Trump. She has the endorsements of former Vice President Dick Cheney and his daughter, former Wyoming congresswoman Liz Cheney. She's also trying to navigate the politics of U.S. and Biden administration's military support for Israel while calling for an end to the post-Oct. 7 war in Gaza and establishment of a Palestinian state.
A NEW CLASS DIVIDE
Ward said educational attainment is becoming one of the most distinct delineators of how someone will vote.
Education level is also often a signal of socio-economic class.
Harris and Democrats are preferred by well-schooled voters. Trump and Republicans are favored by those without college or advanced degrees
In the AARP's Montana poll, voters who don't have college degrees support Trump by 30 points. Harris leads with college-educated voters by 6 points.
Nationally, a pre-debate New York Times-Siena poll shows Harris getting 57% of the college-educated vote in contrast to Trump getting 56% of the non-college-educated vote.
Ward said he's seen the education/class divide grow since 2016.
"It's definitely grown since 2016," he said. "In most cases, it is bigger than the gender gap."
The 2016 election cycle saw Trump's populist ascension/takeover of the Republican Party and his bevy of controversies.
It also saw the COVID-19 pandemic, which brought economic and social shutdowns, close to 1.2 million U.S. deaths attributed to the virus, and unprecedented wealth transfers to the affluent, with stock markets and housing prices hitting record highs.
On the flip side, working-class workers lost jobs during COVID shutdowns and have been hit hard with post-pandemic 40-year highs with inflation.
The NYT-Siena poll shows two-thirds of voters in cities support Harris, while two-thirds of those in rural expanses and small towns back Trump.
'ANY SCHMUCK
'There are oceans of polls that frequent the political and media shores, with the presidential and Senate horse races making headlines and fundraising pitches.
Pollsters have had to adjust to changes in technology (namely more cell phones and younger households ditching landlines) to get an accurate mix of likely voters to respond to their questions.
Gonzales said that 30 years ago people called for polls were often excited that someone asked for their opinions and points of view.
"Today, any schmuck can offer their point of view 24/7 through social media, and that's the way of the world," he said.
Gonzales and Ward said it takes effort and a commitment to having some over-the-phone interviews with respondents to get more accurate takes on voters' pulses.
Ward said the most accurate polling needs to have a mix of landline, cell phone and online interviews to get accurate cross-sections of younger and older voters.
Expectations are for a tight presidential race up until the election with money flowing into both partisan camps and Harris potentially raising more than $1 billion.
Gonzales said he could see some trends and victory lines developing in early October.
He's just not sure which competing argument will grab the 2024 wheel.
The veteran pollster said he could see voters gravitating toward Trump's economic message and dissatisfaction with the Democratic administration's handling of the economy, in particular, or Harris' message of "turning the page" from all the discord and division that centers around the former president.
But he also knows the challenges of polling in the divisive Trump area.
"The media is nonstop, and there are elements of the media who take a political bent and almost demonize those who think differently," Gonzales said.
That can discourage some from sharing their opinions.
"Those human beings are less likely to participate in a poll," Gonzales said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on nationwide political polling and election dynamics between Trump and Harris, covering voter demographics and Senate races, which aligns best with the National News category.

title: Advice for choosing candidates based on faith
author: JEFFREY S. TRIMBATH
content:
Advice for choosing candidates based on faith

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JEFFREY S. TRIMBATH | Section: Columns 
 
 754
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In just over a month, Marylanders will begin casting their votes in this year's general election. Every year, citizens of our state get to exercise their "consent," deciding who they want to represent them in government. In keeping with the scripture's command to love our neighbor (Mark 12:31), Marylanders of faith have a particular responsibility to participate.But how should Christians decide? What criteria should we use to choose one candidate over another?
I suggest the following five criteria may be helpful.
Person. Obviously, the most immediate vote one makes is for the candidate. What is the person like? What is their experience, both in politics and in life? What is their family life like? Do they have children? Have they been successful in a variety of different vocations and callings?
And what about their character? One important aspect of character emerges from the ancient meaning of the term as a "stamping tool." As an image embossed on a coin, does their public persona mirror their stated commitments? For example, if a candidate publicly claims a particular religious faith, his or her position on policy issues ought to be in conformity with, or at least not contradict, the fundamental teachings of that tradition.
Part of the character consideration is understanding that you are voting for political office, not ecclesiastical office. Of course, we want leaders in all sectors to be of good character. Favoring a presidential candidate, however, is fundamentally different than favoring your own pastor or priest.
Principles and Policies. Every person has core values, rooted in what they love and believe to be true. What are those core convictions, and where do they come from?
Every candidate possesses core values. For Christians, our core convictions about the most important issues in life are grounded in how God created us, and what He says in the scriptures.
What does the candidate believe about the human person, the nature of justice and how we're to live together? Which of these principles are more important than others?
A candidate's principles will inform their policies. For Christians, issues of life, family, education and religious liberty are top tier. There are important lower-priority issues too — property rights, rule of law, taxes, immigration, inflation, national security — which are informed by our commitment to justice.
Party. In our country there are two major political parties, both of which adopt platforms. Which platform most closely aligns with how God has created us and tells us to live? A candidate is one person, but that individual brings along with them the staff, resources and commitment of a political party. Which party has a history that aligns with biblical values?
People. Depending on the level of office, winning candidates bring with them staff and personnel to help them serve in office. The newly elected president will place 4,000 staffers in his new administration. Who are the people who will fill those positions? Are they known for their expertise and work ethic, or known for other things that distract from the task?
Prudence. After considering all of the above criteria, a Christian must ask: what is the most prudent choice? People of faith make political decisions in a fallen world, with a phalanx of competing dynamics and realities. Prudence is showing good and careful judgement as we make these choices. Part of making a prudent choice is understanding what is possible given this environment. Will the candidate you're choosing get elected? If that's not likely, are you supporting that candidate for another legitimate reason (to send a message, for example)?
A key aspect of making a prudent choice is weighing which candidate is the least bad. Scripture teaches, and experience confirms, that every human is fallen. Every election, therefore, is the choice of the lesser of two evils. Both candidates may favor abortion, for example. In that case, is there one that favors other policies that better align with other biblical principles?
There you have it — 5 "P's" to help you evaluate which candidate you will choose this November. I would add a final "p," and that's prayer. People of faith should fervently pray that God would give them wisdom and courage to vote for the right candidate, and pray that His will be done regardless of the outcome of the election.
God's people are called to "seek the welfare" of the city in which they find themselves, even if that land is hostile (Jeremiah 29). Taking the time to thoughtfully evaluate which candidates most effectively pursue that welfare is an important way we can love our neighbor and steward the gift of citizenship. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a column advising voters on how to choose political candidates based on faith, focusing on the upcoming general election. This political content aligns best with the broader 'National News' category, with secondary relevance to local/state election issues.

title: Debate process is broken, but it can be fixed
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Debate process is broken, but it can be fixed

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 713
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first and perhaps the only debate between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump is over.Now will be much longer and heated debates between their respective supporters on which candidate won and which candidate lost in the debate.
I suggest the voters lost.
They lost because the current presidential debate process is broken.
The reasons are simple.
They were addressed recently by the Editorial Board at the Washington Post and by Philip Bump, a regular Washington Post columnist.
The Post's editorial board cited a Post and Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University survey reporting only three in 10 residents of six of the most important states in this year's presidential election trusted the media will fairly and accurately report political news.
The Post's Philip Bump was especially blunt when he recently wrote "Americans don't trust the media, particularly when it comes to politics."
Interesting that Bump wrote "the media." He did not write the left of center media or the right of center media. The media includes, but is not limited to the following major television broadcasting networks — ABC, NBC, CBS, FOX NEWS, MSNBC, CNN, PBS and CW.
Despite those conclusions the following were key elements of the Nov. 10 debate.
The debate moderators were ABC News anchor and managing editor David Muir and ABC News Live "Prime" anchor Linsey Davis.
ABC staff wrote the debate questions.
Each candidate had just two minutes to answer each question with a two-minute rebuttal, and an additional minute for a follow-up, clarification or response.
As soon as the debate ended, the media launched into rapid response modes with their analysis of each candidate's remarks, debate performance, fact checks and opinions on the biggest takeaways from the night. The moderators even did fact checking during the debate.
One has to wonder how much those rapid responses reflected pre-determined thoughts rather than thoughtful analysis, reliable fact checks and opinions on the biggest takeaways from the night can occur immediately after the debate rather than after more deliberative, rigorous and objective thinking.
Long before the Nov. 10 debate the words "an existential threat to democracy" have been used ad infinitum.
I suggest one unaddressed existential threat to democracy is when the media, which is not trusted by Americans, is empowered to propose debate ground rules, develop debate questions, moderate a debate or debates, fact check during the debate, and provide rapid response post-debate analysis and rapid response post-debate fact checking.
To address that threat, I suggest there is a much better system based on a model on policy discourses from a time when America was deeply divided, just as we are now.
That time was 1858, three years before the start of the War Between the States.
At that time, Abraham Lincoln engaged in widely followed political dialogue with Stephen A. Douglas. All that dialogue was characterized by open, candid, civil and issue- driven conversations focused on helping voters learn more about the respective views of Lincoln and Douglas.
These conversations with voters often resulted in supporters applauding for their candidate.
When that happened, Douglas said, "My friends, silence will be more acceptable to me in the discussion of these questions than applause. I desire to address myself to your judgment, your understanding and your consciences, and not to your passions or your enthusiasms."
To do that going forward today, we need to reduce the currently outsized role of television broadcasters in presidential election debates. Instead of debates, they should broadcast candidate forums.
These forums should feature one candidate and only one candidate at a time in a 90-minute prime-time broadcast.
Speaking for 90-minutes straight will provide candidates opportunities to demonstrate their understanding of which issues resonate with voters, share their positions on those issues and their stamina to exercise the duties of the most demanding job in the world.
Candidate eligibility for televised forums would be the same as those in place for the current debates — polling thresholds and appearing on enough state ballots to theoretically get a majority of electoral votes in the November election.
Those forums could be broadcast on a rotating basis starting with the broadcast network with the highest levels of viewership, then rebroadcast, unedited, on all the other networks.
In addition, verbatim unedited transcripts of the forums could be widely circulated by print and other electronic media outlets.
Now more than ever, candidate forums instead of debates are an idea whose time has come. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the presidential debate process, media trust, and democratic implications—issues of national political significance, fitting the National News category.

title: Who is better for Talbot County, Harris or Trump?
author: JIM BRUCE
content:
Who is better for Talbot County, Harris or Trump?

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM BRUCE | Section: Columns 
 
 1253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tuesday's presidential debate provides new information about how a Trump or Harris presidency would affect Talbot County. Buried among the barbs and points well-taken in the 90-minute debate are clues about what Talbot can expect, although the debate certainly did not address every way that the next White House will affect our county.Talbot County's economic future depends on who wins the presidency. In the debate Trump doubled down on his plan to impose large tariffs, 20% and more on imported products, particularly Chinese items (about 80% of Walmart's inventory comes from China). He ignores what economists say — foreign firms will raise their prices on their exports to us to offset these import tariffs, leaving American consumers, not the exporter, paying higher prices and prompting inflation.
Further, these tariffs will provoke retaliatory tariffs as happened in Trump's first presidency when our national soybean exports to China plummeted 75%. Talbot County has about 40,000 acres of soybean crops, more than any other cash crop. Note that Goldman Sachs just predicted that Trump's policies on tariffs and immigration would lead to an economic downturn, while the U.S. economy would grow if Harris is elected.
Although Maryland law strongly protects reproductive rights, which a state constitutional amendment on the ballot (Question 4) this fall would further strengthen, if Congress were to pass and the president sign a federal ban on abortions, it would preempt Maryland's protections. Trump said in the debate he does not support a federal law banning abortions, but when asked if he would pledge to veto such a ban, Trump dodged the question. The moderator asked Trump again, noting that J.D. Vance has said that Trump would veto a federal abortion ban. Trump dodged again explaining that Congress would never pass such a bill.
Trump took credit for the Supreme Court reversing Roe v. Wade and shifting the issue to the states. He explained that he acted because some states were allowing abortion in the ninth month and even beyond. "In other words, we'll execute the baby." This was too much even for the moderator who jumped in to say, "There is no state in this country, where it is legal to kill a baby after it is born."
In contrast, Harris was clear, "I absolutely support reinstating the protections of Roe v. Wade," and pledging that when Congress passes a bill codifying Roe v. Wade, "I will proudly sign it into law."
In 2022, 2,810 people in Talbot were listed as foreign-born, but we don't know how many "undocumented immigrants" live here. Trump distracted much of the immigration debate repeating unproven allegations that immigrants are eating our pet cats and dogs. Talbot's real risk is that Trump pledges to deport substantially more than 11 million "undocumented immigrants" using the national guard, local police, federal immigration officials, and if necessary, our military, going door to door.
This largest mass deportation in our history would cause bedlam in our county and certainly in our workplaces with many businesses having to close. Trump continues to demonize immigrants, insulting Talbot's growing Hispanic and other foreign-born populations and creating fear in our communities. The moderator asked Trump why he killed Congress' tough, bipartisan immigration bill that would have put thousands of additional agents on the border. Trump never answered the question. Harris supports this bill, accusing Trump of preferring to run on the immigration issue, but not solve it.
Health care is crucial for Talbot because our population is aging, and our largest employer is health care and social services. The debate focused on what will happen to the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), which is popular because of its coverage for pre-existing conditions. Harris stated her absolute support for maintaining and growing the program and private health care options as well.
When the moderator asked Trump why he initially opposed the program but now supports it, Trump responded that he decided to save the program and improve it. Pressed about whether he has a plan now to do that, Trump said, "I have concepts of a plan," about which we would be hearing more in the future. Kamala pointed out that for nine years the Republicans tried 60 times to kill the program, which survived by one vote from a Republican, the late Sen. John McCain. Republicans never presented an alternative plan.
Nearly 21,000 Marylanders are of Ukrainian extraction and far more of us, including in Talbot, sympathize with Ukraine. In the debate, Harris described her continuing efforts to help Ukraine defend itself, beginning before the Russian invasion. When the moderator asked Trump not once, but twice, if he believes that it is in the U.S. best interests for Ukraine to win this war, Trump said instead it is in our best interests to end the war by a settlement that he claims he could negotiate between Zelensky and Putin, even before Trump's inauguration.
Further, Trump claimed the war should never have started, suggesting falsely that Harris caused it because she was such a weak emissary sent to negotiate with Putin that he invaded Ukraine three days later. In fact, Harris had never met with Putin. Stoking fear and providing insight into his motivations, Trump pointed to Putin's nuclear weapons, adding, "And eventually, maybe he will use them." For 300 years, people of Talbot have learned we must stand up to tyrants like Putin.
With 600 miles of shoreline, Talbot County is especially vulnerable to the rising waters from climate change. In the debate, Harris reiterated her belief that climate change is real, we can and must address it. When Harris said that Trump had called it a hoax, Trump only responded with a disjointed reply on other subjects. (Note that the Republican platform unveiled in their convention has not a word on climate change.)
The difference in the two candidates' specific policy proposals presented in the debate is striking. Kamala Harris calls for a $50,000 tax deduction to help start up businesses. She wants a $6,000 tax credit for young families for the first year of a child's life. To help address affordable housing she seeks a $25,000 down payment assistance for first-time homebuyers, and to build 3 million new homes over four years. She pledges more negotiation with pharmaceuticals to drive down drug costs, such as the $35 cap on insulin prices.
Scouring the debate transcript, all I saw of Trump's policy proposals, other than generalizations (I will make American great again), were his pledge to reduce taxes, and to impose large tariffs on most foreign products. In her closing statement, Kamala lays out her policy vision in broad strokes. Trump spent his closing time attacking Harris' plans, labeling her the worst vice president in history, and darkly predicting we will wind up in a third world war.
To me the most telling clue to what our county and the rest of our country can expect from the next White House regards its character. History is replete with tragic figures whose regimes failed because they could not honestly self-appraise, accept criticism, learn from it, and alter course accordingly.
Throughout the debate we all heard Trump proclaim every aspect of his first presidency the best in history and that of Biden/Harris the worst. In a postscript to the debate, Trump declared, "We won the debate according to every poll — every single poll, I think."
His supporters tried to cover up this obvious falsehood by explaining that the moderators were biased, and even that Harris cheated using earbuds for outside coaching disguised as pearl earrings. Trump now refuses to debate Harris again.
If you care about Talbot County, vote for Kamala Harris. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the presidential debate, candidate policies, and their potential impact on the county, focusing on national political issues rather than local government, sports, or other specific categories.

title: Rep. Harris, local Republicans speak at Denton rally supporting Trump
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Rep. Harris, local Republicans speak at Denton rally supporting Trump

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Republican leaders and supporters gathered for a Caroline County rally Saturday in support of presidential candidate Donald Trump and Maryland Republicans running for office this November.The event, which took place at Caroline County 4-H Park, was organized by Caroline County Republican Women. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) was the featured speaker Saturday afternoon.
As he runs for his eighth consecutive term in the House of Representatives, Maryland's only Republican in Congress asked voters to support him as well as the entire Republican ticket. He emphasized a tight race in Congressional District 6, where Republican candidate Neil Parrott is vying to potentially join Harris as conservative representation in the House.
"We got a job to do. Because if President Trump is going to succeed, we need to have a House majority, so I'm going to ask for your vote," Harris said.
"Those of you who know people who live out in western Maryland, call them up and tell them to vote for Neil Parrott, because I'm tired of being the only Republican in the House delegation from Maryland, and we got a shot," he said.
Caroline County Republican Women member Joanne Smith helped organize Saturday's event. She said the group held a gathering back in 2020 as well. In her eyes, Trump is a fit for Caroline County voters.
"I think Trump represents our values," Smith said. "We're a very red area. Everybody in Caroline County that's elected is Republican."
"We desperately want to see a change in our government and Trump's our man," she added.
Much of Saturday's discussion centered on ensuring Republicans secure a Senate majority. Harris encouraged attendees to vote for former Gov. Larry Hogan as he runs for Maryland's open Senate seat against Democratic opponent Angela Alsobrooks.
Harris emphasized that without a Republican majority in the Senate and a Trump victory, conservative judges cannot be placed on the Supreme Court bench.
Adorned in a "Make America Great Again" baseball cap, Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) also asked voters to toe the party line..
"Vote straight down the ticket, Donald Trump, Larry Hogan, Andy Harris," Mautz said. "Whatever it is, whatever the qualm is, it doesn't matter. We need to get out, and we need to vote."
"This is war," he continued. "We're at a national crossroads right now, and we need to put all of our cards on the table."
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) attended Saturday's rally, as well as Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker.
Speaking to eventgoers, Hutchinson predicted that November's general election will play out similar to the 2016 vote, with Trump claiming swing states and the presidency. "We can't wait to see it happen again," he said.
The state delegate said in an interview with the Star Democrat that the economy is the number one reason for residents on the Shore to support Trump.
"We see with our rising food prices, gas prices, housing prices, it's affecting everybody here on the Shore," Hutchinson said. " … I see it within my district, how it's really affecting the middle-income and low-income families."
Smith and Harris both noted an increase in enthusiasm among local Republicans to win back the White House. "We want to get back to the Trump years," Harris said in an interview.
Denton resident Thomas Conneely Jr. attended Saturday's gathering and echoed that sentiment.
"I see that there's more energy," Conneely Jr. said. "But I also see an urgency that it's an emergency. That's what I see. I see people looking at it as, 'We have to.' If we don't, we're in deep trouble." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a political rally supporting a presidential candidate and congressional races, focusing on national election issues rather than local services or other subject areas.

title: Harris to lead House Freedom Caucus
author: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service
content:
Harris to lead House Freedom Caucus

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 493
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md, 1st) is the new chairman of the House Freedom Caucus.Harris, who represents Maryland's Eastern Shore and is the state's only Republican in Congress, is a founding member of the Freedom Caucus and was already serving on the right-wing caucus's board of directors.
"I look forward to leading this caucus as we confront the reckless spending of the Biden-Harris Administration, work to secure our Southern Border, and defend our constitutional freedoms in the House of Representatives," Harris said in a statement Wednesday.
The late Tuesday vote came after the former caucus head, Rep. Bob Good (R-Va.) lost his June primary reelection bid, leading him to resign from his chairmanship position last week. Good was set to lead the House Freedom Caucus through December 2025.
Good said on X that the chairmanship is in "capable hands," referring to Harris' election.
Since the House Freedom Caucus was formed in 2015, its members have contributed to legislative chaos for Republican leadership.
Notably, the caucus played a key role in the House leadership fight that ousted former Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Ca.) and brought in current Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.).
Harris is a member of the House Appropriations Committee and serves as the committee's chair of the agriculture subcommittee.
His role on appropriations — the committee tasked with deciding spending for most of the government — and his new chairmanship is a win for the House Freedom Caucus, whose members say they want to limit government spending.
"In the annals of, 'it could never happen,' the House Freedom Caucus Chairman is also a cardinal on the House Appropriations Committee," Former Freedom Caucus Chairman Rep. Scott Perry, R-Pennsylvania, wrote on X. "The @freedomcaucus continues to punch above its weight. Well done, Andy."
The House Freedom Caucus is currently pushing to add conservative policies — including a measure that would require proof of citizenship to vote — to a temporary government funding bill.
Harris' new role may help in the Maryland congressional delegation's efforts to secure full federal funding to rebuild Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge, which collapsed in March.
Before the chairmanship vote, Harris told reporters Tuesday that he wasn't sure if the authorization for the bridge could be attached to the upcoming continuing resolution to fund the government.
However, he said that because the authorization, if included, would be a part of a much larger bill, Republicans likely wouldn't base their vote on the Key Bridge.
Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.) said on Tuesday that Harris and the Maryland Democrats are helping in the House to get Key Bridge authorization through. Cardin told reporters that he is hopeful the authorization for the government to pay for the full repairs could be added to the continuing resolution.
Harris' stance wanting the government to pay for the full Key Bridge repair project differed from the Freedom Caucus, which wanted to first look for liabilities from shipping companies before approving government funds.
Harris has served in the House since 2011. Before Congress, Harris was a Maryland state senator for 12 years. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a federal congressional leadership change and related national policy issues, which fits the scope of National News more than any other listed category.

title: Cardin among US reps to UN
author: ANDREA DURÁN Capital News Service
content:
Cardin among US reps to UN

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA DURÁN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Maryland Sen. Ben Cardin will attend the 79th session of the United Nations General Assembly.Cardin, a Democrat, will travel to New York this weekend as a representative of the United States to the U.N. to meet with world leaders, the senator said in an interview Tuesday with Capital News Service.
Cardin said his message to the General Assembly will include "support for Ukraine, put a spotlight on the Sudan — the tragedies that are taking place there — and to try to find a way in which we can move towards the hostage release, cease-fire and peace in the Middle East."
"We know it's an incredible opportunity, in regards to Ukraine, we're gonna have this week, and I expect to use that," Cardin said.
President Joe Biden announced his nominations for U.S. representatives to the U.N. on Sept. 9. Along with Cardin, Biden nominated Sen. Dan Sullivan, R-Alaska, former Biden-Harris campaign official Tanya Leigh Flores and Michael Trager, vice chairman of the State Department's Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board.
"Currently serving as chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Cardin has worked across party lines to further U.S. national security and to ensure that democracy, anti-corruption, transparency, good governance and respect for civil and human rights are integrated into American actions at home and abroad," the White House said in a statement.
Cardin served as a U.S. representative to the U.N. General Assembly in 2014 after being nominated by President Barack Obama.
The assembly opened on Sept. 10 and will continue until Sept. 28, with meetings among high-level government officials beginning on Tuesday. The General Assembly convenes once a year, and this year's theme is "Leaving no one behind: acting together for the advancement of peace, sustainable development and human dignity for present and future generations."
Member states at the assembly will discuss a variety of issues, from rising sea levels to artificial intelligence and equitable financing for low-income countries.
"I'm honored to have President Biden's trust to represent our country at the United Nations General Assembly," Cardin said in a tweet on Sept. 10. "Looking forward to productive, unifying conversations."
The Senate has yet to vote to confirm the U.N. nominations but Cardin said his responsibilities were not "terribly contingent upon confirmation," so he can join the delegation.
"I have my credentials as United States senator, chairman of Senate Foreign Relations Committee," he said. "There's not any official action I will take, because I'm a member of our delegation. It's just to work with our delegation. I don't have to give up my day job."
Biden has addressed the UN each fall of his presidency, and Cardin expects him to address the body again next week.

title: Clear choice for US senator
author: Staff Writer
content:
Clear choice for US senator

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 306
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Based on his duties and performance as Maryland's governor, Larry Hogan is the clear choice for U.S. senator.As governor, Mr. Hogan appointed some 80 judges. He was lauded in March 2022 in no less than the Washington Post for the selections he made and the process he used in assuring diverse and highly qualified candidates for both lower and appellate state courts. As head of the National Governor's Association during the pandemic, he was a very effective leader and spokesperson for the nation's governors, both Republican and Democratic. He worked effectively with leaders of all stripes, including two presidents.
He governed with the money he had, left the state with a surplus, and kept his pledges to Marylanders on taxes and abortion. He improved Maryland business climate rankings. He reacted to the disastrous defunding the police movement by refunding local police. He implemented a school choice program for lower income, underserved students. He left the state far better than he found it.
By contrast, it's hard to discern much about his opponent as Prince George's County executive that compares to Hogan's credentials unless you embrace identity politics. Her school system dwells near the bottom of most rankings. Hers was the last school system to reopen for in-person instruction in the pandemic. She reallocated funding for a proposed police training facility. Violent crime has increased. The current Prince George's state's attorney and Maryland attorney general both endorsed her opponent in the Democratic primary.
We know Mr. Hogan will be a fiercely independent and a reasoned voice in the Senate regardless of who is elected president and will bring people together to find common ground to benefit Maryland. On the other hand, Ms. Alsobrooks, given her continual fawning over the vice president as her mentor, will probably be a mere rubber stamp for Vice President Harris if elected.
EUGENE T. LAUER
Cambridge

title: Sept. 10 debate is history, but the hype goes on
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Sept. 10 debate is history, but the hype goes on

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 747
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first and perhaps only debate for the 2024 presidential general election that was held on September 10th is history.Throughout their long history these debates have always experienced pre-debate and post-debate disagreements.
After one of the first of three televised presidential debates in 1960, there was disagreement on the winner. A majority of voters who watched that debate on television responded in a post-debate survey that John F. Kennedy won. A majority of voters who listened to that debate on the radio responded in a post-debate survey that Nixon won.
Prior to the most recent debate, the Harris campaign adamantly refused to consider an offer from Fox News to host a debate, an offer strongly favored by the Trump campaign.
This year's on-again, off-again debate between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris sponsored by ABC did have a happy ending for many voters. They were happy when the pre-debate hype and the actual debate ended.
While the pre-debate hype and actual debate are over, there have been and will continue to be intense discussions about the Sept. 10 debate between the candidates and their most steadfast supporters.
Topics for the post-debate debates include, but are not limited to: who won, why they won, who lost, why they lost, the fairness of the moderators, the questions posed to each candidate by the moderators, incomplete candidate answers to certain questions from the moderators, the body language of the moderators, one moderator's recent acknowledgement that he chose to aggressively pursue fact-checking a number of Trump's answers during the debate, the validity of his fact-checking observations during the debate, the need for at least one more debate, and even the earrings worn by Kamala Harris during the debate.
Not surprisingly, in many cases, the varied answers to those post-debate debate questions are the result of the thinking on political messaging by communications guru Frank Luntz and two published works in the Washington Post on trust in the media. These observations have appeared in previous commentaries of mine, but all bear repeating here.
Luntz has observed: "It's not what you say or write, it is what people hear or read. You can have the best message in the world, but the person on the receiving end will always understand it through the prism of their own emotions, preconceptions, prejudices and preexisting beliefs."
No doubt the Trump campaign is fully aware of and will work hard to widely distribute the following recent and scathing observations by the Washington Post Editorial Board, and Washington Post columnist Philip Bloom that I referenced in a previous commentary.
The Post's editorial board cited a recent Post and Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University survey reporting only three in 10 residents of six of the most important states in this year's presidential election trust the media will fairly and accurately report political news. Bump recently wrote in the Post: "Americans simply don't trust the media, particularly when it comes to politics."
If and how those Washington Post observations may be viewed by voters remains to be seen.
The same is true on the news on a second assassination attempt on Donald Trump.
We know every political campaign will have unexpected opportunities and unexpected challenges. The question is always when and how will they play out.
For Donald Trump, an unexpected opportunity (now moot) was having President Joe Biden as his opponent when it was increasingly clear Biden was past his political prime.
For Donald Trump, an unexpected challenge was a debate where Kamala Harris exceeded expectations.
For Kamala Harris, an unexpected challenge was launching a presidential campaign on short notice.
For Kamala Harris, an unexpected opportunity was a debate where she branded herself as a viable presidential candidate.
Before the debate, some polls showed Trump leading Harris in all key battleground states.
After the debate, some polls polling in some of those battleground states showed Harris leading Trump in some of the key battleground states.
Neither of the polls projected enough state wins to clinch victory in the Electoral College.
The bottom line is the outcome of their Sept. 10 debate alone is not predictive of the November election outcome.
The voters who decide who prevails in November will not be significantly impacted by who won or who lost a 90-minute debate held in mid-September.
I expect most independent and undecided voters will vote based on their perceptions on which candidate cares most about their deepest concerns and who best articulates a positive and achievable vision for the future.
As always, one and only one candidate will ultimately enjoy a happy ending in the upcoming presidential election. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the recent presidential debate and its political implications, which is a matter of national political interest, fitting the 'National News' category.
