title: Meet the new boss: Artificial intelligence (AI) brings a whole new meaning to political machines
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Meet the new boss: Artificial intelligence (AI) brings a whole new meaning to political machines

 September 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1175
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Vic Miller is in the matrix of artificial intelligence's intersection with politics and governance.Miller ran for mayor of Cheyenne, Wyoming, in August, finishing a distant fourth in the race.Miller's campaign centered on his plan to turn local governing decisions over to an AI-created system called VIC (Virtual Integrated Citizen).
Miller's AI-run for local office drew international attention. He said views of AI are still frequently defined by dystopian science fiction movies with Orwellian outcomes.
"There is a learning curve that hasn't been achieved yet," he said.
Miller said his AI goal is to prioritize public feedback and rational governance and rebuild public trust.
"I'm looking to get politicians out of democracy," Miller said.
Miller said he is looking at a future AI run for Cheyenne City Council, and he expects to see others look at bringing machine learning to governance.
"The toothpaste is out of the tube," he said.
But Miller is concerned about who will be able to access and use AI going forward.
He created VIC via ChatGPT's Open AI, but was booted from that platform over using the Microsoft-backed artificial intelligence technology for political purposes.
"What I didn't do is read their huge terms of service," Miller said.
He hopes the future of AI sits with open-source technology, rather than being controlled by large players. He said if the latter happens, it will be a "horror show" that will create a technological "caste system."
Miller has created the Rational Governance Alliance to foster open-source use of AI for data and public driven governance. Miller is looking to raise $10,000 to get the effort going.
That is a stark contrast to the big technology corporations and big money in the AI space.
The largest corporations in the AI space include six of the largest companies in the world (Apple, Microsoft, NVDIA, Amazon, Alphabet/Google and Meta/Facebook). They have a combined value of $15 trillion, according to CompaniesMarketCap.com.
'SCARY GREAT'
While Miller is focused on proving "the viability" of AI governance, for others, AI generates worries about misinformation and manipulation.
"It has become easier than ever to manipulate source material, create propaganda and influence narratives," said Isaac Mashman, founder of Mashman Consulting Group (a Little Rock, Arkansas-based consulting and branding firm), noting the amplified conservations around misinformation and "fake news" this campaign cycle.
Lou Steinberg, founder and managing partner of CTM Insights, a New York-based cyber research lab, said AI enable individuals to create convincing images and videos, and institutional and govern- mental actors to take their information and disinformation – dissemination to a mass production level.
"We've been using all open-source models, and they were great; Like, scary, great," Steinberg said.
He noted one of the AI voice fakes his group made of a foreign leader cost $20 to make and took a couple of man hours. "It no longer takes Pentagon-level resources," Steinberg said.
Miller said he spent limited money developing VIC via a $20 monthly ChatGPT subscription, but spent "hundreds of hours" feeding his creation documents and information.
Steinberg said there are also productive uses, pointing to India, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi used AI to translate his speeches and other campaign content into various languages and dialects.
"Better communication, better outreach, without subtitles. You can train these models to sound just like a voice. In fact, it only takes, you know, a couple hours of training time and a relatively small amount of video," Steinberg said, noting they don't look as awkward as past dubs.
He said there is a penchant to try to spot deep fakes and manipulated content.
"That's a fool's errand," said Steinberg, the former CTO at TD Ameritrade, stressing the focus should be on confirming what is real, rather thantrying to figure out what is fake.
Mashman said as AI technology improves and more creators adopt it, it will get harder and harder to discern "what is real and what is fake."
Cody Buntain, an assistant professor of information and cybersecurity at the University of Maryland, recommends increased due diligence for election-year content.
"When it comes to the 2024 election, don't take a single piece of information at face value. Always consider the source and how it fits in the broader picture," Buntain said.
While some AI applications will ban users who produce politically oriented content, there are scores of applications to choose from across the growing space.
"Generative AI is almost entirely unregulated, and there are countless platforms available for any person to use, so virtually anyone can create political misinformation with the help of AI," said Edward Tian, CEO of GPTZero, a New York-based AI detection company.
There are measures at the state level, especially in California, and proposals in Congress related to AI-generated content, especially so-called "deep-fake" pornography.
Some content created via AI enjoys First Amendment free speech protections in the U.S., especially parody or opinion. There are instances where prosecutors could pursue AI creators under election interference or fraud statutes.
Democratic presidential candidate Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz said in an August interview "misinformation and hate speech" do not enjoy First Amendment protections, sparking push back from speech advocates.
Scott Dylan, founder of NexaTech Ventures (a Silicon Valley-based, AI-focused venture capital firm), said laws and lawmakers are playing catch up to the AI wave.
"The political system, particularly candidates and officeholders, seems ill-equipped to fully grasp the depth of AI's influence," he said, noting that privacy and other laws will have to play catch up to all the changes.
Despite AI's reach and potential impacts on jobs, it has not been at the forefront in the U.S. elections, including the presidential campaign.
'DATA DRIVEN'
Dylan said AI is already a "transformative and disruptive' force behind the political curtains.
"Campaigns are increasingly leveraging AI tools to personalize voter outreach, optimize resource allocation, and enhance messaging," Dylan said.
He is seeing campaigns using AI to analyze social media trends, predict voter behaviors and maximize fundraising.
"Political groups are using machine learning to identify funding patterns, which helps them allocate resources more efficiently," Dylan said.
U.S. political campaigns are predicted to spend a record $10.7 billion on campaign ads this election (up 19% from 2020), according to research firm AdImpact LLC.
Neil Sahota, CEO of ACSILabs, a San Diego-based AI firm, who is also an artificial intelligence advisor to the United Nations, said political and campaign operatives view AI as "an indispensable tool" to gain a "competitive edge."
He points to both presidential camps and other political entities using AI for micro-targeting of voters and advertising buys — and machine-driven analyses of polling numbers.
The machines are also helping campaigns with speeches, social media and other content.
"Natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning algorithms assist campaigns in generating speeches, social media posts, and advertisements that align with their messaging strategy," said Sahota, who sees even more AI in politics going forward, including more use of augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR).
BIG BROTHER
But Sahota and Dylan also see voters concerned about privacy and groups surveilling their social media posts and online behaviors.
That gets back into the Big Brother dystopian worries referenced by Miller in Wyoming.
Dylan said voters might not like the sausage-making of AI-dominated politics.
"Many voters are wary of how their personal data is being harvested, analyzed and used by AI to predict their political leanings or behaviors," Dylan said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the broader impact of artificial intelligence on political campaigns, governance, misinformation, and regulation across the United States, which aligns best with a national news focus rather than a purely local or business‑specific angle.

title: Experts see AI contributing to misinformation
author: SHAUN CHORNOBROFF Capital News Service
content:
Experts see AI contributing to misinformation

 September 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SHAUN CHORNOBROFF Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1033
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — As millions of Americans prepare to cast their ballots in the election, the federal government has done little to mitigate public fears surrounding the potential influence of artificial intelligence (AI) deepfakes.Despite multiple bipartisan bills being introduced in both the Senate and the House, Congress has yet to enact any legislation and is unlikely to do so before the election.
"Those tools are being used to mislead voters about elections and spread falsehoods about candidates," Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Connecticut, said last week during an AI-focused hearing by the Senate Judiciary Committee's privacy, technology, and the law subcommittee. Blumenthal chairs the panel.
An Elon University survey in May found that more than three-quarters of Americans believe AI abuses will affect the outcome of the presidential election.
Capital News Service talked to multiple experts in AI and politics who explained that, while there are concerns surrounding AI, the evolving technology changing the outcome of elections is not among them.
"Will AI potentially convince some voters to vote for one candidate instead of another? Maybe," said Dr. Keegan McBride, an AI, government and policy expert at the Oxford Internet Institute at the University of Oxford. "Will they be able to convince a couple hundred thousand voters in Pennsylvania that they should vote for candidate A instead of Candidate B? Probably not."
AI has already made its presence known in the 2024 presidential election cycle.
In June 2023, a video shared by the campaign team for one-time Republican presidential candidate and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis showed a fake photo of former President Donald Trump hugging Dr. Anthony Fauci, the former director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and former chief medical advisor to the president.
Trump also posted AI images on Truth Social in August of singer Taylor Swift and her fans supposedly endorsing him. Swift endorsed Democratic nominee Kamala Harris after the Sept. 10 debate between Harris and Trump.
Most notably, robocalls in New Hampshire impersonated President Joe Biden and discouraged citizens from voting in the state's January primary. Steven Kramer, a political consultant, admitted to masterminding the plan and is facing 26 criminal charges, as well as a $6 million fine from the Federal Communications Commission (FCC).
The agency ruled on Feb. 8 that AI-generated voices used in robocalls are illegal.
"We're putting the fraudsters behind these robocalls on notice," FCC Chairwoman Jessica Rosenworcel said.
While these instances drew widespread coverage, Dr. Cody Buntain, an assistant professor at the University of Maryland's College of Information, said the examples the public has seen thus far haven't had the intended effect.
"They're notable because they weren't convincing and no one bought them," Buntain said. "Very quickly the country and the news media jumped on them, said, 'This is totally not legit,' and we've sort of all agreed with that."
While swaying the results of the election was not a prevalent concern with any of the experts, each said AI has the potential to fuel further public distrust of government and the political system.
Peter Loge, the founding director of the Project on Ethics in Political Communication at The George Washington University's School of Media and Public Affairs, has more than three decades of experience in politics.
When he first started out in the industry, campaigns were cutting and pasting images. That changed when Photoshop became popular. "It was cutting and pasting, but way better and faster," said Loge.
Generative AI is the latest evolution, he said.
"It's easier to generate garbage than ever before, and it's easier to circulate garbage than ever before," Loge said. "Making up stuff about your opponents, making up news stories, doctoring photographs, deepfakes — lies aren't new."
For decades, trust in the federal government has been eroding. In 1964, 77% of people said they trusted the government, according to the Pew Research Center. Sixty years later, that number sits at 22%.
The inability to distinguish truth from generative AI has the potential to exacerbate this trend, multiple experts said.
On Aug. 7, Harris and her running mate, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, held a rally in Detroit, Michigan, where a photo of an estimated 15,000-person crowd circulated on social media. Four days later, Trump said on Truth Social that the photos were AI-generated.
The photo was authentic, but Loge believes that Trump's false AI claim represents a major problem.
"You get to claim that the real is fake because everybody believes that everything's being faked anyway, and that increases cynicism," Loge said. "It decreases confidence in campaigns and democracy, all of which is very bad."
In lieu of federal legislation regarding AI and the election, individual states have sought to address the matter. At least 19 states have passed laws since 2019 regulating the use of AI in political messaging, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.
In Maryland, six state lawmakers in February proposed legislation requiring campaigns to disclose the use of artificial intelligence for political materials.
The bill, which was similar to those passed in a number of other states, saw no action in this year's legislative session.
"We need a disclosure if there's an image. We need a disclosure if there's media. We need a disclosure if there's audio," Del. Anne Kaiser (D-Montgomery County) said during a Feb. 27 committee hearing. "This bill would codify Maryland's election law."
With the Congress scheduled to go on an election break next week, it's becoming increasingly likely that there will be more consequence-free AI ads and deepfakes before Election Day.
House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-Louisiana, told Axios on Thursday that he wants Congress to adopt a laissez-faire approach to AI for the time being.
"We got to build consensus on what the right approach is, but I think you'll see a lot of emphasis on that in the first quarter of next year," Johnson said.
While AI is unlikely to influence the result of the election, Buntain did offer a potential doomsday scenario come November if the vote tally is close.
"If people are uncertain about the outcome of the election, and there's a certain cohort of the population who already don't have a lot of trust in the electoral process," he said, "then the use of AI In particular manipulated imagery has a much more risky potential to at least get people out into the streets and stir up feelings of anger and resentment and mobilize people." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses AI-driven misinformation in the context of a federal election, congressional action, and nationwide political impact, which aligns best with the broader scope of national news rather than a more specific category.

title: Breaking barriers: Access has improved, but challenges persist for voters with disabilities
author: MIke Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Breaking barriers: Access has improved, but challenges persist for voters with disabilities

 September 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIke Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: National 
 
 1280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 People with disabilities make up 13% of the U.S. population, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics and U.S. Census Bureau.That's more than 42 million people.
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control has an even broader estimate, which includes more persons with cognitive and mobility issues.
According to the CDC, 28.7% of Americans have physical, cognitive or mobility disabilities.
Whether it's 13% or more than one-in-four Americans, persons with disability also make up a sizable — and frequently ignored — voting bloc as the November elections loom.
"All Americans have the right to vote for candidates and issues that are important to them, and people with disabilities have a lot at stake as what is decided in November can greatly impact their day-to-day lives," said Claire Manning, senior director of advocacy and mobilization at The Arc (an organization which helps and represents those with developmental disabilities).
BARRIERS TO VOTINGAccording to analyses by Rutgers University, persons with disabilities made up 17.7% of the electorate in 2020.
That was on par with Blacks (18.5%) and more than the Hispanics' (16.5%) share in the 2020 elections, according to Rutgers.
But 11 million disabled adults didn't vote in the 2020 election — making up 14.2% of nonvoters in the last presidential election.
Manning said disabled voters are a big enough block to sway the tight November elections — but they face continued barriers to voting.
"People with disabilities have always faced unacceptable barriers to casting their vote, and they continue to in 2024," Manning said. "This means they've been less likely than people without disabilities to turn out to vote in elections."
According to Rutgers' analyses, voter turnout among persons with disability in 2020 was 8.4% lower than among persons without disabilities. Turnout rates among persons with cognitive disabilities and mobility challenges were 25% lower than the non-disabled population.
In some parts of the country, voters with disabilities were more than 20% less likely to vote than voters without disabilities.
That includes Maryland where persons with disabilities are 20.9% less likely to vote than persons without disabilities. In Delaware, people with disabilities were 14.9% less likely to vote in 2020 and those without special needs.
Even with the Americans with Disabilities Act, which has been in place since 1992, some polling places have accessibility issues, said Anna Anderson, voting rights coordinator with Disability Rights Wisconsin.
Anderson points to polling places at schools, churches and other locations that might have challenges with steps, hallways, parking and voters being able to adequately use accessible voting machines.
Manning said pushback against mail-in voting and ballot drop boxes over concerns about fraud work against voters with disabilities.
She also said guardianship laws, lack of visual and audio voting aids and restrictions on who can help a disabled person cast ballots are also impediments.
Anderson said mail-in curbside voting and drop boxes are a big help for disabled voters. "There are never too many options that can exist to help people vote," she said.
Anderson would like to see disabled voters to be able to cast ballots from home. "One of the things that could be the most helpful is to allow people to vote electronically from their homes," she said.
Anderson said persons with disabilities can feel stigmatized voting when they draw extra attention or if poll workers are not properly trained or aware of protocols.
LEGAL ACTIONDRWI has also filed a complaint against Thornapple Township over the Wisconsin locality's move to remove an accessible electronic voting machine for this year's election.
On Sept. 20, the U.S. Department of Justice also filed a complaint against Thornapple in federal court over the action saying it violates the Help America Vote Act (HAVA), a 2002 federal law that requires polling places to be equipped with at least one voting machine that is accessible to voters with disabilities during federal elections.
Thornapple has a population of approximately 800 people and is located in the northern part of Wisconsin — 126 miles from Minneapolis.
Township officials have not yet responded to a request for comment.
DOJ also said it resolved a similar dispute with the town of Lawrence, the agency said.
That town — which along Thornapple is located in Rusk County and is about 150 miles east of Minneapolis— has agreed to install a disability accessible voting machine for the upcoming presidential election.
"Our democracy works when voters with disabilities have the right to vote on the same terms as any other voter," said Assistant Attorney General Kristen Clarke. "By failing to offer accessible voting systems, Thornapple and Lawrence shirked their responsibilities under the Help America Vote Act to provide equal access to the ballot for all voters."
Stacy Zimmer, who served on the Lawrence township board up until earlier this month, said the accessible voting machine was not used in a state election earlier this year and he contends Wisconsin law gives localities that option.
He was frustrated by outside groups' involvement in the issue in the small town of approximately 400 people
Charidy Ludescher said there will be one accessible voting machine at the township's one polling place in November.
'REASONABLE MODIFICATIONS'Sara Kempner, campaigns and strategic collaboration coordinator with the U.S. Vote Foundation, said the HAVA law has helped improve the voting landscape for disabled Americans.
"The 2002 Help America Vote Act (HAVA) has stipulated that the entire process of voting — from registering to casting ballots — must be made accessible,' she said.
"Voters can ask for reasonable modifications. This includes requesting curbside voting, skipping the line, or the opportunity to sit in a chair if standing is difficult. If one's assigned polling location can't meet these needs, voters can ask to be reassigned to a polling location that can," she said.
Kempner said the accessible voting system requirement "means voters with print disabilities may use screen readers. Voters with motor skill disabilities may use touchscreens or sip and puff devices."
HAVA also allows voters with disabilities to receive voting assistance, as long as it is not their boss or union leader.
Kempner said the law has helped shrink the turnout gap between disabled and non-disabled voters.
In Maryland and Delaware, voters with special needs can request mail-in or absentee ballots with online assistance tools, receive help in voting in-person and there are accessible voting machines at polling places including for persons with impaired or low vision.
In Montana, for example, every polling place has a specialized voting machine to help voters with disabilities vote privately. Curbside voting is also available, Voters with special needs can also get assistance filling out ballots from election judges or a designated friend or relative.
VITAL ISSUES
Still, Kempner sees challenges.
"Many polling locations are not yet fully compliant with HAVA standards. Sometimes the accessible voting systems sit unopened in boxes. Poll workers have not been adequately trained on rights and procedures," said Kempner, stressing the need for more awareness of disability voting rights.
Anderson said curbside voting for those with special needs is also helpful and that her group is working with nonprofits, community and churches to help disabled and mobility challenged voters get rides to the polls on Election Day.
She said that is easier in bigger cities such as Madison and Milwaukee.
"In rural areas, it's much more difficult to provide transportation," Anderso said.
Manning would like to see disabled voters and the issues that impact them more present during the 2024 campaign.
"The disability vote is powerful. Yet all too often, people with disabilities and the issues vital to them and their loved ones are absent from candidate debates, interviews, and media coverage," she said.
Manning said the general public is "overwhelmingly unaware of the experiences of people with disabilities in this country" and how elected officials approach various programs have big impacts.
"They decide how government programs like Medicaid, Social Security, and Special Education, which are vital to the independence and futures of people with disabilities, function and are funded," Manning said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses nationwide voting rights issues for people with disabilities, legal actions, and federal legislation, which aligns best with the broader scope of national news rather than a specific local, health, or other category.

title: Read Project 2025
author: Staff Writer
content:
Read Project 2025

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 388
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mary-Eileen Russell wrote to the Star Democrat that she had not even heard of Project 2025 "until recently."Ms. Russell, you wrote that only a Marxist would describe Project 2025 as "fascist" or "bourgeois." So I infer that you have read it. Am I right? If you haven't, you might try searching for some of your favorite topics in the .pdf file of Project 2025. (It took a while for them to release a searchable file. Now why is that?)
Thirty-one of its authors served in the Trump administration, among them Peter Navarro, just home from four months in prison for contempt of Congress. Missing from their ranks are the military leaders who served under Trump, and warn of the dangers of a second Trump administration — James Mattis, Mark Milley — along with an ever-growing number of those who served in the Trump White House — John Kelly, John Bolton. Are they alarmists?
Are your liberal friends alarmists? I don't think so. Even Donald Trump got alarmed about Project 2025. You can find videos in which he disavows any connection with it. (That's after someone told him what's hidden away in its 922 pages of turgid prose). But watch Donald Trump's speech at the annual leadership conference of the Heritage Society in April 2022. At that time — with no knowledge of what it was — he was all in. Have you ever seen Trump deny he ever knew someone or something? Or have you seen it over and over and over again?
I fault your liberal friends for having skipped to the bottom line and told you "it's the end of democracy." I think they should have said, "Let's define Marxism, then fascism and then the bourgeoisie." There are podcasts by scholars and journalists, like Timothy Snyder and Anne Applebaum, who have studied 20th century history and can tell you all about Marxism and fascism and the role of the bourgeoisie. I'd keep in mind, though, that there are the bourgeois and there are the bourgeois. Seriously.
There are news commentators who — bless them — have read all of Project 2025 and can tell you what's in it and give you chapter titles and page numbers so that you can check what they are saying for yourself.
Ms. Russell, I wrote this because you said you were curious.
MARGARET BARTON DRIGGS
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Our military veterans and heroes deserve respect
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
Our military veterans and heroes deserve respect

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 456
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There was a memorial recognition in Poland on Sept. 1 commemorating what is usually noted as the beginning of the Second World War when Nazi Germany invaded Poland in 1939. That long and terrible war would involve many members of my family.My father served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific on an antiaircraft gunboat protecting larger ships from air attack. My father-in-law served in the U.S. Army infantry in Germany fighting in the Hürtgen forest and eventually being seriously wounded. My Uncle Ben was part of the 82nd Airborne Division jumping into France on D-Day. (He was also a great football coach, see Syracuse University 1960). I am very proud of all these people; they were all heroes.
Donald Trump, a former president of the United States, does not agree with me. In his own words he sees these people as "losers and suckers" not worthy of his respect or recognition.
Recently this same attitude was on full display when Donald Trump, invited by grieving families, organized a trip with cameras to Arlington Cemetery to visit Section 60 of that cemetery. Section 60 is reserved for fallen heroes from Iraq and Afghanistan. Arlington Cemetery specifically prohibits using the cemetery for political purposes.
An employee of the cemetery tried to prevent Trump and his staff from filming his political campaign video but was pushed aside. The U.S. Army has subsequently condemned Trump's actions and firmly defended the employee's actions. The employee has declined to press charges citing fear of harassment from Trump's supporters.
Mr. Trump recently denigrated those in our military who were awarded the Medal of Honor, our nation's highest military decoration. He described the Presidential Medal of Freedom, which he recently conferred on a wealthy campaign donor, as better because Medal of Honor winners are "in very bad shape because they've been hit so many times by bullets or they're dead." Our military says that a Medal of Honor winner may be saluted by any member of the military, regardless of rank. That is the respect due to those who wear this medal.
Then there is the issue of bone spurs. Mr Trump, at age 24, sought to avoid the Vietnam War. He was granted a draft classification that allowed him to avoid service because a doctor friend of his family certified that he suffered from disqualifying bone spurs. His family members have stated that no bone spurs were ever previously mentioned. Yet, he feels free to denigrate those who have served.
Any one of these actions makes you ask the question? Why does anyone want to support this man to be commander in chief of our armed forces? If you served our country in uniform, or you honor those who do, you should not vote for Donald Trump. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

As a result, Alsobrooks wound up not paying thousands of dollars on two properties in Washington, D.C., and Maryland.

So, based upon that investigation, voters may need pause and take a hard look to determine that if Angela Alsobrooks were to be elected, would she be a senator in the image of St. Mother Teresa, or tax crook in the image of Marilyn Mosby.
Politics … hmmm.

title: How “blue” is Maryland? A closer look at the state’s voting history
author: DYLAN SHULMAN Capital News Service
content:
How “blue” is Maryland? A closer look at the state’s voting history

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DYLAN SHULMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 663
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 2024 election is Donald Trump's third bid for the U.S. presidency, having won in 2016 and lost in 2020. Maryland voted for the Democratic candidate in both cases, and its 10 electoral votes have been considered a given for the Democratic candidate in past general elections.As the 2024 general election nears, Capital News Service examined how Maryland has voted in presidential elections over the past 50 years.
"Maryland as a whole has high levels of education, which is one of the things—but only one of the things—that helps to account for its commitment to the Democrats," said Matthew Crenson, professor emeritus at Johns Hopkins University's political science department.
Other factors Crenson mentioned were that Black voters make up around 30% of Maryland's electorate, as well as large numbers of the Latino community, although the political leanings of the latter demographic are currently in flux.
Current Maryland opinion polls for the 2024 election have Harris ahead of Trump by a significant margin, par for the course in a state that has voted consistently blue for eight presidential elections. According to data from the Maryland State Board of Elections, Maryland voters have chosen only three Republican candidates since the 1960s: Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush.
In 1972, Nixon was an incumbent president who won re-election in a landslide victory, the largest popular vote margin in United States history. Reagan's 1984 victory was another case where the incumbent was an extremely popular candidate. In the following election, Bush narrowly won 51% of the Maryland popular vote.
It's generally agreed that the 2024 election's swing states are Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin; some include North Carolina in the list as well.
Are there "swing" counties in Maryland?Three counties switched sides between the last two elections: Frederick, Kent and Talbot voted for Trump in 2016, but Biden won in those three counties in 2020.
Kent could qualify as a swing county. Voters there chose the Democratic candidate three times out of the last nine elections, and the voting margins were typically small: in four elections, merely a fraction of a percentage point decided the county's popular vote. Kent is also the state's least populous county, with about 19,000 residents, according to 2020 U.S. census data.
"The balance of politics within a small population can change radically with relatively small changes in the population itself," Crenson explained.
Biden won Frederick County by about 10 percentage points in 2020. The three previous general elections in the county were close, with the Republican candidate winning in each case by less than four percentage points. Crenson said that Frederick County is becoming more politically divided as it becomes "a suburb of Washington."
"The result is that federal employees, most of whom vote Democratic, are beginning to populate Frederick County and taking over its electorate," Crenson said.
In fact, the voting habits along the entire I-95 corridor are subject to influence from the nation's capital, Crenson said.
"Government employees tend to have rather high levels of education and recently—that is, within the last 10 or 15 years—people with college degrees have been gravitating toward the Democratic Party," he said.
Maryland voter turnout—the percentage of registered voters who cast a ballot—also took a dip from 74% in 2012 to about 72% in 2016. A change in voter turnout under five percentage points is typical, but 2016 was the lowest voter turnout since 1996, the general election between Democrat Bill Clinton and Republican Bob Dole.
"Neither of the two candidates electrified Maryland," Crenson said.
The 2024 election will be the first general election after the COVID-19 pandemic. For the last election, which took place at the onset of the pandemic, the Maryland State Board of Elections restricted poll voting and encouraged voters to request and complete mail-in ballots, which accounted for a majority of all Maryland ballots.
The results of the 2024 election will establish whether many Marylanders continue to vote by mail or return to the polls. Crenson predicts that mail-in ballots will likely continue to be the avenue for many voters. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes Maryland's voting history and election trends, focusing on presidential elections and political demographics, which aligns with national political news rather than local, economic, or cultural topics.

title: Putin's obsession with Ukraine has deep roots
author: LENA GILL
content:
Putin's obsession with Ukraine has deep roots

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 979
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Vladimir Putin has held continuous positions as president or prime minister of the Russian Federation (Russia) since 1999. Russia's landmass is the largest in the world and has a population of 141.7 million. Putin has amassed a great fortune in these 25 years by robbing the Russian people of their wealth. Now he robs them of their sons, and potentially ours, in a mad military quest to emulate the glory of a Russian ruler who lived 300 years ago.Putin was born in St. Petersburg in 1952. He was a communist who spent 16 years as a KBG agent in former East Germany. When the Soviet Union collapsed, each member country became autonomous. Putin returned to St. Petersburg and was soon appointed the mayor's adviser on international affairs. The mayor lost his reelection in 1996, and Putin moved to Moscow and among other jobs organized the transfer of the former assets of the Soviet Union and Communist party to the Russian Federation.
In 1997 President Boris Yeltsin appointed Putin deputy chief of the presidential staff. In 1998 Yeltsin appointed Putin head of the FSB (the successor organization to the KGB). In 1999 he was appointed acting prime minister of the Russian Federation.
Today, Putin is obsessed with Ukraine, Russia's neighbor and the biggest country in Europe. Putin wants to be considered the new tsar of a greater Russia and become as famous as Peter the Great, as tsar Peter was called after defeating the Swedes and declaring himself the emperor of Russia.
Tsar Peter was ruler of Russia between 1696 and 1725. He wanted access to the Baltic Sea because Russia was landlocked. All the land around the Baltic belonged to the Swedish Empire. He won the battle of Narva in 1704 against the Swedes and occupied the Baltic province of Ingria (today part of Estonia) and Finnish provinces up the Neva River from the Gulf of Finland.
On these wetlands he decided to build a new city, which became St. Petersburg. The warrior/king Charles the XII of Sweden then attacked Russia from Poland where he had led a successful battle against the Polish king. As the Swedish army of 40,000 men pushed toward Moscow, it lost half the army in a year of battles between the two rulers. Tsar Peter won the final battle at Poltava in 1709. Notably Ukrainian Cossacks fought against him on the Swedish side. This was the end of the Great Northern War between the two empires. (Poltava is a small town located in the center of today's Ukraine).
An additional reason why Putin wants to take possession of today's Ukraine is the capital city of Kyiv. It was the first capital of the Rus, precursors to Russia in the ninth century. The city was later called "the Mother of Russia" and is where the Russians first converted to Orthodox Christianity. In comparison, Moscow became the capital of Muscovy in the 13th century, a Russian province. Peter the Great moved the capital from Moscow to St. Petersburg in the 1720s, but in 1918 Lenin moved the capital back to Moscow.
Putin has commented that the Great Northern War ending in Poltava was a struggle over Ukraine between Russia and the West. He sees himself as the tsar of today's expanding Russian empire. Putin first attacked Ukraine in 2014 and slowly took the Donbas region, an industrial region with a large coal field backing onto the Dnieper River.
In addition, Putin sent in his black-shirted soldiers without insignia to take Crimea under false pretenses. Crimea is a tropical peninsula connected to Ukraine by a land bridge and the home of the important naval port, Sevastopol, on the Black Sea. In 2018 Russia built a long bridge across the Azov (inland) Sea in the other direction connecting this peninsula to the Russian mainland.
In 2022 he again attacked Ukraine, now from the north, thinking it would be an easy war, and that he would take Kyiv in weeks. The Ukrainians were able to withstand this attack and retake any land he had acquired in the north. South of the Donbas, Putin took the provinces along the Dnieper leading down to Crimea to allow Russia better access to this important peninsula.
Many believe that if Putin takes Ukraine, he will not stop there. The three Baltic states and Poland are the next prime targets, and they are all members of NATO. If he attacks one of these states, all members of NATO including the U.S. will have to send young soldiers to fight him, and we may end up with another World War.
Donald Trump and members of Congress seem to admire Vladimir Putin, this communist dictator whose power has gone to his head. According to what he says, Donald Trump does not seem to understand that it is better to send money and munitions made in the U.S. than our soldiers to protect our democracy. As George Will writes in his column in the Washington Post: "U.S. credibility, the coin that purchases deterrence, depends on the success of Ukraine, which does the dying".
We must also not forget that when Ukraine declared its independence from the Soviet Union in 1991, it held the third largest arsenal of nuclear weapons in the world. The U.S., Russia and European nations encouraged Ukraine to move these weapons to Russia for safekeeping and destruction, stripping Ukraine of the ultimate guarantee of their sovereignty. Ukraine agreed reluctantly and in 1994 joined the nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty as a non-nuclear weapon state. In exchange the U.S. and Russia promised economic support and security assurances.
Russia reneged, and the outcome of our presidential election will determine if the U.S. reneges on its promise.
If Donald Trump wins the November election, the result for Ukraine would be catastrophic. Trump has said that he can end the war in 24 hours, meaning that he will give Putin a free hand and no more help for Ukraine from the U.S. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses geopolitical events, Russian aggression, and U.S. political implications, which are core subjects of national news coverage.

title: Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories
author: LINDA EVANS
content:
Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LINDA EVANS | Section: Columns 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Editor's note: This column originally appeared in the Star Democrat on Oct. 17, 2021. It is repeated here after Jimmy Carter celebrated his 100th birthday this week.It was the mid-seventies and I was a young Washington, D.C., Republican staffer with the rare opportunity to work as a personal assistant for the Honorable and Mrs. George Romney (Mitt Romney's parents).
Pretty exciting for a farm girl from the Eastern Shore of Maryland. When the Romneys invited me out to formal occasions, as a member of their staff, I was occasionally mistaken for Mitt's sister, Lynn.
It was cherry blossom time, and a longtime friend who drove me to the Tidal Basin that day happened to be an employee of the Secret Service. As we walked around the Tidal Basin, a long, black limousine pulled up and my friend yelled, "It's the president."
I nonchalantly responded, "The President of what? What company?"
He repeated, "It's President Carter! It's Carter!
As a government employee, he knew to position us near where the president's car door would open, with the idea of taking a photograph of the president, if possible. When President Carter emerged from the limousine, I was indeed one of the first in line, and even though I was a staunch Romney Republican, I did what any American would do, outstretched my hand and shook the hand of the president of the United States. Many would be lost for words at that point, but I somehow found the presence of mind to say sincerely, "Thank you for being our president."
President Carter, apparently touched by my sincerity, thanked me. My friend had his old Polaroid camera with him and asked the president if he would mind posing for a photo. The president quickly agreed, and then said to no one in particular: "Isn't she beautiful?"
What a compliment for me. I smiled for my friend's camera and that was the end of the exchange; my friend and I were off to tour the cherry blossoms with hundreds, possibly thousands of others that evening.
The Polaroids turned out so-so, but my friend, being politically minded, said he had seen White House photographers there. In fact, since I had my new black velour jacket over my arm, he said he felt the Secret Servicemen were carefully watching me for the president's safety.
"Why don't you call the White House and see if any of them got you on film?" he suggested. What an outlandish thought, but tempting. The next day, I looked up the White House switchboard number and hesitantly dialed 212-456-1414, and asked for the White House press secretary, as I had been instructed by my friend.
"Hello, this is Karl Schumaker," the voice on the phone answered with a German accent. Since I am also of German descent, we had something in common. I said, "Sir, you won't believe it, but the president of the United States told me I was beautiful yesterday at the Tidal Basin. "
Pause.
"What were you wearing?" he asked.
"I was wearing a pink jumpsuit and pink scarf."
"You are beautiful," Karl said. "I have three photographs of you. Would you like me to mail them to you or would you like to come to the White House and pick them up this week?"
I chose the date of Thursday that week because my sister would be in town, and we not only got autographed photos that day, but a tour of the Oval Office and presidential memorabilia. I showed the photos to our parents and then I filed them in my big, old file cabinet, with only one of the photos on my office wall, seen by almost no one. I'm still a Romney Republican and always will be, but also a Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter fan.
And a fan of someone else in the White House, the Press Secretary Karl Schumaker, who would teach the importance of customer service and taking extra time out to make memories that have lasted over 40 years. It was President Carter's birthday on Oct. 1 (he turned 100), and he received the Nobel Peace Prize also on Oct. 11 (in 2002), which reminded me of this occasion.
"To this day, Jimmy Carter looks back on a life of faith and service, and ahead to a more peaceful world," Mark K. Updegrove wrote in an article titled "Building a Better World," found in in Parade Magazine, Feb. 18, 2018. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a personal recollection of former President Jimmy Carter, a figure of national significance, and mentions his 100th birthday, fitting best under the National News category.

title: Easily refuted lies
author: Staff Writer
content:
Easily refuted lies

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox

 Words

 In response to the opinionated letter from Sandy Weiland, I find it hard to believe that she is so misinformed that she actually believes the mistruths she attributes to the Biden-Harris administration.If there were a grain of truth to anything in that letter, I would agree that the issues should be given a platform. title: Misleading statements and falsehoods
author: Staff Writer
content:
Misleading statements and falsehoods

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 393
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ms. Wieland's recent letter, which you labeled as, "We need strong leadership," was not long, but contained a huge number misleading statements and falsehoods. In that regard, it was impressive.She opens the letter asking if anyone other than her thinks the White House is devoid of leadership. Clearly this a joke. She should have put "LOL" after the question. Tens of millions of Trump supporters agree with her. Fortunately for America, more tens of millions don't agree. Trump has never won the popular vote and won't in the election.
Ms. Wieland then goes on to cite a series of alternative facts that are mostly not true. Kamala never said defund the police, never said she wants to give "illegals" all they want, never said she does not like Israel, never said she's going to take away Ms. Wieland's sacred guns. Here's a joke. How do you label someone who writes untruths? A Republican. (LOL)
Her closing wish is most ironic. She says she hopes Putin does not read her letter, so he does not learn what a mess America is in. Duh? This is like me saying, "I hope no one reads this, but Trump has romantic feelings for Putin." LOL. That's a joke because he only wrote love letters to the dictator of North Korea.
Finally, she calls for "strong leadership." Trump only thinks dictators are strong. Recently he said Putin is "at the top of his game." China is strong under a dictator Trump said he envies. The weak, according to Trump, are the United States military that are "suckers and losers" for defending America. All women are weak and liars, and they need him as a "protector" to make them happy. Jews are weak and may cost him the election. Immigrants are weak. People of color are weak and only work in "Black jobs." Christians who promote the love of Christ are weak. (In contrast to Christian Nationalists who promote hate and power.)
"Hey, Putin, listen up," Trump also says America is weak.
Trump is a coward. He is a bully, and bullies are cowards. His daddy got him out of service during Vietnam. All the sane military flag officers that served under him have written books about how stupid, reckless and cowardly he is.
Don't vote for Trump for strong leadership. Vote for Trump if you want a stupid coward as our dictator.
MICHAEL DAVIS

title: Hogan and Alsobrooks face off in debate
author: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service
content:
Hogan and Alsobrooks face off in debate

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1034
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OWINGS MILLS — The issue of Republican Senate hopeful Larry Hogan's party allegiance took center stage in his first, and perhaps only, debate with Democratic opponent Angela Alsobrooks on Thursday.As he has throughout his campaign, Hogan, who moderator Chuck Todd mentioned was recruited to run by Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) spent much of the debate distancing himself from the GOP on several issues and attempting to establish himself as an independent.
"You're going to hear nothing but red versus blue," Hogan, the former Maryland governor, said early in the debate, which was televised on Maryland Public Television, WBAL in Baltimore and WRC in Washington Thursday at 7 p.m. "I care a lot more about the red, white and blue."
Hogan also pointedly rejected the premise of being a party-line Republican, saying he has a "proven track record" of standing up to former President Donald Trump, McConnell and the Republican Party. He also said the country needs more "mavericks" in the Senate.
Alsobrooks, for her part, took aim at those claims. Specifically, she asserted that Hogan's personal stance on abortion, and his promises to support the codification of Roe v. Wade, wouldn't matter if the Republicans gain control of the Senate.
"I believe the governor when he said that he would like to vote with Roe," said Alsobrooks, currently Prince George's County executive. "But, you know what? The fact is, if the Republicans have a majority in the Senate, there will be no vote on Roe."
Foreign policyThe through line of partisanship continued as the debate shifted to foreign policy, and specifically the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
When questioned about her stance on the conflict, Alsbrooks echoed the position held by many national-level Democrats, emphasizing both her support for Israel and her concerns surrounding the humanitarian crisis in Gaza and the need for a two-state solution.
"I believe in this moment, we have an obligation to make sure that we're getting those hostages home to their families," Alsobrooks said, referring to hostages taken by Hamas during an attack on Israel on Oct. 7 last year, "and that we get to a ceasefire, making sure that…we get aid into Gaza for the Palestinians who are suffering."
Hogan used his time expressing unequivocal support for Israel, a view he has repeated throughout the campaign. He noted he did not differ with the retiring Democrat whose seat he and Alsobrooks are campaigning for.
"I'm going to be a strong supporter of Israel, as I always have been," Hogan said, "and I'm going to be more like a champion for Israel, like Ben Cardin."
The Supreme CourtAs the debate shifted to the topic of the Supreme Court, Alsobrooks pushed for reform of the nation's highest court, referencing term limits or expansion of the number of justices.
"I think we're going to have to do something to reform the Supreme Court," Alsobrooks said. "Again, looking at the decisions they've made, everything from overturning Roe, I think there are ethical problems with the Supreme Court."
Alsobrooks went on to say, "this is another place where me and Mr. Hogan disagree."
Hogan did draw a contrast between his position and that of his opponent, saying that the pushes for reform are politically motivated.
"I think if there's one thing that we should not be politicizing, it's the Supreme Court," Hogan said, "and yet it has been politicized by both sides. And I think trying to change the rules to jam things through on a party-line vote is not the right way to go about it."
AbortionAs it has been throughout the campaign, abortion was a major issue in the debate.
One difference between the two candidates was their strategies for passing legislation to codify Roe v. Wade, the right to an abortion.
Alsobrooks advocated abolishing the filibuster, a Senate procedure that allows debate on a measure to continue until 60 senators vote to stop it. Many critics of the Senate, including some senators, consider the filibuster an impediment to passing bills that have the support of a majority of lawmakers.
"We've seen the filibuster has been used in ways that have been very destructive, and it really has not been in the interest of the people," Alsobrooks said.
Hogan, in response, cited bipartisanship in his opposition to removing the filibuster.
"I like the idea of continuing to have to find people across the aisle, find that bipartisan compromise," Hogan said.
He also compared Alsobrooks' stance to that of Trump, saying that both of them want to change "long standing rules that require bipartisan cooperation."
Gun control and crimeBoth candidates, in their general comments on gun control, said they supported "common sense gun legislation."
Hogan, for his part, said he would support a "bipartisan, commonsense assault weapons ban."
He also accused Alsobrooks of pulling safety officers out of schools, a point that Alsobrooks disputed.
Alsobrooks said she would be in favor of "eliminating assault weapons" and "removing ghost guns from our streets."
She said the former governor "in fact, vetoed legislation that would have created a waiting period for long guns and outright refused to sign the ban on those guns."
On the issue of crime, Hogan trumpeted his "refund the police initiative," while saying that Prince George's County has cut its police force under Alsobrooks' leadership. Hogan charged that "crime is out of control" in the county.
Alsobrooks insisted otherwise, saying that she "oversaw a 50% lowering in crime."
"I not only support law enforcement, I was law enforcement," Alsobrooks said.
Personal votingIn perhaps her most direct attack on Hogan's embrace of bipartisanship, Alsobrooks took aim at Hogan's write-in vote for Ronald Reagan in the 2020 election and his refusal to vote for Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris in the 2024 election despite the former governor's opposition to Trump.
"For a person who says he could see a bipartisan way forward," Alsobrooks said, "but was unable to do the most bipartisan thing ever in an election where he says he despises (Trump), but cannot bring himself to even vote for Vice President Harris … will have forfeited the chance to vote in three different elections rather than stand up, do the right thing, choose a tough vote and vote for a Democrat."
Hogan explained his reasoning: "I've never voted for someone I didn't believe in."
He went on to say, "that's why we have the ability to write-in and take whatever decision you make." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: As governor, Hogan used veto dozens of times
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
As governor, Hogan used veto dozens of times

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Larry Hogan ran for governor of Maryland in 2014, presenting himself as politically moderate and vowing fiscal responsibility.He defeated an opponent who ran a lackluster and halfhearted campaign. After becoming governor, Hogan used his veto power dozens of times to block legislation needed by Maryland. Fortunately, most, if not all, of those vetoes were overridden by the Maryland legislature.
Hogan vetoed legislation to gradually increase the minimum wage to $15 over several years. He also vetoed an earned sick leave bill that would require employers to give employees five paid sick leave days per year and establish a paid family and medical leave insurance program. The Maryland General Assembly overrode the veto with the hard work of a broad coalition of civic, labor, small business and faith groups, state legislative leaders and the public.
On the issue of reproductive rights and access to abortion, Hogan vetoed a bill that would increase the number of trained health providers and the availability of services including in the two-thirds of Maryland counties that have no abortion care providers. Hogan issued his veto just as the Supreme Court was preparing to overturn Roe vs. Wade, and Maryland was facing the imminent need for reproductive care for women arriving from neighboring states like West Virginia.
After the Maryland legislature overrode his veto, Hogan denied a request from the state comptroller to release $3.5 million in appropriated funds for training new providers in quality and safe care
On education, Hogan vetoed the landmark legislation called "Blueprint for Maryland's Future," which was developed by the Kirwan Commission after extensive input and careful study. The legislature overrode Hogan's veto and enacted a 10-year plan to expand pre-kindergarten programs, increase funding for schools with high concentrations of poverty, increase pay for teachers and create new pathways for high schoolers who don't plan to attend college.
On preventing gun violence, Hogan vetoed background checks on the sale and transfer of shotguns and rifles. Legislation was eventually enacted over his veto in response to the Capital Gazette mass shooting in Annapolis.
On voting rights, Hogan vetoed a bill that would have given voters an opportunity to sign their mail-in ballots if they forgot to do so.
Larry Hogan, when he was governor, consistently championed Republican views and beliefs. Many of the above-mentioned vetoes by governor Hogan were overridden by the legislature because it was the will of voters in Maryland. Now Mr. Hogan wants to be our senator and is taking credit for the work done by the legislature by painting himself as a moderate Republican who will champion woman's reproductive rights, support family leave policy, voting rights and increase school funding.
This is just not true, and Hogan's record reflects that. If Larry Hogan is the senator from Maryland, he will support those ideas and directions that he has supported before.
Most important, even if Larry Hogan were not misrepresenting his position on the issues and would vote as a moderate, his very presence in the Senate as a Republican may well determine which political party controls the Senate and its entire legislative agenda. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state governor's vetoes on major policy issues and the potential impact on Senate control, topics that extend beyond local concerns and have national political relevance.

title: Paper keeps community informed
author: Staff Writer
content:
Paper keeps community informed

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 300
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Locked door and a lock box. No chance of seeing through the blackened window. That's how I found the entrance to the Circulation Department of the Star Democrat one day last February.My heart sank, and not because I would have to get on the phone with them about my subscription. My heart sank at this symbol of an unfree press.
What's wrong? I asked someone who would know. I got information on the hours when one could go to the front entrance and get to visit the newsroom, and mention of the attack on the Annapolis Gazette five years ago.
So, a question of security. But the memory of the locked door and the blackened window remained in my mind as a portent of things that could come.
One of the first items in a dictator's bag of tricks is to shut down the free press and retain one news outlet as the voice of the regime. Did you hear Donald Trump say, after his debate with Kamala Harris, that ABC should lose its license? Trump talks often about shutting down news outlets; he has sued 20 of them. Advisers such as Steve Bannon and Kash Patel have openly talked about plans to seek revenge against journalists.
And here we are in Talbot County, Maryland, proudly celebrating 225 years of continuous news coverage of this community. Over those years the local press has risen from ashes a few times, had its equipment wrecked, and, during the Civil War, lost a Southern-sympathizing editor to exile.
Our local newspaper keeps the community informed about itself, and we're damned lucky to have it. But what if — in a second Trump administration — somebody came over from Washington with the authority to shut down the Star Democrat? There is every reason to consider that possibility.
MARGARET BARTON DRIGGS
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses press freedom, political actions by national figures, and potential federal interference with a local newspaper, making it primarily a national news/politics issue rather than any of the other listed categories.

title: 3 weeks before election, Alsobrooks visits Easton, brings U.S. Sen. Brian Schatz with
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
3 weeks before election, Alsobrooks visits Easton, brings U.S. Sen. Brian Schatz with

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In a crowd of people in front of a parked green tour bus with her face on it, Angela Alsobrooks, the Democratic candidate for Maryland's open U.S. Senate seat, danced to "Can You Feel It" by The Jackson 5 in slacks and sneakers.The current Prince George's County executive stopped by the parking lot behind the Goodwill in Easton Wednesday morning to speak to a group of supporters. The event drew residents from Talbot and neighboring counties.
Between dancing and taking photos, Alsobrooks and a few others spoke at a podium in front of the green tour bus. Speakers included U.S. Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hi.), Talbot County Council members Pete Lesher and Keasha Haythe and Talbot County Democratic Central Committee Chair Patrick Firth.
Alsobrooks talked about the importance of caring for others. She called the election an opportunity to ensure the "right kind of future" is being built, bringing up the importance of reproductive rights, economic opportunity and passing "sensible laws" to prevent gun violence.
"This race has become so critically important to what happens all across the country," she said.
Throughout her campaign, Alsobrooks has talked about the importance of the Democratic party maintaining its Senate majority and how voting for her can help ensure that.
Alsobrooks is running in the Nov. 5 general election to fill retiring Sen. Ben Cardin's (D-Md.) seat. She is running against former Republican Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan, a rare two-term Republican governor in the state, which is widely considered to be a Democratic stronghold.
Hogan has positioned himself throughout his campaign as someone willing to work across the aisle.
During an April visit to Easton, Hogan said, "A lot of people are frustrated that nothing ever seems to get done in Washington, and so I think they think I got a lot done while I was governor."
According to a poll from the University of Maryland, Baltimore County Institute of Politics released Oct. 9, Alsobrooks was found to be leading the senate race with 48% of the vote compared to Hogan's 39%. The poll found that 6% of Maryland's likely voters would vote for some other candidate and 5% are undecided.
In the poll — which surveyed 1,003 Maryland adults from Sept. 23 to Sept. 28 — 863 Marylanders were identified as likely voters. The poll had a 3.3% margin of error.
Schatz said Alsobrooks would be an "incredible" addition to the U.S. Senate because "she understands what the people of Maryland are going through."
"She's done economic development," he said. "She's done public safety. She's fought for women. She's fought for human rights. She's fought for civil rights. And now the stage will be set for her to do that on a national level."
Haythe said Alsobrooks will fight for economic development opportunities in Talbot County and across the Eastern Shore.
"We need her partnership," Haythe said.
Lesher talked about the importance of federal funding in local government. He said Alsobrooks understands the importance of getting federal assistance to local governments.
Easton resident Tara Leeson said she is voting for Alsobrooks to keep a Democratic majority in the Senate. Leeson, who used to be a teacher, said she felt Hogan didn't properly support educators during his time as governor.
Caroline County resident Susan Andrew — who said women's rights and sensible gun legislation are important issues to her — said she enjoyed the event Wednesday morning.
"Just the community and everybody being supportive of each other and wanting to see Democrats win," she said about what she liked. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a U.S. Senate campaign event and election dynamics, which are national political news, even though it is reported in a local context.

title: Bug has invaded brains
author: Staff Writer
content:
Bug has invaded brains

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 164
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There seems to be a virus, or some sort of "bug" that has invaded the brains of nearly half the eligible voters in the United States of America. It attacks the truth receptors and reasoning sectors of these once perfectly healthy brains and renders them helpless.Anyone who still has an unaffected brain can make decisions which benefit this country and its citizens. We can still use our God-given filters to comprehend differences between truth and lies, good and evil, self-service and service to others and those individuals whose personal biases are consuming their reasoning and those who are clearly seeking the truth.
All clear-thinking voters need to stop hand-wringing, go to the appropriate site and vote for Kamala Harris for president and all who have promised to support her down-ballot. Time will be up in a few short days. Our beloved country's future needs your vote. Ride a bike, take a boat, car pool with neighbors and family members. Just be there.
VICKI SPARKS
Fishing Creek
