title: Trump set up takeover
author: Staff Writer
content:
Trump set up takeover

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 403
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Many years ago I saw the creek freeze — an unforgettable sight. Slush suddenly snaps to attention and solidifies. Sometimes verifiable facts coalesce in the same way.Gen. Barry McCaffrey, retired U.S. Army, with a visage like a human thunderhead, explained why it was obvious to him in 2020 that Donald Trump was setting the stage for a coup attempt.
"He had an acting secretary of Homeland Security, he had an acting attorney general, he had an acting secretary of defense," he said. "He tried to fire the CIA director and put an acting director in there."
For those who didn't know — I didn't — he tells us what all those firings and tentative appointments meant. Gen. Mark Milley, as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at that time, "had no command authority over the armed forces at all ... and so when Secretary [of Defense] Mark Esper was fired, and a retired lieutenant colonel functionary of Trump appeared as the acting Sec Def — not confirmed by the Senate — the legal chain of command was Trump and this retired lieutenant colonel. So we've got to understand that there was a potential for censoring armed insurrection suppression of an election."
For a civilian, that last sentence is hard to parse. He meant that Trump had set up a power structure that would allow an armed insurrection to succeed. It didn't succeed. The credit for saving the country, Gen. McCaffrey said, goes to "Gen. Mark Milley, the media and many Republican politicians." (Can't we mention some Democrats, too? Never mind.)
What a clever thing Donald Trump did. He set up a takeover of the United States. All by himself? When he didn't — and doesn't — know squat about how the government works?
Bob Woodward fills in with more facts. Trump has continued to consult with Putin, his mentor in all things dictatorial, as he did plenty of times when he was in office — and wouldn't let anyone listen in. He has had as many as seven calls with Putin since leaving the White House. Trump doesn't deny it.
That's when the slushy facts coalesced. My heart froze, too. Didn't we really know it all along? All those calls between Trump and Putin during Trump's administration? Putin tutoring Trump on how to install yes men and cronies in his government so that he can become a dictator?
What are they plotting now, Putin and Trump?
MARGARET BARTON DRIGGS
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses federal political actions and alleged coup attempts involving the former president, which fits the scope of national news rather than any of the other specific categories.

title: GOP-linked PACs give millions to Hogan campaign
author: SHAUN CHORNOBROFF Capital News Service
content:
GOP-linked PACs give millions to Hogan campaign

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SHAUN CHORNOBROFF Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 931
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Despite having "Republican" under his name on Maryland's ballots, former Gov. Larry Hogan has been running for the U.S. Senate on the notion that he's more of an independent, someone who can work on either side of the political aisle.That messaging hasn't stopped Hogan's campaign from receiving significant campaign support from Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Kentucky, as well as two Republican senators vying to replace him as the next GOP Senate leader: John Cornyn of Texas and John Thune of South Dakota.
Hogan, who was recruited to run in the election by McConnell, is pitted against Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks in what is likely to be one of the country's most pivotal elections. The Maryland seat is being vacated by retiring Democratic Sen. Ben Cardin.
The Hogan campaign declined to respond to questions by phone and email about the contributions.
Hogan's campaign has received more than $235,000, including a $75,000 contribution on Sept. 25, from the Cornyn Victory Committee, according to Federal Election Committee reports filed on Tuesday.
Politico reported that Thune's super PAC, New Heights Action, has given $1 million to PACs to help Hogan's campaign.
New Heights Action has given $750,000 to Maryland's Future, a super PAC supporting Hogan, according to the FEC filings.
A McConnell-linked super PAC, Senate Leadership Fund, gave $2 million to Maryland's Future in July.
Maryland's Future has been behind a wave of advertising engulfing the state and had $16 million left to spend as of Sept. 30.
At the end of September, Axios reported that WinSenate, a Democratic PAC linked to Chuck Schumer, was launching $1.1 million worth of ads for Alsobrooks over the first two weeks of this month.
With the aid of four independent senators who caucus with them, Democrats hold a two-seat advantage in the Senate. Hogan swinging a seat in Maryland, a deeply Democratic state, would represent a major political coup for the Republicans.
"I think there's always one race that people aren't paying attention to that we end up picking up. I think that could be Maryland this time," Cornyn said in a Sept. 24 conversation with Capital News Service.
Both Cornyn and Thune have flexed their well-established fundraising muscles as they, along with Rick Scott, R-Florida, seek to succeed McConnell, who is relinquishing his leadership post at the end of the year.
On Sept. 24, Cornyn sent out a letter to donors detailing that he has raised more than $400 million since he joined the Senate in 2002.
The Cornyn Victory Committee has raised nearly $16 million in this election cycle, according to Open Secrets. The money has been spread out among a number of candidates, with Hogan being near the middle of the group in terms of total donations from the Texan's PAC.
The Hill reported last month that Thune announced at a political strategy meeting that he would transfer $4 million from his personal campaign to the National Republican Senatorial Committee in an effort to chip away at the large fundraising advantage held by Democrats. The donation was the largest ever by a Senate Republican, doubling the previous record, set by Thune in 2016.
The Alsobrooks campaign has held a fundraising advantage over Hogan's campaign in recent months.
Alsobrooks' principal campaign committee raised more than $13.4 million in the last cycle from July 1 through Sept. 30, significantly more than Hogan, whose campaign committee raised $3.3 million in the same period, according to FEC filings.
Both Hogan and Alsobrooks have joint fundraising arrangements with party committees that provide their campaigns with cash and raise money for the parties.
The Alsobrooks Victory Fund, created by her campaign and the Democratic State Central Committee of Maryland, raised nearly $3.8 million during the reporting period. Similarly, the Hogan Victory Fund, set up between his campaign and the National Republican Senatorial Campaign, raised $5.4 million.
Alsobrooks' principal campaign committee had almost $3.4 million in cash on hand at the end of last month, while Hogan's principal committee reported nearly $1.6 million in cash on hand.
Hogan is Maryland's first two-term Republican governor in over 60 years and remains popular.
A University of Maryland Baltimore poll released on Oct. 9 said 53% of likely Maryland voters had a favorable opinion of Hogan, compared to 49% for Alsobrooks.
However, the poll gave Alsobrooks a nine-point lead in a race that was neck-and-neck only a month ago.
Some analysts believe a major reason for Alsobrooks' advantage could be Hogan's party allegiance: the former governor is sharing the ticket with former President Donald Trump. Even though Trump endorsed him, Hogan is not returning the favor, saying he will not vote for the GOP standard-bearer.
Hogan's party ties were a major focus in his Oct. 10 debate with Alsobrooks, with the Prince George's county executive repeatedly warning of the dangers of a Republican-controlled Senate.
More than 30% of those surveyed in the UMBC poll cited either support for Democratic control of the Senate or reproductive rights as their reason for voting for Alsobrooks.
"We are facing an election where the future of our country and our freedoms are at stake," Alsobrooks said during the debate. "The Republican Party has declared war on women's reproductive freedoms, we recognize that this party of chaos and division led by Donald Trump can not lead this country and also has severe consequences for Marylanders."
Throughout the debate, Hogan characterized himself as someone who could overcome partisan politics.
"I think what we need desperately in Washington are people that are willing, that have the courage to put country over party and to put people over politics, and to stand up to the leaders of their party," Hogan said. "I don't think there's anyone in America who has done that more than me." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses federal election campaign financing and a U.S. Senate race, which are matters of national political significance, fitting the National News category best.

title: Access to national security info
author: Staff Writer
content:
Access to national security info

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 392
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am sure I am not the only one who cringes at the thought of Donald Trump receiving daily national security briefings in light of the recent revelations that he has had seven unwitnessed conversations with Putin in his three years since leaving office. I spent over 53 years working in the defense industry holding a top secret clearance. I know about proper handling of classified information and documents which is something Trump apparently does not.The fact that Trump illegally removed and held onto classified documents, some of them marked top secret, for years after he left the White House is deeply troubling. He was given three chances to return those documents (a consideration I would never have been given) and the fact that he refused and tried to obstruct their return led to the search for and seizure of those documents at Mar-A-Lago. This alone should disqualify him from any position or job that involves the handling of classified information.
But that's not all. In addition to those classified documents he hoarded in South Florida, he also shared, over the objection of the intelligence community, highly classified images of the Iranian missile attack on one of our bases in the Mid East, images that may have revealed capabilities (and perhaps vulnerabilities) of our systems that should not have been shared.
He also gave son-in-law Jared Kushner a top secret clearance, over the objections of the intelligence community, who felt that he would be subject to foreign influence because of his foreign business dealings. How many millions of dollars did Jared receive from the Middle East during Trump's tenure in office?
Then there was that infamous meeting in Helsinki with Vladimir Putin in 2018 – the meeting for which no recordings, transcripts, or other records were made (at Trump's direction). One has to wonder what was discussed; what Trump promised Putin that would be damaging if revealed.
All of this demonstrates that Trump should absolutely be denied access to national secrets. Fact is, if Trump was an ordinary citizen, he would have a hard time obtaining a confidential (the lowest level) security clearance. Who do you want to hold the code for the nuclear weapons — someone who has shown us their blatant disregard for national security processes or someone who does understand and adhere to these processes for the safety of all?
STEVE SHIMKO
St. Michaels 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses federal-level security clearance issues and political actions involving a former president, which are matters of national significance rather than local, business, or other specific categories.

title: Oceans of money: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, Democrats and Republicans all have something in common. They all love raking in record amounts of campaign cash.
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG National Enter
content:
Oceans of money: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, Democrats and Republicans all have something in common. They all love raking in record amounts of campaign cash.

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG National Enter | Section: National 
 
 1248
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A record amount of money is flooding into the 2024 U.S. elections with a projected $15.9 billion expected to be spent on federal contests — including the White House race between former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris as well as key and expensive U.S. Senate races.And that bipartisan tsunami of cash doesn't even include the millions of dollars flowing into state ballot measures on abortion rights, marijuana legalization and other issues in states such as Montana and Florida.
The Center for Responsive Politics expects federal campaign spending to hit $15.9 billion this cycle — up from $15.1 billion in 2020.
Federal campaign spending this presidential cycle is up 145% from 2016 when Trump defeated former U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, when spending totaled $6.5 billion, and 152% from 2012 ($6.3 billion) — the first election after the U.S. Supreme Court loosened restrictions on outside groups' campaign spending in its Citizens United decision in 2010.
Harris and groups aligned with her presidential campaign have raised more than $1.25 billion in the race against Trump, whose camp has raised close to $940 million.
Carly Urban, an economics professor with Montana State University, said it has become more difficult to track campaign money since the Citizens United decision and the wider advent of so-called 'dark money' being funneled into elections.
"Those are a little bit trickier to track than regular PACs (political actions committees) were pre-2010," Urban said, referring to more secretive and anonymous groups and financial flows.
She also said the nature of campaign spending is changing away from just hiring staff and buying media advertisements.
"Now, we are seeing all types of different payments," Urban said, referring to campaigns paying social media influencers to promote candidates and messages.
Urban said it is difficult to know how much influencers are getting paid by campaigns and whether there are 'pay for play' deals related to candidate appearances on popular podcasts
."I'm sure there are payments going out," she said.
{strong style="font-size: 1em "}THOSE ENDLESS TEXTS{/strong}
Throughout the campaign, Harris and Trump have both attended high-priced fundraisers with deep-pocketed donors and business executives in affluent bastions such as Jackson Hole, Wyoming, Beverly Hills, Silicon Valley, Big Sky, Montana, Martha's Vineyard and the Hamptons.
Some of America's wealthiest persons are also giving big in the presidential race and are serving as high-profile surrogates.
For Trump, that includes Elon Musk, Dallas Mavericks owner Miriam Adelson, aerospace scion Robert Bigelow and Mellon heir Timothy Mellon (who has given $175 million to GOP groups this cycle).
Bill Gates, media billionaires Michael Bloomberg and Fred Eyhchaner, LinkedIn founder Reid Hoffman and "Shark Tank" co-host Mark Cuban are in Harris' financial and political corner. Gates has reportedly given $50 million to the Harris camp.
Madison Schroder, a political researcher at the University of Oregon, said Trump has been unique in his ability to drive fundraising from both supporters and opponents.
She said Trump has been able to draw support from big-fish donors and ball cap wearing, grassroots conservatives.
"He's made himself into a marketable product and he knows his customer base very well," Schroder said, referring to Trump's marketing of bibles, trading cards and other products associated with his name and campaign.
In the other corner, Harris and Democrats routinely fundraise off of their opposition to Trump.
Harris was installed at the top of the Democratic ticket in August after President Joe Biden was pressured by party leaders and donors to quit the race. She saw a groundswell of campaign money after Biden's pressured exit.
Schroder said social media and smartphones have helped propel more targeted and continuous fundraising texts and emails and a significant number of grassroots voters see contributions as a way to be part of the political process.
The last two Trump-dominated campaigns have seen $31 billion raised for federal races.
But Schroder wonders when voters will reach their tipping point when it comes to fundraising solicitations and wonders how much campaign money is enough.
"How much money do elections really need," Schroder said.
"What does this money really go to and why is it important," she continued, noting the access big donors gain from big donations.
SENATE RACESThe 2024 cycle has also seen very expensive U.S. Senate races that will likely determine which party controls the upper chamber of Congress.
In Montana, Republican Tim Sheehy is looking to unseat three-term incumbent Democrat U.S. Sen. Jon Tester in a contest that has totaled $242 million with more than $140 million streaming into Montana, according to FEC and CRP data as of Oct. 21.
Both Sheehy, a former U.S. Navy SEAL and founder of aerial firefighting company Bridger Aerospace, and Tester, a farmer who touts his Montana roots, both accuse the other of being bankrolled and beholden to billionaires and other wealthy interests.
The Sheehy camp points to backing for Tester from lobbyists as well as groups tied to left-wing financier George Soros. Democrats counter that the GOP challenger is supported by private equity interests including hedge fund manager Ken Griffin and Blackstone chairman and CEO Stephen Schwarzman.
The Montana race is only surpassed in terms of money by the Ohio U.S. Senate race where incumbent Democrat Sherrod Brown is being challenged by GOP businessman Bernie Moreno.
The Ohio contest has a price tag approaching $345 million.
Brown and Tester have raised $83.5 million and $77.9 million, respectively, according to the Federal Election Commission.
That's the most of any congressional candidates. Sheehy and Moreno have also put $2.45 million and $4.5 million of their own money, respectively, in the form of loans, into the race.
Even in races where incumbents are expected to breeze to victory, sitting senators from both parties have amassed overflowing war chests.
That includes Democrats Amy Kloubachar of Minnesota ($20.9 million raised) and Maria Cantwell of Washington ($12.8 million) and Republicans Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee ($16.8 million) and John Barrasso of Wyoming ($10.2 million), according to FEC filings.
BALLOT MEASURESState ballot measures are also drawing significant money.
The most expensive ballot campaign is in Florida where Amendment 3 would legalize marijuana for recreational use if it can overcome the state's 60% benchmark for initiative approvals.
The race has surpassed the $101 million mark with $60 million coming from the marijuana industry in support of the measure and opposition financed by Griffin and GOP donor Tricia Duggan.
There are also state ballot measures in Montana, Florida, Missouri, Arizona, Colorado and Nebraska that look to enshrine abortion rights into state constitutions after the U.S Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022 and sent the issue back to the states. Those measures have generated $125.7 million in campaign money with more than 88% of the money in those races backing abortion rights via support from national groups such as Planned Parenthood and the American Civil Liberties Union, according to CRP.
Some wealthy Democratic donors — including benefactor Marsha Zlatin Laufer and Cargill heiress Gwendolyn Sontheim Meyer and groups financed by Soros — are also bankrolling the abortion rights measures.
In Montana, a ballot measure to enshrine abortion rights has garnered in $11.9 million in campaign money, according to CRP. Almost all of that — $11.8 million — is from abortion rights supporters including contributions of $1 million from Sontheim Meyer, $1 million from Soros' Open Society Fund, $1.3 million from Michael Bloomberg, according to CFP and state campaign finance records.
Urban said wealthy donors have become important drivers for and against state ballot measures in the post-Citizens United landscape.
Schroder notes the influx of out-of-state money — whether it's grassroots activists or access-seeking mega-donors — into state ballot measures, including this cycle's bevy of abortion rights initiatives.
"People are seeing national political platforms as being state by state agendas, too," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses nationwide campaign spending, federal elections, and ballot measures, which are core political events of national relevance, making 'National News' the most fitting category.

title: Republicans predict victories at annual Talbot County Lincoln Reagan Dinner
author: Tom McCall
content:
Republicans predict victories at annual Talbot County Lincoln Reagan Dinner

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Business 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Speeches delivered at the annual Talbot County Republican Central Committee's annual Lincoln Reagan Dinner Thursday evening featured optimistic outlooks and strong calls to action for Republican voters ahead of this year's general election.About 100 Talbot County Republicans gathered at the Miles River Yacht Club to eat a meal, connect over shared interests, and hear from speakers including Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) and keynote speaker Ivan Raiklin, a pro-Trump Republican activist.
"I think Donald Trump is going to win," Harris said to the crowd, which featured several local leaders and prominent community members. "His lead may be too big to rig, but they will still try. … The U.S. Senate I am really excited about because we are going to win the majority of the Senate, no question about it."
Harris, who was recently made the chair of the House Freedom Caucus, encouraged the voters in the room to vote early in the 2024 election, expressing concerns about safety at the polls on Election Day. Early voting in Maryland began Oct. 24 and runs through Oct. 31.
Later in the evening, Harris engaged with Raiklin during a question-and-answer session, during which the representative voiced support for North Carolina legislators allocating the state's presidential electors to Donald Trump, even before the popular vote is complete. In a video of the interaction, which Raiklin posted to his X account following the event, Harris said such a move "makes a lot of sense" in the wake of Hurricane Helene, which devastated western parts of the state.
Having North Carolina's legislature assign the state's 16 Electoral College votes has been proposed by some as a potential measure to combat voting difficulties in storm-ravaged areas. Harris said the move made less sense in other states with Republican-controlled legislatures, like New Hampshire and Arizona, which were identified by Raiklin in his keynote speech.
"It looks like just a power play," Harris said. "In North Carolina, it's legitimate. There are a lot of people that aren't going to get to vote and it may make the difference in that state."
Harris said in a statement sent to media outlets Friday that "every legal vote should be counted. I would hope everyone could agree that legal American voters whose lives were devastated by the recent storms should not be disenfranchised in the upcoming voting process."
The interaction has garnered a lot of buzz on the internet, as has Raiklin's keynote speech from the event, which was posted in full to his X account Thursday evening.
Raiklin gave a multimedia talk at the event. He is a former Green Beret, has a constitutional law degree and has been an intelligence officer. He calls himself a "deep state marauder." He has appeared on Tucker Carlson's blog and Alex Jones' InfoWars.
"Everybody here has courage," Raiklin said to the Republicans gathered in Talbot County. "At some point in time, you decided enough was enough and it's time to stop the tyrannical federal government overreach."
The event stirred emotions. According to Talbot County Sheriff's Office report, Ferdinand Joseph Ricci, 58, of Alexandria, Virginia assaulted another attendee in front of Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, a Republican who was attending the event. The Sheriff's Office said Ricci was charged with assault and taken to the Talbot County Central Booking facility after being removed from the dinner. It was unclear if he was an attendee of the event or there to protest it.
But this did not dampen the attitudes of the attendees of the dinner, many of whom expressed optimism about election outcomes in the final weeks of the 2024 election cycle.
Gordana Schifanelli, a lawyer who ran to be lieutenant governor with Dan Cox, said, "I think the Republican Party is exceptionally energized and educated this time around… I am concerned the Democrats will be throwing a fit, burning and looting. I am concerned about the violence that could ensue if they don't get their way."
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) quoted Abraham Lincoln in his speech to the crowd, one of the annual dinner's namesakes, and said, "We of the Republican Party have a special debt of gratitude to Abraham Lincoln. It was his sincere belief and unfailing devotion to a great principle which brought into being a new political pledge to make all men free and equal." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a political dinner, election predictions, and statements by elected officials, which aligns best with broader political coverage typical of National News rather than the more specific categories.

title: Consider the party platforms
author: Staff Writer
content:
Consider the party platforms

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rather than deciding on one individual versus another, voters might instead consider party platforms and party methods of governing.One party tends to attract those engaged in commercial endeavors that must earn a profit. The other is dominated by those inside mostly non-profit entities whose funding is essentially unearned. These include university academics and their students, social cause activists, information technology groups and media providers. This party believes there are grand ideas for addressing real or imaginary problems.
In view of these distinctions, the two parties are motivated toward different ends. One party seeks a government that promotes free enterprise with only necessary regulations. The other is motivated to gain control of the government in order to implement grand ideas.
It seems that one party supports classical Constitutional freedom while the other seeks to impose a new system that circumvents Constitutional strictures. The 2024 Democratic Party platform states that "America is an idea."
"We must right the wrongs in our democracy, redress the systemic injustices that have long plagued our society, throw open the doors of opportunity for all Americans, and reinvent our institutions at home and our leadership abroad. We do not simply aspire to return our country to where we were four years ago. We know we must be bolder and more ambitious."
The 2024 Republican Party platform states "We will be a Nation based on Truth, Justice, and Common Sense."
To enter military service I took an oath to support and defend the Constitution. Voting for the Democratic Party platform would violate that oath.
PAYNE KILBOURN
Neavitt 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses U.S. political party platforms and constitutional issues, which are central to national political news rather than any of the other specific categories.

title: Use your brain when you vote
author: Staff Writer
content:
Use your brain when you vote

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I couldn't help but laugh at the letter last week from Vicki Sparks. She defined the problem with the Democrat party very well. She points with one finger and has three pointing back at her. Have any of those who are considering voting for Kamala listened to her stuttering and stammering during an interview. She and Joe have been in charge for nearly four years and darn near destroyed this country.Now she wants to fix what is broke, and she is the one who broke it. If it were something that Trump broke, she had 3½ years to fix it. Why didn't she? Even CNN and ABC are getting frustrated with her handling of simple questions. Every time she is asked a question about anything she blames Trump. It is way past time for people to vote with common sense not for the party that promises and does not deliver.
Trump delivered on his promise for lower fuel and gas prices and was working on closing our borders, low inflation and putting more people to work (blacks had the lowest unemployment during his term). He wants this country to prosper.
If you have ever listened to Kamala speak, try to imagine her with any dignitary. It would be disastrous. All I ask is that you use your brain this time and vote for Donald J. Trump.
JOHN GONDECK
Denton

title: Think carefully about who gets your precious vote
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
Think carefully about who gets your precious vote

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 368
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For those of you who have read the articles I have written, you know I am a Democrat. I will strongly support and vote for Kamala Harris and Angela Alsobrooks. I believe they are the right choices for our country and for Maryland. I encourage all of you to do the same, even Republicans who may never vote for a Democrat again except now.For anyone who is considering voting for Donald Trump be very careful. Donald Trump is not who he was. He is not the person who ran in 2016. He is mentally challenged and very, very, radical. This is clear from his consistent, unclear and unintelligible statements at his rallies. If you want proof of that just go to one of them. The rallies are so bad that even Fox News has not shown them because Trump looks so bad.
He recently canceled several interviews because he was quote "too tired." This is a man who has lost his way and tries to cover it by using foul language as he did at the recent Al Smith dinner in New York.
Donald Trump is a great danger to our country and will do nothing but help his billionaire friends like Elon Musk; he will take revenge on anyone he thinks was or is against him. He has told us that — believe him. He will try very hard to become a dictator. He has told us that — believe him.
Donald Trump has denigrated our military and called them "losers and suckers." He has vilified John McCain, a patriot who spent years in a prisoner of war camp fighting for our country. Now he wants to be commander in chief. Gen. John Kelly, Trump's former chief of staff, courageously and at great personal peril if Trump is elected, said publicly this week that Trump meets the definition of "fascist." When a four-star Marine general fears for our country, we should as well.
All of us must vote in the next several days. I appeal to you to think very, very, carefully about who gets your precious vote. I truly believe that we cannot let Donald Trump into the White House because if we do our American democracy will end. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 Words

 By the time you are reading this letter I will have voted for Kamala Harris for president of the United States. title: 'Big surprise'?: Anti-war vote could be a wild card in razor-thin Trump-Harris race
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
'Big surprise'?: Anti-war vote could be a wild card in razor-thin Trump-Harris race

 October 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 1590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Could anti-war voters (including Muslims and Arab-American Christians) upset with U.S. support for Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas potentially tip the 2024 election away from Vice President Kamala Harris in favor of former President Donald Trump?In 2020, President Joe Biden won 69% of the Muslim vote, compared to Trump's 17%, according to Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR). Exit polls by the Associated Press in 2020 gave Biden 64% of the Muslim vote versus 35% for Trump.
Times have changed.
The Biden-Harris administration's military and diplomatic support for Israel's war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7, 2023, attacks and ongoing conflict with Hezbollah in Lebanon have eroded Arab-American and Muslim support for Harris' White House bid.
More than 43,000 people have died in Gaza since the start of the war more than a year ago, when Hamas killed 1,200 Israelis and took more than 250 hostages. More than 100 of those Israeli hostages (including a handful with dual American citizenship) are still being held by Hamas and other Islamic militants.
Israel's continued siege and bombings inside Gaza have killed more than 20,000 women and children, according to the United Nations, citing Palestinian estimates.
A worst-case scenario for Harris is that Muslim voters, Arab American Christians and other anti-war voters (including younger voters) back the Green Party's Jill Stein (who opposes the war and U.S. backing of Israel), Trump or sit out the election, which could potentially tilt the razor-thin election in battlegrounds including Michigan, Wisconsin and North Carolina.
SEISMIC SHIFT?A national poll released last month by the Arab American Institute found Arab Americans shifting away from Democrats and Harris.
The group said in the past Arab Americans voted for Democrats by a roughly 2-to-1 margin.
The October poll found Trump leading Harris among Arab Americans 42% to 41%, with 12% backing a third-party candidate such as Stein or Cornel West, who also opposes the Gaza war.
Harris is polling 18 percentage points below Biden's 2020 standing with Arab Americans, according to the poll.
"In our 30 years of polling Arab American voters, we have not witnessed anything like the role that the war on Gaza is having on voter behavior," said James Zogby, president of the Arab American Institute, in a statement, pointing out 81% of Arab Americans view the Israel-Hamas war as a top issue.
There are more than 3.7 million Arab Americans in the U.S., according to AAI.
Close to 393,000 Arab Americans live in Michigan (which Biden won by just over 154,100 votes in 2020). Another 126,500 live in Pennsylvania (which Biden won by more than 78,500 votes).
AAI estimates two-thirds or more of Arab Americans are Christians, while one-quarter are Muslim.
While Evangelical Christians are among the staunchest supporters of Israel, Orthodox, the Roman Catholic Church and more liberal Protestant denominations — which also have churches in the Holy Land — have pressed for an end to the war and criticized Israel's Gaza bombings and invasion as it seeks to eradicate Hamas.
Another poll released earlier this month by the Arab News and polling firm YouGov gives Trump a 45% to 43% lead over Harris among Arab American voters. Stein gets 4%.
'BITTER PILL'
Late August polls by the Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR) showed Harris getting 28% of the Muslim vote in six key Electoral College swing states, compared to 30% for Stein and 15% for Trump.
The CAIR poll gave Harris 12% of the Muslim vote in Michigan (a key swing state with a significant Arab-American population) versus 40% for Stein and 18% for Trump.
Robert McCaw, government affairs director for CAIR, said Harris hurt her standing with Muslim voters with recent pronouncements that she wouldn't change anything about the Biden administration policies.
"She stands by the policy of providing Israel with U.S manufactured weapons," McCaw said.
"It's a bitter pill for Muslim voters to swallow," he continued.
McCaw said if margins are tight in the presidential race or key Senate contests, anti-war voters could tip the balance. He also said like any group, Muslim voters can look to other issues, including the economy and social matters. He warns candidates not to take them for granted with Gaza in the backdrop.
"They could be in for a big surprise," he said.
'VITAL VOTES'
One leading anti-war group, Abandon Harris, has endorsed Stein.
Hudhayfah Ahmad, spokesman for the group, said the U.S. administration's "disregard for Palestinian lives has deeply damaged Harris's credibility with a large bloc of voters, including Muslims, progressives and human rights advocates."
"Their votes are vital in this election, and with each bomb dropped in Gaza, Harris's candidacy suffers more," he said.
Harris — who has been heckled by anti-war protesters at some campaign rallies and TV appearances — has tried to walk a political balance beam of supporting Israel's right to defend itself after the Hamas attacks and continued rockets from Hezbollah while calling for a ceasefire. She also snubbed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech before Congress in August, and did meet with him at the White House voicing concerns about war deaths.
Harris told CBS News Saturday the U.S. would help defend Israel if Iran strikes back after Israel Defense Forces bombed installations in Iran on Friday.
Ahmad is frustrated with the year-long cycle of top U.S. administration officials, including Harris, calling for and talking up a ceasefire and occasionally criticizing Netanyahu, only to see truce talks falter, coupled with White House and Pentagon pronouncements of "ironclad support for Israel" and continued military support.
"This cycle of empty calls for a ceasefire, followed by a new round of munitions shipments, has become insulting to Muslim voters and others who care about ending the massacres. It's a hollow strategy that tries to pacify the public, while enabling the very acts they claim to denounce. People are tired of the hypocrisy," Ahmad said.
NO FANS OF TRUMPHarris does enjoy backing from Emgage Action, a Muslim group advocacy group that backed Biden in 2020.
Emgage CEO Wa'el Alzayat said "Gaza has been completely destroyed, tens of thousands of civilians have been killed, including many children, and a population of two million has been destitute."
But Alzayat said voting for a third-party candidate will help Trump win the White House.
"Muslims do not need to be reminded of who Donald Trump is," Alzayat said, pointing to the travel bans he proposed from several Muslim countries, moving the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem and backing Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.
Alzayat said Trump also "blessed Netanyahu's expansionism by recognizing Israeli occupation of East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights" and has promised support for Netanyahu on the campaign trail. He sees more hope in Harris, despite her standing by Biden's war stance.
Ahmad is also no fan of Trump.
"Trump's record on Palestine is disastrous — he's championed Israeli expansion and disregarded Palestinian rights altogether. Muslim voters have every reason to distrust him on this issue," he said.
A national poll by The Economist and YouGov shows 36% of Americans sympathize with Israel in the war, 17% back the Palestinians, 25% have equal allegiances and 22% aren't sure. More than two-thirds of conservatives and 45% of wealthy voters back Israel, according to the survey.
The same poll shows 32% of Americans believe Israel is committing genocide in in Gaza, while 35% say they aren't and 32% aren't sure.
'PEACE, NOT WAR'Trump has promised strong support for Israel and is backed by pro-Israeli mega-donor Miriam Adelson and other pro-Israel advocates including billionaire hedge fund manager Bill Ackman. Eighty two percent of white Evangelical Christians — who are among the strongest backers of Israel — support Trump.
But he has also vowed to end the Holy Land war, as well as the war between Russia and Ukraine.
Trump had a group of Muslim leaders and imams — including Dearborn Heights, Michigan Mayor Bill Bazzi — on stage with him during a rally in Michigan on Saturday, welcoming their support.
"We, as Muslims, stand with President Trump because he promises peace, not war," said Imam Belal Alzuhairi. "We are supporting Donald Trump because he promised to end war in the Middle East and Ukraine. The bloodshed has to stop all over the world, and I think this man can make that happen. I personally believe that God saved his life twice for a reason."
Trump has also promised global protections for Christians, promising support for Coptic Christians in the Middle East and pointing to the sectarian dispute between Orthodox Armenians and Muslim Azerbaijanis.
The U.S. provides $3.8 billion in military aid to Israel annually. The Biden-Harris administration backed a $14 billion war aid package and approved a $20 billion long-term weapons sale to Israel earlier this year, and has sent troops, weapons, fighter jets and naval assets during the war with Hamas and Hezbollah and skirmishes with Iran.
Those efforts enjoy bipartisan support. Still, Republicans, including U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, as well as Trump, argue Biden and Harris have not been supportive enough of Israel.
Trump is also courting Jewish voters, another traditional Democratic voting bloc, and has touted his communications with Netanyahu. Jewish voters backed Biden over Trump by a 68% to 30% margin in 2020, according to the Jewish Virtual Library.
A poll this month by academic research group CHIP50 found some slippage, with Harris holding a 54% to 36% lead over Trump among Jewish voters. A new poll by Channel 12 TV in Israel shows 66% of Israelis back Trump in the U.S. election versus 17% for Harris. More than 90% of Netanyahu backers prefer Trump over Harris, according to the Israeli poll.
This comes as Harris and Democrats press the case that Trump is a fascist who admires Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
"I'm not a Nazi. I'm the opposite of a Nazi," Trump told a campaign rally Monday in Atlanta. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses how the Israel‑Gaza war is influencing voter behavior in the 2024 U.S. presidential election, a major national political story. While it highlights Arab‑American and Muslim voting patterns (relevant to Race & Diversity), the primary focus is on national election dynamics, making 'National News' the best fit.

title: Election Day looms: How will the counts go and will voters trust the process - and the results?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
Election Day looms: How will the counts go and will voters trust the process - and the results?

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 1220
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tuesday's election — which has already seen significant early voting across the country and could see record turnout spurred by the neck-and-neck White House race between former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris — will also be a serious test of how much trust the public has in the election system and the government agencies who run it.Right now, those trust levels skew along partisan lines.
A Pew Research Center Poll released Oct. 24 found 42% of Trump voters are not confident the election will run smoothly compared to 90% of Harris voters who trust the system.
According to a Pew survey, 38% of Trump voters have confidence in the counting of mail-in and absentee votes compared to 85% of Harris voters who trust government agencies and poll workers counting the votes.
Close to three-quarters of Harris voters (72%) versus less than one-third of Trump backers (32%) are confident the election system is secure against being hacked.
There is also plenty of curiosity — and some concerns — over how and when ballots will be counted and when winners might be determined not only in the presidential race but also key congressional contests and state ballot measures.
Trump has disputed his 2020 loss to President Joe Biden. Trump led in key battleground states on election night, but Biden overcame those deficits via ensuring counts of mail-in and absentee ballots in the election which occurred in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.
A number of state and local election agencies have increased security protocols and added more transparency to how ballots are tabulated and secured.
Others are counting absentee, mail-in and other early ballots early this cycle to help get results quicker and avoid delays that could fuel worries about how votes are being counted and results. .
Still, barring some unforeseen turnout trends and definitive exit polls, a winner in the presidential race and other key races are not expected on election night or early Wednesday morning.
In Maryland, polls will be open Tuesday from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Key races include the U.S. Senate race between former Republican governor Larry Hogan and Democratic Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks. GOP U.S. Rep. Andy Harris is being challenged for his Eastern Shore congressional by Democrat Blane Miller.
'COUNTING DOESN'T STOP'In Pitt County, North Carolina near the Atlantic coast, County Elections Director Dave Davis said approved absentee ballot envelopes are fed into voting machines weekly in the run-up to the election.
He said the county has sent out more than 4,100 absentee ballots this year. Close to 87,600 people voted in the 2020 presidential race.
Davis wouldn't talk about election security measures but said "counting doesn't stop" until all ballots are tallied.
North Carolina is one of the key Electoral College battlegrounds between Trump and Harris, and there is some consternation about how long it will take for all votes to be counted in places such as Maricopa County in Arizona. That county, which includes Phoenix and Scottsdale, has a two-page ballot which could add to its already cumbersome counting of early ballots.
The Wisconsin State Board of Elections says all ballots — including in-person and absentee votes — are counted on Election Day and matched to voter registration details in poll books.
"All ballots are counted on Election Day," the state agency says in an explainer on vote counts.
Pennsylvania also does not count absentee ballots until Election Day.
Another key battleground, Michigan, has expanded early voting efforts with early voting centers open and is allowing local clerks to count them ahead of time — though results will not be posted until election night.
STORED IN A VAULTIn Montana (where there is a key U.S. Senate race and ballot measure that would enshrine abortion rights in the state constitution), Gallatin County — which includes Bozeman, Big Sky and Belgrade — will count some absentee votes on Monday as allowed by state law, according to Eric Semerad, who serves as county clerk and elections administrator.
"We will start counting ballots on Monday, Nov. 4. State law allows counties of our size to start counting the day before Election Day, but only until 5 p.m.," Semerad said. "We will then start counting again the morning of Election Day and won't stop until we are finished. Likely this will be sometime late Wednesday."
He said 63,500 absentee ballots have been sent out for this election. Close to 71,000 people voted in Gallatin County in 2020.
Semerad did outline some of the procedures and security measures for counting and securing ballots.
"We will begin opening the secrecy envelopes and removing the ballots on Thursday, October 31st," he said. "All ballots that are opened are kept in large security bags by ballot style which are sealed every night with numbered seals that are logged every time they are sealed or unsealed. Ballots are stored in our office vault that is monitored by a security camera."
State law requires localities to keep counting voting ballots election night.
Semerad said the first set of unofficial results won't be posted online until all voters have finished voting. Voting could continue after polls close if there are long lines.
'CHAIN OF CUSTODY'In Florida, there are ballot measures to legalize marijuana for recreational use and to codify abortion rights into the state constitution superseding state restrictions passed after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022.
Under state law, those measures have to get more than 60% of the vote.
Leah Valenti, supervisor of elections in Charlotte County in southwest Florida, also ran through some of the processes and protocols for counting early mail-in ballots.
Charlotte County — which includes Punta Gorda and Port Charlotte — has sent out more than 45,000 mall-in ballots, Valenti said. More than 116,500 voters cast ballots in the county in 2020.
She said mail-in ballots are date-stamped, voters' identities are confirmed and ballot envelopes are batched and counts are reconciled daily.
They are stored in a secured room.
"Unlike the other office doors which have key card access (RFID), the mail ballots are stored in a dual authenticated secure room, which is under video surveillance. The ballots are stored there until they are opened and counted during a public meeting of the Canvassing Board," Valenti said.
She said voting equipment goes through accuracy testing before ballots are tallied, a new auditing system is being deployed this year and there other "election integrity protocols."
"For instance, any time election materials are transported, two election workers from opposing political parties are required to sign off on chain of custody forms. This ensures transparency and accountability from all sides," Valenti said.
NOT CONNECTEDIn Oregon (where all ballots are submitted by mail), Rochelle Long, Klamath County Clerk in the southern part of the state, said counts are done daily leading up to the election with results posted starting election night.
Klamath County has sent out more than 51,500 ballots for the general election. Just over 36,700 voters cast ballots in the 2020 presidential race in the more rural and conservative county, where Trump carried close to 69% of the vote.
Long said the voting counting process is public and can be seen on livestream in a number of Oregon jurisdictions. There are also safeguards, including multi-party presence during vote counts and transparency for the machine that tallies votes.
"The tally machine is not connected to any outside network," she said. "The vote tally machine is in a locked room on camera and can be viewed publicly via live stream." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the upcoming U.S. election, voter confidence, and ballot counting procedures across multiple states, which is a broad political story of national relevance rather than a local, sector‑specific issue.

title: Election Day looms: How will the counts go and will voters trust the process - and the results?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
Election Day looms: How will the counts go and will voters trust the process - and the results?

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 1169

"We will start counting ballots on Monday, Nov. 4. State law allows counties of our size to start counting the day before Election Day, but only until 5 p.m.," Semerad said. "We will then start counting again the morning of Election Day and won't stop until we are finished. Likely this will be sometime late Wednesday."
He said 63,500 absentee ballots have been sent out for this election. Close to 71,000 people voted in Gallatin County in 2020.
Semerad did outline some of the procedures and security measures for counting and securing ballots.
"We will begin opening the secrecy envelopes and removing the ballots on Thursday, October 31st," he said. "All ballots that are opened are kept in large security bags by ballot style which are sealed every night with numbered seals that are logged every time they are sealed or unsealed. Ballots are stored in our office vault that is monitored by a security camera."
State law requires localities to keep counting voting ballots election night.
Semerad said the first set of unofficial results won't be posted online until all voters have finished voting. Voting could continue after polls close if there are long lines.
'CHAIN O
F CUSTODY'
In Florida, there are ballot measures to legalize marijuana for recreational use and to codify abortion rights into the state constitution superseding state restrictions passed after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022.
Under state law, those measures have to get more than 60% of the vote.
Leah Valenti, supervisor of elections in Charlotte County in southwest Florida, also ran through some of the processes and protocols for counting early mail-in ballots.
Charlotte County — which includes Punta Gorda and Port Charlotte — has sent out more than 45,000 mall-in ballots, Valenti said. More than 116,500 voters cast ballots in the county in 2020.
She said mail-in ballots are date-stamped, voters' identities are confirmed and ballot envelopes are batched and counts are reconciled daily.
They are stored in a secured room.
"Unlike the other office doors which have key card access (RFID), the mail ballots are stored in a dual authenticated secure room, which is under video surveillance. The ballots are stored there until they are opened and counted during a public meeting of the Canvassing Board," Valenti said.
She said voting equipment goes through accuracy testing before ballots are tallied, a new auditing system is being deployed this year and there other "election integrity protocols."
"For instance, any time election materials are transported, two election workers from opposing political parties are required to sign off on chain of custody forms. This ensures transparency and accountability from all sides," Valenti said.
NOT CONNECTEDIn Oregon (where all ballots are submitted by mail), Rochelle Long, Klamath County Clerk in the southern part of the state, said counts are done daily leading up to the election with results posted starting election night.
Klamath County has sent out more than 51,500 ballots for the general election. Just over 36,700 voters cast ballots in the 2020 presidential race in the more rural and conservative county, where Trump carried close to 69% of the vote.
Long said the voting counting process is public and can be seen on livestream in a number of Oregon jurisdictions. There are also safeguards, including multi-party presence during vote counts and transparency for the machine that tallies votes.
"The tally machine is not connected to any outside network," she said. "The vote tally machine is in a locked room on camera and can be viewed publicly via live stream." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the upcoming U.S. presidential election, voter confidence, and ballot counting across multiple states, which is a nationwide political event rather than a local, economic, or safety issue.

title: Rallying the troops: Dems, GOP look to energize voters for Tuesday's election.
author: Staff Writer
content:
Rallying the troops: Dems, GOP look to energize voters for Tuesday's election.

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 217
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Local Democrats and Republicans have both been rallying their partisan troops ahead of Tuesday's monumental election.Vice President Kamala Harris is heavily favored to carry Maryland over former President Donald Trump.
But the U.S. Senate race between former GOP governor Larry Hogan and Democratic Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks has attracted $87.5 million in campaign fundraising and spending.
Alsobrooks has raised more than $28.5 million versus $10.9 million for Hogan, according to the Federal Election Commission.
There has been more than $48.1 million in outside spending in the race, from both sides, to fill an open seat with the retirement of Democratic U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin.
Upper Shore Young Republicans and the Kent County Republican Central Committee held an event in Chestertown on Oct. 24 featuring GOP congressional candidate Kim Klacik and Robin Ficker, a longtime fixture in Maryland GOP politics.
The Kent County Democratic Central Committee held its own canvassing event to generate partisans last month in Chestertown.
That event featured former former Congressman Wayne Gilchrest, and former Maryland State Delegate Heather Mizeur.
Gilchrest, a former Republican who became a Democrat in 2019, and Mizeur talked about the importance of the their efforts and reaching out to voters.
"We can become an ambassador to humanity. Let's remind people of what's at stake and why it matters to us," Mizeur said at the event.

title: Listen, think, vote for democracy
author: Staff Writer
content:
Listen, think, vote for democracy

 November 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 378
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What a disgusting display of hate Trump's rally in Madison Square Garden was this week. According to the speakers, Americans hate other Americans. They sought to set neighbor against neighbor. That seems to be the party line. Who are them and who are us? This just isn't the world that I was brought up or believe in. So what do I believe?My father fought in World War II against the Nazis. My parents brought us up to stand up for our country and to do what was right for other people. They taught us to try and live with honor and integrity. I do not recognize the Republican Party. They stand for nothing but to bow to Trump. As Tom Stoppard sings, " You've got to stand for something or you'll fall for anything."
I reject the idea that persons of color are inferior to white people, that persons who are not Christian are inferior or unacceptable, that women are inferior to men, or that other people are not free to love as they wish. This election is about personal freedom versus having personal decisions made by our government or someone else who paternalistically are sure that they know what is better for us than we do.
Trump's rhetoric about vermin, the enemy within, the enemy of the people is straight out of the Nazi playbook. If you vote for him you are giving up your power to him. He has talked about suspending the Constitution. I sense that some people think that what he is going to do won't affect them. A famous quote from a German citizen who was eventually placed in a concentration camp basically says that when they came for the trade unionists and then for the Jews he didn't speak up and when they came for him there was no one to speak for him. That's what will happen.
One will not be able to freely express his opinion because there will be someone who will overhear and "turn them in." Think it can't happen here? History tells us differently. Wake up. Trump wants to take away your power.
From a registered Republican. Listen, think and vote for democracy. Otherwise you will no longer have a voice to complain about our government or vote again.
LINDA BLYTHE
Bozman 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an editorial about a Trump rally, voting, and democratic principles, focusing on national political issues rather than local, cultural, or other specific domains.

AP call: Democrat Angela Alsobrooks wins election to Senate

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Democrat Angela Alsobrooks won the U.S. Senate seat in Maryland on Tuesday. Alsobrooks defeated Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan in a closely watched race with control of the Senate potentially at stake.Alsobrooks prevailed in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans 2-1, but Hogan's popularity as a two-term governor made him one of the strongest competitors for a Senate seat in Maryland in decades.
Alsobrooks, who will be the state's first Black senator, is the chief executive of Prince George's County, Maryland's second most populous jurisdiction next to the nation's capital. The Associated Press declared Alsobrooks the winner at 9:32 p.m.

title: Mid-Shore voters express hopes, anxieties at the polls Tuesday
author: Tom McCall
content:
Mid-Shore voters express hopes, anxieties at the polls Tuesday

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 771
 Words 

 Read News Document

 From the next president of the United States to local board of education races, Mid-Shore voters had both national and local decisions to make at the polls Tuesday.Mid-day Tuesday, multiple election judges at different polling places in Talbot, Dorchester and Caroline counties noted a steady flow of voters.
Some of those flows were bigger than others, however.
Edward Forte, chief judge at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department on Leonard Rieck Drive, said turnout was "busy, as expected." He said there were about 45 people standing in line at 7 a.m.
At Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, chief judges Chris Dawson and Emily Zobel said turnout was slow and steady, adding that other polling places in Dorchester County were busier.
In Caroline County, 658 people had cast their votes at the Denton Volunteer Fire Company by lunchtime. Chief Judge Shawn Howeth said it had been busy at the fire department since 7 a.m. He said there were a lot of new voters.
"People are passionate about this election, I guess," Howeth said.
Going into election night, at the national level, Democratic presidential candidate Vice President Kamala Harris faced Republican candidate former President Donald Trump.
At the state level, Democratic candidate and Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks vied with former Republican Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan for retiring Sen. Ben Cardin's (D-Md.) seat.
On the Eastern Shore, incumbent Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st) faced Democratic candidate Blane Miller III and Libertarian candidate Joshua O'Brien for the Congressional District 1 seat.
Depending on the county, some Mid-Shore ballots also had board of education races on them.
At some polling locations, local Democratic and Republican committees had tables and tents set up, ready to talk to voters.
Talbot County Republican Central Committee member Shari Wilcoxon said she had been outside the Easton Volunteer Fire Department for hours talking with voters.
"I'm feeling extremely positive," she said. "Because I'm getting so many thumbs up. And I'm also getting so many fully-educated voters that know what's on the ballot."
Caroline County Republican Central Committee Chairman Julie Quick said people had been coming over to their tent at the Denton Volunteer Fire Company to take pictures with a cardboard cutout of Trump.
"I have (heard) lots about the direction of our country and how important this election is," she said. "That is why we are here."
Outside the Talbot County Community Center, Judy Wixted handed out voter guides with the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee. Wixted said she was feeling good about the Talbot County elections and was feeling "cautiously optimistic" about the national elections.
"What I know is a truth is, in close elections, ground game wins," Wixted said. "And I really believe that the Harris Walz campaign has the best ground game I have seen since Barack Obama."
Talbot County voter Donna Young said she considers this one of the most important elections she's voted in.
"Because women's rights are being taken away from them left and right, and nobody seems to care," she said.
Multiple voters talked about the importance of the single state-wide question on the ballot, which asks voters whether the Declaration of Rights in the Maryland Constitution should be amended to add a new section that guarantees a right to "reproductive freedom."
Talbot County voter Alecia Weaver said her "main thing" is voting against adding this section.
"Because I don't believe in abortion," she said. "I don't believe in killing babies."
Dorchester County voter Beverly Mundorf said inflation, crime and borders were the most important issues to her going into the election. She said she is excited for Trump. Mundorf also said she is excited for Andy Harris, who she said does a lot for the Eastern Shore, an area that can often get overlooked.
Aaron Woolford, a Dorchester County voter, said he is worried about how the world could change if Trump is elected. He said he thinks it could make life harder for himself and other Black Americans.
Ed Weaver, who is registered as an independent, voted for Trump. He said he sees Trump as "the better of two evils."
"Candidates, they really don't talk about the issues," he said. "All you hear is just a smear campaign." Weaver said this has made it more challenging when it comes to making voting decisions.
Talbot County voter Brendan Wazniak — who considers himself an independent — said he voted blue in the presidential, senate and congressional races but said he didn't think there were any "perfect" candidates.
"I think a lot of the people probably feel that way as well," he said. "So, yeah, it does make it a little bit difficult."
For updated results in local and state races, visit stardem.com. For updated results for the presidential race, see the Star Democrat's national e-edition Wednesday, available at stardem.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on election day coverage, discussing national presidential and Senate races alongside local contests, making it primarily political news of national relevance.

title: Dorchester Republicans, eager for change, rally behind Trump as results come in
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester Republicans, eager for change, rally behind Trump as results come in

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — As Sen. Johnny Mautz said his goodbyes just before 9 p.m. at a Tuesday night Dorchester Republican Central Committee watch party, he left saying the three words that became a rallying cry this election cycle for Donald Trump's presidential campaign — "fight, fight, fight."Attendees cheered and carried on that optimism before calling it a night, just hours before the former president claimed victory over Democratic opponent Kamala Harris. While some sighed in disappointment when Democrat Angela Alsobrooks clinched the U.S. Senate seat over Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan, the hopes for a Donald Trump victory remained high.
Earlier Tuesday evening, Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) implored around 30 Republicans gathered for the watch party in a Bay Country Security garage to carry on the values and messages of the Republican Party — no matter the eventual results.
"That message has got to carry on, whether it's one house, two houses, all three, or God forbid, none," Mautz said. "We've got to be prepared for whatever is coming to us, because there is no walking away. There's no ignoring the reality of the division that's in our country right now."
"Make sure we just keep pounding home the priorities and the principles of what our country is founded on, and we're going to succeed," he continued. "And we'll do it because of you guys."
Bill Travers, from East New Market, voted for Trump and felt optimistic while watching the race. He paid close attention to the swing states as numbers came in, standing up to celebrate when he saw Trump hold leads in Georgia, North Carolina and Pennsylvania, three states the Republican candidate later won.
Travers said his support for the former president was never in doubt. He wants to see change in office, disappointed with the country's trajectory under President Joe Biden.
"It's a no-brainer," Travers said. "We need new leadership."
While Travers thinks Trump "needs to be a little more humble," he said the president-elect aligns with his stance against abortion as well as alleviating his concerns regarding gas prices and interest rates.
Tyler Sears, a 17-year-old from Dorchester County, watched closely, with future college endeavors and worries about paying bills among the practical issues on his mind. When asked if he felt the national election would impact his immediate future, Sears said "without a doubt."
The high school senior saw Trump as the candidate who would most benefit him moving forward, saying he likely would've voted Trump if he was 18.
"I'm praying it's Trump," Sears said.
Many hoped Tuesday's election would bring not just a second Trump presidency, but a calming in political division.
Cambridge resident Sandra Potter, 79, was rooting for Trump. She said she's "never seen an election like this," noting the divisiveness it's created and the relationships with friends and family it's splintered.
Two of her children, one a Democrat and one a Republican, disagreed with one another this cycle but still remained on friendly terms. That's something Potter wants to see on a larger scale.
"It's time we pick ourselves up by the bootstraps and move forward," Potter said. " … I hope we never see this discord again. I hope we learn from this election."
Though the watch party's focus was largely directed at the presidential battle, Mautz said in an interview that he noticed a "super high level of attention" on local and national races on Election Day.
"I think the intensity of the national election has intensified all of the candidacies," Mautz said.
As the night grew older, members of the Dorchester County Republican Central Committee and local Republicans celebrated Trump's win in Texas, with one attendee shouting, "God bless Texas." It gave Trump a 178-113 lead in the electoral college, an advantage he never relinquished.
Adorned in a camo 'Ultra MAGA' cap, Potter vowed that despite what she views as tiring political rhetoric from both sides of the aisle, Trump was her preferred choice to assume the role as the country's next commander-in-chief.
"I think he does absolutely take care of our country," Potter said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local Republican watch party reacting to the results of the U.S. presidential election, focusing on national political figures and outcomes, which aligns best with the 'National News' category.

title: Many election results known by Wednesday, some races still awaiting final counts
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Many election results known by Wednesday, some races still awaiting final counts

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 652
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Election night produced some decisive victories on the Mid-Shore, in Maryland and throughout the nation. Despite predictions that it may take several days before results were known, by Wednesday morning, many races had been called, though some ballots remained to be counted.Donald Trump secured his presidential victory when Wisconsin was called in the early hours of Wednesday, culminating the former president's comeback campaign that outperformed expectations.
Going into election night, many predicted it might take days for the results of the presidential election to be tallied. Trump performed better than he did during the 2020 election against President Joe Biden. His Democratic opponent for the seat, Kamala Harris, was unable to carry the necessary votes in swing states to secure her victory.
"I want to thank the American people for the extraordinary honor of being elected your 47th president and your 45th president," Trump told cheering supporters in Mar a Lago, Florida, Tuesday night before his victory was confirmed.
In the closely watched race to replace outgoing U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.), Democrat Angela Alsobrooks faced Republican Larry Hogan, a former Maryland governor. The race was expected to be close going into election night, but the Associated Press called the race for Alsobrooks just hours after polls closed in the state.
Alsobrooks, the current Prince George's County executive, took the lead as precincts began reporting results Tuesday night. With nearly all precincts reporting, as of Wednesday she had collected about 52% of votes to Hogan's 45%, a wide enough margin that the remaining mail-in and provisional ballots to be tallied will not change the outcome.
Alsobrooks' victory marked a historic moment for the state — the election of its first Black female senator. She, along with Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester of Delaware, will join only a handful of Black women who have served in the office when she takes her oath of office in January.
"Now, it's remarkable to think that in two years, America will celebrate its 250th birthday, and in all those years, there have been more than 2,000 people who have served in the United States Senate, and only three have looked like me," Alsobrooks said on stage at her watch party in College Park Tuesday night.
U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) secured his reelection to Maryland's 1st District Congressional seat, a position he has held since 2010.
Harris, who represents the Eastern Shore, had secured 62.8% of the vote in his race as of Wednesday morning, defeating Democratic challenger Blane Miller. About 82% of ballots in the district had been counted at that time.
But while some victories were able to be called, others need to wait until more ballots have been canvassed. In Maryland, election judges will tally remaining mail-in and provisional ballots over the next few weeks.
Among the races still too close to definitively call are all three Talbot County Board of Education races. Cynthia Marrah Jurrius led the District 6 race by just 46 votes as of Wednesday morning. The county's other Board of Education races had only a few hundred votes separating the candidates.
After polls closed at 8 p.m. Tuesday, unofficial votes from the day were made available on the state board of elections website. Those results included early voting totals, mail-in ballots canvassed prior to Election Day and vote tallies from Tuesday.
Provisional ballots will be canvassed on Wednesday, Nov. 13. Counting of mail-in ballots ends on Friday, Nov. 15.
There were more than 6,000 mail-in ballots requested in Talbot County, of which 3,273 had been accepted as of Tuesday. In Caroline County, more than 2,400 mail-in ballots were requested and 880 had been accepted. More than 3,300 mail-in ballots were sent to Dorchester County voters. Dorchester County will not begin canvassing mail-in votes until Thursday.
Official verification of the vote count and certification of Maryland's election is scheduled for Nov. 15. Statewide certification is expected by Dec. 5, within 30 days of the election, as required by law.
Jesse Yeatman contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on election outcomes, including the presidential race and Senate race, which are national-level news topics, while also covering local election details.
