title: Trump offers ridiculous nominees to flaunt power
author: JIM BRUCE
content:
Trump offers ridiculous nominees to flaunt power

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM BRUCE | Section: Columns 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President-elect Trump's extreme nominees for high office have shocked even Republican members of Congress. World history provides examples of national leaders who appointed outrageous and patently unqualified nominees to important positions of power, as a deliberate strategy to aggregate and demonstrate their own power.If this is Trump's objective, the question is, can he carry it off?
The Roman emperor Caligula (37-41 AD) sought to diminish respect for the Roman Senate and its administrative authority, thereby enhancing the emperor's power. He reportedly planned to name his favorite horse, Incitatus, as a consul to preside over the Senate and serve as the chief magistrate of the state. This would humiliate the Roman Senate and imply that their role was merely ceremonial. In the past week, the horse was Matt Gaetz.
Trump's nomination of Matt Gaetz for attorney general was a means of demonstrating Trump's raw political power. The more outrageous the candidate, the greater the demonstration of Trump's absolute control, if Congress acceded. (It would also fulfill his campaign to disrupt the "deep state." Trump's recent nominees are the epitome of disruption.)
The problem was not Gaetz's positions on policy, which we can only infer, but the absurdity of even imagining Gaetz as attorney general because of his lack of experience, expertise and his questionable character. Republican senators were expected to abandon their Constitutional role of advice and consent, fall in line with Trump's wishes, and vote for the nominee, or face future primary challengers.
Suffering another dishonor, senators would have had to vote blindly to confirm Gaetz because Trump seems unwilling to subject his nominees to the normal vetting process. In the House, the speaker chose to protect Trump's nominee by quashing publication of a House Ethics Committee report on Gaetz's sexual transgressions with minors.
If the Senate had voted to confirm Gaetz under these circumstances, then the Senate's Constitutional role of advice and consent is a rubber stamp. This would humiliate Congress and transfer perceived power from them to the White House.
Second, Gaetz' nomination, if he were confirmed, would have belittled and diminished the Justice Department as an institution in the eyes of the public. If stooges run the Justice Department, then obviously the Justice Department has lost its cherished independence, and the real locus of power is the White House. (The first objective of autocrats is to create chaos and seize the wheels of justice.) On Thursday, enough senators had indicated displeasure with Trump's nominee that Gaetz withdrew.
However, there are other horses in Trump's stable, such as Tulsi Gabbard, who is nominated to lead all our intelligence services. She is not just unqualified, but antagonistic to our national interests. Moscow must have broken out the vodka after her nomination. She has no relevant experience in intelligence and even parrots Putin's talking points. This makes her nomination especially odious, which, of course, serves Trump's purposes of demonstrating his power, undermining respect for our intelligence services, which he detests and weakening their ability to contradict the president.
There are other equine-like nominees such as Pete Hegseth for secretary of defense and Robert Kennedy Jr. for Health and Human Services. They all have in common no apparent experience or qualifications for the job, serious questions about their fitness for the office, absolute fealty to Trump, and nomination to agencies about which Trump is contemptuous.
The coming power struggle between Congress and Trump over nominees will provide an initial indication of whether Congress will stand up to Trump and protect their Constitutional authorities, if Trump clearly overreaches and unwisely flaunts his new political power.
If Congress cannot protect its Constitutional prerogatives, then there is another example from history to consider. French King Louis XIV, intentionally appointed sycophants, and weak, incompetent or corrupt persons to high office to undermine powerful institutions in France and to centralize power in himself. In the end, attributed to the French King was his famous claim, "L'etat, c'est moi! — "the state, it is me!" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses federal political appointments and constitutional issues, which are matters of national significance rather than local, sector-specific, or cultural topics.

title: Protecting kids online or social media censorship?: The year-end push for and against the Kids Online Safety Act
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Protecting kids online or social media censorship?: The year-end push for and against the Kids Online Safety Act

 November 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 934
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Attorneys general from 30 states (and from both political parties) are pressing Congress to pass a measure aimed at protecting kids from harmful content online.But free speech advocates worry the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) will lead to censorship, including restricting controversial and unpopular speech that should enjoy First Amendment protections.
On Nov. 18, the 30 attorneys general — including Republicans Austin Knudsen of Montana, Ashley Moody of Florida, Sean Reyes of Utah and Bridget Hill of Wyoming, and Democrats Letitia James of New York, Anthony Brown of Maryland, Kathleen Jennings of Delaware and Keith Ellison of Minnesota — wrote congressional leaders advocating for KOSA's full passage before the end of the year.
The bill passed the U.S. Senate in July but has faced some roadblocks in the U.S. House of Representatives. Congress is currently in a lame-duck period after the Nov. 5 election but before President-elect Donald Trump and a new GOP-controlled Congress take office.
The latest version of the bill requires social media and online companies to install "mandatory default safety settings" related to minors under the age of 16, and requires social media and online platforms to restrict sexual content aimed at minors, online bullying, and content that promotes self harm, illegal drug use or substance abuse.
The measure also looks to further restrict sexual predators and sex traffickers online.
"Many social media platforms target minors, resulting in a national youth mental health catastrophe. These platforms make their products addictive to minor users, and then profit from selling minor user data to advertisers. These platforms fail to disclose the addicting nature of their products, nor the harms associated with increased social media use. Instead, minor users receive endless tailored and toxic content," the attorneys general wrote in their letter to House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and other congressional leaders.
They want KOSA passed and approved by President Joe Biden before the end of the year and before a new Congress and Trump take office in January and the legislative process starts over.
An amended bill before the House better partners with state-level social media pushes, the attorneys general contend, allows users to disable or block some social media content and looks to restrict online content that is detrimental to kids' mental health.
But the latter aim and some of KOSA's other provisions worry free speech advocates. They say the bill — with its laudable title — could be used to censor content that should be protected by First Amendment free speech guarantees.
Greg Gonzalez, legislative counsel for the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE), said the federal bill "presents some very serious free speech and First Amendment concerns."
FIRE and other free speech groups, such as the American Civil Liberties Union, oppose the bill and argue it will step on kids' First Amendment rights.
"Even if it is speech people don't like, it's speech that deserves First Amendment protections," Gonzalez said.
Gonzalez sees scenarios where social media platforms will use KOSA to restrict content that is unpopular or controversial under the guise of protecting children and teens and their mental health.
"At some point, platforms are going to be overly inclusive," he said of the content that could be restricted.
Large social media and online companies restricted, blocked and prohibited some users and content that challenged the results of the 2020 U.S. elections and questioned COVID-19 vaccines. Other groups and users with controversial or extreme political or social views have also been banned by social media sites and de-platformed by online companies.
Some technology companies, including Microsoft, as well as the American Federation of Teachers and parents' groups such as Common Sense Media, back KOSA.
Other tech groups oppose the federal measure. The Electronic Freedom Foundation said the House version of KOSA "is still a dangerous online censorship bill" that "will coerce the largest social media platforms into blocking or filtering a variety of entirely legal content, and subject a large portion of users to privacy-invasive age verification."
Gonzalez also sees age verification efforts — which several states, including Montana, have imposed on pornography sites — raising privacy concerns for minors and adults.
FIRE also does not like the Federal Trade Commission's potential role in KOSA's implementation.
Gonzalez said he hopes the clock runs out on the measure at the end of the year, and free speech groups promise to challenge KOSA in court if it becomes law.
The measure passed the Senate by a 91-3 margin, with support from both sides of the partisan aisle.
"Children and teens have been subjected to online harassment, bullying, and other harms for far too long. The Kids Online Safety Act will require social media companies to design their products with the safety of kids and teens in mind, provide parents tools to protect their kids, and give families more options for managing and disconnecting from these platforms," said Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., who backed the bill along with conservative Republicans such as Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee (a top sponsor of the bill along with U.S. Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn.), Cynthia Lummis of Wyoming and Steve Daines of Montana.
U.S. Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., voted against the bill, along with conservative Republican U.S. Sens. Mike Lee of Utah and Rand Paul of Kentucky.
Wyden said earlier this year he worries about KOSA eroding online privacy for kids and teens, and an incoming Trump administration using the law to censor political and social voices it does not like.
"I fear KOSA could be used to sue services that offer privacy technologies like encryption or anonymity features that kids rely on to communicate securely and privately without being spied on by predators online," said Wyden, explaining his opposition in a social media statement earlier this year. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a federal legislative measure (Kids Online Safety Act) and its national political context, making it primarily a piece of national news. It also touches on public safety and health aspects, but the core focus is the nationwide policy debate.

title: Race was model for civil discourse in politics
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Race was model for civil discourse in politics

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 741
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I, along with countless others, closely followed a recent U.S. Senate election in Pennsylvania.The stakes in this election were extremely high. The outcome was expected to help decide if Republican senators or Democratic senators would have a majority in and control of the Senate for at least the next two years.
In this election, voters had a clear choice between two candidates with sharply differing views on President Biden's performance record over the past four years.
Both candidates raised and spent hundreds of millions of dollars on advertising to share their differing views with voters. As a result, voters had numerous opportunities to reach informed decisions on which candidate's views resonated best with their own views.
Prior to the election, conventional wisdom was incumbent Democratic Sen. Robert P. Casey Jr. would win reelection.
Senator Casey's father, Robert P. Casey Sr., was a popular and still widely revered former governor of Pennsylvania. Casey Jr. was elected to the U.S. Senate three times after being elected once for state treasurer and twice for state auditor general.
Consistent with many other expected election outcomes this year, conventional wisdom proved to be wrong.
It was wrong, in part because Donald Trump's better than expected support in Pennsylvania generated votes (aka coattails) that helped Dave McCormick, Casey's Republican opponent. At the same time, Kamala Harris' lower than expected support in Pennsylvania did not generate enough votes (aka coattails) to help Casey.
In any event, the outcome of the election was incredibly close.
Before the results were certified, McCormick had 48.8 % of the vote and Casey had 48.6% of the vote. The close results triggered a state law mandating an automatic government-funded recount since the margin of difference was less than 0.5%. The law allows the projected "losing" candidate to decline a recount. Not surprisingly, Casey chose not to do so.
While the recount was underway lawyers for both campaigns engaged in aggressive attempts to seek a Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruling to determine if state law allowed incorrectly dated, undated, incorrectly signed, or unsigned provisional ballots to be counted.
A majority of the seven-member court ruled in a 4-3 vote that state law was clear that these provisional ballots could not be counted. This majority opinion included two Democratic justices voting no and two Republican justices voting no.
Following the Supreme Court ruling but before a recount was finished, Casey conceded.
In his concession speech, Casey thanked the people of Pennsylvania for the privilege of serving them and for placing their trust in him. He said it has been the honor of his lifetime.
In his speech, Casey never expressed bitterness or anger over the election outcome, nor did he assign blame for his loss. He did not complain about an aggressive and ultimately successful effort by attorneys with the McCormick campaign to secure the court ruling prohibiting the counting of certain provisional ballots. Casey noted that he followed a long-standing protocol in politics by calling McCormick to congratulate him on his win.
In response to Casey's concession call, McCormick released a statement that included the following — "Senator Bob Casey dedicated his career to bettering our Commonwealth. Dina and I want to extend our sincere gratitude to Senator Casey, Teresa, and their family for their decades of service, hard work, and sacrifice."
In McCormick's statement, there was no gloating or disparaging remarks about his opponent. He did not complain about an aggressive, extended and ultimately unsuccessful effort by attorneys with the Casey campaign to secure a court ruling allowing the counting of certain provisional ballots.
Some may say both candidates' post-election remarks were carefully scripted by campaign staff and were insincere at best and at worse masked the candidate's true feelings.
Maybe so, but I disagree. I believe both candidates' remarks were sincere and from the heart.
Their remarks reflected the character of two opposing candidates who ran issue-based campaigns, focused on telling voters about significant differences of their positions on critical issues of the day.
When the election results were finally confirmed almost two weeks after Election Day, both candidates accepted a court ruling (the rule of law), accepted the election results and displayed respect for each other.
I suggest their actions reflect a small, but long overdue missing commitment to civil discourse in today's contentious and increasingly polarized world.
The actions of soon-to-be former Sen. Casey and now Sen.-elect McCormick are a model for civil discourse in the political arena.
Going forward, that model should be embraced by every candidate and the supporters of every candidate in every election at every level in America. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The piece discusses a recent U.S. Senate election, recount, and court rulings—issues of broad political significance that fit the National News category rather than the other listed topics.

title: The 2024 election was no Republican landslide
author: LENA GILL
content:
The 2024 election was no Republican landslide

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 542
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The election was no landslide and certainly no mandate for Donald F. Trump to create the total upheaval of the government represented by the president-elect's choices for his cabinet.A landslide was when Lyndon B. Johnson won by 16 million votes in 1964, while Donald Trump won by 2.5 million votes in 2024. For Lyndon B. Johnson it represented more than 60% of the popular vote. For Donald F. Trump it represents 50% of the popular vote while Kamala Harris won 48.4%. (A few races are being recounted, as is required if they are very close, so these numbers are not final.)
Five presidents from the out-of-power party have won with a larger share of the popular vote than Donald Trump did. They are Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952, Jimmy Carter in 1976, Ronald Reagan in 1980, Barack Obama in 2008 and Biden in 2020.
Lyndon Johnson is not listed here, as his party was in power when he was reelected in 1964 as mentioned above.
Trump's win at the top of the ticket did not help down-ballot candidates much in some swing states and elsewhere. In Arizona, Democrat Rep. Ruben Gallego was elected to the Senate; in Michigan, Democrat Rep. Elissa Slotkin was elected to the Senate. In Nevada, incumbent Sen. Jacky Rosen was reelected. In Wisconsin incumbent Sen. Tammy Baldwin was reelected.
The Republicans won the Senate by three seats. The Republicans won the House narrowly by 220 seats versus 215 for the Democrats. This may not be the final tally as Trump may choose more congressmen or women for his cabinet and all races are not yet finalized.
Closer to home in Maryland, Kamala Harris won with 63% of the votes. Donald Trump received 34.4% of the votes. Democrat Angela Alsobrooks was elected to the Senate by 528,659 votes as compared to Republican Larry Hogan's 433,416 votes. She is one of two new senators who is Black and female. The other is the new senator from Delaware, Lisa Blunt Rochester (D).
In Talbot County, the latest tally (dated Nov. 11) was Trump 11,125 votes and Harris 11,119 votes. This difference of six votes does not a landslide make. Three districts in Talbot County voted for members of the Board of Education. Ann C. O'Connor in District 2 received 1,678 votes. Karla Wieland-Cherry in District 5 received 1,590 votes and Cynthia Marrah Jurrius in District 6 received 1,523 votes.
The reason, I include these results is that Ms. Jurrius was the only one recommended by the teachers. Voters may not have been aware that Ms. O'Connor and Ms. Wieland-Cherry apparently belong to a conservative national group called Moms for Liberty. They advocate for changes in curriculum and policies. The meetings of the Board of Education in Talbot County may become very interesting.
The fact that Donald Trump did not win by a landslide does not negate that he won a trifecta of power — the presidency, the Senate and the House. Like many presidents before him, he will have two years to make the changes with which he has threatened. If the voters do not approve of his plans to arrest the undocumented and putting them in concentration camps or tariffs on friendly countries such as Canada and Mexico, the midterm elections may stop Trump in his tracks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the 2024 presidential election results and their implications, which is a national political news story.

title: What happened? Professor explains Trump's victory to local Dems
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
What happened? Professor explains Trump's victory to local Dems

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 843
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What went wrong this November? What happened? Democrats, have been asking that question since President-elect Donald Trump won the White House seat against Vice President Kamala Harris.For Kent County Democrats, last month, they looked to Dan Nataf, professor of political science history, political science and philosophy at Anne Arundel Community College, for the answers.
Since 1995, Nataf has directed the Center for the Study of Local Issues, which conducts surveys of Anne Arundel County residents and students. He's been "passionate how material interests, institutional frameworks and ideology interact to shape political outcomes."
His background makes him a good candidate, pun intended, to explain what happened, lending his expertise to the Zoom meeting attended by members of the Democratic Club of Kent County and the Kent County Democratic Central Committee.
Trump won, Nataf said, but how?
He said because despite what their political opponents claim, it was within a small margin of victory...not by a landslide.
Nataf added, seven million people who voted for Biden in 2020, stayed home this time; that made the difference.
Seven million disappeared, and he explained why, looking into the past.
In 1980, Nataf stated, a democratic model of governance shifted to a more economic model. A newfound emphasis was placed on free trade, low taxes and small government, he noted.
Nataf listed off a multitude of reasons for this shift.
The dependency for the working class waned because of automation. The fear of being attacked after the Cold War was gone, and so the working class were not as valued in some influential circles as they once were.
Companies moved out and found low-cost labor, avoiding unions, Nataf explained.
A gender divide was created too, Nataf said, because there was a new focus on white collar jobs, not blue collar jobs, and so women could compete with men. This also created a college/blue collar divide as well.
In this mode of thinking, Nataf noted, the rich got richer, and America gets split into winners and losers.
Nataf said the thinking was winners went to college and found white collar jobs.
This philosophy affected everyone.
On the Republican side they became neoconservatives; Democrats became neoliberals, Nataf said. And this philosophy drove the parties for years, the professor added.
He illustrated that through those years, neoliberals like former presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama unified their party. The Democrats did not break from that leadership.
But within the Republican camp, there arose a mistrust for neoconservative leadership, Natal said. Under former President George W. Bush, after 9/11, many conservatives were discontent by what they viewed as their leaders' endless wars.
Nataf painted a picture the conditions were ripe for a charismatic leader to move in. With many Democrats attached to the universities, and blue collar Republicans disillusioned, angry, many years later — 2014, enter Trump.
According to Nataf, Trump won using a zero-sum model.
He preached America first and that the country should not be the world's savior. That was different from the Republican leadership, Natal said.
Trump talked about immigration in the negative which goes along with his list of the undeserving, Nataf said. The professor said Trump listed the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) Ukrainians and immigrants especially as undeserving, Nataf said.
Nataf said with this rebellion from traditional leadership, Trump used the zero-sum model to ultimately take over the Republican Party, taking advantage of the lower class.
There were many other reasons Nataf gave for Trump's victory as well.
He said that President Joe Biden should have exited the race sooner. He called those who voted for Trump ill-informed, and at times, "couch potatoes," in their research.
He said that after Covid-19, and the economical instability, it would have been challenging for the incumbent party to win anyway.
Nataf then took some time in his lecture for questions. There were a few. One woman made more of a statement, when she said America was not willing to vote for a "woman of color." She also said that Trump divided men and women as a strategy.
Nataf thought the latter was a good point, claiming that Trump, when faced with Harris, put on the alpha male persona. He said that an angry populace took to Trump's "macho behavior," and Harris' "joy" was not relatable.
Nataf repeated, it was a narrow margin of victory.
He said most of the country already decided on who they were voting for. The votes were already "baked in," he mentioned, therefore it just took a small amount of voters to stay home to make a big change.
Overall, though, Nataf's message was that Trump won the blue collar workers, those who were forgotten about by Democrats since the 80's.
And so the question was what can Democrats do to win them going forward?
Would the Democrats have to move more to the center, Nataf asked his audience.
Or, he said, perhaps Trump will be so bad the Democrats would not have to move at all. They will naturally come back to the party after seeing who they voted for.
"It is going to take some self-reflecting," Nataf acknowledged referring to the Democrat party.
The Democratic Club of Kent County meets most months in Chestertown, on the third Thursday of the month. You can contact them at info@dckcmd.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: It's too early to call election a realignment
author: DAVID REEL
content:
It's too early to call election a realignment

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 764
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following the 2024 presidential election, some political observers have suggested this election was a realignment election that bodes well for Republican presidential candidates and other Republican candidates going forward.Not so fast.
Any meaningful discussion on that suggestion must include a review of research done by political scientist V.O. Key, a preeminent scholar on American elections and voting behavior.
Key's criteria for a realignment election includes shifts in party attachment that extends over several presidential elections and appear to be independent of the peculiar factors that influenced the vote at individual elections.
Using Key's criteria, a determination if the 2024 presidential election marks the start of a political realignment cannot be made yet. It may be eventually but only if the results of future consecutive elections replicate the results of the 2024 presidential cycle elections.
For now, we know the 2024 presidential election was a performance evaluation decision on President Joe Biden's policies and priorities. After Vice President Kamala Harris replaced Biden on the ballot, the election became an opportunity to gauge voter approval on their expectations on policies and priorities in a Harris administration.
We also now know the Harris campaign failed to convince a majority of voters that her administration would be different from the Biden administration. Nothing more, nothing less.
2024 also provided voters with performance evaluation decisions for three long-term incumbent Democratic U.S. senators from Ohio, Pennsylvania and Montana. All three lost in their reelection bids. In West Virginia, a Republican candidate was elected to replace a Democratic incumbent senator who retired in anticipation of losing reelection.
Eventually, the 2024 presidential and U.S. Senate elections may become viewed as the first in a series of elections that taken together, are true realignment elections. The next election cycles that will help answer the realignment question will be the 2026 Congressional mid-term elections and the 2028 presidential election (one unlikely to have an incumbent candidate).
Which party will do well going forward will be determined in large part to who responds best to key unanswered questions as well as to lessons learned from the 2024 presidential election.
For the Republican Party, key unanswered questions from 2024 include:
Can they maintain support from the influential and demanding MAGA wing of the party? Some MAGA Republicans are already angry over reports that four Republican senators opposed Matt Gaetz's nomination for attorney general (now withdrawn at Gaetz's request). More importantly, can the Republican Party retain blocs of historically Democratic voters who gave higher levels of support to Trump in 2024 than he received from them in 2016 and 2020. That largely unexpected outcome included to varying degrees, more support for Donald Trump and other down ballot Republican candidates from young Black male voters, Hispanic/Latino voters, young male voters, working class voters and urban voters.
For the Democratic Party, key unanswered questions from 2024 include:
Can they maintain support from the influential and demanding progressive wing of the party? Already, some progressive Democrats are resisting any effort to pivot to more centrist positions on issues such as immigration restrictions, immigration deportations, deficit spending and aid to Israel. More importantly, can the Democratic Party regain blocs of historically Democratic voters who gave lower than anticipated support for Kamala Harris?
All things considered, I suggest the most important avenues to future election success for both parties, are candidates who do the best job of executing the following campaign strategies.
Listen intently to the voters. Remember that listening is more than waiting for your turn to talk. Remember to seek first to understand, then seek to be understood.
Respect what voters are saying, whether or not you agree with them. Meet them where they are, not where you think they should be.
Accept voter message development counsel from media guru Frank Lunz. "It's not what you say or write, it is what people hear or read. You can have the best message in the world, but the person on the receiving end will always understand it through the prism of their own emotions, preconceptions, prejudices and preexisting beliefs. Get your audience to visualize … imagine. Only when people can see a better future will they consider a change."
Have confidence your party can deliver measurable results on campaign promises. There is always another election cycle when voters can exercise their right to vote against candidates they perceive to be unresponsive to their views on what matters most to them.
With regard to the question of whether the 2024 presidential election was the first in a series of elections that will result in a political realignment that bodes well for Republican presidential candidates as well as other Republican candidates long term, the answers are:
To be determined.
Time will tell. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Delaware woman among 39 people pardoned by Biden
author: Staff and wire reports
content:
Delaware woman among 39 people pardoned by Biden

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff and wire reports | Section: News 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A woman from Bear, Delaware is among the 39 people pardoned by U.S. President Joe Biden on Thursday.Patrice Chante Sellers, now 49, pleaded guilty to distribution of cocaine in 2003, according to court records. She was sentenced to six months house arrest and three years of probation.
A Biden spokesperson said that under current law and sentencing practice, Sellers likely would not have been prosecuted federally.
"Since her conviction, Ms. Sellers enrolled in school, earning multiple certifications and licenses," the White House statement said in a statement. "She gives back to her community by donating clothing and toiletries to a transitional housing program and offering encouragement to its residents. Community members describe Ms. Sellers as someone who goes above and beyond for others."
Sellers' pardon is part of the largest single-day act of clemency in modern history. In addition to the 39 pardons, Biden also commuted the sentences of roughly 1,500 people who were released from prison and placed on home confinement during the coronavirus pandemic.
The commutations announced Thursday are for people who have served out home confinement sentences for at least one year after they were released. Prisons were uniquely bad for spreading the virus and some inmates were released in part to stop the spread. At one point, 1 in 5 prisoners had COVID-19, according to a tally kept by The Associated Press.
Biden said he would be taking more steps in the weeks ahead and would continue to review clemency petitions. The second largest single-day act of clemency was by Barack Obama, with 330, shortly before leaving office in 2017.
"America was built on the promise of possibility and second chances," Biden said in a statement. "As president, I have the great privilege of extending mercy to people who have demonstrated remorse and rehabilitation, restoring opportunity for Americans to participate in daily life and contribute to their communities, and taking steps to remove sentencing disparities for non-violent offenders, especially those convicted of drug offenses."
The clemency follows a broad pardon for his son Hunter, who was prosecuted for gun and tax crimes. Biden is under pressure from advocacy groups to pardon broad swaths of people, including those on federal death row, before the Trump administration takes over in January. He's also weighing whether to issue preemptive pardons to those who investigated Trump's effort to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election and are facing possible retribution when he takes office.
Clemency is the term for the power the president has to pardon, in which a person is relieved of guilt and punishment, or to commute a sentence, which reduces or eliminates the punishment but doesn't exonerate the wrongdoing. It's customary for a president to grant mercy at the end of his term, using the power of the office to wipe away records or end prison terms.
Those pardoned Thursday range in age from 36 to 75. About half are men and half are women, and they had been convicted of nonviolent crimes such as drug offenses, fraud or theft and turned their lives around, White House lawyers said. They include a woman who led emergency response teams during natural disasters; a church deacon who has worked as an addiction counselor and youth counselor; a doctoral student in molecular biosciences; and a decorated military veteran. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trump moving with urgency through transition
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Trump moving with urgency through transition

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As President-elect Donald Trump moves forward on a transition to his second term, he is affirming his oft-stated objective to be a disrupter to business as usual in Washington, D.C.He is doing so in several ways.
First and foremost, Trump has been moving quickly on choosing individuals for his cabinet, sub-cabinet positions and senior staff positions.
Not surprisingly, this has generated criticism from media outlets, individuals in academia and not-for-profit organizations like the Partnership for Public Service, a group that identifies itself as a nonpartisan advocate focused on building a better government and stronger democracy.
With regard to the media, the headline for a recent Associated Press article was — "Trump sets records with pace of appointments, but that doesn't mean the transition is going smoothly."
In the article, the reporter mixed news with opinion, when he wrote, "In the two weeks since Election Day, President-elect Donald Trump has been setting records with the pace of appointments for his incoming administration. But speed shouldn't be confused with organization."
With regard to academia, David Marchick, dean of the Kogod School of Business at American University and co-author of a book on presidential transitions, has said, "Last time they were slow and disorganized, this time they're fast and disorganized."
With regard to the Partnership for Public Service, Max Stier, their president and CEO, has said that Trump's team is missing a critical component of the process. Stier noted Trump is moving at least four times as quickly at rolling out his cabinet as his modern predecessors, but added: "They're moving with speed, but they're making new mistakes."
Stier identified one of the biggest mistakes is a lack of proper vetting saying, "He's going at breakneck, reckless speed because there's no vetting. Moving fast isn't a very good strategy if you don't move well — and they're not moving well."
Stier also has said, "It's being done quickly, but it's being done without the kind of due diligence that ordinarily takes place and ensures that mistakes are not made."
With regard to Stier's observation on due diligence, I suggest that recruiting individuals for serving at high levels in government is a most challenging process. As a result, there are never foolproof ways to ensure that mistakes are not made.
Stier's criticism on vetting and due diligence is a moot issue now as Trump's transition team recently signed an agreement with the Justice Department to conduct FBI background checks despite them not being required by law.
A quick review of the Trump transition efforts to date reflects that he has announced choices for 31 cabinet secretaries and sub cabinet positions that require Senate approval, and 28 senior staff positions that do not require Senate approval.
To date, only two announced choices are no longer under consideration: former Congressman Matt Gaetz for attorney general and Hillsborough County Florida Sherriff Chad Chronister to head the federal Drug Enforcement Agency. Gaetz has said his withdrawal from further consideration was voluntary, Trump has said the Chronister withdrawal from further consideration was not voluntary, despite earlier comments from Chronister that it was.
Trump is not the first president-elect to experience challenges with candidate vetting.
Previous President-elects whose announced choices withdrew from consideration before Senate consideration include Clinton (four times), George W. Bush (three times), Obama (two times) and Biden (one time). The Senate also rejected George W. Bush's secretary of defense choice which was unexpected since his nominee was a former three-term U.S. senator.
Donald Trump is proceeding with an acute awareness (reinforced in last month's congressional election results) that control in Congress is subject to change at any time. This is the case especially after midterm elections, but also by members leaving Congress due to a debilitating illness, death, early retirement and resignations to accept other opportunities.
Trump knows that despite their current minority status in Congress, Democratic members of Congress are preparing strategies and tactics to aggressively challenge, modify or stop the plans of the Trump administration over the next four years. These strategies and tactics are more likely to succeed if members of the Democratic party flip control of one or both houses of Congress anytime during Trump's four-year term.
Accordingly, Donald Trump and his advisors are proceeding on a transition and a governing philosophy in a manner consistent with an observation of Harvard Professor John Kotter in his book "A Sense of Urgency."
Kotter writes: "The single most crucial factor in achieving permanent and meaningful change is a continuous sense of urgency. A true sense of urgency occurs when you acknowledge action on critical issues is needed now, not eventually, not when it fits easily into your schedule. Now means making real progress every single day. Urgent behavior is not driven by a belief that all is well or that everything is a mess but, instead, that the world contains great opportunities and great hazards." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the president‑elect's transition, cabinet appointments, and federal political dynamics, which are classic national political news rather than any of the other specific categories.

title: New sheriff in town
author: Staff Writer
content:
New sheriff in town

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 So Biden pardons his crooked son Hunter. Who cares.This has been going on with presidents for the last 200 years, both Republican and Democrat. The only difference is they usually wait until hours before their final departure on the last day. It's small potatoes pertaining to this country's much needed, work at hand. This country is broken.
The Justice Department is at the top of the list. It's weaponized, pure and simple. All the cases against President Trump were all far-reaching garbage. Proof does exist that a Biden White House line of communication did exist with the prosecutors in all five cases. Are we to believe that White House lawyers were needed to facilitate these cases? State lawyers just weren't capable? Tell that to Alvin Bragg's office who prevailed in a sham case where federal prosecutors all passed. This one's sure to be overturned on appeal.
We're supposed to swallow that Biden is not accountable for mishandling of classified material but President Trump is? What about the Clinton sock drawer president? A federal judge has already ruled on this issue. Even if Jack Smith did prevail in a D.C. courtroom, it was always going to be thrown out on appeal.
And why if Trump was not convicted of any criminal violation in the E. Jean Carrol case, should a N.Y. Leftist court award her even one dime? She first brought this allegation in 2019 during Trump's first presidency and more than 24 years after its alleged occurrence in 1995. An $83 million judgement. More lawfare.
Finally, the shame of the century, the N.Y. fraud lawsuit conviction, where there were no victims, and only industry-accepted accounting practices used to precure business loans. This N.Y. hack judge erroneously attributes a value on the Mar-a-Lago property, under valuing it by more than $50 million and upon Trump's easily overturn able conviction, awards New York a whopping $364 million judgment. More lawfare.
Well there's a new sheriff in town, and he learned plenty in his first term. The country has spoken, and it's time to return America to what it once was, a government of law, not men.
Bondi, Patel and Ratcliffe and Homan are just the right people to allow President Trump to govern while they start the long arduous task of overhauling this corrupt mess of a county. The louder the machine protest, the more we know we're on the right track.
CRAIG WILLIS
St. Michaels
