title: DOGE is not first attempt to reduce government
author: DAVID REEL
content:
DOGE is not first attempt to reduce government

 March 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 948
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Hardly a day goes by without continuous updates from Washington, D.C., on plans of and actions by the Trump administration's Department of Government Efficiency, commonly referred to as DOGE.President Trump created DOGE with an executive order on the first day of his second term, affirming it is a key element of his second term agenda. Elon Musk is heading DOGE as a special government employee.
Strong resistance to DOGE started immediately and has not slowed since then. A lawsuit challenging the legality and authority of was filed the same day DOGE was created. Since then, numerous lawsuits have been filed, including those charging DOGE's efforts to access federal agency data violate federal privacy laws.
As of now, questions on how many and exactly how the U.S. Supreme Court will address these lawsuits is anyone's guess.
One question not receiving much attention is the history of and possible lessons learned from past efforts on improving government efficiency and reducing government spending.
The first such effort occurred in 1947 when Congress created the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, commonly referred to as the Hoover Commission, as former President Herbert Hoover chaired it.
In 1953, Congress approved the Second Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government also commonly referred to as a Hoover Commission, as former President Hoover chaired it.
In 1982, former President Reagan created The President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control, commonly referred to as the Grace Commission, as it was chaired by corporate executive J. Peter Grace, who was an industrialist and CEO of W.R. Grace and Company, a diversified chemical company.
In 1993, former President Clinton launched the National Performance Review (NPR), also commonly referred to as Reinventing Government. Leading it was former Vice President Gore.
Former President Obama established three groups. They were the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform whose co-chairs were former U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson and former White House Chief of Staff Erskine Bowles; the Domenici-Rivlin Debt Reduction Task Force, chaired by former U.S. Sen. Pete Domenici and Alice Rivlin, former director of the Office of management and Budget and former Federal Reserve Board Vice Chair. The third group, Campaign to Cut Waste, was a large group of Obama administration officials with the stated goal of "hunting down and eliminating misspent tax dollars in every agency and department across the Federal Government."
In a recent article on President Trump's DOGE initiative, John Kamensky, emeritus senior fellow at the IBM Center for The Business of Government, and Mark Abramson, president at Leadership Inc., suggest the following key elements are important for success in federal government spending change efforts:
"Making government work better can gain significant support in Congress as was seen in the first Hoover Commission and the Reinventing Government initiatives. When recommendations need congressional approval, being fast can make a difference. When a reform initiative spans the life of more than one Congress — and there is a chance that either house may flip to the opposing party — then bolder recommendations can be jeopardized. Moving fast also allows more time to focus on implementation. This was a strength of the Reinventing Government initiative.
Reform efforts that try to make government cheaper, such as by eliminating programs or reducing headcount, necessarily involve Congress. Such an emphasis was a stumbling block for the second Hoover Commission and the Grace Commission. Including career civil servants in the work of a reform initiative can increase the success of the "improving program" initiatives since they can gain "buy-in" from the civil service. In contrast, the "eliminating programs" approach has been predominately staffed by individuals outside of government, and civil service "buy-in" was not sought.
Kamensky and Mark Abramson conclude with writing, "At the time of this writing, DOGE has not been operating like any of these past reform efforts, where the need for change is assessed, and recommendations are made for the president and Congress to act upon."
I suggest there is a crucial omission from their observations on the underlying rationale on President Trump's decisions to move quickly and aggressively on the DOGE agenda. Those decisions include bypassing Congress for input on and approval of DOGE goals and operations.
I suggest Trump's thinking reflects a sense of urgency on addressing the steadily increasing national debt. In 2000, that debt was $5.659 trillion, approximately 56% of the country's gross domestic product. By 2010, the national debt was $13.562 trillion, approximately 93% of GDP. It is projected to reach $37 trillion in June of this year.
Despite current and yet to be filed court challenges to DOGE, it remains to be seen what the final decisions will be on those court challenges, especially any rulings handed down by the U.S. Supreme Court.
I suggest any mandates on congressional involvement on DOGE plans and actions may not be relevant going forward, even if the courts rule that a president cannot implement DOGE activities without some levels of congressional input and approval.
The current Republican majorities in Congress have been relatively uninvolved in any efforts to slow down or stop DOGE plans and actions.
If court rulings do limit the scope and authority of DOGE, I suggest Congressional Republicans will move to approve whatever is deemed legally necessary to allow DOGE plans and actions to continue.
As always that could change based on the results of the 2026 midterm election cycle which is already underway.
I further suggest, if Republicans retain control of Congress in the 2026 mid-term elections, they will be even more inclined to approve future DOGE plans and actions at least through the end of Trump's second term.
If the Democrats regain control of the House, the Senate or both, DOGE will be no more than a footnote in the history of Trump's second term. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a federal government initiative (DOGE), its political context, legal challenges, and implications for national policy and elections, which aligns best with the National News category.

title: Pair of World War II vets honored as they turn 100
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Pair of World War II vets honored as they turn 100

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A salute earlier this month to two Maryland men who served in World War II and are reaching the age of 100 was as much a celebration of citizenship as it was age and military service.The birthday celebration for Calvert Count yresidents John William Mackall Sr. and Robert Augusto Padilla was held at a jam-packed Lusby American Legion. The chance to say "thank you" to a remarkable generation drew the attention of several community leaders.
"The World War II generation is just something different," Brandon Temple, chairman of the Calvert Commission for Veterans and Military Families, said.
The event was a collaborative effort by the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
In fact, it was VFW Post 2632 in St. Mary's County that received an inquiry that led to the special event.
Marco Padilla wanted to make sure his grandfather's contributions eight decades ago would be remembered for his 100th birthday. Robert "Roberto" Augusto Padilla turned 100 on Tuesday.
"We all knew he was going to live to be 100," Marco told Southern Maryland News. "He's incredibly healthy. We just wanted to honor him. We reached out to the VFW, we went to their website."
Roberto Padilla's story is a wartime odyssey that led to U.S. citizenship that was paid forward from day one.
"He was born in Guatemala," Marco said. "His father was a diplomat. He lived in Italy until he was 17."
When Roberto's family moved to the U.S., the teen enlisted in the U.S. Army and became part of the U.S. Army's 23rd infantry.
"He was a medic," Marco said of his grandfather, who served from July 1943 to May 12, 1945.
Roberto saw action during the Normandy invasion in 1944, which helped librate Europe.
For his bravery and as one of the country's newer citizens, he was awarded the European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal and an overseas service bar.
When his military service ended, Roberto Padilla settled in Maryland, established a successful business in Washington, D.C., and raised seven children.
"He's our patriarch," Marco said. "We're incredibly proud. We owe everything to him."
Mackall, who enlisted in 1944, embarked on a 24-year career with the U.S. Army, retiring in 1968 as a staff sergeant.
During his military career, Mackall earned the National Defense Service Medal with Oak Leaf Cluster and the Army Commendation Medal. He is also recognized as an expert marksman.
Post-military, Mackall served the Sunderland community as its postmaster for 20 years and has been active with the American Legion's Gray-Ray Post 220 in Prince Frederick.
While Mackall's American Legion membership has spanned 80 years, Padilla had no prior veterans organization tie. That situation was remedied Sunday when the local legionnaires presented him with a membership.
Joe Cicchollo, the Veterans of Foreign Wars' Maryland commander, told the audience the who participated in the World War II campaign truly are "the greatest generation," making contributions to labor, economics and civic organizations.
"We have to say 'thank you' to the veterans," Cicchollo said.
"We've got a lot of good veterans here in Southern Maryland," Harry Pool, Post 2632 commander, said of the members who aid others in the community.

title: Relighting candles over the years
author: Staff Writer
content:
Relighting candles over the years

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, as I was sorting through papers I have kept over the years, I came across a letter to the editor of the Philadelphia Inquirer that I had written on March 30, 1982. Of course, I was much younger then.I had attended a peaceful protest march to Stop the Nuclear Arms Race. There were two images I particularly carried with me from that experience. I still do.
Quoting from that letter: "The first is the image of the middle of the road. With police and courteous drivers granting us the right of way, we walked literally down the middle of the roads leading from our meeting places to Independence Hall, over 15,000 people joined in a cause neither radical nor reactionary, but reasonable, logical, right and absolutely necessary."
"The second is the image of the lighted candle. In the cold night with a chill wind blowing, one has to be alert and active to keep one's candle burning. Mine went out several times, but when mine went out the candle of the person next to me seemed to stay lit. Someone's candle always re-lit mine, and I had chances to re-light others' too."
We are all older now, and the issues are surely different; however, some seem equally dangerous. The United States of America must not desert Ukraine and our allies in the free world. In my opinion that would be unprincipled, even immoral and extremely ill-advised for the sake of our own nation.
Again, quoting from the letter, "I hope and pray our political, intellectual, scientific, social and religious leaders will put their enormous energies into finding a way that will not embrace the extreme ... but will find a way for peace with justice." I believe that is what the great majority of citizens in our country want, and it is our duty to say so. As someone who sometimes finds it hard to keep one candle lit, I think I must try harder. If this letter has re-lit anyone else's candle, I am glad.
PATRICIA BRADLEY
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an editorial reflecting on past anti‑nuclear protests and current geopolitical issues such as Ukraine, which are matters of national and international significance rather than sports, health, or local topics.

title: Americans must speak out
author: Staff Writer
content:
Americans must speak out

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last Saturday night, the Trump regime used ICE to illegally detain Mahmoud Khalil (a green card holder) without warrant or charge, to try to arrest his pregnant wife and to kidnap Khalil to an undisclosed location it refused to share with his family. This illegal, terrorizing behavior would be expected from a dictatorship but not from our government.Any doubt as to the in terrorem role ICE would serve for the Trump regime is quickly vanishing. ICE is for Trump what the Gestapo was for Hitler, a force to stifle opposition with threats, force and torture.
Khalil has no criminal record. All he did was to exercise his Constitutional rights by organizing peaceful protests at Columbia that opposed continued funding for Netanyahu as Netanyahu committed well-documented war crimes against Palestinians.
When confronted, ICE first claimed Khalil's visa was being revoked but, when informed that he has a green card, changed its story to state his green card was being revoked. However, the decision to revoke a green card can only be made by an immigration judge after the government procures a warrant, makes a legal arrest, files charges, tries the person, convicts the person and allows that person to exhaust all appeals.
Instead of allowing the due process our Constitution affords every person – citizen or not – the Trump regime executed an autocratic move to stifle dissent and disappear a dissenter that resembles the manner in which Putin deals with dissenters in Russia. This amounts to government terrorism and follows the Trump regime's open repression of student activism and political speech, in this instance criticism of Israel and Netanyahu. Thus, the Trump regime has shown it will use immigration to suppress free speech.
If Columbia secretly colluded with the Trump regime in the arrest, it may be a result of the regime's recent cancellation of $400 million in grants and contracts. Trump proved that he is willing to use extortion to achieve personal goals when threatened to withhold funding to force Ukraine to announce an investigation of Biden, so it is not surprising that Trump would use extortion to force colleges to kowtow to his wishes to silence dissent by wrongfully withholding the funds they are entitled to receive, but it is chilling.
Americans must speak out against this brutal and illegal conduct.
JACK L. WUERKER
Tilghman

title: Free world is divorcing us

Free world is divorcing us

 The March 8-9 edition of your paper gave some good reasons not to reelect Andy Harris.You quote Harris saying: "…I'm hoping with the economic growth we have, we're going to provide plenty of private sector jobs for those leaving the federal government."
Your paper also reported on two NOAA scientists who were fired from the lab in Oxford. I am sure they were not fired for cause. They were fired because Elon Musk was given authority to fire government employees, and he appears to get his gets kicks doing that. (See his chainsaw antics at CPAC.)
Where are those two fired scientists going to get private sector jobs? As reported in the Chesapeake Bay Journal March 2025, Trump is destroying all Bay protection agencies. Musk is firing federal scientists everywhere. Will Harris name some private companies that are going to take over protection of the Chesapeake Bay? Tesla? Starlink? Meta? Amazon? Maybe the two Oxford scientists can get jobs at an Amazon warehouse.
Jobs for the thousands of employees working for Veterans Affairs have been targeted for firing. People have been fired from security agencies that protect us from Russia. What companies are going to do that work? United Heath Care? Pfizer? Maybe each person buying Trump's gold card for $5 million to enter the U.S. will be required to adopt two veterans and assign one person to provide cybersecurity for America.
Mr. Harris's answer that private sector jobs will fulfill these requirements is a tragic joke.
Mr. Harris is also quoted as saying what an honor it was for him to sit next to the leader of the free world. That can't be Trump. He directed the U.S. to vote with North Korea, Iran and Russia denying a resolution supporting Ukraine. A prominent Republican of old called North Korea and Iran part of the "Axis of Evil." The free world, they ain't.
Many countries in the free world are at economic war with us. Our free world friends, such as Canada, are being courted by China to get themselves out of Trump's toxic world order.
The free world is divorcing us, and it seems everyone knows that except Mr. Harris.
If you disagree with Musk disemboweling the government while gleefully prancing around and ruining lives, and you disagree with Trump catering to Putin while making economic war against allies, vote Harris out in 2026.
MICHAEL DAVIS
Easton

title: Future of DOGE in Supreme Court's hands
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Future of DOGE in Supreme Court's hands

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 To date, more than two dozen lawsuits have been filed challenging the authority, power, goals, plans, initiatives and actions of President Trump's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).No doubt many more lawsuits will follow.
The rulings by lower court judges on the already filed lawsuits are mixed.
Some lower court judges have ruled a president has broad constitutional authority to fire, demote or reassign federal executive branch employees without input from or approval of Congress.
Other lower court judges have ruled a president does not have broad constitutional authority to fire, demote or reassign federal executive branch employees without input from or approval of Congress.
Appeals of lower court judge rulings to the U.S. Supreme Court are not a matter of if, but a matter of when, as well as exactly how they will be addressed.
Ilya Shapiro, a senior fellow and director of constitutional studies at the Manhattan Institute, has already predicted a majority of the justices will support a ruling in approving DOGE's authority, plans and actions.
In a recent commentary, "The Supreme Court is Poised to Restore the President's Executive Power," Shapiro writes, "Article II of the U.S. Constitution begins with a simple declarative sentence: 'The executive power shall be vested in a president of the United States."
He also writes: "A majority on the Court now seems set to return to that view.'"
That majority of the Court referred to by Shapiro is presumably Chief Justice Roberts and Associate Justices Thomas, Alito, Kavanaugh, Gorsuch and Coney Barrett.
These six justices are often referred to collectively as a right-of-center bloc.
Shapiro gives special attention to Chief Justice Roberts.
He refers to a 2005 Supreme Court majority opinion written by Roberts on presidential authority. In it, Roberts explained Article II authority in the U.S. Constitution "generally includes the ability to remove executive officials."
He also says that is "a power that is necessary to ensure the accountable and effective execution of federal policy."
Shapiro also notes that Roberts has stated, without the power to remove executive branch officers, "the president could not be held fully accountable for discharging his own responsibilities; the buck would stop somewhere else."
The key word in Chief Justice Roberts thinking is "generally."
The Merriam-Webster's dictionary defines "generally" as often or regularly.
It does not define "generally" as "always."
That is affirmed by recent actions by Chief Justice Roberts on two lower court rulings on DOGE.
In the first action Chief Justice Roberts, along with Justice Amy Coney Barrett, joined the Supreme Court's left-of-center bloc of justices in blocking President Trump's efforts to freeze $2 billion in foreign aid funding and temporarily blocking budget cuts.
In the second action, Roberts and Coney Barrett agreed with a majority of their left-of-center colleagues on a decision that the court would not overrule a temporary order from a lower court to stop Trump from firing the head of the Office of Special Counsel.
These two actions refute the idea that members of the conservative bloc are unified and consistently unable to reach agreement with members of the left-of-center Justices.
It also demonstrates that Roberts and Coney Barrett are willing to side against Trump in legal challenges on certain DOGE Issues.
Most importantly, it affirms that the issue of presidential authority and power will require extraordinarily intense dialogue and deliberations among all the justices on the short-term and long-term ramifications of their ultimate decisions.
Payvan Ahdout, a law professor at the University of Virginia, suggests the court is "open to a role for judicial review of these [DOGE] decisions, but they just have not yet reached consensus on what that judicial role should be."
Going forward, Chief Justice Roberts and Justice Coney Barrett could be part of majority member rulings that all, most, some or few of DOGE actions are unconstitutional or could be constitutional with revisions.
If both do so, the outcomes will be 6-3 majority rulings for DOGE.
If only one does, it will still be 5-4 rulings for DOGE.
Conversely, if both join again with three of left-of-center justices to sustain lower court challenges against DOGE it will be 5-4 rulings against DOGE.
Ultimately, every Supreme Court review and ruling on every lower court DOGE ruling will determine the future scope of DOGE's constitutional authority, plans, efforts, success or failure to meet projected results. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses Supreme Court decisions and federal executive authority, which are matters of national political and legal significance, fitting the National News category.

title: The U.S. has abandoned Zelensky and Ukraine
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
The U.S. has abandoned Zelensky and Ukraine

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When the Russians invaded Ukraine three years ago, the United States, along with Europe, formed an alliance to help Ukraine resist the Russian aggression. President Joe Biden put together a NATO-based coalition that effectively provided arms, intelligence and money to help Ukraine resist the Russian attack and survive.When Donald Trump became president the first time, he withheld that support telling Volodymyr Zelensky the aid would resume if he provided political dirt on Joe Biden. Zelensky refused, and Trump shut off $214 million in military assistance, which the general counsel of the U.S. Comptroller General declared an illegal impoundment.
Under bipartisan political pressure, Trump resumed the aid. When he began his second presidency, Trump once again withheld arms, cut off military intelligence and support, pressuring Zelensky to accept an end to the war. Trump and Vance publicly insulted Zelensky in the Oval Office and called him a dictator but refused to criticize Putin.
Trump then began offering concessions to Putin before peace negotiations even began. Putin responded by dragging his feet on a cease fire, accelerating attacks on Ukraine, and asking for more concessions, making a mockery of Trump's negotiating skills. Ukraine remains a steppingstone for further Russian aggression.
Why would we suddenly embrace a dictator and invader?
Ukraine is fighting for democracy and the very freedoms we enjoy. The world looks to the United States for leadership and strength. Abandoning and humiliating an ally shows neither.

title: Time to be fully informed and be fully involved
author: DAVID REEL
content:
In a world where there is constant talk about more transparency and openness in government at all levels, now is a time to reflect upon an observation by Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Moynihan was once described in "The Almanac of American Politics" as "the nation's best thinker among politicians since Lincoln, and its best politician among thinkers since Jefferson." Prior to three terms in the U.S. Senate, he served Presidents Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Ford.
 One of Moynihan's enduring

title: Imaging a horror show
author: Staff Writer
content:
Imaging a horror show

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 190
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's hard to imagine that the protesters in Cambridge outside of an Andy Harris event really thought that the congressman would waste his time meeting with any of them. Cambridge Indivisible founder and chair Michelle Fowle said, "Harris' constituents just want answers." She wanted a town hall with the congressman. It's hard even imaging that horror show.Why would anyone subject themself to the shouting and abuse from such a meeting? We have already seen these same embarrassing displays on TV before. Another protester Ms. Frost said that she was concerned that Harris' agenda was more aligned with DOGE than with his constituents.
News Flash. Mr Harris was elected by the constituents who voted for him, not against him. Obama once said, "Elections have consequences."
I'm assuming the group looking to elect progressive leaders missed that message from Barack Obama himself. Harris' agenda is rightfully aligned with the party that won the election just as it should be. His true constituents are quite happy with Congressman Harris right now.
Maybe this Cambridge group should contact Bernie Sanders for a town hall since his socialist agenda seems much more in line with theirs.
RICH ADRIAN
Easton

title: Trump steps up push for federal defunding of NPR, PBS
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Trump steps up push for federal defunding of NPR, PBS

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1051
 Words 

 Read News Document

 U.S. President Donald Trump is intensifying his push to eliminate federal funding for National Public Radio (NPR) and Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) stations."NPR and PBS, two horrible and completely biased platforms (Networks!), should be DEFUNDED by Congress, IMMEDIATELY," Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform Thursday.
"Republicans, don't miss this opportunity to rid our Country of this giant SCAM, both being arms of the Radical Left Democrat Party. JUST SAY NO AND, MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!!!," Trump said.
Earlier this week, Trump also said from the Oval Office he backed eliminating federal funding for public media.
Congressional Republicans are looking at funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which helps fund PBS and NPR stations nationwide.
CPB received $535 million in the most recent annual federal budget. The nonprofit was created by Congress in 1967.
"Reducing or eliminating CBP funding would save the federal government little (maximum of $535 million) while having dire though not universally fatal consequences for public broadcasting," said Michael Montgomery, a political scientist and professor at the University of Michigan-Dearborn.
Montgomery contends the funding elimination push from Trump and conservatives is about their objections to what they see as NPR's and PBS' liberal slants.
"Make no mistake, if it happens, killing CPB will not be about saving money - this is about quieting voices and content that those on the right find objectionable or inconvenient," Montgomery said.
Some of Trump's most ardent supporters in the GOP-controlled Congress also want to eliminate government money for public media.
"We will defund NPR and PBS!!," said U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Georgia, in a social media statement responding to Trump. "The American people will NOT pay for disgusting Democrat propaganda anymore!!."
Greene is critical of PBS' coverage of LGBTQ communities, including saying at a congressional hearing Wednesday that it promotes a "trans agenda" pointing to a local affiliate's airing of a segment featuring drag artists.
During the same hearing on CPB funding Wednesday, U.S. Rep. Brandon Gill, R-Texas, grilled NPR President CEO Katherine Maher about her progressive social media posts on white supremacy, reparations and civil unrest in 2020 and 2021.
Maher became NPR boss in 2024.
She said her views have evolved, that NPR was working to offer a wider variety of perspectives in its coverage and had created new protocols to avoid bias, stressing the need for editorial independence.
Maher also stressed the need for public media in rural and lower-income communities.
"Public radio is very often the only news service in places where market economics does not support the expense of local news," she told the House panel.
Montgomery said NPR gets approximately 1% of its funding from CPB compared to roughly 14% for PBS.
"At the local level, an end of CPB funding would hit public TV harder than radio but public broadcasters of both types are likely to cut back, consolidate, or go silent," he said.
Public TV and radio stations and programs they produce would have to backfill any lost federal funding with money from other sources including donors, foundations and corporations.
Rick Ellis, founder and managing editor of Minnesota-based AllYourScreens.com (which tracks media news and industries), said defunding has been a desire of conservatives who either don't like government money for media outlets or "what they consider to be liberal programming."
"They haven't been able to eliminate the spending in the past in large part because the areas that would be most impacted by the cuts are rural areas that are also Republican strongholds. And overall, government financing for public media is pretty popular with voters," he said.
Ellis points to a Pew Research Center poll released Wednesday showing 24% of respondents favor nixing government funding for PBS and NPR, while 43% support public media funding and 33% are not sure.
"In theory, it would probably be politically less complicated for public media to move away from government funding. But while it is overall a small slice of public media financing, it's tough to replace any other way," Ellis said.
He said larger public media outlets in bigger, more affluent cities will survive the funding loss.
"But it would be enough of a loss to decimate outlets in Alaska, Hawaii and a number of Midwestern and Southern states, which are smaller and already struggle to get funding from foundations, viewers and listeners," Ellis said.
A number of local and statewide NPR and PBS stations have not yet responded to requests for comments about defunding and how they might navigate a new financial landscape, including their ties to universities and community colleges (which are also under fire from Trump).
The Heritage Foundation's Project 2025 has called for defunding CPB in its austerity blueprints, citing liberal biases and questioning the necessity of government outlays.
Elon Musk, who owns the X social media platform and runs Trump's Department of Government Efficiency efforts, has also echoed conservative calls to defund public media, in particular NPR. Trump said earlier this week DOGE efforts could also target public media funding.
Irina Tsukerman, president of New York-based Scarab Rising Inc. (a geopolitical consulting firm) said funding cuts could result in public media jobs cuts, less local programming and potentially station closures.
She also sees wider media impacts.
"Public media plays a unique role in the media ecosystem, providing high-quality, in-depth journalism that is free from the commercial pressures faced by corporate media," Tsukerman said, pointing to investigative, cultural and educational content that might not be pursued by other outlets.
'The removal of federal funding would push these stations to rely more heavily on private donations and corporate sponsorships, potentially influencing editorial independence and leading to content shifts that prioritize profitability over public service," she said.
Trump and his populist backers are vehement critics of many traditional media outlets, accusing them of liberal bias.
Trump routinely calls journalists "enemies of the state," frequently characterizing critical coverage of himself and his administration as fabricated or "witch hunts."
A number of major U.S. media outlets and social media platforms are owned by conglomerates such as the Fox Corp. and Walt Disney Co. or some of the wealthiest persons in the world such as Musk, Amazon founder and Washington Post owner Jeff Bezos and Meta/Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg.
The latter trio were all front and center at Trump's inauguration in January inside the U.S. Capitol.
"A weakened public media sector benefits those who prefer a media environment dominated by private interests, where corporate-backed outlets and partisan networks can exert greater influence over public discourse," Tsukerman said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a federal policy debate and actions by the President and Congress, which are matters of national political significance, fitting the National News category best.

title: Lessons learned from Donald Trump’s campaigns
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Lessons learned from Donald Trump’s campaigns

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 797
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After every presidential election cycle, political pundits do a deep dive analysis on campaign strategies that were effective before the campaign launch and during the campaign.One of the most insightful and thought provoking analyses I have seen was written by Michael Grynbaum and John Koblin, published in the New York Times the day after the election.
In their article — "Master of the Media Evolved Yet Again" — Grynbaum and Koblin wrote, "In his improbable journey to the apex of American power, President-elect Donald J. Trump has always adapted to the media tool of the moment."
Former president of CBS News, Andrew Heyward, echoes that conclusion: "He's always looking to the next venue that's best suited to his instincts for generating support. It's part of Trump's extraordinary record of instinctively finding ways to viscerally connect with voters. He's a master of evolving media."
These observations are not a surprise based on reviewing Trump's career before his running for the presidency three times.
Well before he ran for president the first time in 2016, Trump generated substantial name recognition in New York City and beyond with regular coverage in the New York Post. The Post, a daily tabloid newspaper, has the fourth-largest circulation of a printed newspaper in America. Its readership goes well beyond New York with a subscription-based online version.
In 2004, Trump recognized and seized an opportunity for even greater public exposure as the co producer and host of the reality TV show "The Apprentice."
During a long run on NBC TV, Trump worked hard to be viewed as a successful and decisive business mogul, willing to dismiss apprentice contestants with a memorable "you're fired."
The result of that name recognition together with his "take charge" personality, was a key element in Trump defeating a large field of candidates in the 2016 Republican presidential primary elections. That led to a widely unexpected Electoral College win in November 2024.
Grynbaum and Koblin wrote, "Trump recognized the power of Twitter long before other politicians, and in 2016, he started doing cable news interviews."
They also wrote that he bypassed traditional media gatekeepers like "60 Minutes" on CBS, in favor of select online celebrities and podcasts that were especially popular among young men.
As an example, Grynbaum and Koblin noted that "Bryson DeChambeau, a two-time U.S. Open golfing champion and YouTube star, did a video with Trump that had almost 13 million views."
More important than the always critical role of positive name recognition in any election, Grynbaum and Koblin suggested that bypassing the mainstream media allowed Trump to avoid confrontational interviews where he might have faced tough questions, fact-checks and detailed policy debates.
By contrast, Grynbaum and Koblin suggested the carefully selected influencers Trump met rarely challenged him and often lavished him with praise.
The political wisdom of that strategy was affirmed in the one debate hosted by ABC news. Donald Trump did not do as well as expected, and Kamala Harris did better than expected.
Following that debate, Trump declined to participate in a second debate and also pulled out of a planned interview with 60 Minutes. His decision not to appear was the first time since the late 1960s, when the program did not include host the two major-party presidential candidates.
Trump's ignoring 60 Minutes was one of many based on his lack of trust in and disdain for many traditional legacy media outlets that he believed were left of center and hostile to him.
Despite the risk of a negative voter reaction to his positions on the traditional media outlets, Trump assumed correctly that it would energize and mobilize his base if he regularly ignored and aggressively criticized the media, especially the legacy media.
Even before that decision on 60 Minutes was made, Trump was showing up on podcasts, widely viewed as unconventional and even odd in the context of a presidential campaign.
His first podcast with online star and wrestler Logan Paul met that profile. Trump and Paul discussed boxing, immigration and the possible existence of extraterrestrial life.
Some may say this commentary is all about Trump. I agree. The reasons are simple.
Donald Trump has been elected president twice. This commentary includes my thoughts and thoughts of others on how the role of effective communication strategies contributed to those outcomes.
Kamala Harris has not yet been elected president and maybe never will be. In any event, I expect to do another commentary that will include my thoughts and the thoughts of others on how flawed communication strategies contributed to her loss in 2024.
For now, campaign communications strategies covered in this commentary, may or may not be relevant in upcoming elections in 2026, 2028 and beyond.
That said, I suggest there is one timeless lesson for all political candidates going forward. That lesson is: never fail to thoroughly evaluate the effectiveness of and use best practice in campaign communications strategies, especially those that are emerging. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes Donald Trump's presidential campaign strategies and media use, which is a political issue of national relevance, fitting the 'National News' category.

title: Loss of federal funds could leave migrant children in the lurch
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Loss of federal funds could leave migrant children in the lurch

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 803
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Trump administration is moving ahead with plans to end a contract that pays for the legal representation of children navigating immigration court cases after entering the country without parents or guardians.That decision could have outsize impacts in Maryland, where a disproportionate share of unaccompanied immigrant children have landed in recent years, often fleeing violence, sexual abuse, and neglect.
The state's nonprofit legal aid groups are now grappling with the prospect of young clients facing the courts alone, raising the risk that children miss hearings, lose connections to service providers, and receive deportation orders.
Estefani Flores Portillo, a social services coordinator with the Amica Center for Immigrant Rights, says the loss of funding could also leave more than a thousand clients across Maryland — most in their teens — to balance fending for themselves in immigration court with the day-to-day challenges of acclimating to a new country.
"Outside of their legal case, they also have other priorities," she said. Most of her clients are enrolled in school, some hold down jobs to cover basic living expenses, and many require therapy to process traumas inflicted both in their home countries and during their journeys to the U.S.
Burdened with those competing pressures, she added, "it would be hard for them to focus on the legal case" without the assistance of an attorney.
On March 21, the administration notified nonprofit legal aid groups providing representation for unaccompanied immigrant children that it would terminate the contract that funds their work. Those legal aid groups collectively represent more than 26,000 children with cases before immigration courts across the country, and they provide consultations and referrals to thousands more each year.
The withdrawal of federal support for legal representation of immigrant children comes as immigration courts struggle to manage a staggering backlog of cases, including more than 50,000 in Maryland alone as of February 2025.
Maryland has received among the largest numbers of unaccompanied immigrant children in the past decade relative to other states.
Data from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) indicates that nearly 40,000 unaccompanied immigrant children have been released to sponsors — either family members or volunteers — in Maryland since 2014. A majority of those children arrived after 2020, primarily from Central America.
Only Texas, California, Florida and New York received more unaccompanied immigrant children in the same period.
Roughly 13,000 of those children landed in Prince George's County alone, though even some corners of rural Maryland have seen hundreds of new arrivals in the past five years.
Even with legal representation, unaccompanied children often spend years awaiting the resolution of their case, both because of the burden on immigration courts and asylum offices and because of the limited number of visas available each year.
"Kids don't want to think about these things longer than they have to," said Caroline Hodge, a supervising attorney with the Amica Center. The immigration court system is difficult enough for attorneys to navigate, she added, and children hardly stand a chance on their own.
Though the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act requires HHS to provide legal counsel to all children in its care "to the greatest extent possible," thousands of children with open immigration cases already lack representation.
That shortfall is driven in part by a nationwide shortage of immigration attorneys prepared to work with juvenile clients. Until this month, federal dollars also helped nonprofits like the Amica Center train attorneys willing to volunteer their time to represent children in immigration court. The end of the federal contract supporting her organization's work, Hodge said, also means her team will no longer be able to provide that training.
Immigration court data collected by the U.S. Department of Justice between 2004 and 2016 suggests that roughly 60 percent of children with cases in a Maryland immigration court had legal representation during that period. The same data indicates that while nearly all children with attorneys appeared in court for a final decision in their case, only a third of those without attorneys did so.
"The idea of going to court is so terrifying for a child," Hodge said, "and people without information, without representation, will definitely feel more fearful to engage."
The Trump administration has already signaled its interest in following through on deportation orders issued for children who fail to appear for immigration court hearings.
Maryland's Department of Human Services, which houses the state's Office for Refugees and Asylees, has so far avoided commenting on the end of federal funding for immigrant children's legal representation. A department spokesperson referred CNS to its federal counterpart, HHS, for comment, though that agency likewise did not immediately respond to inquiries about the expected outcomes of the decision.
Meanwhile, legal aid groups told Capital News Service that some attorneys fear that continuing to offer pro bono legal assistance to immigrants will make them targets, citing the White House's recent efforts to punish law firms deemed hostile to the administration. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a federal policy change affecting immigration legal representation for children, a topic of broad national relevance rather than a specific sport, health issue, or local event.

title: Rep. Harris defends federal funding cuts during virtual town hall
author: Konner Metz
content:
Rep. Harris defends federal funding cuts during virtual town hall

 April 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) stood by recent federal funding cuts by the Trump administration during a virtual town hall Tuesday.It was the congressman's second telephone town hall in two weeks, following multiple in-person protests of Harris on the Eastern Shore, where constituents demanded he host a town hall.
Tuesday, many of the 12 callers that spoke expressed frustrations with funding and staffing cuts to Medicaid, the U.S. Agency for International Development and the U.S. Department of Agriculture and other agencies.
In response to a question about USDA program cuts, Harris said the Trump administration is focused on pandemic-era funds.
"The philosophy is that COVID is over and we probably ought to end the COVID-era programs," Harris said. "Since we started the COVID programs, the federal budget has gone from $4.5 trillion to $7 trillion in six short years. We're going to have to look program by program."
One caller pushed Harris on why he supports caps to Medicaid funding, stating that any federal drawback will force states to assume more of the burden.
"Medicaid is not an entitlement. It is a vital public service," the caller stated. "I get it, it's expensive, and we have to find a way to pay for it... Lives are tied to this, as well as critical services that the Maryland Eastern Shore depends upon."
Harris said, "It's fair that we ask the states" to cover more of the costs for non-disabled individuals under Medicaid. He argued for the federal government to control its growth of Medicaid contributions.
A Harford County caller posed a question about how Department of Education cuts will impact Maryland. Most recently, the department announced it won't pay back hundreds of millions of dollars in COVID-19 spending that was previously approved, though that action wasn't specifically discussed during the town hall.
Harris emphasized his support to "take Washington out of the equation" and give control to local school boards and states. He added that "teachers' unions are not good for our students."
"The teachers' unions are interested in the teachers and what a contract looks like, how many vacation days you get, how many days off you get, things like that," Harris said, "not in what's actually going to work to make our students function better in a global environment."
Toward the end of the hour-long virtual town hall, Harris reiterated his support for the Trump administration and Elon Musk, the head of the Department of Government Efficiency, which is leading many of the efforts to reduce federal spending.
"No it's not a perfect job," Harris said of Musk's DOGE efforts. "No it's not the way it's usually done in the federal government. But time is of the essence here."
Harris said 3,900 people attended Tuesday's telephone town hall and that there will likely be another held this summer. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses federal funding cuts and policy decisions by a U.S. Representative, topics that are primarily national in scope rather than limited to a single sector like education or health.

title: Jeffrey Epstein's 'little black book' sold at auction house
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
Jeffrey Epstein's 'little black book' sold at auction house

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A "little black book" of names and contact information that once belonged to deceased sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein was sold for $10,000 at Alexander Historical Auctions in Elkton on Wednesday evening.Although the estimated value for Epstein's book ranged from $20,000 to $30,000, at Alexander Historical Auctions in Elkton on Wednesday, the 64 pages filled with nearly 400 printed names and contacts of high-profile individuals were acquired for $10,000, holding the same bidding price throughout the day, far below the estimated value.
Epstein's phone book was up for auction in August 2024 with a starting bid of $35,000 and had previously drawn offers up to $100,000, but the offers were rejected by the owner, who hoped a researcher would purchase the relic to uncover the sex offender's ties to governments, according to auctioneer Bill Panagopulos. Auctioneers assured bidders that their identities are not revealed.
"We tried to sell it last auction with a big reserve, and I called it … radioactive," Panagopulos said about Epstein's notebook moments before the auction started Wednesday morning. "There are people who won't even touch it, right?"
The book went on quite a journey before the Elkton-based auctioneer acquired the black plastic Gestetner-bound contact log. Denise Ondayko, a musician from the East Village, claims she found the book on a Manhattan sidewalk in the 1990s, according to Business Insider. After Epstein's death in 2019, she put it up for sale on eBay.
Christopher Helali — the International Secretary for the American Communist Party, who was working as an independent reporter — purchased it for a mere $425, according to the New York Post.
"Nobody believes it's real. He buys it for nothing, and he is more interested in the story than in the value of the piece," Panagopulos said, adding that Helali had Business Insider bring in a forensic expert to authenticate the book.
The 4.5-inch-by-5.25 inch book contains 386 printed entries varying in length from one or two lines to 10 or 15 lines each. It has two additional entries written in what looks like Epstein's handwriting, but is too small to tell, according to the auction item description. There are five highlighted names who are all well recognized financial and industrial professionals, including current president Donald Trump.
The FBI discovered a different "little black book" of Epstein's circa 2004, and used it in legal proceedings throughout his various for soliciting prostitution from minors and federal sex trafficking. FBI investigations started in 2005, with a pause for several years in between, and ended in 2019 when the criminal was found dead in his jail cell, which investigators declared a suicide, according to the Associated Press.
The earlier book — which was just sold at auction — was not considered important to the investigation when it was discovered. The two volumes combined hold 1,731 names, 221 of which are in the earlier book, but not the 2004 version, according to Business Insider. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a high‑profile national figure (Jeffrey Epstein) and the sale of his infamous contact book, making it primarily a national news story rather than a local, business, or safety alert.

title: We must keep interest on civil, respectful dialog
author: DAVID REEL
content:
We must keep interest on civil, respectful dialog

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 848
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following World War II, Winston Churchill was facing two daunting political and governing challenges in pivoting from serving as a wartime to a post war leader of Britain.The first challenge was how Britain should deal with Germany, whose leaders were ruthless adversaries who inflicted massive amounts of death, pain and suffering on Britain during a six-year war; including bombing raids on London that killed and injured innocent civilians. The second challenge was how Britain should deal with the Soviet Union whose leaders were key allies during that same war, but post war; those same leaders were pursuing, maintaining and expanding the Soviet Union's spheres of influence and their communist ideology worldwide.
Churchill's guiding principle forward was pragmatic. In a world characterized by volatility, uncertainty, complexity and ambiguity, he would not expect permanent allies or permanent adversaries. He would pursue permanent interests.
Recently, two U.S. senators from Pennsylvania embraced Churchill's guiding principle in American politics in a relatively small, but very instructive way. What makes this instructive is these two senators have deeply held and stark differences in their political allegiances and political philosophies.
John Fetterman is a left-of-center Democratic senator who was endorsed by Bernie Sanders in his successful Senate primary election campaign and his successful general election campaign.
In the 2024 Presidential election, Fetterman strongly supported Joe Biden's reelection and strongly defended Biden when there were widespread calls for him to withdraw from the race.
When Biden did withdraw and was replaced by Kamala Harris as the Democratic standard bearer, Fetterman endorsed her and campaigned for her throughout Pennsylvania.
David McCormick is a right-of-center Republican senator who was endorsed by Donald Trump in his successful Senate primary campaign and his successful general election campaign.
In McCormick's challenge to Pennsylvania's then incumbent left-of-center Democratic Sen. Robert Casey, Fetterman endorsed Casey and campaigned for him.
Since those elections, their differences have not stopped the two senators from working together on select issues of shared interest, shared thinking and mutual respect.
One example is the role of mentorships in changing lives.
Both McCormick and Fetterman have a deep commitment to mentoring based on their respective firsthand experiences.
While in college, Fetterman's best friend died in a car accident. Immediately following that tragedy, Fetterman volunteered to be a mentor for Big Brothers and Big Sisters of America. He was assigned to an 8-year-old boy whose father had died from AIDS and whose mother was dying from cancer. Fetterman promised the boy's mother he would continue to be his mentor after her death.
In high school, McCormick was a mediocre benchwarmer on the football team. A new coach saw promise in him, mentored him and made McCormick one of the team's co-captains. That experience helped McCormick boost his low self-confidence and graduate from West Point.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, McCormick and his wife, Dina Powell McCormick, concluded that too many Americans, including their six daughters, suffered greatly from a lack of mentors.
As a result, they coauthored "Who Believed in You?" a book that includes interviews with successful leaders who had a mentor who saw something in them they may not have seen in themselves and helped them find and achieve their purpose in life.
Those interviewed include Gov. Wes Moore; Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella; Tory Burch, chief creative fashion designer and executive chairperson of Tory Burch LLC as well as founder of the Tory Burch foundation; Hollywood producer Brian Grazer, Arkansas Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders and former U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.
As a result of their mutual appreciation of the value of mentoring, McCormick, Fetterman, and their spouses (both of whom also have personal positive mentoring stories to share), agreed to three events where they would discuss their experiences and promote Who Believed in You?
McCormick, Fetterman and their spouses also met for a dinner, a most effective way for people to get to know, understand and respect each other. Following that dinner McCormick said, "I trust him. I think he's a very authentic guy. I think he's going to be a good partner."
Sadly, the first two of the mentoring events were postponed due to "unforeseen logistical issues" and the third event was canceled due to a "scheduling conflict." I believe the reasons were concerns over peaceful outcomes from protests before, during or after the events.
This is a prime example of how a tyranny of the loud is regularly disrupting much needed efforts to advance the cause of civil political discourse in our society.
This unexpected turn of events is also a call to action for elected officials and citizens in our community, our region, our state and our country to commit to doing two things.
We can, and we must replicate the actions of two these U.S. senators with efforts to get to know, understand, trust, respect and seek common ground with others who have opposite political affiliations and opposite views on many local, state and national public policy issues.
More importantly, we can, and we must commit to maintaining a permanent interest on civil and respectful dialogue, which will help us coexist in a society where even when we have inevitable disagreements on a wide range of public policy issues, we can disagree without being disagreeable. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an opinion column about bipartisan cooperation and civil political discourse involving U.S. senators, which aligns best with the broader political coverage of National News.

title: For many Social Security is their sole income
author: LENA GILL
content:
For many Social Security is their sole income

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 678
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Frances Perkins, the famous female labor secretary appointed by President Franklin Roosevelt, chaired the committee that drafted legislation for Social Security, enacted in 1935.It was a reliable insurance system for all working Americans. If you paid into it monthly, you knew that if you lost your job, became disabled or died, you or your survivors would receive a pension based on how much you paid in. Before that, the consequence was often destitution. As of February 2025, an estimated 73.2 million Americans received Social Security checks. In Talbot County, 30% of residents rely on Social Security benefits for income. For nearly half of them, it is their sole income.
Social Security is so popular it is considered a "third rail of politics" because politicians dare not vote to reduce benefits, as they and their party will face certain defeat in the next election. Most Republicans and President Trump pledged before the election not to reduce Social Security benefits.
Instead, Trump brought in his front man, Elon Musk and his DOGE musketeers to eviscerate Social Security, not by reducing benefits, but by slashing workers and field offices that make the program administrable. They suggest staff cutbacks of 7,000 persons, out of today's staff of 57,000 that is already considered insufficient. The ratio of one staffer to 1,369 beneficiaries is twice the ratio in 1995. The average processing time of disability claims has already doubled from four to eight months.
Musk's approach avoids Republicans in Congress voting on the evisceration. Perhaps Musk will then sell Social Security to the highest bidder who will privatize it, promising to make it function again. (At the end of 2024, the two Social Security trust funds held approximately $2.027 trillion in asset reserves. These reserves are owned by the beneficiaries of the Social Security program.)
What have the DOGE musketeers accomplished so far?
Several people who are quite alive were declared dead and their benefits terminated. For example, Ned Johnson, an 82-year-old retiree from Seattle not only discovered his Social Security checks stopped, but more than $5,000 of his prior benefits were clawed back as he allegedly died on November 23, 2024. He waited for eight hours at the Seattle Social Security office to prove that he was still alive. That same office is now earmarked for closure. Earlier, Trump fired the inspector general who would have investigated and avoided such mistakes. DOGE musketeers also claimed to have found $232 million in waste to cut from Social Security. Closer examination changed that to $560,000.
Elon installed one of his musketeers, Leland Dudek, as acting commissioner. In response to a lawsuit, a judge forbade the DOGE musketeers from accessing sensitive taxpayer data. Dudek then threatened to bar Social Security employees from accessing Social Security systems. The next day Dudek backed down and let the employees resume their normal work.
Which field offices will be closed is still not decided. There were protests around the country outside field offices last weekend, and the public was very vocal about keeping their local Social Security offices open. The phone lines available for the elderly and disabled to discuss their claims are already shut down. People are told to do much of their business online. However, it is believed that about 10% of people over 65 are not computer literate. A new claimant must appear in person at a remaining office alive.
For those who rely on the check from Social Security to pay for the essentials every month, failure to receive it is an emergency. I encourage everybody to call or email Sens. Chris van Hollen and Angela Alsobrooks, as well as Congressman Andy Harris to tell them to stop the plunder of the Social Security insurance program.
On June 1, 1950, Sen. Margaret Chase Smith of Maine stood up in the Senate chamber during a debate on Sen. Joseph McCarthy's claims of unidentified traitors in our government and said: "It is high time we all stopped being tools and victims of totalitarian techniques — techniques that, if continued here unchecked, will surely end what we have come to cherish as the American way of life."
