title: Kirk did not invite conversation
author: Staff Writer
content:
Kirk did not invite conversation

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 352
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Let me say at the start that like almost all Americans I deplore the murder of Charlie Kirk. But I want to challenge the opinion pieces by Glen Mollette and David Reel in the Sunday Star Weekend Edition of Sept. 20-21.The headlines accurately sum up their views: "We need more conversation, not assassination" and "Charlie Kirk relished engagement with critics." I believe that Kirk's behavior exhibited neither conversation nor engagement.
Wikipedia tells us that "conversation" is an ambiguous word. The only common element in its various meanings is that it involves at least two people.
At the modest end of the spectrum of meanings one might imagine two people talking about the day's weather. At the other end is something like discussion, wherein two or more people seek a richer understanding of some topic that interests them.
Many commentators, like your two opinion writers, seem to imply that Kirk's activity was of this sort. I believe it was not.
Kirk's behavior in his Q & A sessions were notable for his polite, respectful listening, which implied that he was open to changing his views — if only he could find someone to persuade him otherwise.
This apparent open mindedness seems to have disarmed some of his critics who, like Reel, were charmed by Kirk's manner even while finding his positions disreputable — even despicable. He was never bombastic; he did not promote demonstrations (or worse) on behalf of his views.
What gets lost in appraisals of his mission are his actual beliefs and values, which then go unchallenged — and his offer to be proven wrong has effectively diverted away from them.
Furthermore, there is no way to prove Kirk's views wrong (nor to prove right the views opposing his). These are not matters of proof but rather beliefs involving strongly held assumptions and values.
In sum, Kirk's mantra "Prove me wrong," stated by him over and over– and posted prominently on overhangs of tents at his meetings – while seeming to ask for a counter argument, is a hollow request. It does not invite conversation at all — and certainly not conversation in pursuit of further understanding.
FOREST HANSEN
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an opinion piece discussing the public figure Charlie Kirk and broader political discourse, fitting best under national news rather than the other specific categories.

title: Do not ignore escalating signs of authoritarianism
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
Do not ignore escalating signs of authoritarianism

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 504
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The deployment of National Guard troops and regular military in Washington, D.C,. Los Angles and now Portland, Oregon, is not OK.Nor is Trump's directive "we are going in" to Chicago and his claim that he is ready to deploy in Baltimore. Some will dismiss this as merely Trump's stunts to divert attention from the unstoppable Epstein inquiries. I believe Trump is testing whether he can deploy and control our military in these Democratic cities, despite laws to the contrary, for a more sinister purpose.
Deploying armed troops on U.S. soil for domestic law enforcement invokes authoritarian tactics. It echoes the tactic of securing military power to override civil governance — an infamous step that Adolf Hitler took when the German army aligned with him. By federalizing the Metropolitan Police Department and overriding local control under Section 740 of the D.C. Home Rule Act, the president has bypassed D.C.'s elected government.
Centralization of control is a hallmark authoritarian approach. Declaring D.C. is in a "crime emergency" despite statistics showing plummeting crime rates and deploying troops primarily for a show of power, mirrors how Hitler used fabricated emergencies to legitimize crushing civil rights. This same situation is true in Portland, with reduced crime rates and no need to send in federal troops.
The National Guard and regular military forces were deployed in Los Angeles to assist the Immigration and Customs Enforcement forces in the apprehension of criminal immigrants. The idea was to find criminal immigrants and deport them. However, as we have seen, many innocent immigrants were swept up into this process.
Once Trump controls the military outside the Constitution then there is really no one left to oppose him. In theory the United States Congress can prevent this, but as they have demonstrated since Mr. Trump's inauguration, that is not happening.
The Supreme Court has yet to show its ultimate independence of Trump's control. Gaining the support and cooperation of the military was the final part of the plan that Adolf Hitler put into operation in his creation of the Third Reich, which eventually led to World War II. We must resist.
The question is what should we be doing in the face of these circumstances? I would offer these types of efforts as being very important:
We must stay informed and engaged. Read and listen to what is happening in the politics of our country, express our opinions and thoughts, attend meetings sponsored by our elected representatives, insist that our elected representatives have meetings.Defend our democratic institutions. Make sure you know what the Constitution says and defend those words.Demand that our government do its job and serve the people as they were elected to do.Resist rhetoric that tries to manipulate our thinking. Make sure that we do not accept the takeover of Washington, D.C. as a legitimate response to out-of-control crime that is in fact steadily decreasing. Fight the normalization of unlawful activities.Learn from history. There is too much that is happening in the current administration that mirrors things that happened in Germany in 1933. Do not ignore those signs.Vote. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trump’s dangerous distortion of national security
author: MEL GURTOV
content:
Trump’s dangerous distortion of national security

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MEL GURTOV | Section: Columns 
 
 684
 Words 

 Read News Document

 During a large part of the post-World War II history of American foreign policy, national security meant international security — that is, defense of the U.S. homeland was believed to require a global military presence and regular interventions — political, military, economic — in the affairs of other countries.The threats changed over time from the Soviet Union to China to terrorism, but until Donald Trump, presidents never claimed that these threats required giving internal order the highest defense priority. Their policies of liberal interventionism and their commitment to an imperial presidency were directed at defeating global menaces, even at the expense of real security at home.
Now, under Trump, we are at the start of another and far graver distortion of national security — waging "the war from within," as Trump told the generals. But the enemy within isn't any enemy of past decades: the communist party, organized crime, disease or rampant inflation. It is the non-white migrant worker, the leftist intellectual, the drug trafficker, the Democratic-run city, the "woke" universities, liberal civil society. In short, it is most of us.
National security now requires widespread domestic repression: "We have to handle it before it gets out of control," Trump said. He confirmed the shift to internal order when he said the National Guard would be sent to Chicago: "We should use some of these dangerous cities as training grounds" for military forces. Today's cities will play the role of U.S. military bases abroad.
"National security" once again is the catchword to justify all manner of official acts that have no or very little bearing on the nation's security. Every tariff increase — on furniture, foreign movies, aluminum — is a national security measure. Border reinforcement against increasingly few illegal migrants is to bolster national security. (It's an "invasion," remember.)
Regular military units are dispatched to cities on national security missions. Pressuring law firms, universities and social media companies to conform with the administration's policy on D.E.I., and pay huge fees for compliance, is necessary for national security.
The Trump administration has learned from authoritarian regimes, as well as from previous administrations, that cloaking official acts in the language of national security is almost certain to get Supreme Court approval.
Trump has essentially given up on foreign policy. He has nothing to offer beyond tariffs. He has failed to end wars in Gaza and Ukraine; in his bid for a Nobel Peace Prize, he has fully backed the genocide regime in Tel Aviv and the aggressor state in the Kremlin. And he has failed to bring China to heel; his tariff and foreign aid policies have been gifts to Beijing that have enabled it to extend its economic and political influence.
Now, foreign policy is domestic policy: the militarization of the southern border, the attacks on presumed drug smugglers at sea. The war secretary, Pete Hegseth, may prattle about reviving a "warrior ethos," but the only war he's going to conduct is in U.S. cities. Sure, there may be occasional (illegal) uses of force against Iran or the Houthis or Caribbean boats, but those are easy targets that can't retaliate against U.S. assets. Hegseth's main job is to see that Trump's ambition to quell all sources of American discontent is supported with troops.
Many senior military officers, including Trump's chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, are reported to be upset over his plan to use the military against Americans. As well they should be: The U.S. armed forces and National Guard should never be deployed to satisfy a president's personal political agenda. Trump's plan is patently illegal, a blatant violation of the Constitution and Trump's pledge to uphold it, and a suborning of democracy.
It is frankly traitorous and should be denounced as such by military as well as political leaders. Surely some of our military leaders are mindful of what the militaries in other countries have done when faced with abuses of national security by corrupt, incompetent and self-interested politicians.
Unless opposed, Trump's plan for national security can only end one way: in martial law imposed on our cities and in the mass detention of his critics. Who will rescue U.S.? 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a political commentary on Trump’s national security policies and their domestic implications, which aligns with broad national news coverage rather than a specific local, health, or entertainment issue.

title: Activist groups protest shutdown during Fall Fest
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Activist groups protest shutdown during Fall Fest

 October 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HURLOCK — On Saturday, members of Cambridge Indivisible, the Dorchester Democratic Central Committee and community members marched in the Hurlock Fall Fest Parade as part of the national "Healthcare Not Authoritarianism: Shutdown Showdown" effort.On Oct. 1, the Federal Government shut down after lawmakers failed to pass a funding bill by the 12:01 a.m. deadline. The shutdown occurred due to a partisan argument over extending subsidies for the Affordable Care Act, which currently covers 24 million Americans, according to Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.
Republicans argued that cutting ACA subsidies would help reduce the country's current budget deficit.
The GOP rejected the legislation that extends ACA subsidies, arguing that it could be discussed at a later time. Democrats did not budge on the issue, leading to the Government shutdown.
Activists began marching at 9 a.m. Saturday to advocate for healthcare access "as Donald Trump and MAGA Republicans in Congress push our country into a government shutdown rather than lower healthcare costs for families," according to a press release from Cambridge Indivisible.
The Dorchester Democratic Central Committee has been participating in the Hurlock Fall Fest Parade since 2022, and Chair of the Committee Sydney Bradner-Jacobs said around 15 people participated in the march portion of the event.
"We didn't really have a theme before, but with the government shutdown, I thought it was best to theme it around what's going on in Washington," Bradner-Jacobs said.
Cambridge Indivisible Co-founder and Co-chair Michelle Fowle said grassroots activism efforts in small towns like Hurlock and Cambridge are crucial to stand up against Republican policies she perceives will gut Medicaid and eliminate Affordable Care Act subsidies.
"So to keep the government open, the Republicans are saying, well, basically they're saying it without saying it, 'We want you to ensure that we strip healthcare away from millions of people, of American citizens,'" Fowle said.
Fowle worries that if Medicaid is cut and ACA subsidies are removed, there could be hospital closures and other local impacts.
"I think it's important that rural communities, little tiny communities, have people getting activated," Fowle said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland lawmakers, union leader challenge memo threatening furloughed federal workers’ pay
author: AUDREY KEEFE Capital News Service
content:
Maryland lawmakers, union leader challenge memo threatening furloughed federal workers’ pay

 October 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AUDREY KEEFE Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 598
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Furloughed federal workers may not be entitled to back pay when they return from the government shutdown, according to a draft memo from the White House Office of Management and Budget, first reported by Axios.The memo comes almost a week into the shutdown and marks a stark change in the Trump administration's position on furloughed federal workers' pay.
President Donald Trump further confused the issue on Tuesday. Asked by a reporter whether federal workers should get retroactive pay after the shutdown ends, the president responded: "It depends on who we're talking about."
"For the most part, we're going to take care of our people," Trump said in the Oval Office. "There are some people that really don't deserve to be taken care of, and we'll take care of them in a different way."
However, Maryland lawmakers and a top union leader said the White House and the OMB are attempting to violate a 2019 law and potentially halt about 750,000 federal employees' pay.
"The law is the law," Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, said in a statement. "That legislation was signed into law — and there is nothing this Administration can do to change that."
Everett Kelley, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, said in a statement the memo is "an obvious misinterpretation of the law." The AFGE is the largest federal employee union and represents more than 820,000 workers. Kelley lambasted the memo's goals and said it is an attack on federal employees.
"The livelihoods of the patriotic Americans serving their country in the federal government are not bargaining chips in a political game," Kelley said.
"Those who want the government to stay open and operating do not threaten its employees," Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Maryland, said in a post on X. "Federal workers aren't political pawns; they're patriots."
Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-Maryland, said in a statement "the president has no right to just pay the federal workers in his own political camp."
"The president is threatening to deliberately violate the law; or he is suffering from a debilitating case of legislative amnesia," Raskin said. "Either way, he should refresh his memory on the law he signed. And if he chooses to barrel forward anyway, he should get ready for a fight in court."
The Government Employee Fair Treatment Act was signed in 2019 by President Donald Trump during the last government shutdown. The bill ensured back pay for federal employees during lapses in federal spending.
Now, an amended version is providing OMB with an alleged loophole, stating the compensation is only mandatory "subject to the enactment of appropriations Acts ending the lapse," the bill said.
The new interpretation means furloughed workers could only be paid if the funds are specifically appropriated by Congress, according to Axios. This differs from the original statement made in 2019 by OPM, which said furloughed workers would receive retroactive pay.
Essential federal employees, such as military service members and air traffic controllers, may be the only workers entitled to pay once the government reopens, according to the White House memo.
Van Hollen argued the interpretation shift threatens the original intent of the law. He previously worked with former Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Maryland, in 2019 to "ensure federal employees would receive guaranteed back pay for any future shutdowns," he said in a statement.
Rep. Glenn Ivey, D-Maryland, said instead of "attacking government workers," Republicans and the Trump administration should come to the table with Democrats and create a solution to the Medicaid cuts and expiration of the Affordable Care Act.
"Democrats are trying to force (Republicans) to fix the problem they've created, and that's what we're going to do," Ivey told Capital News Service. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a federal government shutdown, a White House memo, and reactions from Maryland lawmakers and a union leader—issues of nationwide political and policy significance, fitting the 'National News' category.

title: ‘Solar maximum’: More storms from the sun could bring more Northern Lights, potential power grid, technology disruptions
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia
content:
‘Solar maximum’: More storms from the sun could bring more Northern Lights, potential power grid, technology disruptions

 October 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia | Section: National 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More of the world, including parts of the continental U.S., could see increased instances of Aurora Borealis lights over the next several months.That's because the sun is at the height of a cycle which sees its north and south poles flip approximately every 11 years.
Dana Longcope, a professor of solar physics at Montana State University, said the solar cycle's maximum activity can mean more visible Aurora Borealis (Northern Lights) in the continental U.S. farther from their usual polar reaches.
He said those light displays could extend beyond the current solar maximum phase.
"We will have more dramatic Northern Lights for the next year or two," Longcope said.
The so-called "solar maximum" also sees more solar storms, flares and explosive ejections from the sun.
Those geomagnetic storms and energy bursts can have impacts on Earth beyond more visible Northern Lights.
Increased solar activity can result in power outages and damage to power grids, degrade global positioning systems' (GPS) signals and throw off or ruin the more than 12,000 satellites now in orbit.
Approximately every 11 years the sun goes through a "solar cycle" which sees its north and south poles flip.
The cycle includes periods of increased solar flares and geomagnetic storms.
The solar maximum part of the cycle is currently ongoing and expected to last into the spring of 2026, according to the U.S. National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
"It looks like we are reaching the maximum," Longcope said. "We've had a lot of flares and mass ejections."
EARTHLY IMPACTS
The Montana physicist said there could be other disruptions from solar storms' earthly impacts.
Those include weakening GPS systems, including for more precision applications used in agriculture, construction, shipping and mining as well as by militaries.
"It's important in agriculture," Longcope said.
More farmers use GPS and satellite technology, including during planting seasons.
"We are at the peak of the 11-year cycle in 2025," said Ed Norse, portfolio manager for Trimble Inc.
The Colorado-based company helps precision GPS users utilize technology in their operations and deal with the impacts of solar changes.
Norse said there has been significant growth with precision GPS systems that help farmers with planting as well as with mining exploration and construction.
"It's been growing," Norse said, of the marketplace for precision GPS technology.
He said GPS use is part of a wave of technology use in agriculture.
"You can run 24 hours a day in the dark," Norse said.
But that also makes those industries exposed to potential GPS, satellite and power grid disruptions.
"People working in mines in South Africa are very worried about it," Norse said.
Trimble has approximately 200 technology stations that help GPS systems and users with precision operations and mitigate the impacts of solar and other disruptions.
Longcope said solar activity could disrupt radio transmissions and communications for airline flights near the Arctic Circle and could cause power outages, pointing to past blackouts in Canada and South Africa in 1989 and 2023.
Satellites can also be adversely affected by solar storms, including some potentially permanently disabled.
There are more than 12,100 satellites currently orbiting the Earth, according to Kongsberg NanoAvionics and https://orbit.ing-now.com.
That number could grow to as many as 65,000 satellites circling above the Earth by 2030, according to McKinsey & Co.
POWER PLAYS
Longcope said increased energy and frequency flows from the sun can result in voltage surges that can damage or ruin transformers, transmitters and power stations.
Power outages could impact not only utility grids but also hosts of industries and systems that would be taken down.
"That would be dramatic," he said.
There have been past major disruptions caused by solar storms and cycles.
That includes the Carrington Event in 1859, which saw Aurora lights visible in the southern U.S., Caribbean and equatorial areas from a major solar storm.
The Carrington Event resulted in energy surges that sparked fires at some telegraph stations.
A similar event in the technology- and digital-heavy 21st century could have major impacts on power grids, satellites and other financial and communications systems.
David Munson, president and chief inventor of Texas-based FOI Group LLC, worries about solar storms as well as man-made electromagnetic disruptions; such events could take down power grids as well as communications and other technology systems essential for contemporary market economies and modern everyday life.
"If you don't have electricity, everything just comes to a grinding and horrible halt," said Munson, whose company has patents and technology applications for energy storage, agriculture, defense and other sectors.
"Life turns to hell right fast," he said.
A BIG WORRY
Electromagnetic pulses as well as nuclear weapons detonated in space could potentially be used to cause dangerous surges and other disruptions.
Munson said a detonation of nuclear weapons in space by an adversary such as North Korea could send electromagnetic pulses and waves that "could knock out the U.S."
Munson also points to North Korea's construction of extensive underground facilities and tunnels to help withstand a major war.
"They could bury all their troops underground," said Munson.
Munson said a major solar storm like the 1859 Carrington Event (where the Northern Lights could be seen in Florida) would have monumental impacts today.
"A big solar storm is the worry," he said.
Munson points to an industrial and urbanized world dependent on power supplies, data centers, smartphones and digital and technology platforms for banking, communications, defense, health care and other sectors.
Munson said it could take a significant amount of time to replace utility transformers and transmission infrastructure, and he noted most of that power grid equipment is manufactured overseas, including China.
"There's no stockpile of transformers," said Munson. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a nationwide scientific event (solar maximum) and its broad impacts on power grids, GPS, satellites, and the economy, fitting the scope of national news more than any other specific category.

title: Leading by example: John White earns national honor for service to veterans
author: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content:
Leading by example: John White earns national honor for service to veterans

 October 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Bay Times Record Observer | Section: News 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When John White's name was called during the September general membership meeting at the American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18, he thought it was just another business item. Moments later, the Sons of the American Legion (SAL) commander found himself standing before his peers — "dumbfounded," as he described it — as he was presented with the national SAL Squadron Commander of the Year award.The award was given by Maryland SAL Commander Jason Miller of Chestertown and followed by words of praise from Department Commander for the state of Maryland Nikki Randolph of Kent Island.
"John leads by example, and is exactly the kind of person we want representing the American Legion," Randolph said. She added, "I wish every American Legion Post in Maryland was like Post 18 in Centreville," crediting the Post's long-standing leadership and teamwork in support of veterans.
Queen Anne's County Commissioner Phil Dumenil also took part in the ceremony, reading a proclamation signed by all five commissioners recognizing White's dedication.
It read, in part:
"John has been a dedicated member of the SAL since 2015. He devoted countless hours each day volunteering at Post 18, supporting not only squadron activities, but the entire Post family — handling the ordering, shopping, advertising and setup for weekly Friday night dinners. He welcomes veterans each Monday morning for their Veterans Helping Veterans meetings at the Post. John is instrumental in coordinating the Mid-Shore Toys for Tots program, managing logistics across four counties, and personally ensuring that children in need receive toys, candy and letters during the annual Letters to Santa program that reaches approximately 150 local children each year.
"He actively participates in setup and cleanup for the annual Wreaths Across America ceremonies at two local cemeteries, honoring the memory of veterans with dignity and respect. John has contributed significantly to the growth and improvement of the Post home, assisting in fundraising and working with contractors during major renovations, ensuring the success and sustainability of Post 18. The success of Post 18 is a direct reflection of the dedication and teamwork of its members, with John White leading by example — always willing to assist anyone in a time of need, and serving as a cornerstone of the Post's continued success and strength."
White joined the SAL in 2015, eligible through his grandfather and father, both U.S. Navy veterans. His grandfather served during World War I; his father and father-in-law were Vietnam veterans. His father-in-law, who served in the Air Force, flew 116 fighter-jet missions.
White said he joined the Legion in their honor and to serve other veterans. "I had regrets that I never served in the military," he said.
Of the award, White added, "This is a Post award, really. It's not about me. You've seen the turnout we get when our Post hosts events — we have great support from our membership. The award might have my name on it, but it's really for all of us. I don't do all these things by myself."
White also credited past commanders of the Centreville Post "who have led the membership to serve the community and other veterans."
Before his retirement, White served 32 years with the U.S. Department of Justice as a multimedia IT specialist. He is a graduate of DeMatha High School in Hyattsville, Md., where he played football under famed coach Morgan Wootten. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a national-level award given to a local veteran for service to veterans, making it a story of broader national relevance rather than fitting categories like sports, health, or local government.

title: Some thoughts on a US president from Maryland
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Some thoughts on a US president from Maryland

 October 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 736
 Words 

 Read News Document

 To date, no individual born or living in Maryland has been elected to serve as president of the United States.Ever since Gov. Wes Moore was elected in 2022, he has been viewed by many as a rising star in the Democratic Party.
Many of his admirers have even suggested he has potential to be the Democratic Party's 2028 candidate for president.
That is not surprising. Wes Moore is a charismatic, progressive and relatively young elected official at a time when both major political parties are struggling mightily with internal divides between longtime and elderly party leaders and emerging younger leaders.
Despite that political chatter, Moore has repeatedly said he will not run for president in 2028.
Instead, he has said he is eager and ready to run for reelection as governor for a second four-year term.
That said, if Wes Moore does have future national ambitions, they may ultimately be delayed or derailed by another charismatic Maryland Democratic elected official — U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen.
Van Hollen has had a long career in politics starting with elections to serve as a Democratic member in the Maryland House of Delegates and in the Maryland Senate.
He was elected to serve in the U.S. House of Representatives as the Democratic representative from Maryland's 8th Congressional District.
In 2016, he was elected to the United States Senate, re-elected to a second term in 2022, and is now the senior U.S. senator from Maryland.
Van Hollen has not said anything about if or when he may run for president, but his actions speak louder than silence on this matter.
Van Hollen has regularly and aggressively challenged a wide range of decisions and actions of the second Trump administration, including but not limited to federal government spending cuts, immigration deportments and closing or relocating federal agencies.
Van Hollen has opposed Trump administration efforts to detain and deport El Salvador native Kilmar Abrego Garcia, maintaining Garcia has been denied due process on these efforts.
In September, he was the keynote speaker at a Democratic Steak Fry in Polk County, Iowa.
Iowa is a longtime early testing ground on the popularity and viability of presidential candidates from both major parties.
Van Hollen has been a guest on Yahoo News, CBS News, CNN, NBC News and The Hill.
Between now and the next two election cycles, a lot can happen in the Maryland and national political arenas.
In Maryland, Wes Moore is widely expected to win a second term next year, but in today's volatile and unpredictable political environment, that is not a given.
Next year, Maryland's Republican voters may nominate a candidate that unites, energizes and mobilizes their base voters. Those voters combined with enough Democratic and unaffiliated voters, could result in Wes Moore losing next November. That is unlikely, but not impossible.
In 2014, Democratic candidate and former Lt. Gov. Anthony Brown was almost universally expected to be elected governor, but he lost in a historic upset to Larry Hogan.
Key elements of a winning political campaign always include messaging, money and meeting expectations.
In his upcoming reelection effort, Wes Moore will have no problem with messaging and raising campaign contributions.
He may find meeting or exceeding expectations to be a challenge.
His rising star status could be greatly diminished if, in a deep blue state, his reelection vote margin is significantly lower than his landslide win for the governorship the first time when he received 64.5 % of votes cast.
One unanswered question for Wes Moore and or Chris Van Hollen is if either would agree to be nominated as the Democratic vice-presidential nominee in 2028.
Historically, pursuing a nomination for the vice presidency is not something candidates publicly announce or overtly pursue. Instead, presidential nominees for both major parties announce their choice for a vice presidential running mate and their choice is ratified at their party's national convention.
That was the case when Richard Nixon chose Maryland's former governor Spiro Agnew as his running mate in 1968. Agnew served in that role until 1973 when he resigned in disgrace.
Serving as a vice president as a pathway to nomination and election as president has had mixed success. Only six have done so since 1948 — Harry Truman, Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, George H.W. Bush and Joseph Biden.
Ultimately, only time will tell if either Wes Moore or Chris Van Hollen will be the first Marylander in history to be nominated or serve as president of the United States or be the second Marylander in history to be nominated or serve as a U.S. vice president.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses Maryland politicians and their potential bids for the U.S. presidency, focusing on national political implications rather than local services or other domains.

title: Celebrating 250 years of the U.S. Navy through the history of the Washington Navy Yard
author: Alice Swan Special to The Enquirer-Gazette
content:
Celebrating 250 years of the U.S. Navy through the history of the Washington Navy Yard

 October 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Alice Swan Special to The Enquirer-Gazette | Section: News 
 
 1332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Strolling the river walk along the Washington Navy Yard waterfront today, it is hard to imagine that the Anacostia River, from the Yard all the way to its confluence with the Potomac River, was a testing area for the weapons being built here before and during the Civil War. Or that the Yard was once home to more than 20,000 workers in its weapons manufacturing facilities from World War II until the 1960s.Harder still is picturing what the area surrounding the Navy Yard would have looked like when President George Washington picked the site of what would become the U.S. Navy's largest shipbuilding and ship refitting facility in 1799, creating the Navy's oldest active shore base.
Who knew — except for the dedicated Navy personnel and civilians who work there — the history that was hiding behind the impressive white façade of the Latrobe Gate on the Navy Yard's M Street boundary? But thanks to Kristina Higgins, Command Public Affairs Officer for the Naval History and Heritage Command and NHHC Education Specialist Michael Galloway, At Ease was provided a behind-the-gate glimpse into the legends and legacy of this important Navy installation.
According to Galloway, the Navy Yard was created in 1799 for the purpose of having a government-run shipbuilding activity. The Yard was supposed to build large ships of the line — a 50 or more-gun vessel — but that didn't happen, he noted, due to the shallow depth of the East Branch of the Potomac (Anacostia River) caused by its shifting sandy bottom.
"Shipping vessels already had a presence in that area in the 1700s along with many docks," Galloway explained. "The area had plenty of trees to supply lumber for ship building and the marshes supplied hemp for making rope. I found a map in the Library of Congress from 1792 that shows the area was pretty much entirely farmland with heavy woodland. In the book "Round Shot to Rockets", one of the histories of the Navy Yard, it talks about Commandant of the Navy Yard Thomas Tingey's first arrival here in January 1800, and he describes it as a wilderness."
During its early years, the Navy Yard became the Navy's largest shipbuilding and ship-refitting facility. The History and Heritage Command notes that 22 vessels were built at the Yard, from 70-foot gun boats to the Minnesota, a 246-foot steam frigate. In 1815, Navy leaders decided to limit the role of the Yard to just shipbuilding, eventually leading to the Yard's shift in focus to ordnance and technology for the next century. By the 1850s, the Yard's primary function had evolved into ordnance production, spurred by the engineering genius Lieutenant John Dahlgren (who would also serve as the commandant of the Yard).
"Early Navy Yards did a little bit of everything and that comes down to infrastructure," Galloway shared. "There weren't good roads in early America and there weren't railroads until the 1830s, so you had to do everything in one spot. By the mid-1800's the Navy starts to separate operations, so with John Dahlgren, the Father of Naval Ordnance, already establishing a lot of great gunnery work here with testing and development, that's when the Washington Navy Yard becomes a Naval gun factory, and then the Yard is named the U.S. Naval Gun Factory (in World War ll). And that was the Yard's purpose until the 1960s."
Galloway admitted that many people are surprised to learn about the Navy Yard's history of shipbuilding and ordnance manufacturing. At the Yard's height of production, some 25,000 people were working at the Navy Yard, becoming one of the largest employers for the local community, he said. He added that in the 19th century a lot of homes were built for workers just north of the Yard and that worker neighborhoods also formed on the east and southeast sides of the Yard starting in the early 1900s.
"When you are in Washington, D.C., what do you think about — The Pentagon, the Capital and the city being a hub for government and policy," Galloway said. "You don't think about this being a get-your-hands-dirty, blue-collar town. The Navy Yard may be one of the larger remnants of manufacturing that took place in this area. There were 188 buildings, on 26 acres making some of the most dangerous and advanced weapons materials in the world by the end of World War II."
Higgins noted that visitors to the Yard are also amazed by the Optical Tower, a reminder of the Yard's scientific and manufacturing history.
"Just the practicality of putting the tower in the middle of D.C. and using the monuments and buildings of the city to calibrate weapon sights that were manufactured here," she explained.
From the tower, which was built in 1918, sightings were taken on the United States Capitol, the Washington Monument and the Masonic Temple in Alexandria, 10 miles away.
Galloway added that the Anacostia River really was a testing area for the weapons being built at the Yard until the creation of longer-range guns. He said that the Naval test batteries were a big deal for the local community. People would come out to the riverbanks with picnics and watch the guns fire, staying safely out of range.
"President Abraham Lincoln was a frequent visitor to the Navy Yard during the Civil War, and loved to talk with Dahlgren about weapon development," Galloway shared. "In a tragic twist, his assassins are also associated with the Yard. John Wilkes Booth escaped across the early Navy Yard Bridge, and his body was brought to the USS Montauk at the Navy Yard for a postmortem examination. Some of his co-conspirators were held in the copper rolling building before their trial at Fort McNair."
The Yard also was the arrival point in D.C. for many distinguished visitors through the early history of the nation. As Galloway explained, "Before transatlantic flights become routine — where are you going to have visiting dignitaries arrive? They would land by boat at the Navy Yard, including Japan's first embassy personnel in 1860."
Another famous moment for the Navy Yard was the arrival of the USS Olympia, carrying the remains of the United States' World War I Unknown Soldier, docking at the Yard on Nov. 9, 1921, he noted.
As the U.S. Navy marks its 250th birthday on Oct. 13, the Navy's oldest shore establishment still has a critical role to play for the force, Higgins explained.
"While its history is unparalleled, the Yard's modern strategic importance stems directly from the concentration of vital commands headquartered on its grounds: the Chief of Naval Operations, Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA), Navy Installations Command (CNIC), Naval History and Heritage Command (NHHC), Naval Facilities Engineering Systems Command (NAVFAC), and Strategic Systems Programs (SSP). The Yard is the administrative and operational heart of the fleet," she said.
Looking into the future, the Navy Yard will also be a part of the continuing beautification and development of the surrounding community, Higgins added.
"One of the things we are really excited about at Naval History and Heritage Command is that the Navy Yard is going to be a part of that growth through the construction of the new National Museum of the U.S. Navy," she said. "The museum is going to be built in an unused field just off the Navy Yard. I don't know if that would have been possible if not for the expansion of the Nat's Park and the Navy Yard area over the last 20 years. The Navy wanted to keep the museum in D.C.; they wanted it to be walkable, have Metro access and the current growth of the local area made it an easy choice to put the new museum next to the Navy Yard."
Though the current museum is closed, it still hosts special events, including for the Navy's 250th anniversary. Galloway said that interested individuals can visit the 250th events tab on the Museum's website — www.history.navy.mil/content/history/museums/nmusn/navy250.html — to see all the planned activities, locally and at other Navy installations near Washington.
The above URL may not display correctly for all users.
To read more, visit dcmilitary.com/at_ease. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a nationwide institution (the U.S. Navy) marking its 250th anniversary and discusses historical and current significance, fitting the scope of national news more than the other categories.

title: Raskin speaks to Dems in Easton; weighs in on shutdown, '26 midterms
author: Konner Metz
content:
Raskin speaks to Dems in Easton; weighs in on shutdown, '26 midterms

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 701
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md.) visited Talbot County Democrats in Easton on Sunday, taking aim at President Donald Trump and the Republican Party.In a nearly 40-minute keynote speech during the Talbot County Democratic Forum's annual Kennedy-King Unity Dinner, Raskin went on energetic runs to engage the crowd, alternating between current issues such as immigration enforcement and Trump's ongoing battles with federal courts since taking office.
Local officials, including Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher, attended.
Raskin, who represents residents in Montgomery and Prince George's counties, hosted a town hall in Cambridge in March. He said he enjoys trips to the Eastern Shore, especially since he went to summer camp in Worton as a child.
"I come because I know you're the only Marylanders who don't have a Democratic member of Congress," Raskin told a packed crowd inside of Temple B'nai Israel on Sunday.
Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) is the representative for Eastern Shore residents.
Raskin also used the speech to tout some of his optimistic and broad opinions, such as granting Washington, D.C., and Puerto Rico statehood and abolishing the electoral college — a system he called "an accident waiting to happen every four years."
Raskin criticized Trump for imposing tariffs in a manner that the congressman said exceeds presidential power. He said Trump's actions are being rejected in district and appeals courts around the nation.
"The rule of law is holding, Donald Trump is losing until we get to just one court," Raskin said. "There's one court that has been packed and stacked and sliced and diced and gerrymandered to his advantage and to his liking, which is the Supreme Court."
After delivering the speech and accommodating a long line of local Democrats hoping to chat or take photos, Raskin weighed in on the ongoing government shutdown in an interview.
He said an agreement needs to be reached where people are not losing health care tax credits — the central issue driving the Senate's deadlock on an appropriations bill.
"I hope that our Republican colleagues will recognize that and come back to Washington and make a deal," Raskin said. "But right now it's just Democrats in Congress waiting for the Republicans to come back home to D.C."
Maryland Republicans in Congress have placed blame on Democrats, criticizing them for not OK'ing a continuing resolution to fund the government through Nov. 21. Harris said earlier this month that Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Angela Alsobrooks, both Democrats, are part of the problem.
"Because so many Marylanders are federal employees, I think that the two senators should realize that will harm a lot of Marylanders," Harris said.
TALK OF 2026
Sunday evening inside Temple B'nai Israel, early discussions on 2026 election strategy were held. Justin Butler, director of party affairs for the Maryland Democratic Party and a member of the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee, said the party needs to "get back to voters" and listen.
"Here in Maryland, we can't be out of touch," Butler said.
Raskin said the biggest challenge facing Democrats is the national redistricting fight. Republicans have led pushes to redraw maps in states such as Texas and Florida, while Democrats have countered in California and New York.
"They have proven themselves to be focused like a laser beam on gerrymandering us into oblivion," Raskin said. "We have to fight back at the state level wherever we can, and then we have to mobilize a huge popular movement to oppose that assault on democracy."
In Maryland, a state senator filed a bill to redraw the eight congressional districts— a proposal that would edit Harris' 1st District to remove Harford and Cecil counties and add part of Anne Arundel. Harris has said the proposal will lose in court, and "perhaps the courts will redraw a nonpartisan map" to flip seats for Republicans.
Locally, Butler told the crowd Sunday that a priority for Democrats going into 2026 should be winning more seats on the Talbot County Council. Currently, Lesher and Keasha Haythe are two Democrats to three Republicans on the body.
"We have a chance, next year, to fix that," Butler said. "To make sure that we have a majority on the County Council that's gonna be able to implement tolerance, compassion, unity and truly work for all citizens of Talbot County."
This story has been updated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a U.S. Representative discussing federal issues such as the government shutdown, election strategy, and redistricting, which are national political topics, making 'National News' the best fit, with 'Local Government' as a secondary relevance due to the local Democratic forum context.

title: Green Party defines success in political arena
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Green Party defines success in political arena

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Vince Lombardi, legendary head coach of the National Football League's Green Bay Packers, often said, "Winning isn't everything. It's the only thing."The leadership of the Green Party in Maryland does not embrace that philosophy, at least when it applies to winning an election.
Earlier this month, Andy Ellis filed paperwork with the Maryland State Board of Elections, to be the Green Party candidate in the 2026 general election for governor of Maryland. He also filed paperwork for Owen Andrews to be his running mate as the Green Party candidate for lieutenant governor.
According to his campaign biography, Ellis has served as a Green Party organizer and former Green Party nominee for the Maryland House of Delegates. He previously served as co-chair of both the Baltimore City and Maryland Green Parties and has held national roles on the Green Party's Presidential Campaign Support Committee, Ballot Access Committee and Coordinated Campaign Committee.
He is the founder of Debate Strategies LLC, a consulting firm focused on public debate, civic engagement and political augmentation.
Ellis is realistic about his odds of winning.
He has said candidly, "I would love it if we were the next governor and lieutenant governor. But I am a student of history and political science. ... We're not going to go and set expectations that we don't think we can meet."
As a self-described student of history and political science, Ellis is likely aware that Maryland voters have only elected two third-party candidates for governor.
They are Thomas Hicks, the American Party candidate in 1858 and Augustus Bradford, the Union Party candidate in 1882.
With regard to setting campaign expectations, Ellis has three key campaign goals.
The first goal is to take necessary steps for their campaign to qualify for and receive public campaign financing from Maryland's Fair Campaign Financing Act.
That was a fundraising strategy that Larry Hogan used when he requested and received public funds in his first run for governor.
With a goal of $120,000 in contributions from 1,500 Marylanders (capped at $250 each), the Green Party of Maryland could get a state-funded match of the contributions received from other sources.
Ellis and Andrews have already started fundraising with a campaign launch party that met a goal of $2,026.
Goal 2 is to secure an invitation to participate in gubernatorial debates including, but not limited to, the debate sponsored by Maryland Public Television.
Andrews has said, "We think that if Marylanders are able to see and hear us, and see and hear our positions, then we're more likely to achieve that top-line goal."
The third goal is for the Green Party candidates to receive at least 4% of the total votes cast in the November 2026 gubernatorial general election.
If they do that, they will eclipse the best showing by a third-party gubernatorial candidate in Maryland since 1895 when the Prohibition Party candidate received 3.2% of the votes cast.
More importantly, meeting or exceeding that goal will maintain their status as a political party that will automatically be included on future Maryland general election ballots.
This goal is immensely important for the future viability for the Green Party and also for other third parties in Maryland.
Every time the Green Party and other third parties in Maryland fail to get 4% of the votes in statewide general elections, party volunteers have to collect 10,000 signatures from registered voters for their candidates' names to be included on future general election ballots.
That signature collection process requires an inordinate amount of volunteer time and effort.
That time and effort could be reallocated to inform, energize and mobilize Maryland voters who may be ready and willing to consider supporting the Green Party's core values and their positions on such issues economic matters, housing affordability and increasing energy costs.
This has significant potential at a time when polling results are showing increasing voter disenchantment with the Republican Party and the Democratic Party.
The bottom line is, the Maryland Green Party is well positioned going into Maryland's 2026 gubernatorial general election.
That is not because their candidates have any chance of winning that election.
They do have an opportunity to demonstrate to candidates of both major parties that the Green Party's core values and issue positions resonate with at least 4% of the voters.
That is meaningful, as Larry Hogan received 51.0% of the vote in his first run for governor and Anthony Brown received 47.2% of the vote, a difference of 3.8%.
It would also affirm that any third political party with realistic expectations, measurable goals and effective campaign execution can achieve success in the political arena in Maryland without winning an election. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state gubernatorial campaign and political party strategy, which fits best under broad political coverage (National News). The next closest category is Local Government, as it involves state-level government elections.

title: A defining moment in Congress
author: Staff Writer
content:
A defining moment in Congress

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Welcome back to Washington, Andy Harris, for the start of the legislative session. I trust your recess was restful. Unfortunately, it was also silent. You chose not to hold a town hall meeting during your time in the district. That absence did not go unnoticed. It deprived your constituents of the chance to hear you explain why you reversed yourself on the spending bill you had so fiercely opposed — until you suddenly didn't. You claimed "assurances" persuaded you. Assurances of what, exactly? Your vote helped push through the single largest increase in the federal deficit in history. If you stand by that decision, you should have had the courage to face us and defend it.But my main concern today is not the budget, it is the Jeffrey Epstein files. You are a Catholic. You are a father of daughters. Given both, it should not require any moral calculus to condemn not only Epstein, but also anyone who willingly associated with him while he and his circle exploited, abused, and demeaned young women. The conduct in question — sexual assault, abuse of minors, harassment in dressing rooms, grotesque violations of trust — is abhorrent. And participation in, or willful blindness to, these acts is unforgivable.
Your colleagues in Congress are circulating a bipartisan discharge petition demanding the release of all Epstein files. This is a defining moment for you. Will you align yourself with justice and transparency, or will you shield predators and the powerful? As a father, you owe this to every parent whose child was harmed. As a man of faith, you owe it to your conscience. As my representative, you owe it to me.
So let me be clear: I expect you to sign this petition. I demand that you sign it. Your record of retreat and equivocation has already earned you the nickname "nowhere man." If you fail to step up here, it will confirm that title — and worse, it will mark you as someone who turned away from the helpless in their moment of need.
The victims deserve closure. The public deserves the truth. The perpetrators deserve justice. Representative Harris, history will remember whether you stood tall or disappeared. Choose wisely.
DAN McKEW
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an editorial about a federal congressman's actions and a bipartisan petition concerning the release of Jeffrey Epstein files, which is a political issue of national relevance rather than a local, health, or cultural matter.

title: Local No Kings rallies among thousands nationwide
author: CHRISTINE CONDON and DANIELLE J. BROWN Maryland Matter
content:
Local No Kings rallies among thousands nationwide

 October 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CHRISTINE CONDON and DANIELLE J. BROWN Maryland Matter | Section: Local News 
 
 1248
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Queen Anne's County, where 62% of voters went for President Donald Trump in last year's election, some of the people who showed up for the No Kings rally said they were pleasantly surprised by Saturday's turnout.Several hundred people attended, many waving hand-drawn signs by the roadside in Centreville's small historic downtown, while others gathered in the courtyard, where a musician performed at a piano, and organizers opened the mic for testimonials.
"The honks and waves way outnumber the middle fingers," said Tom Gallagher, 74, of the public response to No Kings in Centreville. The Anne Arundel County resident crossed the Bay Bridge to attend the rally here.
No Kings protests dotted Maryland's rural and conservative Eastern Shore, running up U.S. Route 50 from Ocean City and Salisbury to Cambridge and Easton, where protesters lined the busy highway beside a Wawa convenience store, attracting a smattering of honks as cars drove past. A single counterprotester stood in the grass behind them, yelling "We love President Trump." But he was handily outnumbered, as the assembled group chanted: "Love, not hate, makes America great."
Beverly Fox, 75, an Easton resident who is disabled, uses a motorized wheelchair to get around. On Saturday, the back of her wheelchair sported an image of Trump wearing a crown with the message "No Kings."
"That man has got to go," said Fox, who worries about Trump's attacks on health insurance for vulnerable Americans. "Every day I think I can't get shocked any more."
In Talbot County, Trump's victory was far narrower than elsewhere on the Eastern Shore, winning 11,125 votes to 11,119 for Vice President Kamala Harris.
For many attendees on Saturday, it felt difficult to choose just one reason they were drawn to decorate handmade signs and wave them by the roadside.
"I don't even know where to start," said Ashley Cromwell, a Queenstown resident who came to Centreville with a "We the People" sign.
"Since Trump first — in 2015 — came on the scene this way, I've been against what he stands for, and the hatred and the anger and the division and the way that he wants to take power for himself," Cromwell said.
Even if it was sometimes hard to articulate, attendees on Saturday were united by a passion to speak up against Trump.
Across the Bay in Baltimore — where 12.8% of voters backed Trump in 2024 — the challenge was not getting people to turn out, but managing No Kings on the same day as the 25th annual Baltimore Running Festival, when an estimated 10,000 runners were expected to take over downtown to compete in everything from a 5K to a full marathon.
Most coped by combining the two events, with runners wearing No Kings gear and No Kings attendees lining the race route with signs playing off the combination of the two events, like the one that said, "You're running better than the government."
The Baltimore and Centreville rallies were just two of more than 60 events scheduled in Maryland Saturday, from Ocean City to LaVale and from Northeast to Lexington Park and scores of points in between.
They were in big cities like Baltimore and small towns like Centreville. They were in deep blue counties like Montgomery, which had more than a dozen events scheduled, to deep red counties like Carroll, where one event was scheduled for the County Government Building in Westminster for those willing to brave it.
Nationwide, more than 2,600 events were planned, in all 50 states, Puerto Rico, Guam and the District of Columbia, where as many as 100,000 were expected to turn out. Events were being held overseas as well, in Australia and across Europe — although events in the United Kingdom were tactfully labeled "No Tyrants" events.
Some estimates said turnout for the weekend's events could be in the millions.
The latest rallies are a followup to No Kings events in June that were held to counter President Donald Trump's massive military parade in Washington to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Army — and, some say not coincidentally, Trump's 79th birthday.
There were about 2,000 events in June. Organizers said they scheduled this weekend's events because Trump "has doubled down" since the first rallies, ramping up immigration raids, deploying troops to Democratic cities and urging the Justice Department to prosecute his enemies.
A main theme of the events, besides no kings, is peaceful protest. Rallygoers were told to leave weapons at home and were trained in de-escalation techniques. And in Maryland, at least, it seemed to be working.
'What was your tipping point?'
Standing in the courtyard in front of the Queen Anne's County historic courthouse in Centreville, a bulletin board asked locals: "What was your tipping point?"
No more context was needed.
"The day he was elected — the first time," read one sticky note. "Musk + DOGE," read another. "The Apprentice," one attendee wrote.
"We wanted to know, what was that moment that you felt like you needed to come?" said Elaine McNeil, chair of the Queen Anne's Democratic Central Committee, which organized Saturday's event. "Because that's the feedback that we need to get other people to that tipping point to start standing up."
Gallagher, the Anne Arundel County resident who traveled to Centreville for the rally, said he has been disturbed by the administration's decision to attack ships off the coast of Venezuela, killing several people.
"Even if he's correct that they're drug dealers, that's still a legal matter, not a military matter," said Gallagher, a retired Navy veteran. "You're being judge, jury and executioner for people out on boats in the water. It's beyond the pale."
Diana Leonard, a Queen Anne's resident, said she began attending anti-Trump protests for the first time in March.
"I'm out here for the people that can't be out here," said Diana Leonard, a Queen Anne's County resident. "Because there are people that are either disabled or they're afraid, or they've been fighting forever."
But, like many at the rallies, she was keeping it light. Leonard wore an inflatable otter costume Saturday and carried a sign that said, "You otter join us!" adding that she was aiming for a "positive, unifying" message.
Laurie Rome, 63, said that while the Baltimore No Kings rally was a little more spread out than other protests, it was still important to show up, "no matter the format."
"It's kind of nice to have it sort of pervasive along the route. Not just people clustered in one place," she said. "There are people everywhere who think that the current level of unkindness, instability and hatred is not OK."
Protesters lining the roads — and the marathon routes — seemed to be popular venues. In Prince George's County, sporadic clumps of protesters lined U.S. Route 1 from the Washington, D.C., line to the University of Maryland, College Park, and beyond.
On the Eastern Shore, Denise Perdue of Grasonville stood on the side of the road and talked about her "tipping point" while waving a sign. For Perdue, it was Nov. 5, 2024, when Trump was elected a second time.
"I didn't think that there was so much hate in the United States as there is, and so much bigotry," she said, adding that she felt that the electorate scorned Harris, the Democratic nominee, because she is a woman of color.
As Perdue held a sign inviting passersby to "Honk for Humanity," one driver in a pickup truck flew past and yelled, "Sore losers!"
Perdue was quick to respond: "Jesus loves you!" she shouted back. It was the same response she'd used all day for the occasional heckler passing through.
"Because, what are you going to say to that?" she joked. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a widespread political protest movement (No Kings rallies) occurring across many states and cities, focusing on national political figures and issues, which aligns best with the 'National News' category.

title: Hundreds rally for democracy in Centreville
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Hundreds rally for democracy in Centreville

 October 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 486
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Longtime activist Marti MacKenzie led chants and a march around the historic courthouse square in Centreville on Oct. 18 as the Queen Anne's County Democratic Central Committee joined thousands of demonstrations nationwide for No Kings Day, a peaceful protest in support of First Amendment rights."We want our kind country back; this is where our focus needs to be," MacKenzie said, urging participants to reclaim a spirit of unity and civic responsibility as another election year approaches.
An activist since the 1960s, MacKenzie said it was important for Americans to come together and stand for democracy.
MacKenzie estimated that more than 200 people participated in the Centreville rally, one of more than 2,000 held across the country. The national No Kings movement began in 2024 to emphasize democracy over authoritarianism and has since inspired rallies nationwide calling for transparency, equality and civic engagement.
Under sunny skies, the crowd filled the courthouse lawn waving homemade signs reading "We the People" and "Democracy Is Not a Spectator Sport." Throughout the afternoon, rally goers created signs, shared personal stories about what democracy means to them and wore paperclips as symbols of solidarity and unity.
Gathering people from all walks of life, many participants were no strangers to protest, recalling the Vietnam era, the women's rights movement and the Civil Rights movement. They said the freedoms they stood for in their youth are being challenged again by this generation.
Vickie Love, of Chester, has been peacefully protesting since Vietnam and said she was disappointed in what she considered the country going backward with too much misinformation spreading.
Inspired by a recent Portland protest in which a demonstrator "held fast in the face of Immigration and Customs Enforcement" while dressed in a frog costume, Kelley Barrow of Kent Island hopped in solidarity with protesters on the other side of the country as an eye-catching amphibian, joined by her son Jordan, who dressed as a bear.
"We are not terrorists, we are peacefully protesting," Kelley said.
"It's important to show you care about this country and speak out when you can," Jordan said.
The event was not limited to Queen Anne's County residents. Coming from Annapolis to participate, Janet Gambarani, Jill Garrity and Anne Schellie voiced concern for a world being "destroyed" that their grandchildren will have to inherit.
Voicing a need to persevere and promote values outlined in the Constitution, Garrity said she was particularly offended by officials who framed No Kings Day rallies as "hate America rallies."
A teacher for 30 years, committee chair Elaine McNeil noted the importance of education and said No Kings Day rallies across the country highlight the need for change and demonstrate that people will not stand for violations of their rights or the rights of others.
"People should feel safe in the country they pay taxes and work in," she said.
As the crowd dispersed from the Historic Courthouse Square, MacKenzie said she felt hopeful seeing generations standing together.
"That's what democracy looks like," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a widespread, country‑wide protest movement (No Kings Day) with local manifestations, making it primarily a national political news story rather than a purely local government or safety issue.
